fields.headline: Ipswich extend Burley's contract to 2006
fields.trailText: Ipswich manager George Burley has signed a lucrative new contract that will keep him at Portman Road until 2006.
fields.body:
A 2-1 defeat at Charlton on Monday dented Ipswich's Champions League ambitions but their manager George Burley still had good reason to smile yesterday. His achievements have been rewarded with a lucrative new contract that will keep him at Portman Road until 2006.

Under Burley's astute management Ipswich have exceeded all expectations this season, avoiding an instant return to the First Division in such style that they are guaranteed a Uefa Cup spot and could finish in the top three.

The Ipswich chairman David Sheepshanks said the five-year deal put Burley "among the top echelons of football managers in England" and was a "measure of our belief in his talents". Burley will earn around £500,000 a year.

Ipswich's faith in the Scot was apparent 14 months ago when they awarded him a four-year contract before promotion had been secured. This improved, longer deal underlines the club's determination to retain one of the country's brightest managers.

Burley, who spent most of his playing career at Ipswich, has transformed the club since he left Colchester in December 1994 to take over a team bottom of the Premiership.

"I couldn't be any happier," the 44-year-old said. "Last year was the most special moment of my career as a player or manager. This year it has just got better and better."

webTitle: Vialli to take over at Watford

fields.headline: Vialli to take over at Watford
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli will be unveiled as Watford's new manager this morning. The Italian, who has been out of work since his sacking by Chelsea in September, will succeed Graham Taylor, who is retiring from club management at the end of the season.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli will be unveiled as Watford's new manager this morning. The Italian, who has been out of work since his sacking by Chelsea in September, will succeed Graham Taylor, who is retiring from club management at the end of the season.

Vialli's signing represents a major coup for the club, whose chairman Sir Elton John will open this morning's press conference via a satellite link from the United States.

Oxford United have sacked their manager David Kemp and his assistant Alan McLeary after only six months in charge. The former Oxford player Mike Ford took temporary charge for last night's game against Port Vale, the final match at the Manor Ground.

Manchester United have made what is believed to be football history by signing a 12-year-old from Preston in a deal that could eventually cost them £136,000.

Daniel Rowe is the leading striker in Preston's under-13 team. But in a unique deal a Football Association tribunal, which included the Barnsley manager Dave Bassett, has ruled that he can move to Old Trafford to further his football education.

Under the scheme United must pay £8,000 up front, £8,000 more if he signs a scholarship, £20,000 if he turns professional and £100,000 on completing 10 first-team games.

fields.headline: When you should keep quiet
fields.trailText: May 2:Should I tell my current employer I am looking for another job? With the availablity of information on the internet, will he just find out anyway?
fields.body:
The problem

Should I tell my current employer I am looking for another job? With the availablity of information on the internet, will he just find out anyway? Is not better to just tell him up-front?

The solution

There are two schools of thought on this common dilemma. Some think honesty is the best policy since, as you point out, your boss may well get wind of your job-seeking activities anyway. Better to be up-front than risk appearing underhand. And, if they know, you can safely put them down as a referee, which you cannot if they are to be kept in the dark.

It is also true that most employers would rather know if their employees are job-hunting - it can sometimes give them a chance to negotiate the means to encourage you to stay. Certainly, it can put you in a strong negotiating position - if your boss wants you to stay, that is.

On the other hand, many bosses will interpret a desire to leave as reflecting a reduced commitment to your current post. They may start to give longer-term projects or even the more prestigious work to your colleagues, or plan for your leaving - before you have even got shortlisted elsewhere.

And, suppose they know that you have interviews and that you are not successful? This can lower their opinion of you and put you in a weak negotiating position if you want a rise or promotion (since they think that no one else will have you.)

So, to tell or not to tell? I think it depends on your reason for wanting to leave. Reasons to tell might include: if you want to leave for domestic reasons (you are moving to another town etc), because you have been with the present company for a long time and feel ready for a change, or you have agreed with your boss that you cannot get the skills or training (or indeed, financial remuneration) in the present company that you need. Reasons where it might be wiser to keep quiet include: if you have a personality clash with your boss and know that they are likely to make life difficult once they know of your plans; if you have only been in post a short while; or where your leaving would leave people or projects in the lurch, especially if you do not intend to give much notice.


Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: Insurers 'broke code on gene information'
fields.standfirst: The British genetics watchdog has attacked a company for asking applicants to disclose results of breast cancer susceptibility tests
fields.trailText: A leading insurer has come under fire from the British genetics watchdog for using a genetic test for susceptibility to breast cancer which had never been approved for insurance purposes.
fields.body:
A leading insurer has come under fire from the British genetics watchdog for using a genetic test for susceptibility to breast cancer which had never been approved for insurance purposes.

Norwich Union demanded that insurance applicants disclose results of genetic tests for genes that predispose them to breast cancer, even though the Genetics and Insurance Committee (GAIC) had never ruled on whether this was acceptable.

The head of Britain's genetics watchdog, Lady Helena Kennedy, has attacked the insurance industry, accusing it of breaking promises of voluntary restraint in the use of genetic tests. She said a scientist advising both sides had a conflict of interest and hit out at Norwich Union's move.

Lady Kennedy is chairwoman of the Human Genetics Commission (HGC), which yesterday called for a three year moratorium on the use of genetic tests by insurance companies, saying the existing system had failed.

The Association of British Insurers responded with a voluntary two year ban on genetic tests being factored into insurance policies worth up to £300,000.

Lady Kennedy welcomed the insurance companies' move, but said it had taken too long. She added: "We have profound misgivings about the industry's handling of this information and its ability to keep its own house in order."

The Genetics and Insurance Committee was set up in the mid-1990s as an advisory body, to review genetic tests for susceptibility to disease and judge on whether they were scientifically reliable enough for insurance purposes

Lady Kennedy said it had been understood that the insurance industry would only use genetic tests that the GAIC had approved.

Instead, insurers decided they would use genetic tests until the GAIC told them not to.

Growing links between diseases and particular versions of genes is leading to a growth in genetic testing for medical purposes. But while some single genes are accurate predictors of future illness, most are mere indicators of an increased risk of disease.

There is fear that a valuable diagnostic tool, and genetics research in general, could be threatened if insurers are too eager to demand disclosure of the results of tests.

Insurers argue that they should have access to glimpses into a customer's medical future, just as they have access to their medical history. But they have now offered the two year moratorium, as recommended by the Commons committee.

fields.headline: 'Justify Abbey bid' Lloyds told
fields.trailText: The upheaval in retail banking increases this morning when the competition commission asks Lloyds TSB to provide fresh evidence to justify its £18bn bid for Abbey National.
fields.body:
The upheaval in retail banking increases this morning when the competition commission asks Lloyds TSB to provide fresh evidence to justify its £18bn bid for Abbey National.

The move by the watchdog has been prompted by the merger talks between Halifax and Bank of Scotland, which were said to be close to completion last night. Speculation that they were almost ready to reveal details of the deal mounted after BoS took the unusual step of calling off the presentation of its annual results scheduled for today.

A combined Halifax/BoS is regarded as having the potential to create a "fifth force" on the high street to compete with Lloyds TSB, Barclays, HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland/NatWest.

That merger plan has surfaced since the competition commission began its investigation into the competition implications of Lloyds TSB's hostile bid for Abbey National.

Denise Kingsmill, the competition commission deputy chairman, said last night she was writing to Abbey National and Lloyds TSB. "We are inviting both parties to make rep resentations on how we should regard this new proposed merger."

She has already suggested to the two banks remedies for any findings of anti-competitive behaviour. Her shortlist includes selling branches and disposing of subsidiaries, but did not rule out unconditional rejection of a merger.

Much of her investigation, which began after the Lloyds bid was referred by the Department of Trade and Industry, focuses on the provision of current accounts, in which the "big four" have a combined share of over 70%.

"We are still a long way from having formed a view [on the competition implications of the Lloyds/Abbey deal]. A fifth force is one thing, real competition in current accounts is another," Mrs Kingsmill said.

She has until mid-June to report to the DTI.

The City has speculated that a BoS/Halifax merger will make it more likely that the Lloyds bid is cleared.

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, has said that the attempted merger between Halifax and BoS changed the "competitive dynamics" in the financial markets.

"It will create a major com petitor and therefore the idea of Abbey being a 'fifth force' doesn't have quite the relevance that it was mooted to have had," Mr Ellwood said.

Abbey refused to comment last night but has resisted the takeover attempt by Lloyds TSB, which scuppered its own attempts to merge with BoS.

The negotiations between Halifax and BoS gained pace after reports of the negotiations leaked. Both parties were last night trying to secure agreement on the composition of the combined bank's board and its headquarters.

Both sides are thought to be working towards sealing the terms of the deal before the coming holiday weekend. But many issues are still to be settled.

Among these are the precise number of job losses, perhaps in the region of 2,000 from a 57,000-strong workforce, and the amount of revenue the new group would make. Both sides are expected to insist the deal is not about cutting costs and that job losses will be kept to minimum and split evenly between Halifax and Edinburgh.

At Halifax's annual meeting, held in Edinburgh, shareholders urged the management not to "cave in to tartan tantrums".

fields.headline: Drug firms threaten bank boycotts
fields.trailText: Drugs companies are threatening to boycott banks and brokers which give in to demands from animal rights extremists.
fields.body:
Drugs companies are threatening to boycott banks and brokers which give in to demands from animal rights extremists.

The pharmaceutical groups, with billions of assets, are outraged at the way they believe financial organisations caved in to the campaigners and cut ties with controversial research firm Huntingdon Life Sciences. They want pledges of support from the banks that manage their money.

Several of the biggest drugs companies are understood to have written to the big banks to voice their concerns. Trevor Jones, director-general of the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry (ABPI), said: "If they are not prepared to support a member of our industry [Huntingdon], we must ask if they are the people we should rely on for advice and to invest our cash. That debate is taking place right now."

Huntingdon, which works on contract research testing drugs for several of the biggest drug companies, came close to collapse this year after violent animal rights campaigners prompted the Royal Bank of Scotland to refuse further funding. Huntingdon was bailed out by Atlanta investment firm Stevens Group.

The ABPI's approach comes a week after the Association of Medical Research Charities (AMRC) withdrew its account at HSBC in protest at the bank's severing of financial ties with Huntingdon. The AMRC has 112 members with assets of about £16bn and HSBC had angered it by refusing to handle Huntingdon shares. Brokers Merrill Lynch, Charles Schwab and TD Waterhouse also blacklisted Huntingdon as did Barclays Bank.

A spokesman for the ABPI said: "We are concerned that the City has been found so vulnerable to animal rights activists.

"Huntingdon Life Sciences, and the work it does to develop new medicines, is essential. Also, if HLS fails because of these people, they will then turn their attention to other parts of the pharmaceutical industry. They won't stop there." He added: "It also opens the door to any activists in any other industry".

The government - in the shape of Tony Blair, Lord Sainsbury, science minister, and Jack Straw, home secretary - has offered its support to Huntingdon and called on the banks not to cave in.

fields.headline: Vodafone upstages BT
fields.standfirst: Mobile phone group launches £3bn share placing ahead of rival's rights issue
fields.trailText: The Mobile phone group has launched a £3bn share placing ahead of its rival's rights issue, write Neil Hume and David Teather.
fields.body:
Vodafone will today deliver a devastating blow to British Telecom when it makes a £3bn placing of new shares to pay for its continued overseas expansion.

The wrongfooting move could soak up appetite for new telecoms shares ahead of BT's anticipated rights issue, designed to bring down the struggling company's debt. The placing underlines the differing fortunes of BT and Vodafone as well as the relative speed with which they are willing to take action.

Ironically, the cash raised by Vodafone will chiefly be used to pay for stakes in Japan Telecom and its mobile phone subsidiary, J-Phone, that are being disposed of by BT to cut its debts. The placing is likely to provoke an angry reaction from BT executives.

On Monday Vodafone increased its investment in Japan Telecom when it acquired a 10% holding from US telecoms group AT&T for $1.35bn (£925m). If the agreement with BT goes ahead it will take its stake still higher - to 45% - while its holding in J-Phone will reach 46%.

It is not certain which institution is being used to place the shares for Vodafone although it has in the past used the likes of Goldman Sachs and UBS Warburg.

BT hopes to raise £4.5bn from the disposal of its stakes in the two Japanese firms as well as a 17.8% share in Airtel, the Spanish mobile phone company. Vodafone is also in discussions to buy the Airtel stake which would give it more than 90% of the business. BT had otherwise faced the indignity of being a shareholder in a company which Vodafone aims to rebrand under its own name.

While BT scuttles back to Britain, Vodafone has maintained its momentum overseas and has become the world's largest mobile phone company. BT has a market capitalisation of£36bn compared with Vodafone's £138bn.

The retreat from Japan is viewed as a visible weakening of the chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield's position in the company. Sir Peter has been closely identified with the Japanese investments and, until now, BT has maintained that the stakes were not among the targets for disposal.

The City welcomed BT's decisive action although analysts said it had done little to reas sure them of the company's long-term strategy. Shares in BT climbed 41p to 599p, their highest level for more than two months.

BT's withdrawal comes just two weeks after the company negotiated options to buy 5% stakes in J-Phone's operating businesses from Japan Telecom.

The agreements were seen as a sign of BT's determination to keep its foothold in Japan. BT invested £1.2bn in Japan Telecom, together with AT&T, just two years ago. BT has been widely expected to launch a deeply discounted rights issue to raise £5bn.

fields.headline: Most firms flout pay code
fields.trailText: Six out of ten of Britain's biggest companies are not following best practice to control and monitor directors' pay and bonuses.
fields.body:
Six out of ten of Britain's biggest companies are not following best practice to control and monitor directors' pay and bonuses.

A survey commissioned by the Co-operative Insurance Society - one of the country's biggest institutional investors - claims that companies in the FTSE 100 are flouting corporate governance guidelines laid down to ensure the highest standards of boardroom behaviour.

The guidelines, enshrined in the combined code put together over ten years by the Cadbury, Greenbury and Hampel committees, say that the majority of members of any board should be independent non-executives. The remuneration committee should be wholly independent.

But the CIS report says that nearly a quarter of those directors named as "senior independent" on the board are not independent at all and 60% of remuneration committees, which set directors' pay and bonus packages, are not composed entirely of independents.

It also adds that at one in six FTSE companies the majority of non-executives are not independent.

The CIS, which has £26bn of funds under management, is among the UK's most active shareholders. As part of its social responsibility commitment it votes on every resolution put forward by every company where it is a shareholder. Last year it showed disapproval at boardroom behaviour by abstaining or voting against 476 resolutions - 13% of those put before it. That is 13 times more than the industry average.

Among other findings of its new research, published today, is that more than half of FTSE directors - contrary to the guidelines - still have contracts of two or more years. Ten companies still have one man as chairman and chief executive and 11 companies refuse to spell out the targets directors must hit to receive bonuses.

It also adds that at one in six FTSE companies the majority of non-executives are not independent. The CIS, which has £26bn of funds under management, is among the UK's most active shareholders. As part of its social responsibility commitment it votes on every resolution put forward by every company where it is a shareholder. Last year it showed disapproval at boardroom behaviour by abstaining or voting against 476 resolutions - 13% of those put before it. That is 13 times more than the industry average. Among other findings of its new research, published today, is that more than half of FTSE directors - contrary to the guidelines - still have contracts of two or more years. Ten companies still have one man as chairman and chief executive and 11 companies refuse to spell out the targets directors must hit to receive bonuses.

fields.headline: Will you get a windfall?
fields.trailText: Friends Provident members have until June 4 to post their votes on the proposed demutualisation of the life, pensions and asset management group, which is set to float on July 9 with a value of between £3.7 and £4.2 billion.
fields.body:
Friends Provident members have until June 4 to post their votes on the proposed demutualisation of the life, pensions and asset management group, which is set to float on July 9 with a value of between £3.7 and £4.2 billion.

Merrill Lynch, the company's investment banking adviser, has indicated that windfall payouts are likely to be between £450 and £540, which will be paid to about 1.7 million qualifying members. However, more than 60% of these will receive an additional allocation of shares, which will depend on the size of their policy and how long they have held it

UK members and customers of Friends Provident will be able to buy shares in this offer on preferential terms. This will be in addition to the allocation of shares to qualifying members.

David Newbigging, chairman of Friends Provident, is encouraging members to vote for the proposal, saying: "This is an important milestone in the development of the Friends Provident Group. The distribution of shares to qualifying members will release value to them without any adverse impact on their policies."

webTitle: Money Channel founded by Adam Faith runs out of cash

fields.headline: Money Channel founded by Adam Faith runs out of cash
fields.standfirst: The Money Channel, the financial TV service set up by 1960s teen idol-turned financial adviser Adam Faith yesterday admitted it was running out of cash, write Julia Finch and Julia Snoddy.
fields.trailText: The Money Channel has asked for its shares to be suspended, writes Julia Finch and Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
The AIM-listed company, which has 130 staff, asked for its shares to be suspended "pending clarification of its financial position". It is understood to have less than £1m left and has recently been burning cash at a rate of £750,000 a month.

The directors have called in accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers to provide an assessment of the viability of the business.

The TV channel, which is broadcast on Sky Digital, was started in 1999 to provide financial advice to small investors on subjects including pension planning and investment in shares, but it has failed to win the audiences required to keep advertisers happy.

An interactive advertising service, which allows viewers to respond to ads at the click of the remote control, was introduced last year. Yesterday a spokesman for the channel said the new service had performed well, but not well enough to prevent a shortfall in working capital.

The Money Channel floated in 1999 at 22p but within six months were changing hands at 500p. They crashed at the beginning of last year. Yesterday, when the shares were suspended, they were down another 0.5p to 13p.

Mr Faith is no longer closely involved in the company, but retains a 9.15% stake.

fields.headline: Investing for the family
fields.trailText: Anyone who has tried shopping online for travel, home or motor insurance will already have discovered that it is possible to get a greater level of cover for a lower premium by using the web.
fields.body:
Anyone who has tried shopping online for travel, home or motor insurance will already have discovered that it is possible to get a greater level of cover for a lower premium by using the web.

Insurance companies and brokers are now starting to offer online quotations for life insurance, although there are fewer online players offering this product. Many of the big general insurance providers, such as theaa.com, part of the AA insurance company, don't yet offer life insurance on the web.

The simplest and most web-friendly form of life insurance is term assurance. Other products that cover you for serious illness, such as critical illness, are not widely available yet on the web because they are more complex and require detailed medical information.

What is term insurance?
Term assurance offers you cover for a specified number of years. Because it is only for a fixed term, as opposed to the whole of your life, this makes it cheaper than conventional life insurance.

Some of the cheapest deals on offer at the moment come from new entrants, such as Direct Line and Marks & Spencer. But the premiums quoted on term assurance policies can vary widely, so it makes sense to get several quotes. And one of the best ways to do this is to shop around on the internet.

Term assurance is a no-frills protection product that pays out a lump sum if you die within the specified term.

 If you live to the end of the policy, you don't get anything back;
 If you have a staff job, your employer may include life insurance as part of the pay package, particularly if you have taken out a workplace pension;
 If you leave your job, become self-employed or work as a consultant, you will have to arrange your own life cover;
 The older you are, the more expensive the premiums will be.

There are two types of insurers online: "direct providers", who sell their own products on the web or use a preferred provider, and "supermarkets", which aggregate quotes from several different providers.

Al-Karim Govindji, senior internet analyst with Gomez, a company that provides analysis of financial providers online, said it is useful for customers to know how the website insurer works. Are they selling just one product, or are they working on a commission basis for a number of providers? This will affect the spread and variety of quotes you are offered.

The providers who do offer a web-based life insurance product are: Direct Line, Eagle Star, Norwich Union, Prudential, Royal&SunAlliance, Scottish Amicable and Scottish Provident.

Royal&SunAlliance and Direct Line have both scored highly for web-based general insurance products in a recent survey by Gomez. Direct Line came top of the Gomez general insurance product scorecard. The criteria included ease of use, access to policy details, good site design and navigation, and consumer confidence in the brand and the provider.

The best search engines on the web are quick and simple and give you an instant quote. You are asked for your age, whether you are a smoker, the level of cover you require (most independent financial advisers suggest a level of between £100,000 and £150,000 or three to four times your gross annual salary). You will also be asked for the length of the term of the insurance, plus whether you are a smoker.

Take a married couple in their early thirties who have never smoked and who are looking for joint life term assurance for 10 years for £100,000, and a single man aged 60 who is a smoker and wants £200,000 worth of cover.

What can the web offer them?

Eagle Star offers online insurance for people between 17 and 64 but will not extend cover beyond the age of 70.

For the married couple aged 33 and 34 wanting a sum insured £100,000 (not inflation-linked), the monthly premium would be £16.79. If they wanted cover for £200,000 over a term of 10 years, the monthly premium would be £31.11. For the same sum over a term of 25 years, the premium would rise to £46.97 a month.

For a man aged 65 who is a smoker and wants level term insurance of £200,000, the maximum term he can get is just five years of term at a cost of £286.51 a month.

BallaBrokers
One independent financial adviser and insurance broker that has a website presence is BallaBrokers.com, based in Douglas, Isle of Man. You can't get an immediate quotation as you can with Eagle Star, but you can usually expect a reply within 48 hours. They reply arrives by email, with a key features document explaining the policy.

The quote for a married couple in their thirties looking for level term insurance of £100,000 for 10 years was £7.99 a month from Swiss Life. For this quotation, BallaBrokers was also offering a cash-back of three month's premiums on the policy.

Some sites give you a selection of quotes, from which you can choose either the cheapest, or the provider you feel comfortable doing business with.

Easy-Quote
For example, Easy Quote offered three sample quotes for the married couple, and three for the man in his sixties.

For the married couple in their thirties, the quotes for a monthly premium for term insurance of £100,000 were: C&G £10.50; Scottish Equitable £11.84; Scottish Widows £11.88;

For a man born in 1940, term insurance for five years, sum insured £200,000, the quotes were:
L&G £146 Scottish Equitable £189.98 Standard Life £211.14

 Marianne Curphey is the author of E-cash, a step-by-step guide to managing your money online. Find out how to keep control of your own finances, search online for a mortgage, move bank accounts and invest in shares. Buy it at Bol

webTitle: Supporters take control of Chesterfield for £6,240

fields.headline: Supporters take control of Chesterfield for £6,240
fields.trailText: Chesterfield Football Supporters' Society, formed only six days ago, claims to have taken control of the troubled club after buying a 78% shareholding for £6,240.
fields.body:
The fans of Chesterfield, the Third Division club facing expulsion from the Football League, took matters into their own hands yesterday. A supporters' organisation, formed only six days ago, claimed to have taken control of the troubled club after buying a 78% shareholding for £6,240.

Today the Chesterfield Football Supporters' Society will discover the size of the task awaiting it when an independent disciplinary panel reconvenes to discuss whether the club, having been found guilty of financial irregularities, should be expelled.

Howard Borrell, spokesman for the Chesterfield Football Supporters' Society, said: "We have reclaimed the club on behalf of the fans and the town. Now we can begin the process of turning Chesterfield Football Club around."

It is almost certain the panel will increase Chesterfield's punishment, possibly blocking their promotion or demoting them to the Conference, after the league's board of directors declared last week that the initial recommendation of a nine-point deduction and £20,000 fine was too lenient. If Chesterfield are denied promotion the society plans to appeal.

The supporters have bought UK Sports Group Ltd, which held the controlling interest, after a collection and a raffle at an inaugural meeting attended by about 1,000 people last Wednesday. They are taking advice about ways to ease debts believed to total more than £1m.

However, Darren Brown, a club director and former chairman, disputes the legality of the sale of the shares and is said to be considering legal action.

A winding-up order is due to be served against the club at Leeds crown court on May 10 on behalf of the Inland Rev enue and Glory Years, the club's shirt manufacturers, and the following day Norton Lea, another former chairman, will challenge the supporters' ownership of the 78% shareholding in the high court.

Several players have not been paid for up to two months. The goalkeeper Mike Pollitt handed in his notice yesterday and will become a free agent in two weeks.

Brown has proposed that the club ground-share at Mansfield Town but the society is opposed to leaving Saltergate. "We have three aims: the first is Second Division football, the second to make sure that our football is played at Saltergate and not at Mansfield and the third to assess the financial situation and prevent a winding-up notice being served," said its chairman Ian Yeowart.

The takeover mirrors events earlier this season at Lincoln City. Brian Lomax, chairman of Supporters Direct, which has advised Chesterfield's supporters, said: "This is the second time this has happened in a short period. It is becoming a mass movement in which the people who morally own football - the fans - are reclaiming the game."

fields.headline: Premier League nets £48m deal
fields.trailText: After four months and several rejections the Premier League finally secured a sponsor for the next three seasons yesterday when Barclaycard agreed to pay £48m for the privilege.
fields.body:
After four months and several rejections the Premier League finally secured a sponsor for the next three seasons yesterday when Barclaycard agreed to pay £48m for the privilege.

The deal with Britain's largest credit card company, unanimously accepted at yesterday's meeting of the Premier League clubs, will see the FA Barclaycard Premiership come into being from August, when the clubs will also begin to benefit from a new TV deal worth more than £1bn over three years.

For Barclays, which sponsored the Football League from 1987 until 1993, it also marks a return to supporting the national game. The package has been available since January when Carling, the sponsor for the past eight years, withdrew after having a £39m bid rejected. Bass had paid £27m for the rights the last time around.

After that withdrawal it was reported that the Premier League was looking to secure backing from a company with more of a global outlook but Pepsi, Budweiser and Vodafone among others were said to be put off by the asking price of £15m-£20m a year.

Under the terms of the current deal the league is known as the Carling Premiership in TV broadcasts to the United Kingdom but referred to as the FA Premier League everywhere else. Matches are shown in 127 countries, all of which will in future refer to it as the FA Barclaycard Premiership.

"They're a brand that fitted our global aspirations," Richard Scudamore, chief executive of the Premier League, said. "The Premier League is bigger than a domestic competition now, when you look at the overseas interest."

The Premier League has also announced an alliance with Barclaycard and the British Tourist Authority that will see footballing images involved in promotions to help attract visitors to Britain. The BTA will pay around £2m over three years for exposure to an estimated global TV audience of 158m.

webTitle: Lazio's racist banner may be answered with a ban

fields.headline: Lazio's racist banner may be answered with a ban
fields.trailText: Lazio could be exiled from their home ground after their fans' latest outbreak of racist abuse at Sunday's derby match against Roma.
fields.body:
Lazio could be exiled from their home ground after their fans' latest outbreak of racist abuse at Sunday's derby match against Roma.

During the 2-2 draw Roma's Brazilian wing-back Cafu and the French defender Jonathan Zebina were barracked with racist chants every time they touched the ball, despite pleas from Lazio's president, Sergio Crag notti, to end the abuse. A 30-metre banner, reading "Black team, Jewish supporters", rippled across the packed Olympic stadium.

Lazio, who lie in third place seven points behind Roma, could be forced to play all their six remaining games away from the Olympic stadium, effectively ending their hopes of a second successive league title.

A fine, their sixth this season, is very likely. Only 10 days ago Lazio were fined £11,000 for eruptions of jungle noise during a match against Parma, who fielded two black players. "If it happens again," Cragnotti claimed then, "they will pull us out of the Olympic stadium."

Clashes before and after Sunday's derby left 10 policemen injured, a journalist stabbed, a car burned and several fans under arrest. "We call that a success," said a police spokesman.

Roma have historically been supported by the city's small Jewish community, whereas right-wingers, including Benito Mussolini, supported Lazio. Last season Lazio fans plumbed new depths with a 40m banner: "Auschwitz Is Your Homeland; The Ovens Are Your Homes".

The assassination in Belgrade of the Serbian indicted war criminal Arkan did not pass without comment: "Honour to the Tiger Arkan".

Cragnotti's appeals to desist only encourage some hardcore fans - the self-styled irriducibili - who feel alienated by his tenure, despite last season's league title. "He doesn't help us travel to away games, so we punish his wallet with our messages," a banner-maker said.

Before unfurling Sunday's banner several dozen irriducibili dressed in white angled their bodies to give their rivals a more traditional message: "Roma shit".

fields.headline: Real Madrid 0 - 1 Bayern Munich
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Real Madrid: Casillas, Salgado, Carlos, Hierro, Helguera, Raul, McManaman, Figo, Guti, Karanka, Makelele. Subs: Cesar, Savio, Campo, Conceicao, Munitis, Celades, Solari.

Bayern Munich: Kahn, Sagnol, Lizarazu, Kuffour, Andersson, Scholl, Elber, Effenberg, Jeremies, Salihamidzic, Linke. Subs: Dreher, Sforza, Sergio, Tarnat, Jancker, Hargreaves, Santa Cruz.

Referee: H Dallas (Scotland)

1 Real Madrid kick-off what is the biggest match of the season for both clubs, quite possibly ever, in the history of the universe if you believe the hype. Bayern are out prove that they are not an easy passage to the final for the Spanish side.
3 Roberto Carlos whips in a free-kick from distance to the head of Raul - goes for a corner, comes to nothing.
4 McManaman plays in Raul just outside the area - he turns and wafts his shot over the bar.
5 Free-kick to Bayern 25 yards out, square on - Jeremies darts off a crazy diversionary run (no-one pays him any attention at all) before Effenberg strolls up to poke the ball through a tiny gap in the Real wall. Easy for keeper Casillas with the sting taken off the ball.
9 Two free-kicks in succession for Bayern after Scholl and then Lizarazu try to cut in from the left and are upended; Effenberg fails to make use of both.
12 A fairly scrappy start and a conspicuous lack of rhythm to the game despite lots of movement from both sides. No chances and not much to get excited about so far.
16 Lizarazu almost blows it for Bayern when he allows Salgado to get around him and cross for Raul only three yards out... but he can't get his foot to it and the Germans survive.
19 Bayern break after a period of concerted pressure from Real - Effenberg finds Salihamidzic on the right as Real are caught short at the back, but Scholl wastes Salihamidzic's pass into the area and puts wide despite being under no pressure.
24 The pressure's back on Bayern and the Germans are reduced to attacking on the break. Roberto Carlos prowls around the edge of the area, popping balls in from the Real left, and is unlucky to find the side netting with a wayward, rocket-like cross.
26 Free-kick to Real just outside the area. Too close for Roberto Carlos? No way, but he crashes it into the wall.
35 Bayern beginning to step up the pace as Sagnol breaks down the right; his cross just fails to reach Elber at the far post.
37 Bayern steam up again with Salihamidzic and Scholl on the left; free-kick 35 yards out - Effenberg wafts in a looping ball towards the far top corner of the net... and misses by a mile.
38 Helguera mis-hits a cross into the six-yard box, both Guti and Kahn go for it but neither gets close.

47 McManaman cuts in from the left and finds Raul on the edge of the area; Raul lays it off for Figo but his shot goes nowhere.

50 Figo's corner is headed clear at the near post.

55 Substitution Savio on for Guti.

58 Kahn does well to deny Real an almost instant equaliser from McManaman's shot. Straight after that, Helguera heads over from six yards. More than sense of urgency about Real's game now.
60 All Real at the moment as they pepper the area. McManaman rampant on the left, lofting balls into the area.
61 Great save by Kahn when he gets down to deny Salgado from the the edge of the area.
70 Real have eased back a little and Bayern take full advantage when Scholl gets up on the right to test Casillas from distance.
71 Almost a spectacular equaliser from Roberto Carlos when tries an overhead kick from seven yards after Helguera plays him in from the edge of the area.
72 Substitution Paolo Sergio on for Scholl - no sitting back for Bayern.
73 Effenberg's corner finds Linke virtually unmarked beyond the far post; Casillas flaps Linke's header clear.
74 Substitution Jancker on for Elber. Bayern clearly have no intention of sitting on their lead, as manager Hitzfeld tries to intimidate Real with another attack-minded substitution.
77 Figo corner; Kahn flaps but Bayern clear. Substitution Munitis on for Salgado.
79 Booking Big blow for Bayern when Effenberg picks up a second yellow in the competition, meaning he will miss the second leg of this semi-final. Referee Dallas called him over for a chat and Effenberg blew any leeway he may have had when he appeared to shove the ref in frustration.
81 Real claim handball when Raul shoots from 10 yards from Figo's corner - nothing doing.
86 Booking Munitis for pointlessly chopping down Sagnol near the touchline.
87 Bayern now finally falling back in numbers as they attempt to cling on to their lead...
88 ... when Jeremies gets away on the left and tees up Paolo Sergio to shoot high when it could so easily have been the clincher.
90 Three minutes extra to play. Bayern free-kick 40 yards out; they take their time and it comes to nothing. Paolo Sergio goes down under pressure from Figo and tries to milk as much time out of it as possible. Another Bayern free-kick - Effenberg chips it over the wall from 25 yards but Jancker can't make it work. Full-time. Great performance by Bayern, now the only German team ever to win in the Bernebeu stadium.

fields.headline: Chesterfield punishment upheld by panel
fields.trailText: Chesterfield remain on course for promotion to the Second Division after the Football League's disciplinary panel reaffirmed their decision that the Spireites should be docked nine points for financial irregularities.
fields.body:
Chesterfield remain on course for promotion to the Second Division after the Football League's disciplinary panel reaffirmed their decision that the Spireites should be docked nine points for financial irregularities.

Last week, the Football League's board of directors claimed that Chesterfield's punishment was too lenient - and asked their disciplinary panel to reconsider their decision.

But today the panel upheld their original verdict. If the nine point deduction is upheld - and it still needs to be ratified by the League's board of directors - Chesterfield will drop to third with 77 points, three points ahead of Hartlepool, who only have one game left to play. Chesterfield chief executive John Green felt it was "the common-sense decision" for the panel to agree the same punishment again.

"I knew this would happen," he added. "It's a common-sense decision made by a panel of three men who have been honourable throughout the hearing put in a position by the authorities above them to find another decision that suited their views and not a decision based on the facts presented at the hearing.

"This is a fantastic day for everybody at Chesterfield and a great boost for the lads against Brighton tonight and let's just everybody get behind the team now."

What happened at the anti-capitalism demonstrations in London, minute-by-minute

Special report: May Day 2001
Full story of the day's events
fields.body:
7.30pm: standoff in Oxford Circus
Police and protesters are left in an uneasy standoff in Oxford Circus, with the rump of cold and wet demonstrators remaining penned in by riot police and awaiting permission to leave the area. Headlines from UK latest

7.20pm
IndyMedia reports that police containment is contributing to a crush at the centre of the crowd in Oxford Circus. The site adds that police are starting to release people one by one from the Holles Street containment area, after searching and photographing them. A total of 35 people have now been arrested.

6.50pm
A police announcement urges the core of around 1,000 protesters hemmed in at Oxford Circus to move towards the centre of the area and tells them that if they remain calm, arrangements will be made for them to leave as soon as possible.

6.38pm
Two protesters who climbed on to a balcony of the John Lewis building in Holles Street, Oxford Circus, rip two CCTV cameras from their mounts and pass them down to the crowd. They also strip metal segments and pass them into the crowd where people appear to be trying to smash John Lewis windows. Meanwhile police mount a charge on Oxford Street as they come under a hail of bottles from protesters attempting to join other campaigners in Oxford Circus.

6.15pm
According to reports from IndyMedia, the demonstrations appear to be petering out, with most protesters leaving the Oxford Circus area. Around 1,000 protesters have moved on to Mayfair where a good-natured carnival atmosphere is prevailing, the site reports.

6.05pm
More trouble breaks out at Oxford Circus as police move in to arrest a protester, and are forced back by a volley of missiles outside the boarded up windows of Niketown. They are forced back to join their colleagues sealing off Oxford Circus at the junction with the eastern part of Oxford Street. There is no indication when the 1,000 people crammed into the sealed-off Oxford Circus area will be released.

5.50pm
31 people have now been arrested. The London ambulance service said that 15 people have sustained minor injuries, with 10 taken to hospital.

5.40pm
Officers, some on horseback and some wielding batons and shields, exchange blows with demonstrators at several points around Oxford Circus.

Riot police clash violently with protesters in the flashpoint area of Holles Street near Oxford Circus. Several protesters emerge from the melee with bloodied heads. One protester had to have his head bandaged and said: "I got kicked in between the legs and then hit over the head with a truncheon."

5.30pm
Police say all the 29 arrests are for "relatively minor" offences. Protesters trying to break out of Holles Street on to Oxford Street fight a battle with dozens of police, and officers use batons to keep back protesters taunting them with chants of "scum, scum".

5.20pm
Two of those arrested so far were detained for causing alleged criminal damage in a Sainsbury's store in Victoria Street, central London. IndyMedia reports that the police have requested the closure of Bond Street tube.

5.15pm
Protesters have broken through police lines at Holles Street, just off Oxford Street. Police charged protesters with shields and hit some with batons.

5.05pm
IndyMedia reports that windows have been smashed at the H&M store in Oxford Circus. A group of around 500 protesters are making their way west down Oxford Street to Marble Arch, police said.

5.05pm
A group of around 40 white-overall clad Wombles make an appearance at the protests and lead a group of hundreds of protesters to Portland Place, north of Regent Street, Guardian Unlimited reporter Simon Jeffery reports.

5pm
Police have closed Waterloo, Lambeth, Vauxhall and Hungerford bridges to pedestrians, Scotland Yard said. Police on Regent Street launch another baton charge in new clashes with demonstrators after some of the crowd moves north to Cavendish Square, then storm through the line of police in Holles Street.

4.30pm
London ambulance service said seven people are being treated for minor injuries in the Oxford Circus area. There have been a total of 29 arrests, Scotland Yard reports.

4.15pm
Police make the following announcement to protesters at Oxford Circus: "You are being detained here to prevent a breach of the peace and criminal damage to property. You will be released in due course."

4pm
Scotland Yard says 22 people have been arrested and one person has been wounded. Police in riot gear and protesters remain in a tense standoff at Oxford Circus.

3.48pm
IndyMedia reports that police have begun using batons.

3.25pm
IndyMedia reports that police are sending snatch squads into the crowd on the north-west corner of the crossroads at Regent Street. Scotland Yard says the number of arrests now stands at 18.

3.21pm
The police containment zone has been expanded to half way down Regent Street, IndyMedia reports. One demonstrator is carried away with his face covered in blood. Officers in riot gear replace officers in regular uniform policing the demonstration.

3.12pm
Police come under a hail of wine bottles, beer bottles and sticks as protesters attempt to surge forward into Regent Street. The demonstrators advance momentarily before being pushed back towards Oxford Circus. Scuffles break out among the crowds.

3.06pm
Police have estimated the number of demonstrators gathered at Oxford Circus at about 3,000.

3.02pm
Some reports said "up to 10,000" have gathered in Oxford Circus and are now penned in by police vans and officers. The demonstration is noisy but mainly peaceful.

2.57pm
"Riot police in many side streets getting ready for something - but the crowd in the area are relaxed and in good spirits although very tightly packed", IndyMedia says of the situation in Oxford Circus.

2.46pm
14 people have so far been arrested in the capital during the demonstration, Scotland Yard said. Westminster Bridge has been closed.

2.45pm
Police block off all exits from Oxford Circus where several hundred protesters have congregated. Exits along Regent Street and Oxford Street are blocked by police vans. Dozens of officers are stopping those inside the police ring from leaving.

2.35pm
The protest in Oxford Street continues. The Metropolitan police says a total of 10 people had been arrested, mainly for the possession of cannabis and offensive weapons.

2.25pm
There are reports that Oxford Street has been closed to traffic and the tube stations have been closed.

2.05pm
IndyMedia says around 1,000 protestors are moving quickly up Regent Street and protesting against the World Bank. Protesters are gathering outside Nike Town in Oxford Street and giving out Monopoly money. The demonstration has remained peaceful.

2pm
All the demonstrators from the anti-privatisation picnic at Elephant and Castle are now heading towards the South Bank area beside the Thames, IndyMedia reports.

1.50pm
Protesters on cycles near Euston station are being allowed out of the cordon by police one by one, provided they give their names and addresses.

1.40pm
Protesters start moving off from Elephant & Castle towards nearby Kennington, IndyMedia reports. Metropolitan police say there have been seven arrests so far.

1.05pm
IndyMedia reports that there have been some minor scuffles between protesters and police at an anti-privatisation picnic at Elephant and Castle, where around 300 protesters have gathered. Protesters have begun a peaceful sit-down demonstration in Oxford Street.

12.40pm
Around 150 cyclists descend on Trafalgar Square whistling and cheering. IndyMedia reports that police have surrounded the square.

12.30pm
Police are outnumbering protesters by 20 to one. Meanwhile, according to IndyMedia, police reinforcements have been called to Euston station plaza with the intention of doing a "stop and search" of all the cyclists for weapons.

12.15pm
IndyMedia reports that around 1,000 protesters have gathered at Euston station plaza and police are blocking them from returning west along Euston Road.

11.25am
The crowd of protesters outside King's Cross station is estimated at between 600 and 700 people. The blockade brings traffic to a standstill before the demonstrators begin a slow march towards Euston station under a heavy police escort. The protest remained peaceful.

11.05am
Reports from IndyMedia state that around 1,000 people have gathered at King's Cross station, and police lines have moved in on Marylebone Road from the west and are indicating that people should start moving off.

10.16am
A third person involved in the May Day protest is arrested "for being equipped to cause criminal damage", Scotland Yard said. Police make two men and a woman awaiting the arrival of the Critical Mass cycle protest remove pollution masks covering their faces.

10.15am
Critical Mass bike rides converge on King's Cross station, blocking Euston Road with cycles, scooters and skateboards.

9.55am
Scotland Yard said two protesters have been arrested in Southwark, south-east London, on suspicion of being in possession of drugs.

9.50am
Police release three protesters detained on the critical mass cycle ride, IndyMedia reports. London Animal Action begins handing out veggie burgers in front of McDonald's at King's Cross.

9.10am
Police arrest three people participating in the bike ride between London Bridge and Cannon Street, where demonstrators have blockaded the road, independent media website IndyMedia reports.

8.00am
Around 550 cyclists set off from Liverpool Street and Marylebone stations, in two Critical Mass bike rides protesting against traffic pollution and congestion.

webTitle: Places to stay in the Maldives

fields.headline: Places to stay in the Maldives
fields.standfirst:
We have the option of a stop-off in the Maldives but are concerned that the only accomodation is of the "all-inclusive", ie expensive, variety. Can anyone who has been there as an independent traveller recommend places to stay?
Mariel Thomas
fields.trailText: • How long is your stop over in Maldives? You will need an approved holiday address which is acceptable to immigration at the airport. You will need no more than two nights in Male. Each of the 70-plus resorts have an office in Male and you can shop around for any specials. Be warned, though - you may end up paying more by doing it yourself rather than taking the all-inclusive package.
fields.body:
 How long is your stop over in Maldives? You will need an approved holiday address which is acceptable to immigration at the airport. You will need no more than two nights in Male. Each of the 70-plus resorts have an office in Male and you can shop around for any specials. Be warned, though - you may end up paying more by doing it yourself rather than taking the all-inclusive package.

The dhoni (boat) from Male to your resort island and then from the resort island back to the airport island can be expensive if you choose a resort too far from the airport. Bed and breakfast packages on resorts can leave you with expensive bills for meals and drinking water. The Nasandhura Palace is a tourist-type hotel on the harbour, convenient for the airport. It is relatively expensive - as is most holiday accommodation - cheaper is the Blue Diamond, en suite rooms, run by an ex-VSO with excellent food.

Don't be put off by the difficulties, as the Maldives islands are really fabulous and well worth a visit.

John and Rhian Blakey

fields.headline: May 1 2001
fields.trailText: In a week that saw the publishing of some data suggesting that 4% of students are working in the sex industry just to make ends meet, here is this week's ultra focused email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.
fields.body:
In a week that saw the publishing of some data suggesting that 4% of students are working in the sex industry just to make ends meet, here is this week's ultra focused email from The Guardian's graduate section Rise - the next move for young professionals.

As usual we take a look at the best graduate jobs, review last Saturday's Rise and there's a past article that we think is worth a second read in Rise Gold. We even get a sneak preview of next week's edition.

For anyone having trouble opening articles or accessing links, try cutting and pasting the URL (funny code included) into your internet browser. This will work better than clicking on the URLs from the email.

If you didn't make it to the newsagent at the weekend, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 28 April).

Continuing the theme of the oldest profession, Rise took its first look at brothels - digital brothels that is. Fiona Thompson suggests more of us will be working for Cyber-madams in the future and it's all legit.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,479642,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Barbara Oaff offered her guide to surviving the last few weeks in the run up to finals. First thing to do is blitz the laundry and stock up the fridge.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,479646,00.html?bnr=email.grad

NEXT WEEK'S RISE argues that it is possible for anyone to develop a "can-do" attitude. We examine what the future holds for graduates leaving agricultural college and we look at how networking through organisations such as the Junior Chambers of Commerce can advance your career. And there's another chance to win four months in the sun with the Volvo Environmental Scholarship.

This week's RISE GOLD is a look at the some of the more unexpected things that can happen at interviews. Heard the one about the graduate who upon being invited to "surprise" his interviewer, set fire to his newspaper?
http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,3908292,00.html?bnr=email.grad

THIS WEEK'S TOP TIP
Get used to not exaggerating. One of the most common mistakes grads make at interviews is boasting about accomplishments beyond the realm of their experience. Allen Salikof of recruitment firm MRI says keep it honest and straightforward.

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS.
If you definitely WEREN'T at the May Day demonstrations in London earlier this week, then Bloomberg is looking for Global Data Analysts with a degree in Economics or similar. "Show us an understanding of financial markets and even better, language skills, and we will want to show you around."
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100115974,00.html?bnr=email.grad

The Foreign & Commonwealth Office is looking for a research analyst to fill a vacancy within North Asia and Pacific Research Group. They want someone with intellectual strength and a good knowledge of Chinese affairs - and spy planes, presumably.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116242,00.html?bnr=email.grad

And if you were in London on 1 May, the Centre for Sustainable Energy in Bristol is looking for a researcher who wants to "make a difference". You'll work on a variety of projects to influence Government policy. Got to know what fuel poverty is.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100115525,00.html?bnr=email.grad

If the Meejia is more your cup of tea, Fox Haynes Media Headhunters has got a new string of jobs with some big companies in a variety of areas - from media buying to sales.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116237,00.html?bnr=email.grad

How about a career as a court stenographer? Smith Bernal International is seeking graduate students to train for one year to record what goes on in courts. It promises a guaranteed £12,000 training salary and the potential to earn £60K a year!
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100115561,00.html?email.grad

If you've an interest in chemistry and education - yes really - the Salters' Institute of Industrial Chemistry's looking for a camps administrator to organise several of its "highly successful residential chemistry camps for Year 10 students". Just don't let them set fire to the place.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116416,00.html?bnr=email.grad

For those thinking of going down the TEFL route, GEOS has 487 English schools in Japan and needs "professional, committed graduates to teach in our schools in Japan". Most importantly, TEFL experience is an asset, but not essential.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116350,00.html?bnr=email.grad

Just graduated in Interior design? Connaught Kitchens in London is looking for a design graduate with work experience. Got to have good drafting, CAD and project management skills - it's paying £18K.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100116173,00.html?bnr=email.grad

And finally, if you know which way to turn after canoeing up the Amazon, the Royal Geographical Society is looking for a computer literate graduate to help staff its Expedition Advisory Centre in London. Only £14K and you've got to be quick - closing deadline 4 May.
http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114698,00.html?bnr=email.grad

fields.headline: Running to stand still
fields.standfirst: The time he spent relaxing in Zambia seems like a distant memory to Sam this week when, after wrestling with cancelled flights and absent officials, he arrives in Victoria Falls in the nick of time - only to find his tour has been called off
fields.trailText: Week 21: Lilongwe to Victoria Falls The time he spent relaxing in Zambia seems like a distant memory to Sam this week when, after wrestling with cancelled flights and absent officials, he arrives in Victoria Falls in the nick of time to find his tour has been called off
fields.body:
A week of travel woes.

While in Malawi, I had taken the decision to continue with my circuit of southern Africa rather than trying to fit in Tanzania and Kenya as well. The main reason for this was that I really wanted to explore Namibia properly. It sounds so completely different from anywhere else I've been: the enormous Namib desert with its towering sand dunes; Etosha National Park with its amazing wildlife and salt pans; the lonely Skeleton Coast and the spectacular gorge of the Fish River Canyon. With all this in mind, I had booked myself a three-week trip with a South African-based company called CampWild, which would take me from Victoria Falls through Botswana, Namibia and down to Cape Town.

After our visit to Zambia, H and I spent a couple of days relaxing in Lilongwe before we had to go our separate ways again. Obviously neither of us were particularly happy about this and the mood was pretty miserable in the taxi out to the airport. Things didn't improve when I arrived to discover that my flight to Zimbabwe had been cancelled - and there would be no more until October. I saw H off on her London flight and then went back to have an argument with someone, anyone.

This was the Easter weekend and therefore not exactly the best time to try to make new travel arrangements. The Air Zimbabawe official was on holiday, and a phone call to Harare proved fruitless. The Air Malawi official was more helpful, and she told me to come back early the next morning and she would see what she could do.

I was beginning to get worried. My tour was due to leave in three days and I still needed to get from Harare to Victoria Falls. Back at the hostel in Lilongwe (a nice overland truck place called Kiboko Camp) I spent the afternoon playing bauo with the barman and trying to drown my sorrows.

The next morning I was at the airport before they'd even had a chance to open the doors. The Air Malawi lady had good and bad news. I could catch a plane to Blantyre where there was an onward flight to Harare that day. Unfortunately, it was fully booked so I would have to wait and see if someone cancelled. The alternative was a crazy detour via Johannesburg which would mean spending the whole day on planes.

So I flew to Blantyre and had a nervous couple of hours watching the Harare flight fill up. Then ten minutes before take-off, an official came over and told me someone hadn't arrived and I was allowed on the plane. Hooray. That afternoon I took a walk round Harare which, although quiet, seemed a pleasant, compact city.

A day later I arrived in Victoria Falls and got to check my email for the first time in four weeks. There sitting on the screen was a message telling me that my Cape Town tour had been cancelled due to lack of numbers. All that hassle for nothing.

I spent a little while feeling sorry for myself and then went out to come up with a plan. First of all I had a look in all the hostels hoping to find someone driving down to Nambia, but everywhere was quiet. Then I went to a very helpful travel agent in town called the Backpackers Bazaar. The people who ran the hostel I was staying in (357 Gibson Road - I recommend it) also had some good advice. By the end of the day I had lots of scribbled notes and sat down to look at my guidebook and work out the options.

Basically, I could do everything I would have done on the tour by using local buses and different companies, but it was going to cost more and take a lot longer. Five months ago I wouldn't have thought twice about this, but now, with only six week left, my budget was beginning to pinch. And it wasn't just the money. For the first time, the end of my trip is beginning to loom on the horizon and I'm not at all sure how I feel about that. On the one hand it will be good to see my friends and family again. On the other, home means coming back down to earth and having to sort out a job and a place to live - none of which I have given a thought to since I arrived in Africa.

But it's not all over yet. So back to my current problem. The constraints of time and money meant that something had to give, and unfortunately it had to be my visit to the Okovango Delta in Botswana. This was desperately disappointing - it's supposed to be one of the best parks in Africa - but it's just too expensive. I'll have to save it for another, wealthier time.

Determined not to miss out on anything else, I took a day-trip to Chobe National Park across the border in Botswana. This involved a boat trip down the flooded Chobe River (only a tributary of the Zambezi, but still huge for all that) followed by a game drive. The day was okay and we saw plenty of lions and elephants, but there were an awful lot of tourists about. As soon as one boat or truck found an animal then all the others would flock round. I hate to think what it would have been like in high season.

Tomorrow, I get on a bus that will take me down to Windhoek to begin my exploration of Namibia, but before I go I should respond to a couple of your emails.

Julie asked about getting round South Africa without a car. From what I saw you shouldn't have too many problems. There's a pretty good bus network between the major places, plus there's a backpackers' option called the BazBus which I've had recommended to me again and again. They have a number of useful routes and will even pick you up at your hostel.

And Mike's message about my flying to Malawi has to be the most annoying one I've received. I agree, I could have made it by bus. But anyone who's travelled in Africa knows that the buses are notoriously unpredictable. The point (which Mike seems to have missed) is that I needed to be in a certain place at a certain time to meet my girlfriend, who was flying out from London. As I hadn't seen her for four months, I thought it might be rather rude to turn up late. And I'm pleased to say that the one-hour flight was considerably more comfortable than 19 hours on the bus would have been.

fields.headline: Madly in love with love
fields.standfirst:
Do we care about the new Romantic Novelist of the Year? Of course we do. Why? Because you've got to have a dream

What do you think about the appeal of romantic fiction? Have your say on the talkboards
fields.trailText: Do we care about the new Romantic Novelist of the Year? Of course we do. Why? Because you've got to have a dream.
fields.body:
Last week, Cathy Kelly became the Romantic Novelist of the Year, winning £5,000 and very little respect from the critics. This is par for the course in the world of romantic fiction: you earn a lot and die unnoticed. "Romantic" novels are the mainstay of publishers' fiction lists: know them in their pure form by their thickness (Kelly's Someone Like You is 677 pages long), the blue and gold or violet and silver jackets, and the fetching girl on the cover; see them everywhere, on newsagents' shelves and in the supermarket - buy them, discounted, along with your lottery ticket, that other hope of future bliss. The market is huge and growing - 182m books sold worldwide back in 1996, and add to that the recent chic-lit phenomena, the Bridget Jones lookalikes, and a massive influx of new young female devotees to the genre.

All the genre novels have a hard time in literary circles - science fiction gets a bad press, crime thrillers (unless they're John le Carré) are shrugged off - but special abuse is reserved for the romantic novel. I suspect we struggle against ourselves. It's the junk food of the literary appetite - fills you up but fails to nourish. Dangerous.

Personally I read Someone Like You into the early hours and enjoyed it very much, though skipping the office detail, like pushing the gherkin to the edge of the plate, preferring to focus on the loss and longing bits, not to mention the clothes. I'm so glad Hannah got David in the end: I really am. Felix was bound to be trouble. Of course women can live happy and fulfilled lives without men - and perhaps they should try to, and certainly often have to. It's just, well, you know. You can dream, can't you?

And it's not as if falling in love isn't real: we've all been there, done that. So OK, it was a rush of endorphins to the brain, a flood of hormones, a flurry of neurotic dependency because of what your father did - but it felt like romance at the time, if only for a moment. And the more they try to train you out of it, the more late-night hooker programmes they thrust at you on TV - so that's all sex is, yuk! - the more insanely you'll cling to those moments when you felt most alive and knew what you were on this earth for. Love. And you'll reach for the blue and gold, the violet and silver.

"A novel that deals with sexual love in idealised form" is the formal definition of the romantic novel, but the pattern has changed, as have women's lives, and their practical dependency on men has lessened. There's good sex and bad sex for today's romantic heroine, and in detail, too: she goes out to work, worries about her job, her character, her looks and her weight. Unlike Madame Bovary and Anna Karenina, she does not have to be punished for her infidelities. She is usually written, and read, by other women. Her life is not without real problems. Social issues can surface - in Someone Like You, they are Alzheimer's and infertility.

So how do you tell romantic fiction from the rest? Salman Rushdie's The Ground Beneath Her Feet could be seen as sexual love in idealised form: it's certainly long enough, too. But he's not exactly going to join the Romantic Novelists' Association.

The style of writing, perhaps? It's effective, certainly: precise and vivid, but tends to the heavy-handed. Sentences are weighed down with adjectives and adverbs: luscious, glowing, rippling, tumbling; gracefully, haltingly, languidly. Long, slender limbs are stretched and it's a rare character who simply speaks: he or she groans, growls, confides, teases, snaps, grins, squeals or roars. Mouths are bruised and sullen. And no jokes, please, no irony. This is not, repeat not, the literature of alienation.

But mostly it's just the view from the windows. See it like this. See all of literature as the City of Invention, the celestial city of the imagination. It's where writers go, over the centuries, to build their houses, choosing the best area they can afford, talent allowing.

It's where the readers flock, as tourists, to take a holiday from their lives, and come back to reality refreshed. The critics are the guides, the publishers are the estate agents. The city has its desirable districts and its bad. Castle Shakespeare looms over all, insisting on building standards few live up to. Over there, the busy red light porno district; over there, the stately heights of biography; and here, the guides' favourite, is the old, central, proud, uneasy, drink 'n' druggy literary centre, with its many garrets, full of snobs and bohos and running wild with the little black dogs of depression - how some of the younger builders will jump up and down in the turds.

Over there, crime - lean out of the coaches and take a wave at the twin mayors, Rendell and James - and there, see, stretching into the distance, the vast, pretty suburb of romance, all neat gardens and lace curtains, with spotlessly clean pavements - this is where the guides get off.

None of these houses looks outside to the real world. Draw back the lace curtains in the sci-fi district and see outer space and bug-eyed monsters; if it's the Pentagon and an eternal Checkpoint Charlie, why then you're in thrillers. In Romance it's a girl with tumbling hair and slender legs, who might be you, moving with arms outstretched towards Mr Right.

The windows are quite small: you can't see to left or right, and really you'd rather not, in case you see too much. But you can always tell you're in a house down literature way, because the windows have been left blank. You must paint on them what you want. You have work to do. Of course sales are small. Who wants to work? Booker Prize aspirants think they're lucky to get a print run of 2,000. Any halfway proud romantic novelist expects one of at least 30,000.

I suspect we struggle against ourselves. It's the junk food of the literary appetite - fills you up but fails to nourish. Dangerous. Personally I read Someone Like You into the early hours and enjoyed it very much, though skipping the office detail, like pushing the gherkin to the edge of the plate, preferring to focus on the loss and longing bits, not to mention the clothes. I'm so glad Hannah got David in the end: I really am. Felix was bound to be trouble. Of course women can live happy and fulfilled lives without men - and perhaps they should try to, and certainly often have to. It's just, well, you know. You can dream, can't you? And it's not as if falling in love isn't real: we've all been there, done that. So OK, it was a rush of endorphins to the brain, a flood of hormones, a flurry of neurotic dependency because of what your father did - but it felt like romance at the time, if only for a moment. fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Lindsey Fraser looks at The Brimstone Journals by Ron Koertge, and Coasts of the British Isles by Terry Jennings
fields.body:
The Brimstone Journals
Ron Koertge
(Walker, £4.99)
Age 11-14 yrs

This novel could so easily be sensationalist. It isn't. It takes the form of fragments from journals kept by students at an American high school called Branston, but which they call Brimstone. These are everyday kids with all the normal dreams and worries. One of their biggest worries is The List, which it is rumoured is being collated by disaffected Boyd who thinks that the only point of rules is to break them. This compulsively readable novel's integrity lies in its acute observations, its low-key but finely honed prose and its simple truths. But this is a book that constantly has you surprised by ordinariness.

Coasts of the British Isles
Terry Jennings
(Evans Brothers)
Price £11.99
Age 9-12 yrs

Britain's island status has shaped its industries, its defence policies and its politics. Our coastline is a vast mix of different environments, at the mercy of climatic and environmental change and economic pressures, from fish-farming to seaport developments. The text and photographs cover subjects as diverse as life in rockpools to the story of Liverpool. This particular devotee of the west coast of Scotland felt the coastal features map was a little short of sand-dunes up there, but otherwise the book is informative, clear and fascinating. And it's a refreshing change from all those non-fiction books masquerading as something else.

fields.headline: Bullet points
fields.trailText: What's going on?
fields.body:
What's going on?

Five and a half billion quid, the biggest quango ever etc etc and we still haven't a dickybird of a clue about what the Learning and Skills Council does. Not only are the main council pow wows, which shuffle from one London hotel to another, secret, but they are not even, as they agreed to do, publishing reports of the proceedings within 10 days on the website. Zilch. For all anyone knows they lock the doors and play blind man's buff for two hours. Meanwhile how much of the five and a half billion is left? Actually, it turns out that even those who take part in the meetings can't find out later what they are supposed to have discussed and decided. Thanks to a bug in the Learning and Skills Council computer system nobody seems to be able to retrieve the reports.

We don't know

Why won't you let us into your meetings, we asked one of the distinguished members of the coven. What have you got to hide? "That we haven't a clue what we're supposed to be doing," came the candid response.

Bird brained

Bournemouth & Poole college thoughtfully sends a copy of its latest newsletter. It's stuffed with details of summer courses. "Parrot psychology" catches the eye. And what on earth are "Abrasive Wheels"? Presumably if parrots have psyches then why not wheels. And if so, they probably do get a little tetchy from time to time. But what really got a second glance was "Knife Skills and Techniques". Jack Straw really has failed if one can't walk the streets of Bournemouth without getting tooled up.

fields.standfirst: Amanda Holden
fields.trailText: Amanda Holden
fields.body:
Born February 16, 1971

Occupation Actress; starred in string of telly dramas; perhaps best known as Miss Titley in The Grimleys

College Bournemouth & Poole

Attended 1987-88

Courses A-levels in Eng lang, Eng lit and theatre studies

She recalls that her tutor, Charles Lamb, "spoke just like Sean Connery. It started off as a silly thing -then it turned out for real - it was major crush."

He blushes "I can't imagine her really being serious about fancying an old fogey like me."

She adds "My old college and Mr Lamb taught me to believe in myself...that I was going to be an actress."

He retorts "You can always spot someone with talent. Amanda was a student with star quality."
