webTitle: The big idea to restore Britain's industrial greatness

fields.headline: Can we trust the specials?
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley  examines the big idea to restore Britain's industrial greatness
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley examines the big idea to restore Britain's industrial greatness
fields.body:
In a bid to improve the UK's international competitiveness in the 21st century, more than half of England's traditional general further education colleges are going to be designated centres of excellence for one or more areas of advanced-level vocational training.

These colleges, which were once a byword for the best industrial training of its kind in the world, are to be encouraged to focus their efforts once more on meeting the real needs of local and national firms for highly skilled workers, ie with skill level 3 to 4.

In the UK we produce fewer people with advanced craft, technical and equivalent skills than many other advanced industrial nations.

Under the new initiative half of all further education colleges in England will have at least one centre of vocational excellence, representing skills from a wide spectrum of industrial and business related areas. Some 150 colleges will be designated by 2004-5.

However some key questions remain to be answered about precisely how the new initiative is going to work.

Some say that this was a wheeze dreamt up by Tony Blair's education adviser, Andrew Adonis, who saw specialising working well in schools and sixth-form colleges. Adonis, it is said, wondered why further education colleges - which were often not performing especially well and were seen to have lost touch with the needs of employers - should not specialise as well.

It was then left, so it goes, to civil servants, the new Learning and Skills Council and the Learning and Skills Development Agency to put some flesh on the bones of his idea.

So now colleges, together with their local learning and skills councils, will assess present and future local skill needs and attempt to meet them in a more planned and co-ordinated manner.

The Learning and Skills Development Agency has been asked by the Learning and Skills Council to help identify colleges which already have areas of excellent skills training that might qualify them as "pathfinder" centres of vocational excellence. The plan is to come up with a shortlist of up to 40 such colleges from which 12-15 may eventually be designated.

These pathfinder colleges should be exemplars of good practice as recognised by inspection reports and will act as mentors for colleges seeking vocational excellence status in future.

The second phase in the summer is to publish the criteria by which a much greater number of colleges will be designated as centres of vocational excellence in future.

In March the DfEE published a consultation paper on the proposal to which responses must be received by June 19 2001.

A number of key issues have yet to be resolved. Chris Hughes, chief executive, Learning and Skills Development Agency, says that the initiative will only work if it makes colleges more focused on working with employers as clients. It is about being involved in employers' business planning and anticipating future skill needs, as opposed to just laying on some courses.

He added that further education has two distinct traditions - one is that of offering technical and vocational education and the other is of access and giving people opportunities. It may be, he added, that the latter tradition has been stronger than the first one in recent years and there is now a need to return to being leading edge technical and vocational institutions.

Once the centres of vocational excellence are established, the next task is to identify ways of transferring good practice to other colleges. In order to avoid creating a second tier of colleges that perceive themselves to be second rate, it might be necessary to designate colleges for other kinds of excellent practice, for example, community development.

The initiative, he added, might well involve some economies of scale and concentration of effort. But then level 3 training in, say, marine or automobile engineering is expensive and already concentrated in specialist centres anyway.

David Sherlock, chief inspector of the Adult Learning Inspectorate, asks why the initiative is restricted to colleges and not extended to sixth-form colleges, or to the private sector which undertakes some £12bn of training annually. He also asks how industry will benefit from the initiative? He adds that there has to be something special about the curriculum, for example trainees spending substantial amounts of time in industry, if there is to be a real partnership with industry.

However Sherlock says that such centres could work very well in some industries. For example, in the care industry they could break the downward spiral in work-based training where the already poorly trained train new entrants; or in areas such as gas fitting, railways and IT, where such training centres could offer top-down strategic planning at times of national emergency.

Dr John Brennan, director of further education development at the Association of Colleges, said that while the association welcomed the initiative as a way of enhancing the status and capability of colleges, there are also dangers.

If one college is designated a centre of excellence, does another college down the road with the same area of vocational provision disband its department? He favours a networking partnership model which would allow other non-designated colleges a role in providing progression routes into the specialist programme.

He also asks, how do you define excellence? In some industries, for example, catering and business administration, some 2-300 colleges offer training. So do you have 50 centres of excellence, or 100?

If you concentrate provision in a particular college, then students will have to travel to that centre and who is to pay for these travelling costs?

Dr Brennan said: "I think there are some quite big questions around all of this, which have got to be resolved. I don't think as yet the department has produced answers to all of those questions and, in part, this consultation is about trying to refine some of those answers."

fields.headline: CD-rom reviews
fields.trailText: Paws in Jobland | The Coral Reef Study Pack
fields.body:
Paws in Jobland
(CASCAiD Ltd, tel: 01509 283390) Price £58.49 inc VAT
Age KS2

This title supports the PSHE curriculum, and the need to know about a range of jobs and how to develop skills. It provides teachers with a bank of information, and allows pupils to look at jobs that may be of relevance to them. It provides some very good worksheets and activities. It is easy to use and best approached during short, intensive sessions. For schools committed to the PSHE curriculum, this program has much to offer. It does, however, address just one strand within the subject, something that teachers might find off-putting.

The Coral Reef Study Pack
(Ransom, price £34.99 inc. VAT) Age KS3/4

This package offers a virtual field trip to the University of Belize research centre. It supports teaching objectives in geography and also has value within biology and environmental science. One of its strongest features is that it provides resources that are not readily available elsewhere and presents them in a unique format. Sound, video clips and images offer a level of detail appropriate to the secondary curriculum. It can be used in a number of curriculum areas, making it excellent value. It is easily accessed by students on their own and is a helpful resource for individual research.

You can read a full evaluation of this program at www.teem.org.uk.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My daughter, who is two and a half, has an August birthday and could start in reception class at the age of four and four months, but I feel that is too young. I am less concerned about the teaching content than about putting my daughter into an institutional setting so early.
fields.trailText: My daughter, who is two and a half, has an August birthday and could start in reception class at the age of four and four months, but I feel that is too young. I am less concerned about the teaching content than about putting my daughter into an institutional setting so early.
fields.body:
The DfEE is strongly encouraging schools to allow in-year deferral and to be flexible in considering summer-term entry, so this mother can insist on delaying entry until the summer. The school won't lose out financially either: they are allowed to fund reception classes on the basis of places available, even if the classes aren't full.

But I think this parent is worrying too soon. It's more important to think about whether the child is ready to start nursery rather than school; she can leave the decision about reception until later. If the little girl has had a good start in pre-school, with an emphasis on play and social interaction, she should be ready for school at four and a half.

Most children do grow out of nursery class and want to move on to reception - and it's a particularly easy transition if nursery is attached to the school. Many schools stagger the intake into reception, allowing the children to be part-time for the first few weeks. They have the power to be flexible and to plan intake in a way that will be the most advantageous for the children.

Good teaching will focus on creative and imaginative play as a means of learning - all the current moves are in the direction of encouraging flexibility and the development of the whole child.

Anne Jarvis
Chair of the Association of London Governments Education Panel

Just four is incredibly young. Britain is the odd one out in Europe on this issue, and there is increasing evidence from all over Europe that it is better to start school around the age of six or seven. When children make a later start, their literacy and numeracy are much better because you haven't flogged the donkey up the hill: you've waited until the child is big enough and able to cope. Children who start formal schooling very early are quite simply weary of education by the time they get to the point where they should be self-motivated; it can lead to educational burnout.

Steiner schools bring in different elements of education slowly, which keeps children motivated because there is always something to look forward to. Steiner early-years settings aim to be extensions of home; the children build up motor control skills, dexterity and social skills with play, painting, baking, climbing, walking and so on. Then intellectual activity can happen on the basis of an unhurried childhood. It's about stepping out gradually from family life; the children keep their class teacher throughout their school life, which builds security.

And when it comes to GCSEs, Steiner pupils do twice as well as the average.

Contact the Steiner Waldorf Schools Fellowship on 01342 822115.

I spend a lot of time visiting infant schools and there is a real buzz to them. Activities are structured, but that's part of education and the children learn from each other. I can't think of a reception class in the last five years that hasn't been dynamic, so I'm not sure that children's creativity is stifled by school. The ability of a child to adapt to school depends on their individual strengths and weaknesses, and if a child has had some years of nursery they are more likely to be ready for more formal education.

There is research showing that the younger children in a class generally have lower levels of attainment than the older ones; children who only just get in tend to perform less well, and there can be an 11-month age gap. But this is down to maturity and a better concentration span than age per se; it doesn't necessarily mean that a child would be disadvantaged.

However, if this parent is so worried, they should find out about later intakes. At this stage, parents should go by instinct. When sending the daughter to school, they need to have a positive attitude: if they are nervous and uneasy, the child will be nervous as well - and starting school should be a time of excitement.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Readers' letters
fields.body:
Compulsory - it's a fact

The parent governor has got things back to front (On the board, April 24). The latest national curriculum has been compulsory - all of it - since September 2000. It's the literacy and numeracy strategies that have never been compulsory.

Nor is the citizenship programme in primary schools. It's a pity that your governor didn't check facts with the DfEE's Guide to the Law for School Governors to save further misunderstandings.

Mike Brogden
Much Wenlock, Shropshire

Not quite above board

Your governor has the wrong information (On the board, April 24).

The decision to remove a governor on the grounds of poor attendance is one for the governing body, not the headteacher.

Neither is the six-month rule an absolute one. Governors can approve absence - which may be entirely unavoidable, for example illness.

With regard to the national curriculum, it is the "freelance writer of educational books" who is out of date. Whilst there was some relaxation of the foundation subjects while the literacy and numeracy strategies were being introduced, their statutory status was returned from September 2000.

Having said that, the foundation curriculum is by no means as prescriptive as some teachers would have you believe.

Roger Watts
Chesterfield, Derbyshire

Snob sentiments

I have been offered a conditional place at Oxford next year and am disturbed by the sentiments of Jen Taylor and Simon Newton (Letters, April 10 and April 17).

Mr Newton, my state tertiary college not only encouraged my Oxford application, but supported it throughout, offering practice interviews and the like.

Ms Taylor and Mr Newton, I firmly reject the inference that all Oxford students feel somehow "better" than the £6,000 being offered to trainee teachers.

I resent the suggestion that students are shaped by their institution. We're all individuals, Mr Newton, and an Oxford degree doesn't turn one automatically into a snob.

Ms Taylor, if your job satisfaction comes in the form of a fat paycheck I wish you just as much luck as if it was a classroom full of succeeding students. I believe young people are capable of making their own decisions, whichever university they attend (or not), fully backed by their state education.

Clare Langley
by email

Circles are central

While it was good to see the value of peer support featured so prominently (Education, April 17), it is sad that it still remains a bolt-on to an essentially academic curriculum.

Driving up standards and promoting social inclusion were always potentially incompatible yet, compared to funding for literacy and numeracy, the resources directed towards making schools comfortable, both emotionally and socially, for children with special needs, have been minimal.

Creating a Circle of Friends not only transforms the life of the focus child, but helps to make the wider school community more tolerant and respectful of diversity.

Having been involved in setting up a Circle of Friends in secondary school, I have been dismayed by the routine bullying that the young person was previously subjected to (and which teachers were largely unaware of).

Yes, a Circle of Friends is relatively inexpensive in terms of hard cash, but to listen to young people does require time, proper training and a recognition that educating the emotions is as central to the curriculum as literacy and numeracy.

Carole Morgan
by email

Cut the red tape

My wife returned to work after bringing up our family, gaining a degree as a mature student and completing a postgraduate certificate in education. No mean feat.

She entered the profession teaching business studies with a wealth of experience gained in commercial environments. She has taught at three secondary schools. In her experience the major problems in education are as follows:

Pay. This falls far behind that of any comparable professions in commerce, for example accountancy.

Personnel management. Most manager-to-staff relationships seem to be a mixture of bullying and nepotism. People-managing skills are non-existent.

Peer relationships. With the refreshing exception, to each other teachers are arrogant, disloyal, unsupportive, sniping, critical in front of pupils and generally lacking in team spirit.

Physical environment. The facilities endured by teachers are abysmal compared to industry; sharing desks, computers and dirty, cramped offices where lessons are prepared and marked. Schools are poorly resourced and managed.

Teachers don't need more red tape. They need better pay and professional management and support to do the job they are trained for.

R D Roberts
Witham, Essex

What's in a grade?

I have just finished unravelling the intricacies of the GCSE sets and exam format.

A, B and C are still the pass grades for GCSE (the old O-level), but for foundation-level maths, a student cannot gain a pass grade because the highest available is D - even for a mark of 100%. And everyone gets a grade, even if they score just 2%; for foundation it's D, E, F, and G. In some subjects at intermediate level, only a C grade is awarded for a mark of 80% and above.

This is an educational system catering for children who are supposedly unable to achieve. What sort of mentality says "if at first you don't achieve, go down a set and then you will be able to get the answers right (because we will make the questions easier for you)"?

If a child achieves a pass in an intermediate paper instead of a higher paper, is the result worthy of the title GCSE O-level? In the "old days" the lower paper was called a CSE.

And are the children left in the lower levels missing out on that chance to excel and pass a GCSE?

Joel O N Scott
Corwen, Denbighshire

fields.headline: Farmed out
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones bites her tongue and takes it on the chin
fields.trailText: Janet Jones bites her tongue and takes it on the chin
fields.body:
"She's a teacher." "That's why she never does any work!" The laughter went on for a long time.

Have you ever found yourself the lone teacher among a group of livestock farmers?

There's not a lot you can say. You have to laugh along with them and enjoy the joke at your own expense, while the wind blows straw across the mud and puddles and the dogs, cats and chickens ignore each other.

"I see you've got a big pay rise," one of them said to me last week. We were on the telephone this time, not in the yard, as we were discussing the ravages of foot and mouth.

"That's the school teachers," I said. And I explained again that further education was something else: "You know, like that place in town, by the roundabout below the station."

"Ah," he said, "college you mean."

"Yes."

He knows the college now, he tells me, because his youngest daughter has just started there: "She's doing nursing, she doesn't think much of it."

"Oh. Why's that?"

"Whenever she goes in the teacher doesn't turn up."

It's 14 miles from the farm to college. And 14 miles back again - 28 miles of expensive petrol. Further education's reputation will be spreading round the county every bit as fast as news of foot and mouth.

Our farming neighbours feel some kinship and solidarity with the nurses. Not with any other work force. Nurses, they reckon, also work all or any of the hours of the 24 and care for their patients as farmers care for their stock. There is fellow feeling; they turn up.

Our neighbours have a point. If our college gets too cold, we pack up and go home. If the farm gets too cold, the farmer starts the generator, monitors it 24 hours a day, tucks the newest chicks up in the bottom oven of the solid-fuel Aga and gathers the lambs under the infrared lamps.

I am not suggesting that these are reasonable options for us in further education. (What good could we do sitting in the bottom of an Aga or under an infrared lamp?) But it is worth remembering that in some industries the client-patient-customer cannot "go home" so their "management team" cannot go home either.

In fact one herd of precious cattle has been sealed into a barn for the duration of the foot and mouth outbreak. Three human beings have been sealed in to look after them for as long as it takes. The Duke of Westminster, who owns the herd, was reported as saying he was "very grateful".

How many of us put our lives on hold in a sealed barn? Submariners, perhaps. Or hostages. Certainly it would be an odd approach to further education.

So when our farming neighbours have a joke at our expense, I take the point and try and represent our profession as capable of a good-humoured nod and a shrug before we go home.

webTitle: The government's controversial plans for illiterate adults

fields.headline: Enrol or no dole!
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston  outlines the government's controversial plans for illiterate adults
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston outlines the government's controversial plans for illiterate adults
fields.body:
The government yesterday gave more details of its stick and carrot approach to tackling the problems of adult illiteracy and innumeracy. A range of incentives and disincentives, from cutting benefit to increasing it, will be tried out in selected areas to try to discover what works best in persuading people to learn basic skills.

In north Nottinghamshire, unemployed adults identified through screening as having serious literacy and/or numeracy problems will lose their Jobseeker's Allowance (JSA) if they refuse to undertake specified remedial training.

In Wearside, by contrast, those idenitified as needing teaching in reading and number, and who undertake full-time courses in them will earn an extra £10 a week. And if they successfully complete the courses they will get a £100 lump payment.

Unveiling the next stage of Skills for Life, the government's national strategy for improving adult literacy and numeracy, the lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks said: "Learning and support has been available to adults for many years and yet significant numbers still do not take advantage of the opportunities offered to them."

But the notion of punishing adults has prompted grave reservations among the teaching force. Paul Mackney, general secretary of Natfhe, the lecturers' union, who is a former basic skills teacher, said it ignored the complex of motivation among adults for learning.

"I know that some people need jolting out of a sort of slough of despond, but removing people's benefits is merely likely to make them turn to crime."

And a current basic skills lecturer in an inner city college said that putting people into classes under duress was likely to provoke abuse, disruption and even violence.

"We've got enough problems from teenagers who are unwillingly forced to learn basic skills without getting more from adults," she said.

Wicks announced nine "pathfinder" projects, one in each English region, which will test out the best ways to try to improve the massive basic skills problem.

Ministers have set themselves the target of improving the literacy and numeracy of 750,000 adults with low skills by 2004. This would be a significant inroad into the shocking statistic, calculated by the Basic Skills Taskforce, that seven million adults have serious literacy and numeracy problems.

"For too long the scandal of adults not being able to read, write and do maths has gone unchecked," said Wicks. "We have already announced the radical steps that we will take to reverse this situation. We are committed to ensuring that high-quality adult literacy and numeracy skills education is free to every learner, no matter who provides it, where it is provided or in what form."

Jobseeker's Allowance claimants are already screened for literacy and numeracy skills at the six-month stage of unemployment.

In some pathfinder areas screening of claimants' basic skills needs at 13 weeks will be trialled. And a new screening process will be tested. Initial screening will take place at the Jobcentre. If potential need is identified, claimants will be referred for independent assessment. Those then assessed as below "entry level" will be referred to basic employability training, those at entry level will be sent for intensive eight-week literacy and numeracy provision, and those just below level 1 will be sent for part-time provision in a college or with learndirect.

fields.headline: Live to learn
fields.standfirst: Why are white-collar workers getting all the lifelong learning, asks  David Ashton
fields.trailText: Why are white-collar workers getting all the lifelong learning, asks David Ashton
fields.body:
The historical image of training in Britain has been that of a manual worker "sitting next to Nellie" and learning the job. Even today when we think of innovative schemes for self-development such as the famous Ford Employee Development and Assistance Programme scheme, which provides funds for courses chosen by employees for their personal enrichment, it is manual workers who are thought to benefit.

Yet research on company training practices sponsored by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development and conducted by the University of Leicester's Centre for Labour Market Studies has revealed a very different reality.

When it comes to using the workplace as a source of learning today, it is through structured on-the-job training and "Nellie" is far more likely to be one manager teaching another. In the same way employees on self-development schemes are far more likely to be managers or white collar workers than manual employees.

The survey found that 92% of managers were in establishments providing structured on-the-job training for some, if not most, managers, whereas those same establishments made no such provision for 47% of manual employees. It is the same story when it comes to self-development; of those establishments which had a budget for self-development, 92% of managers were covered but only 58% of manual workers.

For some time we have known that those most likely to be provided with formal training were the white collar and professional classes, while other workers were left to get on with learning in their own way, unaided. To this we must now add the use of the most widely used form of training, namely on-the-job training and one of the most recent innovations, self-development schemes. What started as a good idea for workers ended up being monopolised by managers and white-collar workers.

To the cynic, one of the reasons for this is that the managers and professionals control the budget. They are also the most highly educated and motivated people when it comes to further education and learning. They have more demanding jobs in which there is more to learn and to continue to learn. For many of them lifelong learning is a reality. It should therefore come as no surprise that they are more likely to take advantage of any opportunity to further their skills.

Yet for many manual workers to take advantage of opportunities for structured on-the-job training and self-development it is necessary first to provide those opportunities and this is often not happening. In this new "learning" society, preparing itself for the "new economy", to be a manual worker is to be marginalized in a very real sense - a form of training apartheid.

In one sense this would not matter if all we wanted manual workers to do was to pull levers and press buttons. If we are to continue to produce low cost goods with low paid labour, then the lack of skills is not a problem for the country, although it might be for those denied the opportunity to develop themselves.

But, if we are serious about moving into a high skills, high performance economy, into hi-tech industries and the knowledge society, can we afford to leave such a significant proportion of the labour force without the basic opportunity to learn, even about their own work? If we are serious about creating a society of lifetime learners can we afford to ignore the opportunities to learn at work for such a large segment of the population? Our competitors in south-east Asia are taking this very seriously, with educational and training programmes targeted at this group of manual workers, who are most at risk in the new economy. Is it not time for us to do the same and send Nellie into a well-earned retirement?

Professor David N Ashton is director of international development at the Centre for Labour Market Studies, University of Leicester.

In the same way employees on self-development schemes are far more likely to be managers or white collar workers than manual employees. The survey found that 92% of managers were in establishments providing structured on-the-job training for some, if not most, managers, whereas those same establishments made no such provision for 47% of manual employees. It is the same story when it comes to self-development; of those establishments which had a budget for self-development, 92% of managers were covered but only 58% of manual workers. For some time we have known that those most likely to be provided with formal training were the white collar and professional classes, while other workers were left to get on with learning in their own way, unaided. To this we must now add the use of the most widely used form of training, namely on-the-job training and one of the most recent innovations, self-development schemes. What started as a good idea for workers ended up being monopolised by managers and white-collar workers. To the cynic, one of the reasons for this is that the managers and professionals control the budget. They are also the most highly educated and motivated people when it comes to further education and learning. They have more demanding jobs in which there is more to learn and to continue to learn. For many of them lifelong learning is a reality. It should therefore come as no surprise that they are more likely to take advantage of any opportunity to further their skills. Yet for many manual workers to take advantage of opportunities for structured on-the-job training and self-development it is necessary first to provide those opportunities and this is often not happening. In this new "learning" society, preparing itself for the "new economy", to be a manual worker is to be marginalized in a very real sense - a form of training apartheid. In one sense this would not matter if all we wanted manual workers to do was to pull levers and press buttons. If we are to continue to produce low cost goods with low paid labour, then the lack of skills is not a problem for the country, although it might be for those denied the opportunity to develop themselves. But, if we are serious about moving into a high skills, high performance economy, into hi-tech industries and the knowledge society, can we afford to leave such a significant proportion of the labour force without the basic opportunity to learn, even about their own work? If we are serious about creating a society of lifetime learners can we afford to ignore the opportunities to learn at work for such a large segment of the population? Our competitors in south-east Asia are taking this very seriously, with educational and training programmes targeted at this group of manual workers, who are most at risk in the new economy. Is it not time for us to do the same and send Nellie into a well-earned retirement? Professor David N Ashton is director of international development at the Centre for Labour Market Studies, University of Leicester.

webTitle: So you want to learn about...Queen's Counsels

fields.headline: So you want to learn about...Queen's Counsels
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
There'll be a verdict today. Looks that way.

Am I going down? Difficult to say.

It's just you're looking well chuffed. Well, I've had splendid news.

Oh yeah. Yes. I'm one of the 77.

The 77 what? The new silks - the Lord Chancellor's just announced them.

What's that? Your brief, namely me, has been promoted to QC.

What's it mean? For one thing, your bill has just doubled.

@$%*!! Why? I'm going to be a Queen's Counsel.

So what? Queen's Counsels are barristers who have been appointed to advise the monarch.

Strewth! She ain't been nicked as well, has she? No. In practice no duties are required. Taking silk is treated as a mark of distinction like a medal or any other honour.

What's all this silk? Traditional court dress is a silk gown, hence "taking silk".

So, how do you become a silk? Any barrister with 10 to 15 years experience may apply for a "patent" or "take silk" in order to become a Queen's Counsel. It's necessary if they wish to become a High Court or Court of Sessions judge.

And how do you become a barrister? You need a degree. Doesn't have to be law. If not you'll need to do the Common Professional Examination or approved postgraduate course in law.

That all? You jest. Then you've got to join one of the four Inns of Court in London (Gray's Inn, Lincoln's Inn, Inner Temple and Middle Temple) and complete 12 qualifying units. And complete a Bar Vocational Course at one of the validated institutions throughout the country.

How do you get on one of those? Applications for a BVC are made through a centralised clearing system known as CACH (Centralised Applications and Clearing House).These take one year full-time or two years part- time. When you've successfully completed the BVC you are called to the bar. Then you can start to practise as a barrister.

Next stop silk. Woa! It's not that simple. You have to complete a period of "pupillage" in barristers' chambers.

Pillage? That's what I'm up for, isn't it. No. Pupillage - two periods of six months under the guidance of an experienced barrister.

Then bingo! Not quite. When they qualify, practising barristers must either obtain a tenancy in a set of chambers and work from there for at least three years, or with a barrister who has at least five years' experience.

What skills are needed? Well, it's a long training which requires a high degree of intellectual ability. Barristers also need excellent presentation skills and must be able to argue, convince and explain points of law to a jury and cross-examine witnesses.

I can see that it's a good earner. Actually earnings vary considerably. The majority earn anything from £17,000 to £250,000. A few top barristers earn over £1m.

That's better than crime. Perhaps, but it's a long haul. Initially it can take three to five years to build up a practice and overheads still have to be met. Barristers are self-employed and have to share the expense of running chambers, paying a part of the cost of the premises and salaries of staff.

So I need at least three years at least from the judge. What do you mean?

To get an OU law degree . . .

fields.body:
(TTS, tel: 0800 318 686, www.tts-shopping.com)
Price: £52.60 inc VAT
Age/ability range: 5+ yrs

The manufacturer says:

"A practical, easy-to-use introduction to electrical circuits, this set consists of a large mounting board with individual components on brightly coloured bases."

Elaine Waugh, ICT Coordinator, Condorrat Primary School, Cumbernauld, Scotland, says:

"This excellent kit is for the use of single circuits and allowing the development of a series of circuits. It has a very solid base with Velcro on the bottom of each section. It was very self-explanatory and I was able to use it straight from the box. It comes with a good set of workcards and batteries, which is a real bonus.

I used the kit in P5, P6 and P7 (9- 11-year-olds), who found it easy to use and thoroughly enjoyed it. They were also able to employ their knowledge of electricity symbols.

The kit can be added to, and was wonderful for morse code and for showing a running motor.

We're really pleased with it - it's much better than the one we had before. A very good resource."

Primary information technology, 1F understanding instructions and making things happen.

webTitle: The 'shocking' omission of staff from university figures

fields.headline: Missing persons
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod  reports on the 'shocking' omission of staff from university figures
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod reports on the 'shocking' omission of staff from university figures
fields.body:
Universities and colleges are still not gathering information about more than half of their staff, despite being urged to do so by the education secretary David Blunkett.

Data is not collected on the estimated 150,000 non-academic staff in higher education - who range from librarians and administrators to porters and lab technicians. Lecturers' unions are also concerned that the growing number of academics working part-time, and on fixed-term contracts, are not counted.

Calling for a census of higher education institutions, David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Lecturers, said today that the present confusion was undermining initiatives to improve equal opportunities.

"When universities claim to know what they are doing, it carries all the conviction of a Jeffrey Archer novel."

Nearly two years after the Bett report into academic pay and conditions complained it was unable to get reliable data, the universities are still discussing what information they should provide to the Higher Education Statistics Agency.

The agency, which proposed collecting data on non-academic staff in 1993 but was overruled by the university vice-chancellors, is hoping to have a new system in place for September 2002, with the first national figures becoming available in 2003.

While universities (and academics) frequently complain that they have to provide massive amounts of data to Hesa - it is a condition of receiving public funding - the AUT believes that many part-time workers have become invisible. A fifth of its members are non-academic staff.

The agency does not collect data on staff who work less than 25% of a full-time contract - disproportionately women, people with disabilities and younger staff.

Triesman said it was shocking that institutions could misplace hundreds of staff members: "The saga of the 'missing academics' must be solved by the concerted effort of institutions to collect accurate data.

"A census by individual universities could uncover a whole generation of missing staff, living on a succession of temporary contracts, and denied the professional status they have earned."

There is an apparent discrepancy between the Hesa figure for disability of 0.8 % (1,060 staff) with the national Labour Force Survey, which indicates that 19% of the workforce has some form of disability - approximately 6.7m people.

Brian Ramsden, chief executive of Hesa, said the door was open to collecting data on non-academic staff as far as he was concerned. "There is a general view that there should be an extension, particularly of data about ethnic minority and disabled staff."

Concerns about equal opportunities were positive but had delayed the introduction of a new system - the agency has engaged consultants to advise on forms of monitoring, said Ramsden.

Tony Bruce, director of policy development, Universities UK, which represents the vice-chancellors, said he hoped new guidance would be issued later this year. "Obviously universities do keep staffing records for the purposes of running their individual institutions effectively; the key issue that emerged during the Bett inquiry was that this data was not easily comparable as institutions tended to use individual systems when dealing with staff groups other than full-time academic staff. It has been a tough challenge to address this issue, but good progress is being made. All parties, including the unions, are involved in this challenge."

Blunkett and his department's permanent secretary, Michael Bichard, have been infuriated by the universities' apparent lack of drive in tackling a poor record in equal opportunities, and his 1999 letter to the Higher Education Funding Council for England said: "I am deeply concerned about the present position on equal opportunities for all higher education staff. Evidence suggest that only a minority of academic staff in higher education institutions are from an ethnic minority background, are women or have a disability, and that relatively few from these groups reach senior positions."

webTitle: On the Web: SATs revision | The solar system

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.standfirst: SATs revision | The solar system
fields.trailText: SATs revision | The solar system
fields.byline: Compiled by Jim Merrett and Andy Reid
fields.body:
SATs revision

Revisewise

www.bbc.co.uk/education/revisewise

Suitable for KS2 pupils

An excellent site designed to run in parallel with the television programmes of the same name, although it can be used independently. Maths, English and science are available and there is a choice of activities, factsheets and tests, which aremarked. Within each subject there is a good choice of theme, enabling children to work on their weaknesses. There are also game zones for some light relief after all the hard work.

Woodlands

www.woodlands-junior.kent.sch.uk/revision/index_main.html

Suitable for KS2 pupils & teachers

This is a colourful site, providing sample questions from past papers and essential facts. The English pages include a spelling test, parts of a sentence and grammar links. Within the maths section, there is an interactive mental arithmetic test.

Sats School

www.sats-school.co.uk

Suitable for KS2 pupils & teachers

The impressive graphics on this site are a major attraction although the content isn't so easy to use, as some areas are restricted to members. Children intending to make good use of the facilities (such as online tutorial support) would find it worthwhile to join. There are plenty of revision activities organised on a weekly basis.

Sam Learning Scheme

www.freeserve.net/education/examrevision

Suitable for: KS1/2 pupils, teachers and parents

KS1 material offers maths or English (with a small "e"!). The four rules are available in the maths pages and the children can take simple tests - but the result is given in percentages, which will not make much sense to a year 2. KS2 material offers a fairly good choice of material in maths and English but the science activities are divided into a choice of biology, chemistry and physics, terms which will be unfamiliar to most year 6 children. However, within those sub-headings there are the more familiar theme headings such as life processes, forces and materials.

The solar system

An introduction

www.howstuffworks.com

Suitable for KS4/5 pupils & teachers

Although limited on the solar system in general, it does have illustrated descriptions of the Sun and interplanetary travel.

Astroweb

cdsweb.u-strasbg.fr/astroweb.html

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

Links to all aspects of astronomy, from university research departments to dedicated educational websites. Another very useful starting point.

The planets (1)

www.bbc.co.uk/planets/

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils

The BBC's planetary tour offers comprehensive descriptions. As a bonus, the site includes star map-making facilities, a quiz and links.

The planets (2)

pds.jpl.nasa.gov/planets/

Suitable for KS5 pupils & teachers

Virtually every hard-to-find fact you may ever wish to know, and this site includes surface images. Keep a science dictionary handy, as technical terms are not explained.

A tour of the solar system

www.seds.org/billa/tnp/

Suitable for KS4/5 pupils & teachers

A fully interactive tour, with a no-nonsense design that makes navigation quick and easy. Excellent resource for images and technical information. See the pintsized sibling for younger pupils at www.planets4kids.com/

Starchild

starchild.gsfc.nasa.gov/docs/StarChild/StarChild.html

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

The higher of this site's two levels is more informative, technically more advanced and aimed at older pupils. But both are easy to navigate, with useful links that explain the jargon.

NASA

<A HREF="http://"www.jpl.nasa.gov/

Suitable for KS4/5 pupils & teachers

Latest images from NASA's ongoing missions, plus extensive archives and useful, explanatory captions.

Solar system simulator

space.jpl.nasa.gov/

Suitable for KS4/5 pupils & teachers

This awe-inspiring site allows the user to position themselves on any planet or spacecraft and get a simulated view of that part of the solar system.

webTitle: Quality assessment in universities yields surprising results

fields.headline: Wheel of fortune
fields.standfirst: The saga of quality assessment in Britain's universities has taken an extraordinary turn - dethroning some of the oldest academic stars and cronwing some of the newest. Francis Beckett reports
fields.trailText: The saga of quality assessment in Britain's universities has taken an extraordinary turn - dethroning some of the oldest academic stars and cronwing some of the newest. Francis Beckett reports
fields.body:
When, last month, the government caved in to pressure from Oxford, Cambridge and other elite universities to get the quality inspectors off their backs, it accidentally triggered a remarkable chain of events which produced the nearest we have ever seen to an official league table of English universities.

The results, which are supposed to be top secret, are going to be a severe embarrassment to the Russell Group - the top universities club - because it shows that they are not really the top universities at all.

This is how it happened. In recent months there have been fierce attacks on the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA) from Russell Group universities which think they are far too grand to have its sticky fingers meddling with their affairs.

In response, Education Secretary David Blunkett announced a 40% reduction in the number of inspections to be carried out by the QAA. The best universities were to be exempt.

The government could hardly say it was going to get the inspectors off the backs of the Russell Group universities. Instead Blunkett said: "University departments which have achieved good scores in the current round will be exempt from external review in the next round." In Blunkett's book, a "good score" is 21 or more on the 24-point scale.

Reviews conducted before 1995 were not scored, so the QAA and the Higher Education Funding Council decided that for pre-1995 inspections, if a department was inspected and deemed excellent they would call that 21 or over.

The higher the proportion of a university's departments that fall below the threshold of 21, the more likely a university or higher education institution is to be inspected again. The QAA and the Hefce therefore drew up a list of universities, against each of which they attached a score.

And - though these august bodies did nothing so impolite as to put the universities in order of excellence - clearly the best institutions will have the smallest percentage of their departments scoring below the Blunkett threshold.

So once you see the figures, universities fall naturally into a league table of teaching excellence. And the league table you get is quite startling.

Oxford University is pushed into fourth place, beaten not just by Cambridge and Warwick, which are at least in the Russell Group, but also by York and Loughborough.

The proud London School of Economics doesn't even make the top ten. It has to share eleventh place with, of all places, the Open University. Leeds University is one of the 19 elite Russell Group institutions, and therefore likes to think of itself as out of the top drawer, but it comes in at number 61. Its humiliation is compounded by the fact that it comes below no less than 13 of the new universities, or jumped up polys as they are known in Russell Group circles, and by two institutions of higher education.

Many new universities do remarkably well. Two of them - the University of the West of England (UWE) and Northumbria - get into the top ten. And in the top 20 there's even a university college, Canterbury Christ Church, at number 17.

But perhaps the most startling thing about the league table is the way in which old universities are regularly hammered by the new university or university college with which they share a city. UWE is sixth, but Bristol, a Russell Group institution, cannot do better than 32.

Northumbria is eighth, Newcastle 19th; Canterbury Christ Church is 17th, but Kent comes in at 45; Manchester Metropolitan University is 26th, but prestigious Russell Group Manchester languishes just nine places above Leeds, at 52. Brighton is at 27, Sussex at 33, while Leeds Metropolitan University, at 55, is six places higher than Leeds University.

The places that think they are Britain's top universities could begin to regret the success of their own lobbying, for it may mean only that they will face an invasion of QAA inspectors, whose enthusiasm for their work may be sharpened by the abuse they have suffered at the hands of the Russell Group.

Guardian university guide 2001

The Guardian's 2001 subject by subject guide to good university teaching will be published this month in a special supplement, ranking university departments in 43 different academic disciplines. The guide represents the most sophisticated attempt so far to gauge teaching strengths across the UK academic sector. It aims to inform and help prospective students secure their place at university.

Recent academic and government reports have called for more information to help university applicants choose their degree course, particularly those whose families have little experience of the university world.

Scores for departments are based on teaching quality inspections and statistics published by the Higher Education Statistics Agency. These include figures for spending per student, student-staff ratios, graduate employment rates, and average A-level and Highers scores for students. Departments that have lower A-level entry scores but produce upper-second or first-class degrees are rewarded in a special value-added score.

An interactive version of the guide will be available online, so users can rank and sort departments according to their interests. Users can find out how many students are female/part time/mature/non-white/ postgraduate/from overseas or local areas. Profiles of universities will include crucial links.

Clever moves

fields.bodyText: When, last month, the government caved in to pressure from Oxford, Cambridge and other elite universities to get the quality inspectors off their backs, it accidentally triggered a remarkable chain of events which produced the nearest we have ever seen to an official league table of English universities. The results, which are supposed to be top secret, are going to be a severe embarrassment to the Russell Group - the top universities club - because it shows that they are not really the top universities at all. This is how it happened. In recent months there have been fierce attacks on the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education (QAA) from Russell Group universities which think they are far too grand to have its sticky fingers meddling with their affairs. In response, Education Secretary David Blunkett announced a 40% reduction in the number of inspections to be carried out by the QAA. The best universities were to be exempt. The government could hardly say it was going to get the inspectors off the backs of the Russell Group universities. Instead Blunkett said: "University departments which have achieved good scores in the current round will be exempt from external review in the next round." In Blunkett's book, a "good score" is 21 or more on the 24-point scale. Reviews conducted before 1995 were not scored, so the QAA and the Higher Education Funding Council decided that for pre-1995 inspections, if a department was inspected and deemed excellent they would call that 21 or over. The higher the proportion of a university's departments that fall below the threshold of 21, the more likely a university or higher education institution is to be inspected again. The QAA and the Hefce therefore drew up a list of universities, against each of which they attached a score. And - though these august bodies did nothing so impolite as to put the universities in order of excellence - clearly the best institutions will have the smallest percentage of their departments scoring below the Blunkett threshold. So once you see the figures, universities fall naturally into a league table of teaching excellence. And the league table you get is quite startling. Oxford University is pushed into fourth place, beaten not just by Cambridge and Warwick, which are at least in the Russell Group, but also by York and Loughborough. The proud London School of Economics doesn't even make the top ten. It has to share eleventh place with, of all places, the Open University. Leeds University is one of the 19 elite Russell Group institutions, and therefore likes to think of itself as out of the top drawer, but it comes in at number 61. Its humiliation is compounded by the fact that it comes below no less than 13 of the new universities, or jumped up polys as they are known in Russell Group circles, and by two institutions of higher education. Many new universities do remarkably well. Two of them - the University of the West of England (UWE) and Northumbria - get into the top ten. And in the top 20 there's even a university college, Canterbury Christ Church, at number 17. But perhaps the most startling thing about the league table is the way in which old universities are regularly hammered by the new university or university college with which they share a city. UWE is sixth, but Bristol, a Russell Group institution, cannot do better than 32. Northumbria is eighth, Newcastle 19th; Canterbury Christ Church is 17th, but Kent comes in at 45; Manchester Metropolitan University is 26th, but prestigious Russell Group Manchester languishes just nine places above Leeds, at 52. Brighton is at 27, Sussex at 33, while Leeds Metropolitan University, at 55, is six places higher than Leeds University. The places that think they are Britain's top universities could begin to regret the success of their own lobbying, for it may mean only that they will face an invasion of QAA inspectors, whose enthusiasm for their work may be sharpened by the abuse they have suffered at the hands of the Russell Group. Guardian university guide 2001 The Guardian's 2001 subject by subject guide to good university teaching will be published this month in a special supplement, ranking university departments in 43 different academic disciplines. The guide represents the most sophisticated attempt so far to gauge teaching strengths across the UK academic sector. It aims to inform and help prospective students secure their place at university. Recent academic and government reports have called for more information to help university applicants choose their degree course, particularly those whose families have little experience of the university world. Scores for departments are based on teaching quality inspections and statistics published by the Higher Education Statistics Agency. These include figures for spending per student, student-staff ratios, graduate employment rates, and average A-level and Highers scores for students. Departments that have lower A-level entry scores but produce upper-second or first-class degrees are rewarded in a special value-added score. An interactive version of the guide will be available online, so users can rank and sort departments according to their interests. Users can find out how many students are female/part time/mature/non-white/ postgraduate/from overseas or local areas. Profiles of universities will include crucial links. webTitle: How can you tell if a 'bad' school is about to get better?

fields.headline: To boldly go ...
fields.standfirst: There's only one good school locally and it's hopelessly oversubscribed. Do you: a) bribe the head, b) move house, or c) send your kids to the school that's  about  to be good?  Hilly Janes  meets the people who know how to spot a winner
fields.trailText: There's only one good school locally and it's hopelessly oversubscribed. Do you: a) bribe the head, b) move house, or c) send your kids to the school that's about to be good? Hilly Janes meets the people who know how to spot a winner
fields.body:
Everyone thought she was crazy. Why would anybody send their talented musician daughter, who had won places at private and top-performing state schools, to an inner London secondary where only one-third of a per cent of pupils achieved five GCSEs at grade A-C?

But four years later Frances Jagodinska's risk has paid off. The school, St Marylebone, is now the most improved in the country, according to the DfEE. Last year 89% of students attained those grades and it has Beacon School status in performing arts. Her daughter, now 13, is extremely happy there, and, says Jagodinska, the school is getting better all the time. Every year it gets harder to get into.

How did Jagodinska get ahead of the pack? A teacher and lecturer for more than 20 years, she did her homework. She looked at league tables, Ofsted reports, even old local authority reports in the public library for 22 schools. She worked out that St Marylebone had gone through a bad patch several years earlier and its reputation had never recovered. But since the current head, Elizabeth Phillips, had arrived, results had improved dramatically and the school had won Performing Arts College status, which would attract more funding and improve facilities.

But more than anything, Jagodinska relied on her gut instinct: "The school had a good atmosphere, it looked welcoming, the staff were upbeat and the girls polite," she observed. "The intake is very mixed, but there is a very good can-do spirit."

With many parents now paying up to 20% more for a home to live within the ever-shrinking catchment area of a good school, and many more suffering sleepless nights after receiving rejection letters from the school they wanted, such insight is priceless.

But now a group of researchers believe they have come up with a formula which will allow any parent to spot a school that may not have a great reputation, but is about to.

The Hay Group, a leading international human resources consultancy, were asked by the government to look into what makes highly effective teachers and heads, and concluded that creating the right atmosphere in classrooms is a major factor. Improved results, they claim, are bound to follow.

And they came up with some guidelines for parents: follow their advice, they say, and you will be able to spot those schools that, a couple of years down the line, other parents will be queuing round the block to get into.

Hay, which also helped develop the award-winning Leadership Programme for Serving Headteachers (LPSH), spoke to hundreds of teachers, parents and academics to find out what really made a difference. But most important of all, they say, is to ask the pupils. "Our research showed there is a clear link between how pupils feel in the classroom and success in exam results and inspections," says Hay's Russell Hobby.

"We checked against the value-added progress that pupils made [ie how much the children had achieved given their abilities on entering the school] and standards of achievement and came out with nine components of successful learning. If potential parents are aware of these, they can identify schools where long-term success can be predicted, even when it may not be obvious to others."

In other words, a school may come way down the league tables, but still be good. Given a more able or motivated intake, its results will soon soar.

The group designed questionnaires that tested these nine components in classrooms across the country. More than 30,000 children have now completed them, and the consultancy has developed a potted version that parents can ask, for example at open days, to establish if the school offers the right "climate" for progress and how effectively children are learning.

But the Hay Group's findings are not simply designed to assist parents in the increasingly bitter battle for places. It is also hoped that the research will help spot a school which is on the way up, and help others improve more rapidly.

For things to change, however, teachers must take pupils' views into account. To this end, Hay has developed a commercial website that enables individual teachers, in total confidence, to access the results of their own pupils' questionnairesand work out a course of action.

Kingsthorpe Community College in Northampton participated in the pilot scheme last year, and staff there are among the first to use the website, which went live in January. Trevor Arrowsmith, the head, says: "The research is well-grounded and staff find it a powerful and efficacious tool."

But it is early days yet. "It is not an instant fix - it's a long term thing."

He confirms that the nine key factors are linked to better performance. "If you get all these things up to where they should be you are bound to see improvements. Some of the nine elements are very similar to some Ofsted criteria, so working on them should result in better inspection reports."

Some of the thinking is not new, he concedes, what is different is getting the feedback from pupils. "It makes the job of the teacher more manageable because the students are going to be more focused if there is clarity and fairness, for example," he says.

"It's better value for money than many other commercial packages where staff pay £200, go away for the day and come back with a ring-binder. I have 87 teachers who can all access the website - that is incredibly cost effective."

Cynics might say that Hay's findings are simply another government ruse for putting all the onus for improvement onto teachers, and that the consultancy is cashing in on a new market created by performance related pay, while schools stump up the money - from £500 to £2,000 pounds depending on the size of the school - to use the website.

How can a school in a deprived area, for example, turn itself around if the clientele is the same and there is no extra funding to improve facilities?

Jeff Richardson took on a school that was at rock bottom. He is head of Wexham Secondary School in Slough, a non-selective comprehensive in an area where 30% of pupils attend grammar schools. He arrived when the school was formed in 1987 by the merger of two others which had closed against total opposition from staff and parents. Within three years of Mr Richardson taking over, Wexham was oversubscribed.

There was never a precise moment when he felt the school had turned a corner; he always believed it would. But there were signs that parents could pick up on. "Change was incremental. The first year I took over the GCSE results were abysmal. Only 1%-2% per cent were getting five at grade C or above. Now that's 29%. And the number getting a pass of any description has risen from 50% to almost 100%."

He points to two Ofsted reports and an LEA report that highlighted improvements. Another defining moment was five years after his arrival, when every pupil in the school had always been a Wexham pupil, sharing the same values from the word go. Establishing a PTA was another marker. So was a Sportsmark award from the DfEE for quality, range and involvement in physical education.

Richardson's philosophy reflects the Hay findings that pupils matter. "Only they can tell you what it really feels like to be at this school," he says. Knowing that Wexham's reputation would lag behind its achievements, Richardson made a point of welcoming visitors so that views were not based on hearsay, especially if they had contacted him to complain about behaviour outside the school gates. All this sends a message to pupils that he is not ashamed of them.

As for Frances Jagodinska, she has been ignoring received wisdom again. She is about to take a chance with a school for her son, now in his last year at primary. He will be attending London Nautical School in Southwark, where there is an emphasis on seafaring skills. "It has a reputation for being discplinarian, traditionalist and non-academic," she says. But Jagodinska believes this does not reflect recent improvements in performance and Ofsted ratings. She also believes it is right for her child. "My son likes the nautical bit and he's also keen on the arts, one of the school's strong points. And I liked the head."

So, if you want to know if a school is really getting better, the answer, it seems, is do your homework and ask those who really know - the pupils.

Visit the Hay Group's website at www.transforminglearning.co.uk

Ask the children

The Hay Group have identified nine tell-tale signs that a school is on the verge of becoming good. To spot the signs, talk to the pupils.

1. Interest

You can't force children to learn but if you create a buzz and make learning fun and exciting, they will lap it up.

Ask Do you enjoy coming into class? Would you come to school if you didn't have to?

2. Standards

Do staff and pupils carry with them a sense of excellence and ambition?

Ask Are you always expected to try hard? Do you find the work you are set can be quite difficult?

3. Clarity

Knowing why you are doing something helps you do it better.

Ask When you study something, are you clear about which bits you will be tested on? By the end of the lesson, do you know what you were supposed to have learned?

4. Safety

Children cannot pay attention if they are distracted by fear.

Ask In class, do pupils ever damage each other's things or hurt each other?

5. Support

Everyone makes mistakes, especially when they are being stretched. If pupils think they will be laughed at they won't bother.

Ask Is it OK to say when you don't understand something? Do pupils help each other to solve problems?

6. Fairness

Noticing effort and rewarding it consistently are vital if children are going to keep trying.

Ask If you do your best, are you praised for it? Are good marks ever given out when someone hasn't done a good piece of work?

7. Participation

Do all pupils have the chance to ask questions, discuss issues and work in small groups.

Ask Do you get the chance to discuss things in class? Are you encouraged to say what you think in lessons?

8. Environment

A dirty, drab room implies children are not important and encourages them to treat their work in the same way.

Ask Is your classroom clean and tidy? Do you think it looks nice?

9. Order

Buzz must be balanced with a sense of discipline and structure.

Ask Do lessons usually start and finish on time? Do you pay attention in class?

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst: Its teaching is on a par with Oxford, but Bolton Institute is still being denied university status
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Alderman
fields.body:
Bolton. The name evokes a world of Dickensian "smokestack" towns, muck (or rather textiles) and money. A university in Bolton? A mechanics' institute, perhaps; even a technical college. But surely not a university. In fact, Bolton has what is, to all intents and purposes, a university. The trouble is, the government won't allow it to be called one.

Bolton Institute is one of the few non-universities to possess the power to award undergraduate, masters and doctoral qualifications. It can trace its origins back to the 1820s. As an institute of higher education it has flourished and grown. Like any flourishing and growing institution it has had its problems. Some of its early Teaching Quality Assessments by the universities' watchdog resulted in mediocre outcomes. A score of 13 out of 24 for Communication Studies included one unsatisfactory grade. Bolton had not yet learned to play the TQA game.

But communication studies scored 20 on the compulsory revisit by Quality Assurance Agency inspectors. More recently, Bolton's TQA results have been extremely good. Modern languages scored 22 and materials technology scored 23 - results as good as Cambridge. Education was awarded 24 points - maximum marks. So was psychology, a result which, according to the QAA, again puts psychology teaching at Bolton on a par with Oxford and Cambridge.

Bolton applied for the university title. But just as it did so the QAA decided that the rules for conferring this status had to be changed. An institution that has had an unsatisfactory TQA within the previous five years, or a satisfactory result that included three grade 2s, is now virtually certain to be denied QAA support for upgrading to university status. Bolton's application, it seems, was doomed at the outset.

Let's now travel to leafy Gloucestershire, a county without a university. But Cheltenham & Gloucester College of Higher Education has distinct university aspirations. It began life in the 1840s as a teacher-training facility. In 1992 the college received degree awarding powers and in 1998 the power to award research degrees.

C&G has never had an unsatisfactory TQA, but some time ago it suffered a potentially disastrous inspection of its art & design provision. This resulted in a total score of 18 points - "quality approved" - but including the dreaded three grade 2s. The college lodged a vigorous appeal against this most upsetting result. The QAA was persuaded to agree to a complete re-inspection, even though there's no mention of such a possibility in the agency's rulebook. New inspectors were appointed and there was a fresh inspection, resulting in the respectable score of 21 points.

Don't get me wrong. I know the reasons that led C&G to appeal against its first art & design result. The libel laws prevent me from printing them. You will have to take my word for it that they were compelling. C&G is a fine institution, and I wish its application for university title every success.

But if C&G succeeds where Bolton has failed, there will have been a multiple miscarriage of justice.

First, C&G was allowed to appeal against a satisfactory result despite the QAA's explicit declaration that only an unsatisfactory TQA score could be appealed. Second, by agreeing to a completely fresh visit, C&G was permitted to expunge the official memory of the original art & design result, which was thus struck from the record.

Bolton's unsatisfactory communication studies result, on the other hand, remains on the record (for anyone to view on the QAA's website), and cannot, it seems, ever be erased.

But the insult to Bolton goes further. A very small number of institutions already have university status, but would not warrant such status under the QAA's current rules. Leeds is one, Exeter is another. It might be argued that there is therefore a case for stripping Exeter and Leeds of their university titles.

But, owing to a drafting error in the 1992 Education Act, the government does not have the power to do this.

May we assume that, in fairness to Bolton, David Blunkett will now take such a power and use it?

Professor Geoffrey Alderman, vice-president of Touro College, New York, was formerly pro vice-chancellor at Middlesex University, London.

First, C&G was allowed to appeal against a satisfactory result despite the QAA's explicit declaration that only an unsatisfactory TQA score could be appealed. Second, by agreeing to a completely fresh visit, C&G was permitted to expunge the official memory of the original art & design result, which was thus struck from the record. Bolton's unsatisfactory communication studies result, on the other hand, remains on the record (for anyone to view on the QAA's website), and cannot, it seems, ever be erased. But the insult to Bolton goes further. A very small number of institutions already have university status, but would not warrant such status under the QAA's current rules. Leeds is one, Exeter is another. It might be argued that there is therefore a case for stripping Exeter and Leeds of their university titles. But, owing to a drafting error in the 1992 Education Act, the government does not have the power to do this. May we assume that, in fairness to Bolton, David Blunkett will now take such a power and use it? Professor Geoffrey Alderman, vice-president of Touro College, New York, was formerly pro vice-chancellor at Middlesex University, London.

webTitle: Are the unions ignoring the plight of lecturers?

fields.headline: Union blues
fields.standfirst: Why are Natfhe and the AUT fighting for more money for students - and ignoring the plight of lecturers, asks  Wendy Piatt
fields.trailText: Why are Natfhe and the AUT fighting for more money for students - and ignoring the plight of lecturers, asks Wendy Piatt
fields.body:
Pay negotiations for lecturers have yet again collapsed and a summer of industrial discontent is duly forecast. The government has pledged to replenish the coffers for staff pay with £330m over three years. But compared to their colleagues in the public, never mind the private sector, academics have had an embarrassingly raw deal for over a decade. The case for a substantial rise in academic salaries is overwhelming.

A sewage operator for Thames Water earns £12,031. With a good, usually first-class degree and a minimum of three years' doctoral study on the CV, most aspiring academics become research assistants earning between £10k and £15k. Assistant escalator staff on the London Underground can expect £22,247 on the night shift. Junior lecturers in their mid- to late 20s have to settle for £16k-£18k. Professors heading a department are rewarded with £49k, while headteachers can command salaries of up to £78k.

Unlike the teaching profession, academia has not yet suffered pervasive recruitment problems for several reasons: lecturers have relatively high social status, far greater autonomy, intellectual satisfaction and, crucially, they are not expected to be disciplinarians.

But these attractions are under threat as teaching loads become more onerous, incidents of "challenging" behaviour among disaffected students are increasing and social status is diminishing with remuneration. The job is bedevilled by insecurity: short-term contracts are prevalent and only 5% have a modicum of stability.

The "swinging 60s timebomb" is predicted to explode in 2005, when up to one third of academic staff are due to retire. Attracting applications for their replacements in subjects such as law and economics is proving increasingly problematic. Several universities have resorted to financial incentives to fill their PhD places. But a bright graduate is understandably seduced by starting salaries in other areas that wipe out their money worries.

Many lecturers complain that their undergrads have landed lucrative deals surpassing their modest salary. So why are the lecturers' unions, Natfhe and the Association of Uni versity Teachers endorsing a policy to subsidise these predominantly middle-class and potentially high-earning students? The support of the lecturers' unions for a campaign to abolish tuition fees and restore maintenance grants is self-defeating, if not suicidal, and, above all, politically naive. The political process demands prioritisation in apportioning limited resources. The budget for HE has been increased under this government. But it is unreasonable to expect the state to meet all financial demands, never mind revert to a policy that is both highly regressive and very costly.

One of the key choices facing policy-makers is how to distribute funds between students on one hand and institutions, including staff, on the other. The UK has historically allotted a far greater percentage of the HE budget to financial aid for students than most other countries. Even in 1997 when maintenance grants were minimal, Britain spent 35% of the total budget on student support compared to the OECD average of 19%. Despite the abolition of grants and introduction of fees, this percentage has not greatly diminished. The taxpayer still foots the bill for the interest on loans, a range of grants to lone parents, mature, disadvantaged and disabled students and a hefty 50% of tuition fees. Even the maximum constitutes approximately 25% of the average cost of a course, much less for subjects such as medicine and engineering.

If the cause that AUT and Natfhe are backing ever wins the day, surely the first casualty would be any rise in academics' pay! Equally, the first source of funds for additional pay should be the graduates whose earning potential so exceeds their lecturers' that they are shunning the very profession that wants to subsidise them further.

So-called "top-up fees" are probably the fairest and most feasible method of funding universities, yet one of the most misunderstood and misrepresented of policy proposals. A relatively "dilute" differential fee system could lever in enough funds to provide a substantial pay rise. A fee structure reflecting the ratio of real costs of courses could charge the existing £1,000 for classroom-based subjects, £2,000 for laboratory subjects, law and economics and £4,500 for clinical stages of medicine and dentistry courses. The vast majority would contribute no more than £2,000 and the prospective doctors and dentists would almost certainly be subsidised. Yet this scheme would generate almost £600m of recurrent additional funding across the HE sector - almost exactly the cost of Bett recommendations for an increase in academic pay. Introducing an element of differentiation between institutions would provide a closer correspondence between course costs and rates of return and might even prevent our most talented academics fleeing across the Atlantic.

All the caveats about the dangers of deterring the disadvantaged should be heeded. A portion of the money raised should fund targeted maintenance allowances. The repayment threshold should be raised to £20k so most public-sector workers would be granted a few years' grace at the outset of their careers. Most importantly, young academics should be awarded a bursary akin to the £6,000 introduced for trainee teachers. London colleges could use their extra revenue to emulate their US counterparts in providing accommodation for staff.

So when the lecturers' unions meet for their annual conference in Scarborough this month, they could focus on defusing rather than detonating the so-called timebomb. A scheme deriving greater contributions from those who profit handsomely from their education might at last achieve the pay rise their members truly deserve.

Dr Wendy Piatt is Research Fellow in Education at the Institute for Public Policy Research.
