webTitle: How psychodynamic counselling can help staff cope with disruptive children

fields.headline: Trouble in mind
fields.standfirst: With more disruptive children in the classrooms than ever before,  Reva Klein  looks at how a new training course in psychodynamic counselling can give staff the skills to cope while  Marina Cantacuzino sees how such children affect a day in the life of a normal class
fields.trailText: With more disruptive children in the classrooms than ever before, Reva Klein looks at how a new training course in psychodynamic counselling can give staff the skills to cope while Marina Cantacuzino sees how such children affect a day in the life of a normal class
fields.body:
Imagine for a moment that you're William, a year 10 pupil who's feeling strange. Your parents have recently divorced, your mum is depressed and withdrawn and you haven't seen your dad for weeks. You feel abandoned by both of them and are desperate for attention. You've always been good at making people laugh and find yourself little by little slipping into a new persona as disruptive, underachieving clown. Other kids love it. Your teachers don't and show it by shouting, criticising and assuming the worst of you before you've even opened your mouth.

Now imagine that you're William's maths or English teacher. Something's wrong with this boy, but you don't know what and don't have the time, energy or inclination to find out. From being occasionally silly he's become a full-blown troublemaker whose attention-seeking is a constant irritant and whose underachievement is a real worry.

In a class of 28, William has become a thorn in your side. You've tried cajolery, threats and visits to the deputy head, but nothing seems to bother him. He's got a learning mentor who's suggested that he see the school counsellor, but the waiting list is six weeks because she only comes in twice a week. And, frankly, for one 20-minute session a week, who knows if it's going to be any use? All you know is that you can't wait to see the back of him at the end of the year.

William's got problems and he's not the only one. There are more troubled children in mainstream schools than ever before. One in five children and adolescents experiences a mental health problem serious enough to warrant professional help, but only 10% to 20% get it. And it's not that the rest don't want help, it's just that, despite the government's drive for early intervention, it doesn't exist in their area. With the rise in the number of children displaying emotional and behavioural difficulties at school, including the worrying escalation in conduct disorder, classroom teachers have very little in their professional armoury to equip them to deal with it.

Initial teacher training pays scant attention to child psychology and the vast majority of inset courses focus on curricular subject areas. But without the understanding, expertise or time to deal with these children, teachers can feel overwhelmed, at a loss and defeated by their demands, particularly when set against the diverse needs of the others in the classroom.

In this new era of inclusive schools, no one can say how many children have transient or more serious mental health problems that are ignored and who instead get shouted at, sent to the head or are temporarily excluded, again and again until, finally, they never come back.

School counselling services are very variable, says Dinah Morley, deputy director of Young Minds, the child's mental health charity. "Some are linked up with the health authority's child and adolescent mental health services, but many are hit-and-miss with people who may be qualified counsellors, but have no training in working with children. And then there are many school nurses who take on a counselling role without any training, carrying tremendous case loads of children with mental health problems of real concern."

The plethora of short, general counselling courses on the market and the absence of quality control has led, says Dorothy Eddi Piper of the Trust for the Study of Adolescence, "to some extraordinarily badly qualified counsellors working in schools. On one course I know of, people get called counsellors after just 15 hours of training." In response to the increasing demands on schools, and the absence of appropriate training, Sue Kegerreis, a child and adolescent psychotherapist and school counsellor, has developed what's believed to be the first such course of its kind: an MSc in psychodynamic counselling with children and adolescents, at Birkbeck College, University of London.

Designed for professionals working with young people - including teachers, school counsellors, social workers and youth workers - it's an intensive course that provides the insights and strategies they need to work with troubled young people within the formal structures of school.

In contrast to the short courses for professionals working with children, the Birkbeck course, which starts in the autumn, is a demanding commitment for employers as much as for participants. It runs one day a week over a period of two years for a diploma, or three years for an MSc, with the final year on placement. In addition, students are required to go through psychotherapy themselves once a week.

Schools and LEAs strapped for cash and staff are unlikely to be clamouring for places on such long-term and expensive training courses for counsellors, teachers and related staff. Since the introduction of local management of schools, education authorities no longer employ a pool of specialist counsellors. Instead, schools must buy in themselves, having to choose from the burgeoning market in counselling services run by voluntary and other agencies.

Kegerreis aims to sharpen up practice by offering a course focused on how the young person interacts with the school setting as well as with their home and social environment.

"As well as looking at how the conscious and unconscious mind works, psychodynamic counselling is about looking at the relationships around the child and at the impact of the child on people around them," she says. "It's concerned with the child in context, with what's going on around them and with finding a shared understanding with them about why they're feeling and behaving the way they are, rather than just giving them solutions."

In a case like William's, for instance, psychodynamic counselling would involve the trained adult working with him to see that his disruptive, clownish behaviour was his way of communicating despair and lack of control over his life because of his parents' divorce and their withdrawal from him.

"If the professional just reacts to the child's aggression, it becomes part of the problem," says Kegerreis.

"If a child seems wild or out of control, you can get into a situation where you're just condemning the behaviour and can so easily miss out on the underlying problems."

An important part of the Birkbeck course is the way students are put in a position of understanding what it means to be a pupil, looking at their own relationship to authority and at their own experience as learners. It's something that the increasingly pres surised "them and us" culture in schools, which separates professionals from pupils, doesn't allow reflection for.

"It gives students on the course a way of understanding more fully the kinds of things kids are experiencing with teachers, other figures of authority and their peers. It reminds them of how difficult it is to learn."

Morley believes that there is, finally, "an awakening to the realisation that children's mental health matters," with the growth of child and adolescent mental health services and their attempts to link up with the education sector.

Enabling teachers and school counsellors to understand the mental health problems being played out before their eyes day in, day out, also gives them an opportunity to reclaim their professionalism.

"The space to think is at a terrible premium in schools," says Kegerreis, "and it can be soul-destroying for teachers. If anything contributes to burn-out, it's that."

webTitle: Technology in a tin offers instant hot coffee

fields.headline: Technology in a tin offers instant hot coffee
fields.trailText: The burgeoning love affair between the British and their coffee is about to become more intimate as caffeine fiends prepare to cut out the middle man and get down to basics.
fields.body:
The burgeoning love affair between the British and their coffee is about to become more intimate as caffeine fiends prepare to cut out the middle man and get down to basics.

For those seeking an instant fix without the grind of interminable queues and the plethora of choice in well known coffee houses, the ideal solution presents itself in the humble form of a can.

A simple push of a button and a gentle shaking action is all it will take to satisfy the urge for a hot beverage any time, any place, anywhere.

Trials of Nestle's new "hot when you want" coffee, the first of its kind in Britain, are to begin in the midlands at the end of May.

Thirsty shoppers, who will be able to buy the brown and white cans for £1.19, are required to make just one simple choice - Nescafe original with milk and sugar or white without sugar.

The drink, which has been developed over the past two years, is heated up by pressing a red button on the base of the can and waiting for three minutes as a quick-lime and water reaction in the inner membrane does all the work.

Once heated the can will be slightly warm, but not too hot as it contains reinforced materials to prevent this. All the drinker has to do is to release the ring-pull and drink.

"It is about enabling people to have coffee whenever and wherever they want it - on a train, on a park bench or wherever," Nestle's Deborah Tilley explained.

webTitle: Global watchdog launched to combat the number of attacks on teachers and students

fields.headline: Fighting back
fields.standfirst: A global watchdog has been launched to combat the number of attacks on teachers and students.  John Akker  reports
fields.trailText: A global watchdog has been launched to combat the number of attacks on teachers and students. John Akker reports
fields.body:
In many parts of the world, university academics and students live in perpetual fear. The same is true for teachers in colleges and schools, and increasingly for pupils. For some, this is the reality of life in the first part of the 21st century. Killings, imprisonment, abuse and harassment are on the increase .

This is the reason behind a new global watchdog, Network for Education and Academic Rights (Near). Inspired by a meeting called by Unesco early in 2000, it is being launched to aid the rapid transfer of information on a global basis. It will alert those able to take action to protest to governments and international agencies and will quickly inform the leaders of countries with the worst record that their actions are being closely watched by an international community.

News about attacks on educational establishments do not often hit the headlines. How many of us have heard that recently in Ethiopia 49 people were killed in clashes, most of these linked to universities and schools? Amnesty International reported that security forces were using "excessive force against students and other demonstrators". According to Agence France-Presse (AFP), students and schoolchildren protested and police rounded up protesters, who were demanding greater freedom of expression.

A statement from the Addis Ababa University Students Association posted on the net on April 23 said, "We are in grave danger . . . we want the world to hear our side of the story . . . many students are seriously wounded and are being detained". Over the last 10 years, university academics have either been forced to flee Ethiopia or been imprisoned. The BBC website shows the student dormitories splattered with blood.

Near will provide a site where reports from many sources have been incorporated.

Other examples can be found in Afghanistan, Indonesia, Burma, China, Malaysia, Belarus and Uzbekistan - just a small number of countries where those in education are at risk. In Afghanistan, academics were forced to flee from the Taliban regime. Many arrived in Pakistan where they faced further harassment and threats.

Academics in Serbia continue to grapple with the legacy of Slobodan Milosevic's attempts to control the universities that served as centres of opposition to his government. The University Act of 1998 subjected faculty members to political oversight and deprived them of the right to select their administrators. As a result of this law Belgrade University alone lost some 180 instructors and professors.

The dictator's measures backfired. Opposition to the University Act was one of the central demands of stu dents and academics protesting against the Milosevic government, with many university professors and members of the Serbian Academy of Science and Arts backing Otpor ("Resistance"), a loosely structured, student-led opposition movement that played a critical role in Milosevic's electoral defeat.

One of the first moves of the new Serbian Minister of Education was to rescind the University Act. While Yugoslav universities now operate under the law as it was before 1998, they still have to deal with those academics who were sacked because of it. Although ministers have suggested a new law, the first drafts have been criticised as insufficiently protective of academic freedom. In the meantime, cases are being looked at individually.

As well as these large-scale occurrences, there are countless situations of police detaining individuals who try to leave the country or those who are dismissed from their posts for expressing views opposing the ruling party. One academic was detained recently leaving a Middle East country because he was an outspoken advocate of human rights. He faced imprisonment because of remarks made at an international conference in which he criticised the country's human rights record.

Some will say that others face the same risk from totalitarian regimes. Universities and schools, however, are often at the forefront of any human rights conflict - which is as it should be if basic educational values are to be upheld.

But what can be done? Well, quite a lot. China has detained three academics without trial. An international campaign of protest is under way led by the academic freedom committee of Human Rights Watch, the New York Academy of Sciences and the American Association for the Advancement of Science, while 400 international China studies scholars have sent a letter to President Jiang Zemin. China's cultural and academic links are at risk. The authorities there certainly would not realise the extent of the international concern if the world of education had remained silent.

So how will the new network be organised? Funded by Unesco - with other grants now being sought worldwide - its whole raison d' tre will be to assist those who already promote educational rights. It will work vigorously to improve information transfer among those best able to take action. Member organisations will be able to post alerts and other information on the Near website, which is now under construction.

The network will, through the opportunities provided by the internet and other communication technologies, develop links with NGOs, trade unions, professional bodies, decision makers, educators and the general public making vital information aimed at defending freedom of expression available and accessible.

Founding members of the network are the American Association for the Advancement of Science, Human Rights Watch, the Council for Assisting Refugee Academics, the Association of University Teachers, the worldwide teacher organisation Education International, the Scholars at Risk Network (University of Chicago) and the Council for the Development of Social Science Research in Africa.

The new network's related organisation is the International Freedom of Expression Exchange (Ifex) with which it already has close links (www.ifex.org). Formed in 1992, with the support of Unesco, Ifex has transformed the global exchange of information about abuses against the rights of journalists. It now has in excess of 50 member organisations throughout the world, and its website receives more than 60,000 hits a week. The alert system that it deploys brings together a worldwide group of interested and concerned organisations that can quickly bring pressure on governments and international bodies.

Sited next to the Council for Assisting Refugee Academics in London, Near will be building its lists of member organisation throughout the world. Links with Africa, Asia and South America will be a vital part of the network's development plan.

Mary Robinson, the UN human rights commissioner, recently stated that universities, colleges and schools have a vital role to play in the development of human rights. The network will be working to ensure their rights are upheld.

John Akker is the executive director of Near. Email: near@jakker.fsnet.co.uk

Harassment in Tunisia

Dr Moncef Marzouki, a former professor of medicine at the University of Sousse in Tunisia, has been subjected to an ongoing campaign of harassment by the authorities because of his human rights activities. A previous president of the Tunisian Human Rights League and spokesperson for the National Council for Liberties in Tunisia (CNLT), he has been imprisoned for his "anti-governmental" activities, had his passport confiscated and been banned from leaving the country. He was also arbitrarily dismissed from his academic post in July 2000. Dr Marzouki was found guilty of disseminating information "liable to disturb public order" and "maintaining an unauthorised association" with the CNLT. Recently, restrictions on Dr Marzouki's movements meant that he was unable to leave Tunisia in March while trying to rejoin his family in France.

Carla Tsampiras

Persecution of Basque professor

A Basque professor targeted by the terrorist group ETA has been awarded one of this year's Hellman/Hammett grants to writers in financial need as a result of political persecution. Administered by Human Rights Watch, the fund was set up by the writer Lillian Hellman and her long-time companion, Dashiell Hammett (of Maltese Falcon fame), who were interrogated by the House Un-American Activities Committee during the McCarthy anti-commu nist "witch hunts" of the 1950s.

Professor Mikel Azurmendi, a social anthropologist at the University of Bilbao, was a member of the armed separatist group ETA until 1970, when he joined the Basque pro-democracy movement, and founded the Foro Ermua, one of the most prestigious intellectual groups advocating peace and democracy.

An author of many books, his major contribution has been to deconstruct the "ethnic exclusionism" used by radi cal nationalists to define the Basque historical experience, and to criticise this ideology as one leading to intolerance.

Azurmendi has reportedly been on an ETA hit list for some time. Appeals to kill him have been distributed in pamphlets; and he was the direct target of a bomb attack in August 2000 in San Sebastian. As a result, he was forced to leave Spain and is working in North America.

Inspired by a meeting called by Unesco early in 2000, it is being launched to aid the rapid transfer of information on a global basis. fields.headline: Higher browsing
fields.trailText: Higher news
fields.body:
The third degree

 Students just sit around listening to music, right? On the new King's College London MA in Visual and Performing Arts they certainly will. Based on the Proms concerts, the course takes place over two summers and students get a promming season ticket and attend rehearsals, as well as studying the history of this very British institution. It is not so much a few nights at the Albert Hall for a total of £3,500, more the "advanced critical and practical study of music in a clearly defined social context". Apply by end of June www.kcl.ac.uk/ip/paulsmith/MAVA/Index.htm

 While the outside world imagines universities aspire to Oxbridge, those in the know realise everyone now wants to be Warwick. The State of UK Higher Education (Open University Press, £19.99) looks at the way different types of institution have coped with change - all but one of its contributors worked at Warwick, and the concluding part of the book is entitled the Warwick Way. It is all a tribute, say the authors, to one man - Michael Shattock, the university's registrar since the 1970s, described as the only man who from childhood wanted to be a university manager.

 Baldrick, aka Tony Robinson, is launching a cunning plan at Lincolnshire and Humberside University next week - the students' union Is turning itself into a co-op. The 7,000 students in Lincoln and Hull will become owners and shareholders of the SU. Plans include a student housing cooperative, telephone and power supplies, group insurance, a job shop and a credit union for students.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News: American money

US colleges and universities raised an estimated $23.2bn (£15.5bn) from voluntary donations in the 1999-2000 academic year. According to the preliminary results of a study published last week, the US academic sector has again broken all fund-raising records, increasing income from alumni and other private sources by $2.8bn on the previous year.

The funds raised by US universities dwarf the voluntary contributions to academic institutions in the UK. One alumnus recently donated £27m to Imperial College, London. But this is rare: the UK academic sector is thought to raise only hundreds of millions of pounds of funds in this way, although no official record of the income exists.

Religious organisations and other groups contributed some $1.75bn to US universities last year, up 15.1%. Alumni donations rose by 14.7 %, and gifts from the business sector increased by 15%. Last year voluntary support made up 9% of the budgets of US colleges and universities.

The funds have helped to boost endowments owned by US institutions: 41 colleges and universities now report funds of $1bn or more. The full report, by the Council for Aid to Education, is due to be published next month.

Research news: Stem of the problem

The House of Lords' select committee for stem cell research visits the medical research council's clinical sciences centre at Imperial College in London this week, as a part of their review of the law and scientific practice around stem cell research.

The use of stem cells to create different human tissues could lead to many medical developments, such as human tissue transplants. But current research, using embryos and foetal tissue from dead babies, has raised ethical concerns - and several US states have banned it.

Universe: Ethiopia frees students

Police in Ethiopia last week said that they have released students detained after last month's protests at the University of Addis Ababa. But students are refusing to fill in government forms stating that they were guilty of causing the riots.

An estimated 2,500 Ethiopian students were arrested after the protests, which have left at least 41 people dead and more than 250 injured. Africa's bloodiest campus riots in nearly a decade were triggered when students demanded a greater hand in the university's affairs.

fields.headline: Nursery stakes
fields.standfirst: The government has made great strides in increasing childcare places - but strangely this good news has gone largely unnoticed by parents
fields.trailText: The government has made great strides in increasing childcare places - but strangely this good news has gone largely unnoticed by parents.
fields.body:
For a government supposedly wedded to spin, Labour makes a pig's ear of selling genuinely good news. Childcare offers some. Look at the chart. Childminders are in decline (though 25% of children in paid care still go to them) but nurseries are booming, thanks to Labour. More places are in the pipeline. Enough is going on for the Daycare Trust to be thinking, not implausibly, of a childcare place for every working parent who wants one within a decade*.

But its survey finds barely 25% of parents even know the government has a "national childcare strategy". One reason for childcare's low salience is fragmentation. This year the Department for Education and Employment is spending £202m on childcare but in 12 separate packages, £3m for toy libraries, £41m to help recruit childminders and so on. A full accounting of the public money available would also include bits of the separate £290m for providing nursery places for three- and four-year-olds in schools and the £450m children's fund giving grants to councils in poor areas.

One reason so few parents have been shouting praise from the rooftops is administrative. In the past a major new service would have been announced with a big bang, like Lloyd George on pensions or Attlee and the health service. Labour will not do that partly because it is sensitive over accusations of centralisation, partly because it has not so far wanted to commit the huge sums necessary to create a new national service, at least not up front. An alternative might have been to force employers to do their bit. After all, productivity and profit depend on parents. Yet only 4% of them get any financial help with childcare from their firms and only 5% of companies provide a workplace nursery.

Childcare falls between stools because the thrust of policy, so far, is redistributive - it has been about assisting lower income parents first. The "national" strategy is in fact sectional, with overlapping ambitions both for poorer people and the areas in which they live. The official target is a childcare place in the most disadvantaged areas for every lone parent entering employment by 2004. But the political cost of such a focus is the programme's invisibility and the non-participation of the middle classes. To realise the Daycare Trust's ambition of a "universal coherent system based on a children's centre in every neighbourhood" - with funding to match - is going to take middle-class involvement. More affluent parents are going to be needed both as activists and as voters to approve the large increases in public spending that would be necessary.

We are some way off. The 725,000 places available last year serviced some 5m children under eight. The appetite for help with care is huge - children between eight and 11 could benefit mightily from an expansion of after-school-hours supervised activities. Some 58% of mothers with a child aged under five are at work and four out of 10 women of working age have dependent children. Health minister Yvette Cooper was extolling the government's maternity arrangements on these pages yesterday. But as more women return to work after maternity leave, shortfalls in childcare places become more apparent.

Still, the number of economically active women whose youngest child is aged less than four rose from 48% to 58% over the decade to last year. Childcare places did expand under the Tories. But in many families it is granny and neighbours who paper over the cracks. Some 70% of work ing women with dependent children make "informal arrangements" for all or part of their childcare. Childcare outside the home is used by 13% of parents all the time and by a further 8% in combination with friends and family.

Labour has wanted to expand employment as its principal anti-poverty measure. The working families' tax credit (WFTC) is part of the armoury and is meant to contribute to the cost of childcare. WFTC childcare averages £33.48 a week, a long way short of the England average of £88.87 for childminding, let alone the £110.49 for a nursery place.

Meanwhile, in another neck of the woods, women ministers, notably Margaret Hodge and Tessa Jowell, with effective lobbying from former social security secretary Harriet Harman, have tried to expand the local supply of places. A total of 1.6m is promised by 2004 - meaning at the very least that the next three years are going to see terrific expansion of employment in this area. That must mean more training and better payment.

It is at this point that the lack of "strategy" shows. Is state-supported childcare a welfare state graft, a new arm on an old body? Open acknowledgment that this is the expansion of collective provision would raise the political stakes but might improve chances of the money being found. Childcare helps families and probably children, too - getting children out of their homes is a key aim for the parallel Sure Start programme for the disadvantaged.

There is only one subsidised childcare place for every 14 children under three who are living in poverty. But, paradoxically, the best way to provide for them might be to create children's centres in every neighbourhood. Childcare would get its missing political charge if state- sponsored nurseries catered for middle-class women who might be able to afford to pay but find the difficulties of combining parenthood and employment just as acute as poorer women.

*Thinking Big: Childcare for All from Daycare Trust 0207 840 3350

fields.headline: School wins dreadlocks case
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: The mother of a Liverpool schoolboy expelled for having dreadlocks yesterday vowed to take his case to the high court after he lost his appeal.
fields.body:
The mother of a Liverpool schoolboy expelled for having dreadlocks yesterday vowed to take his case to the high court after he lost his appeal.

An independent review upheld the ruling by St Francis Xavier's college, Woolton, Liverpool, to exclude Sanchez Palmer, aged 11, for having a haircut that did not conform to the school rules.

Last Friday the independent appeals panel, set up by Liverpool's education authority, agreed with counsel representing the school that Sanchez had repeatedly breached its discipline code by refusing to cut off his dreadlocks.

The Toxteth schoolboy was due to start at the voluntary aided school last September, but was sent home each time he turned up for lessons because of his hair. The school's headteacher, Brother Francis, said that Sanchez did not adhere to the school's requirement "of short, neat and tidy hair with no extreme styles".

But the boy's mother, Karen Palmer, claimed that at her son's enrolment interview a teacher said his hair would not be a problem if tied back.

Brother Francis said that the school gave the family plenty of opportunity to conform but that Mrs Palmer had made it clear that she had no intention of forcing her son to do so.

Mrs Palmer said her son had been very upset about being excluded. "When Sanchez began crying, I realised that it was getting to him."

She sought legal advice but, her son was excluded permanently last December. At the time Liverpool's education officials wrote to the school advising them not to exclude the boy. "The local authority expresses the same view as stated in the guidelines, that hairstyle alone is not enough for a person to be excluded permanently," said Paul Clein, the council's executive member for education. "The transition from primary to secondary school is problematic in any case. We are very concerned and want to ensure Sanchez doesn't get disconnected from the education process."

Only in the past two months has Sanchez had home tuition, which has been provided by the local education authority.

Mrs Palmer said Sanchez, a Roman Catholic, had always worn dreadlocks because of his father, a Rastafarian. While her counsel looks into a judicial review, she is trying to find a Catholic school in Liverpool that will take Sanchez.

"Let's hope one will take my son and prevent him being pushed out of the Catholic faith," she said.

While her counsel looks into a judicial review, she is trying to find a Catholic school in Liverpool that will take Sanchez. "Let's hope one will take my son and prevent him being pushed out of the Catholic faith," she said.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Simon
fields.trailText: I don't know how long you are in Buenos Aires, or whether you will have the chance to see other places in the country, but here's what we did over Christmas and New Year.
fields.body:
Dear Sue

I don't know how long you are in Buenos Aires, or whether you will have the chance to see other places in the country, but here's what we did over Christmas and New Year.

BA is very much like a European city, so there's no need to be nervous after Australia and NZ! It's as expensive as England or America: some things more so. Take time to wander round San Telmo: mostly full of antique shops, and there is an interesting covered market for vegetables etc. El Caminito, in La Boca, has very colourful painted houses, and is the home of the tango: beware the very smelly river nearby! You can also take a train from El Retiro station to Tigre, which is an area honeycombed with canals and summer houses, where you can take nice boat trips (very cheap). If you like cats, you should visit the Botanic Garden (between Scalabrini Ortiz and Plaza Italia underground stations), which is full of them: the zoo is opposite, and you can feed the llamas there.

If you have more time, you could visit Iguazu Falls (two hours by plane from BA). It takes a day to explore these properly from the Argentine side: it is a very well run national park with good instructions about where to go, on foot or by boat. Another place, this time to the south, is the Peninsula Valdes in Patagonia. This is very wild, and takes at least a day to explore properly: you will need either to take an organised trip or to hire a car and start early in the morning. Places worth seeing are Punta Delgada, where you see seals, and Punta Norte, for penguins. Warning: the roads are all gravel, and should not be tried in the dark. If you don't get to either of those places, you could stop at Salina Grande (in the middle of the peninsula), where for a peso you can see an extensive and shining salt lake surrounded by eucalyptus, and be rewarded with a complimentary Coke and biscuits.

Have a good time, wherever you go.

Simon Tabbush and family.

fields.headline: Could 'Japanglish' be a legitimate language?
fields.trailText: An American academic in Japan believes that Japanese students should ignore the 'snobbery' of British and American English and speak the langauge in a way that suits them.
fields.body:
"We wish all the time to be able to provide you fresh bread and to propose you a joy of eating life with bread," says the sign in my local bakery. "Especially, we want to be a host at dinner of your kitchen. We are waiting for you with various kinds of bread, cakes and sandwiches."

The general meaning is clear, but could it ever be considered correct English? Yes, according to an American academic in Japan, who says that "Japanese English" has as much claim to legitimacy as the English spoken in, for example, India, Jamaica and the Philippines.

Marshall Childs, who has a doctorate in education, believes that Japanese students should ignore the "snobbery" of British and American English and speak the language in a way that suits them, even if that means breaking the accepted rules of grammar, pronunciation and sentence structure.

But his championing of "Japlish", also known here as "Japanglish," has infuriated some of his colleagues and led to a lively spat in the columns of Japan's English language newspaper, the Daily Yomiuri.

Mr Childs, who is academic dean of Katoh Lynn, an international college in Japan, says the blend of two languages is acceptable because it makes English comprehensible to the Japanese ear.

"Creative syntax is the hallmark of Japanese English. The result is a waker-upper for those who expect standard syntax, but the meaning is usually perfectly comprehensible, perhaps because it follows a natural flow of thoughts.

"If we (native English speakers) feel prejudice against Japanese English, that is our problem, not a Japanese problem."

A resident of Japan for 16 years, Mr Childs criticises English language schools which "shame" their students into signing up for lessons in "correct" English.

"I know one student who, after 15 years of English study, faithfully accepted the word of a new teacher that she had to relearn pronunciation from the ground up, this time learning it 'properly' in British English.

"That experience set her back several years and several million yen. Most students do not need high-prestige accents; they need to develop smooth habits of hearing and speaking. These habits are much more easily developed if the variety of English is congenial to the learner."

Mr Childs adds: "The sheer exuberance of popular uses of Japanese English is admirable and should be encouraged, not condemned.

"In school, students are rightly bored with the 'correct' English that does not touch their lives." Fluency in standard British or American English, he suggests, should be left to specialists in literature, the performing arts, interpreting and international negotiation.

Nonsense, retorts fellow American academic Daniel Webster, who says Mr Childs is doing Japanese students of English a disservice by telling them something is right when it is simply wrong.

"People in Asia and the Caribbean who speak those other kinds of English to which Childs compares Japanese English can and do converse fluently in them, with each other and with foreigners", says Mr Webster, a visiting instructor in the English department of Waseda University in Tokyo. "They can also understand English-language movies without subtitles, and the educated among them can understand Henry James. Some of these latter can even write in an English that is of the highest literary quality.

"None of the above is true of those who use 'Japanglish'. In fact, I can assure Childs that the only place where this Japanese-English exists as a real medium for more than the most rudimentary kind of communication is in households where one, or some, of the members is a native-speaker of Japanese and the other, or the others, is not.

"It will never extend beyond these homes. Outside of those individual houses and apartments, the Japanese-English Childs admires so much is just a lot of gobbledegook. And that's exactly what it will always be," Mr Webster declares.

Japan is currently looking for ways to improve the standard of English teaching in its schools. Although virtually all children learn English for several years, the Japanese lag behind other Asian countries in English proficiency - a trend which politicians and business leaders say makes them less effective in commerce and diplomacy. A textbook called "English for the Over-40s" is a bestseller here, and growing numbers of executives are enrolling in English courses to improve their promotion prospects.

Last year, a panel of experts advising then prime minister Keizo Obuchi called for a national debate on whether to make English Japan's "second official language". The idea, which would oblige government, local councils and other official bodies to draw up documents in both languages, has been criticised by some as a further move towards western erosion of Japanese culture.

Whatever the new government of Junichiro Koizumi decides, one can only hope that no one removes the notice at the Tokyo City Air Terminal which advises passengers to be "cautious for pickpockets." Or the sign on a drinks vending machine which says the company responsible has selected "first class ingredients with confidence for offering consumer best products which get you a nice time day after day."

webTitle: Student organisations shy away from May Day protests

fields.headline: Student organisations shy away from May Day protests
fields.trailText: Students organisations have been scared away from today's May Day protests in London because of media coverage and political statements which have suggested the demonstration will be violent and confrontational.
fields.body:
Students organisations have been scared away from today's May Day protests in London because of media coverage and political statements, notably Ken Livingstone's on Friday, which have suggested the demonstration will be violent and confrontational.

In previous years, large numbers of students took part in the anti-capitalism protests. This is still likely to be the case this year, as individual students around the country have been gearing up for the event, but it is clear that organised student groups have been hesitant about getting involved.

Legally, unions cannot use their funding for issues that do not directly affect students. But union officials are usually informally involved with organising student events. Hugh Johnson, campaigns officer at Sussex University, is helping to organise a May Day protest, but not in his official role.

However, he is not campaigning in London. "What the government and media have been saying is actually more likely to make London's May Day violent, because that's what people will be expecting. So weêre going to have a demonstration in Brighton outside a multinational company."

Matt Coakley, president of Cambridgeês student union, agreed that organisations are wary of getting involved, and that predictions of violence have influenced that decision.

However, Owain James, president of the National Union of Students (NUS), said there is a bigger issue at stake. Although he supports environmental issues and believes many of the protestors in London are acting in good faith, "I don't think the protests take the issues forward. They need to engage the public, but incidents like the one at the cenotaph put off most of society."

It is not just the unions that are worried. Individual students have also voiced their concern. Seasoned protestor Tom Greaves, of Warwick University, is reconsidering his involvement.

"I'm getting so angry. It's incredible the stuff that's getting printed. But it has made me a bit worried. I was in that crush a couple of years ago where a police officer ran over a woman, and knew I didnêt want to be in those scenes again. But then I decided to see what was going on for myself," he said.

Like Hugh Johnson at Sussex, he has organised his own agenda for the day. The May Day organisers have encouraged autonomous protests, and Mr Johnson and his friends will be protesting peacefully outside a Brighton company involved with oil exploitation in West Papua.

Having decided to be in London, though, Mr Greaves will be at the main rally in Oxford Street at 4pm, where everyone will discover how accurate the predictions of violence have been.

fields.headline: Phytopharm chief turns on critics
fields.trailText: Phytopharm's chief executive, Richard Dixey, has hit out at detractors of his plant-based medicines, complaining that a "hippy" tag is distracting attention from its pioneering technology.
fields.body:
Phytopharm's chief executive, Richard Dixey, has hit out at detractors of his plant-based medicines, complaining that a "hippy" tag is distracting attention from its pioneering technology.

Announcing a 61% jump in half-year losses to £1.37m, Mr Dixey said Phytopharm had built "major drug discovery platforms" in obesity, Alzheimer's disease, eczema and inflammation. "We've really got this 'platforms' concept established," he said. "All these jibes are very easy."

Mr Dixey said Phytopharm's monthly cash spend of £230,000 was relatively low. "Drug development is like roulette. If you can get a seat at the table for just 200 grand, it's worth it."

Phytopharm's most advanced products include an Indian curry plant for the treatment of bowel disorders and an appetite-suppressant - extracted from a South African cactus - for obesity sufferers.

Mr Dixey said his most treasured project was in researching the use of a secret Asia root in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. The product, which is in phase-one clinical trials, could be useful in other neurological disorders, he said. "If you could halt the ageing process in the brain, you could tackle all sorts of diseases - chronic fatigue syndrome, Parkinson's disease."

Phytopharm's shares rose 12.5p to 567.5p, having slipped from 860p since disappointing results from a baldness drug in January. That prompted analysts to suggest the company should make nutritional food supplements and veterinary medicines, rather than prescription drugs.

 Cambridge Antibody Technology announced encouraging results from a study of CAT-152, its drug preventing scarring after eye surgery. After a two-year follow-up, patients taking the product had significantly less damage to their eyes. Further data suggested the drug could prevent cataracts.

fields.headline: John Beishon
fields.standfirst: Managing change in a turbulent student world
fields.trailText: Managing change in a turbulent student world.
fields.body:
John Beishon, who has died aged 70, achieved national prominence in 1984 as the troubleshooter who calmed the student rebellion at the North London Polytechnic - a situation that provoked court orders and a threat by the then education secretary, Sir Keith Joseph, to close the institution down. An innovative manager of public services, Beishon later turned his attention to the Consumers' Association, though he was probably less successful in shifting the culture there than at the polytechnic.

His management methods reflected his pedigree. The son of an entrepreneurial communist engineer in London's East End, with whom he had a stormy, but, in the end, affectionate relationship, he blended the academic disciplines of engineering and psychology with communist convictions and a belief in blunt speaking.

This mix generated a unique management style, which inspired intense loyalty among some of those who worked with him, and even a certain awe among those who felt he was going about things the wrong way.

Not a school high-flyer, Beishon studied metallurgy at Battersea Polytechnic (now the University of Surrey), a subject he developed further on national service with the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers in the canal zone in Egypt.

Back home, he combined fulltime jobs at ICI and British Insulated Callender Cables with part-time studying at Birkbeck College, London, where he obtained a first-class honours degree in psychology. He completed his doctorate at Oxford, and went on to work as a behavioural science researcher at Bristol and Sussex universities.

But Beishon hankered after a different, less elitist, sort of university. So he leapt at the chance to become professor of systems when the Open University was founded in 1970, and built up an innovative team of colleagues and a pioneering range of interdisciplinary courses. Then, quite unexpectedly, he was appointed director of the South Bank Polytechnic in 1980.

The London polytechnics had had a distinguished past, but were now in a period of transition, staffed by an uneasy mixture of young leftwing sociologists and more elderly masonic engineers, lazily overseen by the Inner London Education Authority (Ilea) - but scarcely managed at all.

Arriving in this environment, Beishon lived dangerously, trampling on vested interests, shedding long established staff, promoting others and generally provoking the wrath of the old establishment. He survived by dint of his clear, systematic approach, and his ability to recruit a cadre of supporters who felt his change was long overdue.

As the management values of the early 1980s took hold, he increasingly gained the reputation of being a highly-successful trouble-shooter. So when, in 1984, student riots exploded at the then North London Polytechnic, he seemed the natural candidate to restore order. After months of hesitation as the situation deteriorated, Ilea finally summoned up the courage to sack the existing director and second Beishon to the post.

When he arrived in January 1985, the place was in chaos. Patrick Harrington, a student of extreme rightwing inclinations, was being boycotted by staff and students alike, and Mr Justice Mars Jones had made a court order that he should be taught normally, with full access to the library and the canteen. Mars Jones had also ordered the student union to be suspended and its funds impounded. Yet the court orders were being daily and blatantly breached.

In his first week, Beishon negotiated with the suspended student union executive and, by deftly marginalising the more extreme leftwing factions, constructed a majority willing to obey the law - first, in the student union executive, and then in a student union vote. Harrington was being taught on his own, because no other student would sit in class with him, and had acquired a measure of media martyrdom. Once the press had been invited to talk to him, however, they began to write more positively about the new regime.

Within Beishon's first three months, the tide began to turn. The Daily Mail wrote an encomium about his "SAS" management style, the courts lifted their injunctions, and the new director prised an extra £1m out of Ilea to smarten up the polytechnic.

Three years later, with his troubleshooter reputation now at its peak, Beishon took on another venerable, but complacent, institution, the Consumers' Association. He applied the same methods - tearing up hallowed traditions, gathering around him a cadre of loyal appointees, and speaking bluntly. As director for the next seven years, he did succeed in starting the process of redefining the CA's agenda - beyond washing machines and towards the delivery of public services. But the CA was not a polytechnic, and too many feathers were ruffled too quickly.

In truth, John was a bit of a loner, not as self-assured - either as man or manager - as he sometimes appeared. He compensated for his lack of confidence with a steely determination, an acute and systematic mind, an instinct for divining correctly the motives of the people he encountered, and an ability to win not just the loyalty, but also the deep affection, of most of those with whom he came into close contact.

He is survived by his wife Gwenda, and five children.

 John Beishon, academic and administrator, born November 10 1930; died April 29 2001

fields.headline: Goodbye Seattle, hi sonic boom
fields.standfirst: The world's largest planemaker believes it can perform a rapid change of course without dumping staff
fields.trailText: Boeing, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer, is a company in crisis, painfully embarking on the slow process of transforming a business which has more to offer than just history-making aircraft.
fields.body:
Boeing, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer, is a company in crisis, painfully embarking on the slow process of transforming a business which has more to offer than just history-making aircraft.

This past week, at its Seattle headquarters, Boeing has gone to considerable lengths to show that all is right with the company and that the future beckons brightly.

With Blairite echoes, Phil Condit, the planemaker's chief executive, refers to his organisation as "New Boeing" in an attempt to demonstrate that a fitter, leaner company will make strides in areas where it had faltered.

The company has just published its quarterly report, showing that Boeing made a profit of £540m, a good starting point.

But it is involved in a rationalisation programme which it has been forced to implement because of the relentless competition from Airbus, its buoyant European competitor in the commercial airliner market.

From a position of complacency over the past five years, Boeing has finally admitted that Airbus has bitten deep into its financial skin and that it must repair the damage.

End of the affair

Mr Condit claims that while Boeing holds 60% of the commercial market today, that could sink to less than 50% over the next few years, a figure Airbus already claims to have relegated its US rival to several times already. "Yes, I have to admit that commercial will amount to a lesser percentage of our company, but we are certainly not going to shrink it."

The company has also had to admit that it must finally part company with Seattle as its corporate headquarters. The city has long been associated with Boeing's remarkable success in civil aviation, where a long line of proud and profitable large airliners has been built, culminating in the 747, one of the most popular and safest aircraft ever to be manufactured.

Mr Condit and his colleagues now feel that Seattle and Boeing must end their love affair, with corporate headquarters moving to a more anonymous location such as Chicago or Denver. Final decisions will be made over the next few months, with Chicago the pundits' favourite.

Mr Condit does not blink when he utters the words "leaner enterprise", which in the minds of most people is synonymous with a reduction in staff. Neither the staff nor the unions appear to be restless, although the city of Seattle itself is extremely unhappy and is toiling to prevent the departure, to the extent of offering the company belated but generous tax concessions.

A "leaner enterprise" does not mean to Mr Conditwhat many might fear. It means a 15% growth in the company this year, without any reduction in staff. "The goal is to continue to expand, but to become leaner."

The immediate course for Boeing is to try to trump Airbus. If the European consortium can build the A380, the world's largest superjumbo, able to carry upwards of 555 passengers, then Boeing is prepared to develop the world's fastest "sonic airliner", a trim double delta winged craft with a speed of 750mph.

Boeing's £6bn project makes it possible for such an aircraft to fly non-stop between London and Sydney in 18 hours, knocking four hours off the existing flight time, Mike Bair, Boeing's marketing director, said yesterday.

Mr Bair said that deals might be signed with several leading American airlines over the next 12 months which would enable the first "sonic cruiser" to fly by 2006. Coincidentally, this is the year when Airbus plans to roll out its first A380.

But Airbus is further down the commercial runway. While the Americans have scoffed at the concept of a superjumbo, Airbus has secured firm orders for 60 A380s and the first will start construction next year.

Boeing's project has been greeted with a mixture of scepticism and excitement in the industry. Critics are unconvinced that Boeing can commercially outsmart its main rival whose senior executives pri vately scoff at the technical and commercial feasibility of the "sonic cruiser".

Mr Bair said the new aircraft would open up "entirely new routes for a non-stop faster service". But he conceded that much had to be done before the project could take off. The success of the cruiser rested on talks with airlines - Boeing has only been taking the idea seriously for the past five months - "and they will decide what they want and we will have to decide whether we can adapt to their ideas".

Spoiling operation

Mr Bair rejected the idea that a flight ceiling of 45,000 ft would expose it to cosmic radiation and a heightened risk of cabin decompression. Potential buyers are bothered about such matters, although executives such as Maurice Flanagan, managing director of Emirates, are more concerned about whether the aircraft's fuel burn would lead to higher fuel prices.

Mr Flanagan and other airline chief executives have received only three spread sheets from Boeing and are unhappy about the paucity of information. If Boeing is to outmanoeuvre Airbus, it will have to hurry. Nobody in the business sees Boeing able to achieve this spoiling operation before 2006, with 2010 as the earliest in-service date.

If Boeing is to become the truly global aerospace company to which Mr Condit and his colleagues aspire, it will have to place much more emphasis on its other activities.

Mr Condit concedes that it has faced a setback in its "traditional military and space markets", and that to achieve new business and higher earnings it must reduce costs faster than its competition. "At the same time, we must recognise that parts of our traditional business are maturing" - another way of suggesting that the company is out of date in many areas.

Boeing intends focusing just as strongly on its space and communications achievements and its missiles systems, which are thriving. It is about to launch its sixth satellite as part of its Sea Launch programme, an alliance with the Russians, Ukrainians, and Norwegians.

Other parts of its "new" empire have yet to be tested. It has the skill and technology to run an efficient system of air traffic management, but this means breaking down national government barriers. It can turn your aircraft seat into a virtual office with superfast internet access, but is still awaiting takers.

Boeing is at a crossroads and uncertain of its direction. Being a large company it has an immense capacity to adjust. But the most poignant revelation of the past week is that Boeing now has its own real estate company. This is busy selling off tracts of its base at Long Beach, California, home of the 717 short hop jet, for a lucrative property development.

fields.headline: Beaver makes a comeback
fields.trailText: The European beaver, extinct in England for almost 1,000 years, is to return to a wildlife reserve.
fields.body:
The European beaver, extinct in England for almost 1,000 years, is to return to a wildlife reserve.

The Kent Wildlife Trust is introducing 10 animals to an undisclosed restored wetland area in a five-year trial.

webTitle: University lecturer accused of murdering his wife

fields.headline: University lecturer accused of murdering his wife
fields.trailText: A leading mental health scholar in New Zealand has been accused of killing his wife by administering a lethal cocktail of hypoglycemic drugs to her over a three-month period until her death last year on January 5.
fields.body:
A leading mental health scholar in New Zealand has been accused of killing his wife by administering a lethal cocktail of hypoglycemic drugs to her over a three-month period until her death last year on January 5.

The preliminary hearing of a murder charge against Colin D Bouwer, who at the time of his wife's death was the head of the department of psychological medicine at the University of Otago, in the southern township of Dunedin, is currently in its third week at the city's district court.

The case is the second involving a university lecturer in recent years to have come before the New Zealand courts, and one of a growing number worldwide involving mental health specialists accused of killing their spouses or colleagues, including the manslaughter conviction handed down in London last September in the case of Steven Reid, a psychology lecturer at the University of Westminster who battered to death a female researcher at the institution.

The prosecution has alleged that the South African-born Dr Bouwer began prescribing the drugs for Annette Bouwer, 47, after he embarked upon an ill-starred sexual affair with a colleague during an international medical conference in Copenhagen. Both the name of the other woman and details about her occupation have been suppressed by the court.

It was alleged that Dr Bouwer gave his wife drugs designed to promote insulin secretion, and that the resultant abnormal lowering of her blood glucose levels led to her being admitted to hospital in a hypoglycemic coma.

Believing that her condition stemmed from a pancreatic tumour, or insulinoma, Ms Bouwer subsequently underwent surgery to have two-thirds of her pancreas removed - although no traces of any malignancy were found at the time of her operation or in tissue tests conducted after her unexpected death less than a fortnight later.

Her death came as "a complete shock" to medical staff who had treated her during the preceding weeks, the court was told by a nurse late last week.

Sarah Romans, a professor of psychology at the university, told the court yesterday that Ms Bouwer had said shortly before her death that she had been the victim of foul play, possibly at the hand of a family member.

Dr Bouwer has claimed that he is innocent of any wrongdoing.

In a bizarre but unrelated coincidence, the court also heard that Dr Bouwer's son, who shares his father's name, is currently on trial for the murder of his own wife, in their Kempton Park home in Johannesburg.

Of more immediate interest to watching academics, however, were the similarities between aspects of the New Zealand case and another local trial held five years ago in nearby Christchurch, in which a molecular biologist from the University of Canterbury's department of plant and microbial sciences was accused of administering a near-fatal dose of a neurotoxin to a botanist colleague who had broken off a relationship with her for another academic.

The "Unapoisoner" trial, as the earlier case was dubbed in some quarters, transfixed the New Zealand public, all the more so because of its parade of often traumatised faculty members testifying for and against the accused, Victoria Calder, who was later acquitted of attempting to murder David Lloyd.

Although the case has been closely followed in academic circles, New Zealand law forbids any public comment on the proceedings of a criminal trial or depositions hearing.

Even it is found that he has no case to answer for, it is unlikely that Dr Bouwer will again find work at the University of Otago. During the police investigation that led to his arrest, it was discovered that he had previously been suspended from practising medicine in his native South Africa in 1981, as a result of pethidine abuse.

webTitle: Q&A: Why are family doctors protesting?

fields.headline: Q&A: Why are family doctors protesting?
fields.trailText:
Why are GPs protesting?
The UK's 36,000 family doctors claim that their workload is unsustainable. Patients are more demanding, clinical work that used to be carried out in hospital is often now done in GP practices, and there is more paperwork to plough through. All this against the background of a "chronic shortage" of GPs. The result is "widespread demoralisation" according to the British Medical Association (BMA).
fields.body:
Why are GPs protesting?
The UK's 36,000 family doctors claim that their workload is unsustainable. Patients are more demanding, clinical work that used to be carried out in hospital is often now done in GP practices, and there is more paperwork to plough through. All this against the background of a "chronic shortage" of GPs. The result is "widespread demoralisation" according to the British Medical Association (BMA).

What constitutes an "unsustainable" workload?
Too many patients, and too few hours in the day to see them - the "ideal" 15-minute consultation with an individual patient is often squeezed into eight minutes. Patients can also be rude, aggressive, and even physically abusive. Then there are house visits to do, all the time while being "on-call". Not forgetting the piles of paperwork and meetings with other GPs, and health managers.

I'm surprised they haven't mentioned money...
This particular revolt appears not to be about financial rewards - but then the average GP earns between £54,000 and £70,000, and in some cases as much as £140,000 a year. Factor in a decent pension, six to eight weeks holiday a year, and excellent job security, and it becomes clear that they are well-remunerated for their troubles.

What are GPs proposing to do about it?
Hundreds of doctors are holding a day of action. Organised by Doctor magazine, action will include the closure of surgeries, various "work-to-rule" initiatives (such as seeing patients but refusing to do paperwork, or doing paperwork but refusing to see patients), marches, writing to MPs, or simply just putting up posters. Not forgetting Epping high street surgery, whose practice manager will be dressed as a fairy for the day on the grounds that "it is only by magic that it will be possible to implement the NHS plan!"

What is the BMA proposing to do about it?
The BMA doesn't support the day of action, claiming that it may harm patients, and might anyway involve a breach of the GPs contract. It wants changes to the GP contract to ease family doctors' workload, and has proposed to hold a ballot of its members to see whether they will consider resignation from the NHS unless a new contract is not swiftly forthcoming.

What is the government proposing to do about it?
Ministers have promised a package of measures to improve the working lives of doctors. The package includes: recruiting over 2,000 extra GPs; investing £100m over three years in measures to recruit and retain GPs; handing out £10,000 per practice to support services; providing an occupational health service for primary care; and reducing bureaucracy (such as ensuring GPs no longer have to sign driving licences or passport applications).

Doesn't sound bad at all - so why is the BMA still angry?
Behind all the rhetoric, there is a very dull medico-political dispute going on. The BMA are sore at losing the right to represent GPs on personal medical services contracts (known as PMS - locally negotiated "paid-by-results" contracts); one view is that they want to restore their industrial muscle by bouncing the government into conceding this right, and feel the best time to achieve this is by kicking up a stink just prior to a general election.

Will they succeed?
Unlikely. The public may sympathise, but is unlikely to get too indignant. After Harold Shipman the stock of GPs is hardly at an all-time high, and in the age of the consumer your average citizen is not quite so in awe of doctors as previously. The government has so far treated the BMA with polite disdain. The national press is unconvinced by the BMA's stance, while parts of the GP press believes the BMA failed to fight hard enough for its members.

fields.headline: EMI 'too expensive' says News Corp
fields.trailText: 5pm: Rupert Murdoch will not revive its interest in the music group, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation will not revive its interest in EMI, following the collapse of the music group's proposed merger with Bertelsmann.

Sources close to the media tycoon's company said News Corp had considered bidding for EMI a few years ago but it would not help the group in its desperate search for a merger partner.

News Corp has been put forward as a possible bidder, alongside the US media giants, Disney and Viacom.

However, a News Corp insider today said EMI was "too expensive", even though its share price has tumbled from a 12-month high of 705p to today's 414.5p.

"We looked at EMI a few years ago and it was too expensive. Unless the price gets much lower, I can't see us going for it," said the source.

Music is an obvious gap in News Corp's multimedia portfolio, although it owns a number of small Australian labels.

Analysts today questioned the attractiveness of EMI's stock, despite its depressed price and big acts such as the Spice Girls on its books.

"The sale of EMI has been dragging on for years," said Nicola Stewart, an analyst at Commerzbank.

"If it were such an attractive asset, one of the rumoured big bidders would have made an approach by now. The music sector is still very unattractive."

EMI has long been looking for a strategic alliance to help it survive in a stagnating music market.

Last year the market shrank for the first time as it was hit by the activities of rogue internet sites such as Napster.

Today's abandonment of the £10bn link-up with BMG, the record label owned by German media giant Bertelsmann, follows the collapse of a similar deal with Warner Music in October last year.

The group has consistently fallen foul of EU competition regulators and shareholders.

Watchdogs have ordered EMI to shed its Virgin subsidiary in order to let a deal through.

However, the shareholders do not want the group's value diminished by a deal.

fields.headline: Raul expects Real easy ride
fields.trailText: Real Madrid striker Raul reckons his side's Champions League semi-final with Bayern Munich will be a formality. "I'm looking forward to the final against Valencia," is his nonchalant assessment of the tie.
fields.body:
Real Madrid striker Raul reckons his side's Champions League semi-final with Bayern Munich will be a formality. "I'm looking forward to the final against Valencia," is his nonchalant assessment of the tie.

No one else agrees.

At a press conference yesterday, Madrid coach Vicente Del Bosque denied his side were overwhelming favourites. "The outcome of the match is very uncertain," he said. "If we play well, we have enough talent to win this match but I am not going into it thinking that Bayern are an inferior team. They have got players of enviable quality, in defence, in midfield and attack."

His view was shared by Bayern coach Ottmar Hitzfield, who is confident his side can repeat their quarter-final victory over Manchester United. "The best possible motivation for my players is to be told they do not have a chance of winning the game," he said. "They are really looking forward to showing that the experts have spoken too soon."

Real go into tonight's first leg at the Bernabeu without Fernando Morientes, meaning either Guti or Savio will be pushed forward to partner Raul. However Fernando Hierro and Ivan Helguera - who both missed Saturday's home draw with Osasuna - are expected to return.

Despite worries over their forward line, Real enter the match as favourites. They have won all seven of their Champions League matches at the Bernabeu this season, and have the competition's top scorer in Raul. They also possess a psychological edge having beaten Bayern in the same stage last year.

Nevertheless, Del Bosque has made it clear that Real would not be underestimating their opponents.

"Bayern are a strong, competitive team that are strong in all areas of the game," he said. "They are always well-positioned on the pitch and know how to play counter-attack football to perfection."

Meanwhile, the Germans are happy to play on their underdog status, with Oliver Kahn reminding journalists: "It's the best thing that could happen to us. Manchester were hoisted up as a great team and we beat them twice."

Bayern have been boosted by the news that Giovane Elber and Jens Jeremies have made remarkable recoveries after undergoing knee operations a day after the defeat of United. Elber will definitely start, while Jeremies will undergo a late fitness test before the match.

"If we play well, we have enough talent to win this match but I am not going into it thinking that Bayern are an inferior team. They have got players of enviable quality, in defence, in midfield and attack." His view was shared by Bayern coach Ottmar Hitzfield, who is confident his side can repeat their quarter-final victory over Manchester United. "The best possible motivation for my players is to be told they do not have a chance of winning the game," he said. "They are really looking forward to showing that the experts have spoken too soon." Real go into tonight's first leg at the Bernabeu without Fernando Morientes, meaning either Guti or Savio will be pushed forward to partner Raul. However Fernando Hierro and Ivan Helguera - who both missed Saturday's home draw with Osasuna - are expected to return. Despite worries over their forward line, Real enter the match as favourites. They have won all seven of their Champions League matches at the Bernabeu this season, and have the competition's top scorer in Raul. They also possess a psychological edge having beaten Bayern in the same stage last year. Nevertheless, Del Bosque has made it clear that Real would not be underestimating their opponents. "Bayern are a strong, competitive team that are strong in all areas of the game," he said. "They are always well-positioned on the pitch and know how to play counter-attack football to perfection." Meanwhile, the Germans are happy to play on their underdog status, with Oliver Kahn reminding journalists: "It's the best thing that could happen to us. Manchester were hoisted up as a great team and we beat them twice." Bayern have been boosted by the news that Giovane Elber and Jens Jeremies have made remarkable recoveries after undergoing knee operations a day after the defeat of United. Elber will definitely start, while Jeremies will undergo a late fitness test before the match.

fields.headline: Rent protesters target Blair
fields.trailText: The prime minister, the home secretary and the lord chancellor have been drawn into a row over massive rent hikes on Church of England properties that have been reserved as affordable housing for almost a century.
fields.body:
The prime minister, the home secretary and the lord chancellor have been drawn into a row over massive rent hikes on Church of England properties that have been reserved as affordable housing for almost a century.

SocietyGuardian.co.uk reported last month protests against the church commissioners over plans to raise rents - in some cases by up to £1,000 a month - on its Octavia Hill estates in London.

Campaigners have now written to senior ministers, including the prime minister, Tony Blair, and the home secretary, Jack Straw, who are church commissioners by virtue of the their office, inviting them to distance themselves from the plan.

The letter says: "Given the government's track record and commitment to social inclusion and building strong sustainable communities, we find it hard to believe that you would want to support these proposals."

The move comes as a church-based charity in the north-east also came under fire for raising rents to market levels on homes where previously affordable or "fair" rents were charged.

The Lord Crewe trust owns about 60 homes in the north, including 43 in the village of Blanchland, Northumberland. Rents on three bedroom homes have more than double to £450 a month after tenants move out.

The campaigns against the rent rises in London and Blanchland have remarkable similarities.

Campaigners in London have pointed out that the commissioner' plans go against the charitable principles of the social pioneer Octavia Hill. Campaigners in Blanchland have evoked the principles of Lord Crewe.

Chris Close, chairman of Blanchland village residents association, said: "Lord Crew left his property in trust so as to benefit the clergy but it was also clearly his intent that local social housing at a reasonable rent should be provided to maintain the local community."

The Lord Crewe trust has also used the same justification, as the church commissioners, for increasing rents. It claimed that as a charity it has a duty to get the most from its assets.

Mr Close said: "So called good church men hide behind charities law or at least their selective interpretation of it."

But Jon Williams, receiver of the trustee of Lord Crewe's charity, said: "The purpose of the charity is to provide support for the clergy in Newcastle and Durham who have some of the lowest stipends in the country. It is a misunderstanding that the charity's purpose is to provide cheap housing."
