fields.headline: May Day around the world
fields.standfirst:
As UK police prepared for the worst from anti-capitalism protests in London, here's what took place in May Day events around the world

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: As UK police prepared for the worst from anti-capitalism protests in London, here's what took place in May Day events around the world.
fields.body:
Germany
Police battled hundreds of violent May Day protesters in Berlin, using water cannon to break up burning street blockades and arresting several dozen leftists. Far-right marchers took to the streets later in the day, kept apart from counter-demonstrators by police. Even with 9,000 police in the streets, the violence dented the city's hopes of ending an annual ritual of violence that officials view as undignified for Germany's revived capital.

France
Thousands of workers and trade unionists took to the streets across France on Tuesday to celebrate May Day but also to protest against recent layoffs. Pride of place at the head of the marches was given to those affected by a recent wave of restructuring in companies, including food giant Groupe Danone SA and Marks & Spencer. Many M&S former employees wore black t-shirts carrying the words, "I was one of 4,000 employees made redundant by e-mail." Marches were due to be held in around 70 French towns and cities.

Ukraine
Around 1,000 Communists rallied in Kiev against President Leonid Kuchma, whom they blame for creating miserable conditions in the former Soviet country. To the sound of Soviet anthems, the procession slowly wound its way through the city centre, bearing red Communist flags, portraits of Lenin and banners proclaiming: "All power to the workers" and "Out with the bourgeoisie." The protesters, mainly pensioners nostalgic about life under Soviet rule, did not mince their words in reference to their leaders. "They should all be hanged, Kuchma and company," said Lidia, a 75-year-old protester.

Indonesia
Thousands of workers staged mostly peaceful rallies in major cities across Indonesia to demand greater freedom to organise, an end to arbitrary layoffs and that May Day be declared an official public holiday. At one rally in Bandung, the capital of West Java, hundreds of protesting workers clashed with police and several were injured. More than 1,000 workers marched to Monas square in central Jakarta, urging the government to declare May 1 as Indonesia's labour day. Some of the protestors staged dances and marching band performances.

Iran
Several thousand Iranian factory workers staged a peaceful rally outside parliament. "We have come before the house of the people to attract the attention of government officials to our problems," said a worker from a factory close to Tehran. The workers listened to speeches from reformist MP Elias Hazrati and a workers' representative Ali-Reza Mahjub. The workers urged the authorities to take measures to solve their problems. "We are asking the authorities to pay more attention to our problems such as the presence of foreign labour force and temporary working contracts", a statement read.

Greece
More than 10,000 people joined a march through central Athens, but many Greeks used the holiday to go to the country. Trades unions held two separate demonstrations in the capital and later formed a single march to parliament. Similar demonstrations were held around the country. "We win our rights through struggle," workers chanted as they waved red banners and flags. Unions took advantage of the rallies to protest a decision by the Socialist government to overhaul the country's nearly bankrupt pension system.

Korea
North and South Korean workers sang and danced together in their first joint celebration of May Day. Some 1,000 workers from the two Koreas observed May Day at Diamond Mountain, a scenic North Korean resort area. The festivities were the first of their kind since the division of the Korean peninsula in 1945. In Seoul, 10,000 workers and students beating gongs and drums marched under a large banner reading: "Down with (President) Kim Dae-jung, who ruined workers' lives." During a separate march in Seoul, 3,000 workers cheered while protesters set fire to a coffin symbolising the government's economic reforms that have resulted in layoffs

Australia
In Sydney, hundreds of anti-globalisation protesters fought with riot police. Two police were hospitalised and 28 protesters injured as police detained 30 demonstrators. In Brisbane, about 35 activists were arrested and several people injured as protesters tried to storm the stock exchange. Protesters in Melbourne briefly threatened to storm a McDonald's restaurant and sprayed it with slogans in front of cheering onlookers.

webTitle: Black Tory peer says race row is over

fields.headline: Black Tory peer says race row is over
fields.trailText: May 1, 5.45pm: The Conservative party tonight moved to close ranks over the damaging race issue which has seen two of its MPs forced to apologise for their views.
fields.body:
The Conservative party tonight moved to close ranks over the damaging race issue which has seen two of its MPs forced to apologise for their views.

The black Tory peer, Lord Taylor of Warwick, who had strongly criticised William Hague's handling of the affair, has now told the party he is happy the situation has been resolved.

His move comes after Tewkesbury MP Laurence Robertson apologised for backing the Yorkshire East MP John Townend's controversial remarks on immigration.

Lord Taylor, who had been linked with possible defections to both Labour and the Liberal Democrats after his earlier comments on Mr Hague's leadership, said tonight: "I have made my point and am not currently planning to take the matter further."

Lord Taylor said he had achieved his goal in getting the party to make clear its commitment to a vision of Britain where racial intolerance and bigotry were "totally unacceptable".

Mr Robertson was today forced to apologise for endorsing Mr Townend's stand, and retracted his own remarks after a 10 minute grilling from the party's whips. They threatened to expel him from the party if he did not back down.

Last night Mr Robertson defied the leadership to appear on television condoning Mr Townend's opinions, and adding that "cramming" different racial groups together was making society difficult to manage.

Today Mr Robertson said: "I apologise for saying that John Townend's comments were right, and I retract my own comments to that effect.

"I undertake not to cause further embarrassment to the Conservative Party, nor to give further offence to others... nor will I repeat my remarks under any circumstances."

Meanwhile, a Tory spokesman said the party had "no quarrel" with remarks on the issue made earlier today by veteran rightwinger Lord Tebbit. The peer said he did not know of any "happy multicultural society".

And the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, earlier today rejected claims that William Hague acted too late in the row over racism that has dominated coverage of the party.

At a press conference in Scotland, Mr Portillo claimed that by bringing MP John Townend to account over controversial remarks, the Tory leader had shown firm and effective action and had defined the party's stance against racism.

Mr Portillo was speaking in Edinburgh at an event where his central message - an attack on Labour over the economy - was overshadowed by the row over race.

Mr Portillo added: "It has led to an opportunity in the end to define ourselves, to make clear we will not tolerate racism or inflammatory language and anyone who transgresses that will be dealt with."

Mr Portillo also said he hoped Lord Taylor, the black Tory peer who led demands for Mr Townend's expulsion following his remarks, would recognise the depth of Mr Townend's apology.

fields.headline: Hague fails to heal rift
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Lord Taylor of Warwick, the black peer at the centre of the Conservative race row, last night refused to accept that William Hague's public humiliation of John Townend was sufficient punishment for the maverick MP and demanded his supension from the party at Westminster.
fields.body:
Lord Taylor of Warwick, the black peer at the centre of the Conservative race row, last night refused to accept that William Hague's public humiliation of John Townend was sufficient punishment for the maverick MP and demanded his supension from the party at Westminster.

Though most MPs on both sides believe Lord Taylor has won enough ground not to quit the party in protest, his determination to make the party sweat by not immediately saying so left Hague aides nervous that Labour is orchestrating a slow motion defection for maximum electoral impact.

Having earlier demanded that Mr Townend, ex-chairman of the rightwing 92 Group, be expelled, Lord Taylor's proposal that he lose the party whip was a retreat. But the peer simultaneously appeared to be undecided.

After Mr Hague took the dramatic step of forcing a reluctant Mr Townend to apologise for his "ill-chosen words" - which he admitted had given the impression that racism had a place in his party, Lord Taylor called the move "too little, too late". He predicted that the retiring MP for Yorkshire East will, "by signing a piece of paper, just go away laughing".

Mr Hague's hopes of drawing a line under the row were last night dealt a fresh blow as the former prime minister Sir Edward Heath denounced his handling of the affair. Sir Edward said Mr Hague should have expelled Mr Townend for claiming that the British were becoming a "mongrel race", but could not do so because the party was in the grip of the "extreme right".

"He should have got rid of him without question," he told BBC News 24's One to One programme. "Look at the publicity he's got. This is now going to be an election issue."

He contrasted Mr Hague's handling of the situation with the way Sir Edward had immediately sacked Enoch Powell from the shadow cabinet over his infamous "rivers of blood" speech.

But he added: "Of course, with an opposition which is placed in the position that they are, which is on the extreme right, you can't expect them to do what I did. So many of them feel and think the same way."

But last night the Asian Conservative peer, Baroness Flather, who had also called for Mr Townend's expulsion, said that the matter should now be allowed to rest, although she too was critical of Mr Hague's inaction.

"I find it very surprising that he didn't take firm action right at the start. He always talked about firm leadership and then he let this happen," she said.

Speaking outside Conservative central office yesterday, Mr Hague said: "I will not allow John Townend's offensive remarks to be mistaken for those of the party.

"Today I spoke to John Townend and told him that unless he was prepared to apologise for his ill-chosen words, withdraw them, undertake not to repeat them and accept that racism has no place in the Conservative party, then he could not remain a member.

"We mean business about being an inclusive party that has no truck with racism. And we mean business about being a disciplined party determined to win the election," he said.

"Britain is made up of many ethnic communities. Conservatives believe that we are richer and stronger for it."

Mr Hague's demand for what aides described as a "humiliating apology and retraction" from Mr Townend, was a bid to end a row that has dogged him since the MP's initial complaint on March 27 that immigration was underming Britain's "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society".

Lord Taylor, whose weekend criticism of Mr Hague's "weak leadership" on the issue brought matters to a head, did make one immediate gesture of conciliation with his party which gave Mr Hague hope that he will not defect to Labour on the eve of the general election campaign.

He agreed to sign an open letter - also signed by 11 black and Asian Tory MEPs and candidates - urging people of all communities to back the party on June 7.

But Lord Taylor did not return urgent calls sent all day by senior party officials, MPs and Lord Strathclyde, the Conservative leader of the Lords, or say during a series of media interviews that he would definitely stay in the Tory ranks.

Tory veterans like Peter Bottomley and Steve Norris, both "inclusive" politicians, believe that Lord Taylor is acting on Labour advice.

The peer, who says he has not spoken to Labour recently, told the Radio 4 PM programme: "It is too little and too late. Mr Hague has really been forced into this position, which is pretty weak anyway. He has vacillated over a number of days. He should have taken strong action.

"Don't forget, this is a man [Mr Townend] who wrote to a constituent saying William Hague's views on race were the same as his. That is quite outrageous." Lord Taylor contrasted the treatment of the "racist" Mr Townend with the withdrawal of the whip from Tory MP Charles Wardle for a more trivial offence.

The Tory Reform Group, which counts Kenneth Clarke, Michael Heseltine and Chris Patten among its members, issued a statement saying that Mr Hague's failure to act against Mr Townend had given the MP a "green light" for further inflammatory remarks.

fields.headline: Losing his grip
fields.standfirst:
William Hague has played out the race row so badly because he was desperate

Special report: Conservative party
Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: One of the more enduring mysteries of the 2001 general election/Tory leadership campaign is likely to prove to be William Hague's reluctance to expel the far right Tory MP, John Townend, over his warning that immigration was creating "a mongrel race".
fields.body:
One of the more enduring mysteries of the 2001 general election/Tory leadership campaign is likely to prove to be William Hague's reluctance to expel the far right Tory MP, John Townend, over his warning that immigration was creating "a mongrel race".

For the political party which has held the western European record for winning elections over the past 130 years, it seemed such an obvious political howler. Hague showed no qualms last month about throwing the pro-Fayed MP, Charles Wardle, out of the party. Nor did Heath show any such hesitation in sacking Enoch Powell in 1968 from the shadow cabinet after making his infamous "rivers of blood" immigration remarks.

Much speculation has already centred on the idea that Hague's refusal to con front his own racist right has been part of a deliberately cynical decision to shore up what remains of the core Tory vote. Conservative candidates have never commanded more than negligible support among black and Asian voters - only 11% voted Tory in 1997 and even among their strongest supporters, the Indian community, they took only 18% of the votes.

On this theory, Hague has made a cold calculation that the electoral arithmetic favours keeping Townend in the party while presenting the defection of the black Tory peer, John Taylor, as merely some kind of well orchestrated Labour plot to maximise Conservative discomfort.

But this explanation falls down when you consider that not even Hague's brand of "skinhead Conservatism" contains an avowedly racist agenda. He is not some kind of closet racist.

So what about an alternative explanation? As the decision day for a May or June election approached, Central Office strategists sat down and had a long hard look at all their political polling data. Despite the foot and mouth crisis they have failed to make any headway since the petrol protests last autumn. Their share of the vote has flatlined at about 33-34% leaving Tony Blair heading straight for another 100-plus Commons majority.

The only ray of hope that the figures have offered is on the single issue of asylum and immigration. While Labour has commanding poll leads on all the other big questions that voters say they care about - health, schools, crime, the economy - asylum is the only issue that appears to be a vote winner rather than a vote loser. None of the traditional opposition party tactics seems to be doing the trick. The old tunes of Time For A Change and Labour Isn't Working don't seem to provoke the kind of mass singalong among the voters that they once enjoyed.

In this desperate situation that one shaft of light (the polling lead on asylum) takes on an importance out of all proportion to the other concerns of the average voter. For the Tories it becomes something like football's "golden goal in extra time", some kind of totem by which they can magically win the whole election if they win on that one issue.

Asylum also had the advantage over Europe in being an issue on which the party did not immediately start to tear itself apart as soon as Hague opened his mouth. Whenever Europe is debated in Tory circles those who want to leave the EU soon make their voices heard. At least until now there was a line in the sand within the party which divided a harsh policy on asylum from a more tolerant position on race and community relations.

Labour is partly to blame, for the way it has fought the asylum debate has only encouraged them. It is rather as though Blair's team is six goals up with 10 minutes to go. Instead of leaving it alone they are so determined to get that seventh goal with the result that they let the Tories score one in the final minute. The Tories get a consolation goal and claim a moral victory. Hague keeps Blair's majority below 100 and lives to fight another day.

That, at least, is the way some inside Conservative Central Office saw the way the election might unfold. Hague made his now famous "foreign country" speech in which he promised "elect a Conservative government and we will give you back your country".

But the row over the commission for racial equality's anti-racist pledge smoked out Townend. Then Hague's closest rival for the leadership, Ann Widdecombe, successfully sidestepped the whole issue by saying she had signed it but thought it "silly" thus avoiding alienating either wing of her party.

Hague failed to close down the row. He knows that to make real inroads into the Labour vote he has to drive the party back to the centre-left of British politics. The problem lies in the fact that some parts of the Tory party do not know the difference between asylum and race. Discussion of asylum soon turned to calls for the abolition of the CRE. The left of the Tory party - stronger on race than on Europe - fought back and the hoped for surge in the polls turned to an alarming drop in Hague's own standing, as Tory voters took fright at the sight of a party out of control.

Hague's weak threat to Townend yesterday - no more than a warning - is really little more than another day of vacillation and humiliation in his own campaign diary.

fields.headline: Hague acts but bitterness remains
fields.standfirst:
Tory leader's move 'too little, too late' says peer amid fears that party may not recover

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Wounded by days of damaging headlines, William Hague carefully choreographed his appearance yesterday afternoon to send out a clear signal that his party will not tolerate racism. Standing under a union flag flying over the entrance to Conservative central office, Mr Hague was flanked by a black Tory barrister as he announced that John Townend had been forced into a humiliating climbdown.
fields.body:
Wounded by days of damaging headlines, William Hague carefully choreographed his appearance yesterday afternoon to send out a clear signal that his party will not tolerate racism. Standing under a union flag flying over the entrance to Conservative central office, Mr Hague was flanked by a black Tory barrister as he announced that John Townend had been forced into a humiliating climbdown.

Judith Edwards, an adviser to the shadow cabinet on tax, who is standing for the Tories in Liverpool Riverside, nodded in agreement as Mr Hague declared: "We mean business about being an inclusive party that has no truck with racism."

After the press conference, Ms Edwards toured the Westminster television studios to praise Mr Hague for acting decisively against Mr Townend and for challenging Lord Taylor to fall into line behind the Tory leadership.

The presence of Ms Edwards, however, symbolised how central office will struggle to convince voters that the Tories are serious about stamping out racism. The barrister, along with virtually every other black and Asian Tory candidate in the election, stands no hope of winning her constituency, where the Tories came third in 1997 with 9.5% of the vote.

Her appearance provided vivid proof of Lord Taylor's criticism that Mr Hague's language on inclusivity never appears to match the reality on the ground. Of the 11 Tory black and Asian candidates who signed yesterday's "open letter" to the media, only Shailesh Vara in Northampton South - the Tories' ninth target seat - stands any hope of winning.

Mr Hague finally decided to take action against Mr Townend when he met his senior advisers at central office at 10am yesterday for his daily "team meeting". After four days of relative inertia by the Tory leadership, Mr Hague decided that the party would suffer serious damage in the run-up to the election if he failed to take action to end the newspaper headlines.

Expelling Mr Townend was ruled out because that would have left Mr Hague vulnerable to criticism of weak leadership after he specifically ruled out withdrawing the whip from the rightwinger in the wake of his "mongrel race" outburst last Thursday. Mr Hague also took no action when Mr Townend first sparked the row about racism by lavishing praise on Enoch Powell last month.

In addition, Mr Hague feared a backlash from the party's core supporters who sym pathise in large numbers with Mr Townend. This view was articulated yesterday by Laurence Robertson, the Tory MP for Tewkesbury, who endorsed Mr Townend's outburst, saying: "We have a very crowded island which we have to manage and when you have people coming in from abroad, different cultures, it becomes very difficult to manage that situation."

At the meeting of senior members of the shadow cabinet at his room at central office, which included Michael Portillo and Ann Widdecombe, Mr Hague drew up plans for a compromise. He would, as one adviser said, "read the riot act" to Mr Townend and issue an ultimatum that he should sign an apology or face expulsion.

The group also agreed to take action on a second front. Worried that Lord Taylor was being "run by Millbank", the Tory chairman Michael Ancram agreed to draw up a statement outlining the party's abhorrence of racism. This would be signed by as many black and Asian Tories as central office could lay its hands on - and Lord Taylor would be asked to add his name. "The letter says what Lord Taylor has been asking us to say, so how can he have a problem signing it?" one Tory source asked.

Retraction

With the twintrack plan in place, the mini-shadow cabinet broke up and the plan swung into action. At 1.30pm Mr Hague telephoned Mr Townend to instruct him to sign a two-paragraph statement, apologising for and retracting his remarks on race. Mr Townend initially put up a fight, denying he was a racist, but quickly gave in as Mr Hague made clear that he was not prepared to negotiate.

The rightwing MP for Yorkshire East asked for half an hour to reflect. Mr Hague agreed - less than half an hour later Mr Townend was on the line to say he would sign. "We have not only silenced John Townend, we have also forced him into a complete and utter retraction of what he said," one Tory source said.

Across the corridor, Mr Ancram drew up the "open letter" to the media in which black and Asian members of the party would declare that "the Conservative party is an open and tolerant party". Nirj Deva, an MEP for the south-east of England, the most senior elected Tory, was one of the first to be contacted by Mr Ancram to be asked whether to sign.

Mr Deva immediately agreed, dismissing Mr Townend as a "nonentity". However, there was confusion about Mr Ancram's discussions with Mr Deva, raising questions again about the party's handling of its relations with its ethnic minority members.

The MEP said he had helped to draft the open letter, but that he had no idea that it would be used to test Lord Taylor's loyalty to the party. This was dismissed by Tory officials who insisted that the letter was drawn up in central office and that Mr Deva was merely asked to sign the letter.

Mr Hague's "put-up-or-shut-up" challenge to Lord Taylor appeared to do little to restore relations with the peer who made clear that he would only sign the letter under protest. Describing Mr Hague's actions as "too little, too late", Lord Taylor said it was odd that he should be expected to sign the letter when he was neither a prospective parliamentary candidate nor an MEP.

Confrontation

There were also questions about the wisdom of asking black and Asian Tories to sign a declaration so soon after senior members of the party expressed reservations about the commission for racial equality's anti-racist pact.

Tories on both the left and right of the party praised Mr Hague last night. Steve Norris, the former London Tory mayoral candidate, who had called for the whip to be withdrawn from Mr Townend and who was consulted by Mr Hague yesterday, thought he had acted decisively.

One Tory MP said: "William Hague has triumphed. John Townend is eating humble Yorkshire pie and John Taylor has been put in a box."

Others felt that Mr Hague's actions had backfired and done nothing to restore the party's reputation on race. The former prime minister Sir Edward Heath, who sacked Enoch Powell from the shadow cabinet immediately after his "rivers of blood" speech in 1968, said: "William Hague should have got rid of [John Townend] without question. Look at the publicity he's got. Look what he's done to the party. This is now going to be an election issue."

Sir Edward reflected the views of some Tories on the left of the party who fear that Mr Hague has demonstrated that the Tory leadership is simply incapable of showing genuinely inclusive credentials. They pointed out that a racist speech by a Tory MP has ended, not in his expulsion, but in a confrontation with the most senior black Conservative parliamentarian.
The Tory signatories

Judith Edwards, Liverpool Riverside
Barrister, 36.
Special adviser to shadow cabinet on ethnic issues

Shailesh Vara, Northampton South
Solicitor with international law firm

Suresh Kumar, Ilford South
Business consultant, 37. Member of party since 1996 and chairman of Redbridge Cultural Association

Mohammed Riaz, Bradford West
Stood in Bradford North in 1992 and Bradford West in 1997, where he achieved second place in Labour seat

Ali Miraj, Aberavon
Standing in safe Labour seat once held by Ramsay MacDonald

Iftkhar Hussain, Birmingham Smallheath and Sparkbrook
Labour seat is number 378 on Conservative target list

Sandip Verma, Hull East
Standing for first time - against John Prescott

Zahid Iqbal, Bradford North
Standing for first time in a seat Labour won in 1997 with a 30.5% majority

Anita Kapoor, Doncaster North
One of 55 new Conservative women candidates last year, standing in unwinnable seat

webTitle: Profile: Barrister who turned to politics

fields.headline: Barrister who turned to politics
fields.standfirst:
Quiet peer makes waves in party

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A dapper, distinctly bourgeois figure with a weakness for pin-striped suits, John Taylor looks and sounds the successful barrister he became before turning to politics.
fields.body:
A dapper, distinctly bourgeois figure with a weakness for pin-striped suits, John Taylor looks and sounds the successful barrister he became before turning to politics.

As Lord Taylor of Warwick, the first black Tory peer, he has been making waves as the man who forced William Hague to haul John Townend back into line on race.

It is the sort of thing that has long angered Lord Taylor. "This is one of the hypocrisies of British society. The British complain about immigrants, but British people are the greatest immigrants of all time.

"My great-grandmother was from Dublin. A lot of Irish came across to Jamaica. My father was taught by nuns and the Roman Catholic influence remained very strong upon him," he said in 1999.

Lord Taylor's father came to England as a professional cricketer, playing for Warwickshire in the late 40s. The family settled in Birmingham. John, born in 1952, went to grammar school, Keele university and the London bar, then returned to build his own practice in the Midlands.

Taylor came to Westminster's attention as special adviser to David Waddington, Margaret Thatcher's last home secretary, in 1990. The following year he beat 250 rivals to become Tory candidate for the Tory seat of Cheltenham.

But the local party made it clear they were not happy with the idea of a black MP: Taylor was called a "bloody nigger" by one Tory activist, and some supporters defected. The Lib Dems won.

Some decent Tories privately conceded that Taylor had not worked the patch hard enough. He is not a hyperactive peer (John Major ennobled him in 1996), - "not there in the heat of debate," as one Lib Dem noted.

webTitle: Tories try to mend damage caused by MP

fields.headline: 'I entirely accept that racism has no place in the party'
fields.standfirst:
Tories try to mend damage caused by MP

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: John Townend
fields.body:
John Townend

I entirely accept that racism has no place in the Conservative party and am very sorry that ill-chosen words by me may have given a different impression.

Accordingly, I withdraw the recent words which I have issued on the subject of race, apologise for the embarrassment which they have caused the Conservative party, regret any offence which I have caused to others and undertake not to repeat them under any circumstances.

Tory candidates and MEPs

Coming from many different ethnic backgrounds, we are Conservatives because we believe in Conservative principles and policies.

We believe that the Conservative party is an open and tolerant party which values the rich variety of our multicultural society today.

The party has made abundantly clear the inclusive and welcoming nature of the Conservative party, which stands in stark contrast to the patronising attitude of other parties.

We unequivocally state that we will be campaigning with all our strength and determination for a Conservative victory at the coming general election.

William Hague

In politics, issues blow up unexpectedly, but they do give you a chance to say who you are as a party.

webTitle: Liverpool's former winger, Bradley Walsh's former sidekick, and  Oxford's former manager

fields.headline: Liverpool's former winger, Bradley Walsh's former sidekick, and  Oxford's former manager
fields.trailText: SHORT HAIR, BIG CUP
fields.body:
SHORT HAIR, BIG CUP

In recent weeks, Steve McManaman has trimmed his trademark shaggy locks for a suspiciously mid-west-looking mullet. But don't worry: the care-free Scouser isn't about to starting foolin' around with his cousin or plannin' to buy a pick-up truck. He's got better things on his mind. Namely having a pop at Manchester United. Again. "United suffered this season because they never sorted out a proper game-plan in Europe," claimed Macca through crocodile tears today. "When you look at United's results in Europe all season, you could say as soon as they came up against a decent side they would struggle. I know most of the lads at Madrid wanted United in the semi-final, because they felt it would be the easier tie."

Unfortunately for Macca (providing he shakes off an ankle injury) and Madrid, they face a much tougher Big Cup proposition tonight: Bayern Munich. The "confident" Germans, as Clive Tyldesley so delicately puts it, will no doubt be buoyed by hearing that Giovane Elber and Jens Jeremies are both likely to be fit despite having knee surgery little more than a week ago. "My knee is fine and I am on fire for the match against Real," Elber said. "Now it's up to the coach to decide whether I'll start or not."

Meanwhile, according to Spanish paper Marca, Valencia coach Hector Cuper is preparing his defenders to face Leeds by encouraging them to mimic "the illegal play typical of dirty British defenders" in training sessions. Just in case you're wondering, that includes giving license to "elbow, knee, push and shove" John Carew, Juan Sanchez and Pablo Aimar in preparation for tomorrow's match against Leeds. The paper also picks out two unlikely hardmen that Valencia need to look out for: Dominic Matteo and Rio Ferdinand. "Matteo is one of the toughest players in the Premiership," the paper claims, "and Ferdinand's aggression on the pitch is as noteworthy as his £18m transfer fee." Yeah, and Alan Smith's a little angel too.

HURL-Y BURLEY

The Fiver has always said that Ipswich are rubbish. That kit, that funny pair of lips on Richard Wright, that sweet, flowing football that has mesmerised defences all across the country - Joe Pasquale, the lot of it. So when those crazy Scythe-wielding Boys announced today that they've given joker George Burley a new five-year contract expected to earn him £500,000 a year, we weren't surprised. Oh no. After all, it wasn't city folk who invented pigswill.

"I doubt that the club can call any more important press conference than announcing a new contract for their manager," said Ipswich chairman David Sheepshanks today, momentarily forgetting about the signing-Rivaldo conference, the beating-Real-Madrid-ten-nil conference, and the we've-annexed-Poland conference. "George has done tremendously well over the past six years and this is due reward and recognition for that. We are fourth in the Premiership, still challenging for a [Big Cup] place and in [Euro Vase] for sure so there is a tremendous amount to celebrate."

Talk about getting over-excited. And it doesn't stop there. "I couldn't be any happier," said Burley himself, momentarily forgetting about how happy he would feel if he'd just single-handedly wrestled Godzilla into submission and saved Japan. "Ipswich has always been a special club for me. This year, it has just got better and better for everyone concerned. There is lots still to be done but I am so proud of the way we have performed at the highest level." Yeah, well enjoy it why you can, laughing boy. When the revolution comes, attractive, home-grown, financially sound, family football clubs will be the first against the wall.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have never given an interview to a dirty magazine. I learned from my father that the most important thing in life is to be decent, and I would never promote pornography or any of the other dirty things that have come from the West and made ours a false democracy. If my parents were alive today, they would die of shame!" - Gheorghe Hagi bubbles over with hot rage upon finding his name splashed all over the cover of a Romanian jazz mag.

OX OH

Today is the day on which working class people the world over are taking to the streets in solidarity against exploitation, oppression and all types of inequality. It is the day on which people can express their longing for socialism and their disgust for the capitalist-imperialist system. It is a day which will make eff all difference, sadly. But not all protest is futile. No! Because today, totally hopeless Oxford manager David Kemp was relieved of his post after a smart show of people power.

During Oxford's 3-1 victory [note to sub: this can't be right, please check] against Swansea at the Manor on Saturday, very many paying members of the public vocally opined in unison on the merits of the aforementioned Mr Kemp, who oversaw one of the worst campaigns in the history of the Football League. And they seem to have made a difference. "I have always said that I will do what I feel is best for the club rather than listening to supporters," chairman Firoz Kassam said this afternoon, "but on Saturday there was not just a handful of fans chanting for David to go but thousands. That was not nice for me to listen to and I don't think it was very good for David either."

As a result, Kemp and his assistant Alan McLeary were dismissed by Kassam following the club's annual general meeting today. "We are moving into a new stadium for the start of next season and we will be looking to start afresh with a new manager," explained the chairman, who has placed former player Mike Ford in temporary control. However, Kemp was still hanging around like a bad smell, telling everyone he hadn't been sacked and that he wanted to leave anyway. "I offered to stay for the last two games but the chairman said I might as well go straight away," he grimaced, kidding on he didn't care. "It's not true that I was sacked. I agreed to leave by mutual consent!" Of course you did, mate. After all, you'll have no trouble finding work elsewhere, will you?

THE RUMOUR MILL

Internazionale are confident of signing Sol Campbell this summer - providing they qualify for Big Cup. Inter director Gabriele Oriali revealed: "If we are in [Big Cup] we will have him. If we are not, he will probably not come."

Kaiserslautern are considering a move for Steffen Freund. "I know Steffen quite well. He is a reliable and interesting player," said assistant coach Reinhard Stumpf. Interesting?

Barcelona have ruled out a move for David Beckham, according to the club's adviser Josep Maria Minguella.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The FA have admitted that the Wembley Stadium project is doomed to failure unless the government bails it out. "We cannot act as the sole sponsor of the scheme," said the FA tonight of the £475m scheme which has been beset by problems over the past two years. "Neither sports governing bodies nor banks will take the risks associated with such a project."

Watford are expected to announce Gianluca Vialli as their new manager at a press conference at Vicarage Road tomorrow.

The Albanian FA have escaped with a £2,000 fine for the incident which saw Ashley Cole hit in the eye by a lipstick case during England's 3-1 victory against Albania.

Blackburn's Graeme Souness has won the Nationwide manager of the month award. Millwall coach Mark McGhee was awarded the Second Division prize, while the Third Division award went to Steve Parkin of Rochdale.

Nottingham Forest chairman Eric Barnes has confirmed the club are in negotiations with manager David Platt about extending his contract.

Argentina's players have decided to start an indefinite strike because they claim clubs owe them millions in unpaid wages and bonuses.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (11.30pm, 2,20am)
Two Sideshow Bobs for the price of one. Actually, you can shove that deal where the sun don't shine.

Channel 4: Football Italia (2.50am)
You expect us to stay up for a league everyone knows is rubbish these days? You can stick your programme in your pipe and smoke it, mate.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm, 11.30pm)
But it's already over. And they've broken it into two pieces for no discernible reason. Take it away, we don't want it.

Live Football Special - Newcastle v Southampton (7.30pm, 12.30am)
And now you're insulting us with this mid-table rubbish. Who do you think we are?

You're On Sky Sports! (10.30pm, 5am)
Phone-ins? You are joking, aren't you?

Sky Sports 2: Asian Football Show (10.30pm, 2.30am SS1)
We can't even be bothered with football in this continent, pal.

ONsport 1: Live Big Cup Football - Real Madrid v Bayern Munich (7.30pm)
Nope.

ONsport 2: Live Big Cup Football - Real Madrid v Bayern Munich (7.30pm)
We said no!

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 with Ian Payne (7pm)
We're right at the end of our tether, us.

fields.headline: Jackson's pay tops £500k
fields.trailText: Michael Jackson's remuneration package rose by £42,000 in 2000, taking it more than £500,000 for the first time, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The salary and benefits package of the Channel 4 chief executive, Michael Jackson, rose by £42,000 in 2000, taking it to more than £500,000 for the first time.

Mr Jackson enjoyed an 8.5% increase on his 1999 remuneration of £494,000 to £536,000.

He is now more highly paid than the BBC director general, Greg Dyke, who earned £432,000, according to the BBC's last annual accounts.

But he gets significantly less than other bosses in the commercial sector.

The Carlton chairman, Michael Green, got a package of £892,000 last year, in addition to his lucrative share options.

Other Channel 4 executives also enjoyed significant salary rises.

Tim Gardam, the broadcaster's director of programmes, saw his pay package swell from £227,000 to £262,000 - a rise of 15%, year on year.

He and Janet Walker, the director of business affairs, each got £25,000 in bonuses.

David Brook, the Channel 4 director of strategy and development, gained a pay rise of £18,000 - or nearly 7% - to £287,000.

The managing director, David Scott, earned £380,000, while the commercial director, Andy Barnes, took home £376,000, £119,000 of which was a bonus.

Mr Barnes is responsible for Channel 4's advertising and sponsorship.

His total package was down on the year before, when he received £385,000.

The total wage bill last year for Channel 4's six full-time executives, seven non-executive board members and four retired board members was £2.271m - down from £2.337m in 1999.

Vanni Treves, the non-executive chairman, was paid £62,000, while each of the non-executive board members were paid £19,000 a year.

fields.headline: Coke unveils 'Popstars' campaign
fields.trailText:
4.45pm: Coca-Cola is to launch a Popstars-style search for the stars of its new national advertising campaign, reports Claire Cozens.

Fantamates website
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is to launch a Popstars-style search for the stars of its new national advertising campaign.

The company's Fanta Best Mates Challenge will give talented teenagers across the country the change to appear in a series of commercials as part of a marketing blitz.

Its search launches today with a series of TV commercials kicking off in tonight's episode of the Channel 4 chat show, the Priory.

The advertising features real-life teenage best friends telling funny stories about what they have got up to together.

They will direct viewers to a website that gives details of the "Fanta cam", the talent scouts that will be visiting shopping malls around the country to spot teenagers to appear in the next campaign.

The campaign will run for six weeks before being replaced by a new set of adverts featuring the teenage stars.

"Programmes like Popstars have shown that fame is a great motivator for young people," said a Coca-Cola spokeswoman.

"The campaign is a sort of virtual circle with the TV adverts driving entries to the auditions."

The advertising is part of a major marketing blitz from Coca-Cola that began last week with the launch of a campaign for the main Coca-Cola brand.

Two more campaigns will launch on Friday, one for Dr Pepper and for Coca-Cola's new still fruit drink Alive.

All four campaigns have been specially made for the UK market, a change of tack for Coca-Cola, which has traditionally tended to focus on global advertising campaigns.

webTitle: No Yahoo! for racist UK website

fields.headline: No Yahoo! for racist UK website
fields.trailText: A UK website advocating the repatriation of black and Asian people has been closed down by Yahoo!, writes David Hencke.
fields.body:
A British website advocating the repatriation of millions of black and Asian people and praising the parliamentary speeches of Tory rightwinger Gerald Howarth has been closed down by Yahoo!, the US host provider.

The site, which claimed to be sponsored by Yahoo!, was deemed "inappropriate" by the provider after they received complaints about its content.

Run by Ian Heffernan of a new radical rightwing group called New Democracy - with a PO box address in Watford, Hertfordshire - the site calls for the introduction of a repatriation scheme linked to government aid for third world countries.

"We will also campaign for an end to non white immigration (both legal and illegal) and for a public apology from the government for the mass immigration of recent decades."

The site also links to racist and rightwing websites in the United States, Europe, an anti-semitic site called Jew Watch and recent speeches by Jean-Marie Le Pen, as well as neo-fascist parties in Albania, Greece, Italy and Romania.

It praises Gerald Howarth, the MP for Aldershot, as "one of the rare few who have the courage to brave the inevitable torrent of abuse" by attacking race relations legislation in the Commons.

Mr Heffernan approves of a call by Mr Howarth to repeal all racial discrimination laws and his attack on the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence as "intellectually shoddy and devoid of logic".

He also lauds Mr Howarth's views that no British government has ever received a mandate to turn this country into a multiracial society. Mr Heffernan describes multiracialism as a "bathtub society" where the scum floats to the top.

He concludes: "I must reiterate my admiration for him (Mr Howarth) as a rare challenger of the multiracial consensus. I hope he and those few others who have been prepared to speak out against the racial policies of our liberal elite will one day receive the recognition they deserve."

A spokeswoman for Yahoo! said that the company decided that it would no longer host it as it was "inappropriate". Yahoo! has a policy of refusing to host abusive and racist material. She said: "Yahoo! itself did not sponsor the site but the person constructed the site using materials from Yahoo! which are available to business."

The Guardian tried to contact Mr Heffernan but he was unavailable.

fields.headline: Climb every mountain
fields.standfirst: Monkey awards alternative gongs to the badly behaved hacks and PRs who made the annual pilgrimage to Montreux
fields.trailText: Monkey awards alternative gongs to the badly behaved hacks and PRs who made the annual pilgrimage to Montreux.
fields.body:
Another year, another set of awards from the chocolate-box setting of Montreux in Switzerland. While Lenny Henry can bask in the glory of his Golden Rose this morning, lesser delegates at the festival can content themselves with Monkey's own set of gongs.

For those unfamiliar with the Rose D'Or festival, it is an annual pilgrimage for lig-starved hacks and PRs to an eighth-floor suite of the Intercontinental, the swish hotel overlooking Lake Geneva, where the flow of beer is only matched by the flow of showbiz flannel.

The Michael Barrymore award for self-restraint goes to Times media correspondent Paul "mine's a pint" McCann. After a lunchtime booze-up with top media contacts (well, all right, the Channel 5 press office) McCann stumbled into ITV's Popstars press briefing a little too refreshed. McCann filled a gap in the questioning with this gem lobbed at the bemused band members: "Is there a dark side," he inquired, mysteriously. It later turned out that McCann had meant to ask about the "down side" of fame, which disappoints Monkey, who had been looking forward to that Times photo spread: "Popstars - the parallel universe."

Staying with a musical theme, the Geri Halliwell award for self-importance goes to Myleene from Popstars, whose enthusiasm for fame knows no rivals. Describing the highlights of her celebrated status, she told of the fans who had camped outside the Hear'Say home in north London. "It's like a mini-Graceland," she said. You see, this is what one No1 record does to your sense of proportion.

The Robbie Coltrane award for worst piece of hotel-room misbehaviour goes to the TV team who frightened the fish in Lake Geneva with carefully-aimed beer bottles projected from the balcony eight floors up in the Royal Plaza. Apparently in memory of the year Coltrane threw his television set out of his window, one group of badly-behaved PRs launched a competition to see how far into the lake they could aim their empty receptacles. No-one owned up the next day, but Channel 5 chief spokesman Paul Leatherissued this statement to staff: "The hotel management team complained about bottles being thrown into the lake from the eighth floor suite. Not only is it dangerous, but it is illegal. I assured them that it didn't happen but if it did, I was the best."

The Victor Meldrew award for miserable behaviour goes to Angus Deayton. After accepting an invitation by the BBC to travel to a delightful mountainside restaurant for dinner with executives, other telly stars and assorted hacks, Mr Deayton declared his disapproval of the seating arrangements and refused to be placed with the Sun's Emily Smith. He then sat by the wall, flanked by two BBC executives and failed to be witty, warm or engaging to anyone who dared to come anywhere near him.

Lifelong achievement award for services to smoothies - stand up Nigel "the charmer" Havers. Not only did he remember everyone's first name, the newspaper they worked for and their shoe size, but he left the dinner organised by the BBC by indulging several female journalists' fantasies with a lingering smacker. "We were all wafting in a cloud of hormones," said one delirious hackette. Angus Deayton, watch and learn.

The Anne Robinson award for talking about your salary goes to the Daily Mail showbusiness editor Alison Boshoff who surprised everyone at a press conference when she accepted Johnny Vaughan's challenge to reveal her own salary. "I am on seventy-two and a half thousand and worth every penny of it," she beamed to the baffled star. Vaughan still refused to talk numbers while other hacks gasped in awe. But one did break ranks. "Alison," he gushed admiringly, "you are worth far more than that." Is Alan Yentob planning a dawn raid? Monkey should be told.

The Uriah Heep award for sycophancy is awarded collectively to the BBC. As Johnny Vaughan arrived in the eighth floor suite for his press conference he was followed by 12, yes 12, corporation executives. The most star-struck was drama and entertainment supremo Alan Yentob, who could barely contain his enthusiasm for the newly signed big-money presenter, patting his shoulder repeatedly. Just remember, this is the man who only a few years ago branded Frank Skinner greedy for demanding, er, lots of money.

The Alan Yentob award for forgetfulness goes to... Alan Yentob. When he presented his passport at the airport upon departure for Geneva, he was met with a bemused look. "I see you've changed sex since the last time you were here," the official said. Surprise, surprise Yentob had, of course, taken his wife's passport to the airport.

A special Pride of Britain award for LWT's countess of spin Zoe McIntyre, who (literally) jumped off the side of a mountain in a para-glider, as part of a PR stunt to promote Claire Sweeney's new ITV show. Surely this was taking the job a little too seriously, especially when like McIntyre you are afraid of heights and afraid of flying.

The 'we're just good friends' award goes to Graham Norton who brought Castaway star Ben Fogle to the Brit awards earlier this year prompting speculation of a courtship. The Channel 4 star explained how they were simply worlds apart. "When we were spotted I turrned to him and said 'you too are on stage'. And he turned round and said, 'U2, golly, they are just the cat's pyjamas'." It must have been that year on Taransay. Either that or a nasty knock on the head, Ben.

And the award for brass neck goes to the customs lady at City Airport who apprehended three hackettes - two from the Sun and one from Monkeyland on their return from Montreux. "Are you aware of the kinds of things you are not allowed bring from one country to another?" she enquired. "Yes," replied one, naturally thinking of the repeated warnings about foot and mouth, "Food". Wrong answer. "No... drugs and firearms," she snarled, after a pause to much hilarity. After forensic tests on all luggage, computers and Toblerones proved fruitless, she had to let them go.

And finally, a return to Angus Deayton who left Montreux before he could officially be told his Have I Got News for You show had lost out to Lenny Henry, Anne Robinson, Popstars and everything else. Unwittingly, he ended up in the vicinity of journalists once again on his plane home, one of whom overheard him say this: "Well it must have been very difficult for foreign juries to understand even with subtitles, because everyone talks over the top of each other". Yes, Angus, yes.

webTitle: Scandal in the loft: why Belgian pigeons flew higher

fields.headline: Scandal in the loft: why Belgian pigeons flew higher
fields.trailText: Nowadays there is practically no sport left untainted by drug scandals. Even the noble pursuit of whippet racing came under investigation in 1999 when several dogs tested positive for caffeine. It transpired that the results were caused not by cheats nor the encroachment of cappuccino culture into the canine world but by the owners' habit of giving their pets too many pre-race chocolate drops.
fields.body:
Nowadays there is practically no sport left untainted by drug scandals. Even the noble pursuit of whippet racing came under investigation in 1999 when several dogs tested positive for caffeine. It transpired that the results were caused not by cheats nor the encroachment of cappuccino culture into the canine world but by the owners' habit of giving their pets too many pre-race chocolate drops.

It should have surprised nobody, therefore, when police swooped on homing lofts and pigeon-feed merchants across Belgium recently and carried off large quantities of illegal substances. The operation, led by the prosecutor Louis Denecker, was begun after suspicious chemical traces were found in a number of birds during random post-race dope tests.

In Britain pigeon racing is linked in the popular imagination with pithead winding gear, pints of mild and pickled eggs. Even the fact that the queen has a loft at Sandringham is unlikely to shake the sport's cloth-cap image.

In Belgium things are different. There are 60,000 pigeon-fanciers in Flanders and Wallonia, the top echelon of which is fully professional. Races are shown live on television. Legendary status is conferred on star breeders such as the Herbots brothers, Jos "the Master" Thone and the Houben family of Ichtergem, whose slogan, "Houben pigeons! Popular as Coca-Cola! Reliable as Mercedes-Benz! Unbeatable over Belgium's middle distances!" is surely one of the most evocative in sport.

There is big money in birds too. Prizes in the major races have crept over the £100,000 mark and gambling turnover frequently tops £1m a race. Pigeons change hands for small fortunes. In 1996, for example, Thone sold one of his stars, Gerda B94-5315093, to a Japanese homing enthusiast for $120,000 (£80,000).

The amount of cash washing around has inevitably tempted some of the fancy to cheat. Not that drug use is new to the sport. The hope of finding a winning potion means that pigeon racing has always had its share of quacks. In his memoirs the great Belgian writer Georges Simenon recalled how in the 1920s a chemist in his home city of Liege had perfected a particularly potent pigeon laxative. This delighted the Liegeois fanciers, who queued round the block to obtain it. Presumably it was less popular with everybody else, with the possible exception of local umbrella salesmen.

As a result, Belgium, despite taking a firm stance against avian doping, is well known as the centre for what British homing enthusiasts tend to refer to as "continental practices" (a phrase that sounds like the sort of thing a dragged-up Les Dawson would have mouthed: "Divorced her husband. Said he asked her to engage in... continental practices").

The situation was brought to my attention some years ago when a pigeon-fancier I know asked if I would bring some "stuff for the birds" back for him from a bike race I was attending in West Flanders - a race, coincidentally, that was interrupted when police took a number of riders in for questioning over alleged amphetamine trafficking at the instruction of the public prosecutor, Louis Denecker naturally. I envisaged a scene at customs in which I was forced to confess that I was acting as mule for a pigeon and declined.

Later it crossed my mind that, if he really wanted to import illegal pigeon dope, he could get the birds to bring it in themselves - a notion that might be dismissed as whimsical were it not that two years ago South African police, acting on a tip-off, shot down a homing pigeon in Port Alexander and found £6,000 worth of uncut diamonds taped to its chest.

In truth, of course, the doping of animals is worthier of stiffer penalties than the doping of human athletes. Human beings after all have free will, even though it may sometimes appear to have been handcuffed to a radiator by the monomaniacal desire for fame, glory or a neo- Georgian detached house next to a championship golf course, while animals do not.

Birds dosed with steroids are likely to suffer from health problems ranging from perpetual colds to premature sterility and renal failure. The effects can be passed on to their offspring too. So it is to be hoped that, when Denecker begins his interrogations, at least one unscrupulous pigeon fancier will sing like a canary.

webTitle: Rugby League: Nikau in surprise return

fields.headline: Nikau in surprise return
fields.trailText: Tawera Nikau, the New Zealand international, is in line for a surprise return to the Warrington team for tomorrow's Super League match against Bradford Bulls.
fields.body:
Tawera Nikau, the New Zealand international, is in line for a surprise return to the Warrington team for tomorrow's Super League match against Bradford Bulls.

The 33-year-old loose-forward flew home following the sudden death of his wife on April 6 and was thought to have played his last game for the club. However, Nikau was back in England yesterday, accompanied by his 13-year-old daughter and seven-year-old son, and announced his intention to resume his career.

"I'm delighted," said Darryl van de Velde, Warrington's coach. "It's a big boost to the club and to the team to have 'T' back. He has decided he wants to play the season out and is determined to get back to normal as soon as possible. He will be training and we'll decide then whether he plays at Bradford. If he doesn't, he will definitely be in the side to play Huddersfield on Sunday."

Nikau, formerly with Castleford, Cronulla Sharks and Melbourne Storm, joined Warrington on a two-year contract in October 1999 and had missed only one match up to the beginning of April.

The players' union is taking legal advice in the light of allegations from Wakefield's directors that the body misrepresented former Trinity players. The club's board had claimed that the 11 players sacked at the height of their financial crisis last September stood to receive less compensation because of the actions of the Players Association, part of the GMB trade union.

Wakefield were ordered by an industrial tribunal last week to pay out more than £150,000; it ruled they were in breach of contract and had unfairly dismissed four of the 11.

The directors claimed that they had lodged within the club's Creditors' Voluntary Arrangement a larger amount to pay the players in the event of them being successful in recouping money pledged to the Super League club by the former chief executive John Pearman.

The Players Association responded through its chairman Andy Goodway: "The club seems to allude that the association has not done the best for its members. We are taking legal advice as to whether or not the association and its advisers have been libelled.

"Throughout the hearing on April 23 and 24 and at the pre-hearing on January 8 the club stated they had no liability to pay any monies awarded by the tribunal. In their press release the club seem to indicate that the monies will be available to pay the players in full but we know that is not the case."

webTitle: Rugby union: Woodward banks on Barkley

fields.headline: Woodward banks on Barkley
fields.trailText: In four eventful years at the helm of England Clive Woodward has never been the type who embarks for distant lands with a skeleton crew and yesterday's announcement of a 40-man squad to tour Canada and the United States this summer under the captaincy of Kyran Bracken once again bore the hallmark of a man who likes to think big.
fields.body:
In four eventful years at the helm of England Clive Woodward has never been the type who embarks for distant lands with a skeleton crew and yesterday's announcement of a 40-man squad to tour Canada and the United States this summer under the captaincy of Kyran Bracken once again bore the hallmark of a man who likes to think big.

The absence of 18 players on Lions duty was always going to allow Woodward room to experiment but the obvious difference from the 1998 "Tour from Hell", when England last travelled without their big names, lies in the depth of reserve talent they can summon for what he insists is "not a development tour".

Bracken, Tim Stimpson, Simon Shaw and Mark Regan are already Lions and Paul Sampson, Joe Worsley and Julian White will not have given up hope of an emergency standby call from Graham Henry. Alongside 20 capped tourists on England's three-Test trip, however, will be two players yet to play a Premiership game, including one whom Woodward has never even seen play.

Not only has the 19-year-old Bath fly-half Olly Barkley not made his league debut; he is currently 12,000 miles away on a gap year in New Zealand. His potential, though, has impressed coaches of the calibre of Brian Ashton, Andy Robinson and Jon Callard.

Sampson, plucked from schoolboy obscurity to train with England under Jack Rowell, may well have a quiet word with Barkley on the subject of too much fame at an early age but the choice of the 22-year-old Leeds lock Tom Palmer is less of a surprise to those who have studied his club's progress this year.

Among other interesting selections are Josh Lewsey's inclusion as a centre, a recall for Stade Français's urbane ex-pat flanker Richard Pool-Jones, one of eight survivors from the 1998 tour, and the presence of five hookers. Of those not on the list Leicester's Andy Goode will play in the Sanzar Under-21 tournament and his Tigers colleague Darren Garforth enjoy an officially sanctioned summer of rest.

Woodward is also taking a new-look coaching panel, with John Wells, Ellery Hanley and Paul Grayson filling the spe cialist boots of Robinson, Phil Larder and Dave Alred, all Lions-bound. They, in turn, will be shadowed by four other coaches as Woodward continues to develop a structure he wants to be strong enough to cope "even if I get run over by a bus tomorrow".

Beyond Woodward's control is the political cloud hanging over the England itinerary. The Premiership clubs' contractual agreements with the Rugby Football Union expire on May 31, three days before the first Test against Canada in Toronto. Gloucester's owner Tom Walkinshaw says that Premier Rugby Partnership reserves the right not to release players if negotiations with the RFU falter.

 Cardiff's coach Lynn Howells has resigned. Dick Best, released by London Irish last month, and Leeds's rugby director Phil Davies are among candidates for the job.

webTitle: Motor racing: No favours for Coulthard

fields.headline: No favours for Coulthard
fields.trailText: David Coulthard knows better than to ask the McLaren-Mercedes management to throw their entire efforts behind his attempt on the world championship after his team-mate Mika Hakkinen's bitterly disappointing retirement from Sunday's Spanish grand prix when almost within sight of the chequered flag.
fields.body:
David Coulthard knows better than to ask the McLaren-Mercedes management to throw their entire efforts behind his attempt on the world championship after his team-mate Mika Hakkinen's bitterly disappointing retirement from Sunday's Spanish grand prix when almost within sight of the chequered flag.

The Scot, who finished fifth after stalling on the grid and getting involved in a first-corner collision, is widely regarded as the only McLaren driver to have a realistic chance of the title. Yet the team will not require Hakkinen to play a subservient role until his own chances are effectively extinguished.

"In principle we will not ask one driver to drive in a supporting role to the other until he has no chance of winning the title," said Martin Whitmarsh, the McLaren managing director, yesterday.

"However, I think when you get to the point where, to all intents and purposes, our second driver in the championship placings has no longer got a reasonable chance, then we will obviously call team orders."

If Coulthard stays ahead, he will eventually get the same level of support from Hakkinen as he himself provided in 1998 and '99 when he rode shotgun to the Finn in the closing races of the season after his own chances of the title had faded away.

For the moment this means putting aside the fact that Michael Schumacher's 36 points put him eight ahead of Coulthard. Although Hakkinen is 32 points down on the Ferrari driver, which means he has to win at least three races without Schumacher scoring a point toget within striking distance, with 12 of the season's 17 races to go there is plenty of time for things to change.

That also means, therefore, that Coulthard may have to wait some time before he is given the sort of priority treatment enjoyed by Schumacher at Ferrari.

Schumacher's contract with the Italian team gives him absolute priority status as team leader, even though his proven superiority over first Eddie Irvine and now Rubens Barrichello means he has seldom needed to pull rank in any obtrusive fashion.

 The crash that killed the Italian Michele Alboreto was caused by a damaged tyre, the Audi car company said yesterday. Alboreto, 44, was killed last Wednesday on the Euro-Speedway circuit at Lausitz, Germany, at the wheel of an Audi R8 that he was testing for the Le Mans 24-hour race.

webTitle: Snooker: Hunter falls prey to Hendry

fields.headline: Hunter falls prey to Hendry
fields.standfirst: The seven-times champion races to victory on a day of slow play
fields.trailText: Stephen Hendry's 13-5 trouncing of Paul Hunter took the seven-times world champion through to the quarter-finals of the Embassy World Championship at the Crucible Theatre and left the 22-year-old Benson & Hedges Masters champion to reflect that this has still been his best season.
fields.body:
Stephen Hendry's 13-5 trouncing of Paul Hunter took the seven-times world champion through to the quarter-finals of the Embassy World Championship at the Crucible Theatre and left the 22-year-old Benson & Hedges Masters champion to reflect that this has still been his best season.

Hunter has the sort of blond boy-band looks to be found on posters on young girls' bedroom walls. To judge from his tabloid coverage, he does not appear to have much trouble interesting older girls either, but a colourful private life counts for nothing at the table.

This summer the young Yorkshireman has tempered his pursuit of life's pleasures with better preparation for matches and yesterday was simply outplayed.

Hunter made the two highest breaks of the morning, 74 and 65, in the only two frames he won. Hendry, who had obtained his 6-2 overnight lead in his most familiar style, single-scoring visits of 71, 129, 100 and 95 snuffing out four frames, brought himself to the verge of victory by reaching 12-4 at lunch in far less characteristic fashion.

Even in his prime, the 32-year-old Scot seldom won a high percentage of fragmentary frames but having to try harder in the second half of his career to produce the quality he came to take for granted in the first, he hardly made a mistake in the tactical exchanges and still scored heavily enough, with 60 as his highest break, to accumulate six of the morning's eight frames.

Hendry's average shot time for the session was 22 seconds, perfectly acceptable in any circumstances. However, slow play came on the agenda in two second-round matches.

Peter Ebdon employed attritional tactics against Stephen Lee, who would have preferred a more free-flowing game. In Sunday's second session Ebdon's average shot time soared to 36 seconds, reduced to 33 by the close with Lee, drawn into playing similarly, on 30 seconds. These averages were maintained yesterday as Ebdon turned his 9-7 deficit into a 12-11 lead going into an unscheduled fourth session.

The higher standard of play and the approach of the winning post made the match more compelling but, even so, there was time only for seven frames.

Chris Small, a notoriously slow Scot, averaged 31 seconds per shot in falling 11-5 behind to John Higgins, the 1998 champion, but still contrived to occupy the table for 51% of the time. Taking victory for granted, Higgins was relatively slack yesterday and the fable of the tortoise and the hare fleetingly came to mind.

The tortoise would have had to play out of his shell, though, to snatch victory and Higgins eventually won 13-8 for a quarter-final place against Ken Doherty, the 1997 champion.

Small's, polar opposite is Ronnie O'Sullivan, who four years ago made a 147 maximum in 5min 20sec - just under 10 seconds a shot. Patrick Wallace, attempting to secure a quarter-final against his fellow Northern Irishman Joe Swail, is also on the slow side, although there has been no doubting the quality of his play here.

He defeated the Romford left-hander Mark King 13-5. Leading 5-3 overnight, Wallace won two of the morning's first three frames, marathons of 49 and 42 minutes respectively, before going to 7-5 with a run of 125.

Of even more significance, however, was his fluke yellow halfway through the 57 clearance which gave him the next frame on the black and another black-ball success saw him four clear at 9-5. By adding the two remaining frames of the morning, he stood 11-5 up and with a 71 break in the first frame of the evening he went seven up with eight to play.

A time limit per shot would not work but with more computerised information available it is being mooted that referees might, over a number of frames, be able to check any impression of slowness against hard fact and, if necessary, issue a warning.

Some shots call for more consideration than others; broken play takes longer than a player flowing easily from shot to shot with close control; tension can make one more deliberate; some sight a potting angle and drop into their stances instinctively; others simply cannot produce their standard without following a preparation procedure.

webTitle: Racing: Sheikh's wonder horse put down

fields.headline: Sheikh's wonder horse put down
fields.trailText: Dubai Millennium, the best ever horse owned by Sheikh Mohammed, has been put down after suffering with grass sickness.
fields.body:
Dubai Millennium, the best ever horse owned by Sheikh Mohammed, has been put down after suffering with grass sickness.

He won nine of his 10 races, including last year's Dubai World Cup and his only defeat was in the 1999 Epsom Derby when he finished ninth to Oath.

Winner of £2m in prize money, Dubai Millennium went to stud this season with a covering fee of £100,000.

He had covered threequarters (70) of his first book of mares when he was struck down by the illness.

Dubai Millennium was ridden by Frankie Dettori in his first nine races with American Jerry Bailey deputising for the injured Italian at Royal Ascot in the Prince Of Wales's Stakes, which he won by eight lengths.

The Royal Ascot race was the colt's last for just as a match with French champion Montjeu was being planned last August, he fractured a leg on the gallops and was retired to stud.

Dettori said: "I'm absolutely devastated - it's a tragedy. He was one of the best horses I have ridden."

 Tomorrow's televised meeting at Ascot has been abandoned because of waterlogging. Today's Flat programme at Nottingham hinges on an early morning inspection.

webTitle: Racing: Munir shortens as Hills deserts Nayef

fields.headline: Munir shortens as Hills deserts Nayef
fields.standfirst: Rider takes sides with Greenham winner for his Classic partner
fields.trailText: The many 2,000 Guineas ante-post vouchers bearing the name Nayef looked even more threadbare last night after Richard Hills deserted the much-hyped colt to ride Munir in Saturday's race at Newmarket.
fields.body:
The many 2,000 Guineas ante-post vouchers bearing the name Nayef looked even more threadbare last night after Richard Hills deserted the much-hyped colt to ride Munir in Saturday's race at Newmarket.

Hills had the choice of owner Sheikh Hamdan Al Maktoum's two candidates, Greenham Stakes winner Munir and Nayef, who was winter favourite for the Classic after two impressive victories as a juvenile but was a disappointing third in the Craven Stakes on his return.

Hills, who has ridden both colts in all their races, said: "They are two very high-class horses but I was very impressed with Munir at Newbury. He's got a turn of foot and he's got speed. I've won two 1,000 Guineas (Harayir and Lahan) and both horses had lots of speed which you must have if you're going to win the Classic.

"Nayef is a lovely horse with a lot of class but I just felt that he was a bit one-paced over a mile at Newmarket and may be better over further."

Munir is trained by Hills's father Barry, who won the 2,000 Guineas in 1979 with Tap On Wood.

The Marcus Tregoning-trained Nayef, who will now be ridden by Willie Supple, finished only third to King's Ironbridge when sent off at 4-6 for his reappearance at Newmarket.

Ladbrokes now go 8-1 Munir from 10-1 while they have pushed Nayef out to 7-1 from 5-1. William Hill have cut Munir to 7-1 from 10-1 and the Tote now make him an 8-1 chance.

Champion Irish trainer Aidan O'Brien is responsible for five of the 24 confirmed entries for the 2000 Guineas, headed by Middle Park Stakes winner Minardi.

Rumpold, the only horse to defeat Minardi, is one of three Godolphin entries. The others are the unraced Devine Task and market leader Tobougg, the intended mount of Frankie Dettori.

John Gosden has confirmed the entry of Free Handicap winner Clearing, who is owned by Khaled Abdulla. But the colt is not certain to be in the line up on Saturday.

"We are also considering the French Guineas for him and a decision will be made in the week," said Teddy Beckett, the owner's racing manager.

A total of 19 fillies were left in at yesterday's confirmation stage for Sunday's 1,000 Guineas with the Henry Cecil-trained Quick To Please the most notable withdrawal.

Ground conditions have dried out at Newmarket ahead of the Guineas Festival which gets under way on Friday.

Clerk of the course Michael Prosser said: "I've changed the going report to good to soft. Hopefully we won't get too much rain and the ground will continue to dry out."

 All three days of Goodwood's May meeting will be shown live on BBC, it was announced yesterday. The meeting, which is scheduled to go ahead on May 22, 23 and 24, features the two Classic trials, the Predominate and the Lupe Stakes.
