fields.headline: Pakistan circus hits town
fields.standfirst: Waqar's squad is full of talent and animosity.
fields.trailText: A couple of decades ago, when the mighty Imran was in his pomp and hurtling himself down the Hove slope for Sussex, he would respond to the nickname Fred, as in Khano. But how nicely ironic that the greatest captain Pakistan has possessed, indeed in the eyes of many the only captain they have ever had, should be associated with the undisputed maestro of disorganisation.
fields.body:
A couple of decades ago, when the mighty Imran was in his pomp and hurtling himself down the Hove slope for Sussex, he would respond to the nickname Fred, as in Khano. But how nicely ironic that the greatest captain Pakistan has possessed, indeed in the eyes of many the only captain they have ever had, should be associated with the undisputed maestro of disorganisation.

In fact, by comparison with those who try to run Pakistan cricket, Fred Karno would be a byword for efficiency. The current situation is that flight PK 757 will be bringing the Pakistan touring team into Heathrow airport tomorrow afternoon whence, eventually, they will play two Tests and a limited-overs triangular series also involving Australia. This presupposes they can go for a month or so without everyone falling out with each other.

Originally, according to the chairman of the Pakistan Cricket Board Lt Gen Tauqir Zia, the party was to consist of 16 players captained by Waqar Younis, a wonderful bowler in his more youthful days, who has played 71 Tests and led the side ona single occasion (as it seems has just about anyone who has ever played for Pakistan) 7 years ago.

When the squad was finally announced last Saturday, however, 17 names were read out, there having been the last-minute addition of Wasim Akram, the greatest left-arm pace bowler ever but someone whom Waqar regards as a couple of points below bubonic plague in the popularity stakes.

They formed one of the most potent bowling partnerships in the history of the game and they have fuelled it on pure unadulterated hate.

The team will arrive with a bowling consultant, the Australian Daryl Foster, a member of a specialised committee at the University of Western Australia which has just passed as legitimate the bowling action of another member of the party Shoaib Akhtar, the Rawalpindi Express.

They do not have a coach, however. Javed Miandad resigned after the recent tour of New Zealand, demanding an investigation into what he described as deliberate under-performance by his players, something which has already attracted the attention of the International Cricket Council's Anti-Corruption Unit.

The wicketkeeper in this party will not be Moin Khan, who led them against England in the winter when his delaying tactics on the final day of the series led to the match finishing at a time and in conditions normally associated with Ovaltine rather than overs, but another former captain Rashid Latif, a team-mate of Waqar in domestic cricket.

Latif has not played a Test in three years since he came home from a tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe and accused his team-mates, a number of whom are still in the side, of match fixing.

Not least among them are Wasim, who after the investigation by Justice Malik Qayyum was fined and banned from captaining his country again, and Waqar, who was deemed to be guilty of "amnesia" under questioning.

Finally, the vice-captain of the side is Inzamam-ul-Haq, a batsman who can have you gasping at his talent and clutching your ribs at his ineptitude in the course of the same innings. This is the fellow who sits in a comfy chair while his team-mates flog their way through training sessions and fielding drills and who once, during a match in Canada, waded into the crowd, wielding a cricket bat, in pursuit of a spectator who called him a potato. He does not want Wasim there, either.

Genuinely, one could not make this lot up.

But the relationship between Waqar and Wasim is the intriguing one. Wasim, unquestionably, is a genius, the only player to have taken more than 400 wickets in both the long and short form of international cricket. His partnership with Waqar was arguably the most devastating of all time, with more wickets taken as an opening combination than any other, although they were especially productive when the ball was old and reverse swinging. Waqar, for his part, has 319 wickets and a remarkable strike rate of a wicket per roughly 43 balls.

He maintains he would have had a shed-load more victims, too, if Wasim, during his own tenure(s) as captain, particularly the last one, had not ignored him where possible.

In 1993 Waqar was at the centre of a players' revolt against Wasim who, he believes, has been determined to get even ever since. During the 1999 World Cup, in which Pakistan reached the final, Waqar played only one match after the side had qualified for the later stages and was pointedly ignored for much of the subsequent tour of Australia.

For this tour Waqar could make out a genuine case, as opposed to one based purely on antipathy, for not including Wasim, who has performed sporadically in recent years and has become increasingly prone to injury.

Now, though, he has been imposed upon him in the worst possible way, by the casting vote of Tauqir Zia, against Waqar's vehement wishes and by some accounts following intervention from Imran.

Not that Wasim will get a game if Waqar has his way. "I cannot assure him a place in the side for the first Test," the new captain said on Sunday. "I would like to play Shoaib Akhtar, Mohammad Sami, Abdur Razzaq and Saqlain Mushtaq." So, Wasim has had his card marked. As for the rest of the team, they will do what they always do which is give us a thrilling time. So light the blue touchpaper, sit back and watch the fireworks.

webTitle: Cricket: Stylish Welton better late than never

fields.headline: Stylish Welton better late than never
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 170
Nottinghamshire 174-2

Nottinghamshire won by eight wickets
fields.trailText: For Nottinghamshire the only way in the Benson & Hedges Cup is up. They have the worst recent record of any of the 18 first-class counties, having failed to reach the quarter- finals since 1995, and last year lost four of their group games and had the fifth washed out.
fields.body:
For Nottinghamshire the only way in the Benson & Hedges Cup is up. They have the worst recent record of any of the 18 first-class counties, having failed to reach the quarter- finals since 1995, and last year lost four of their group games and had the fifth washed out.

But that meant nothing to Guy Welton, their 22-year-old opener and former Grimsby Town youth trainee, who had not played a B&H match in his four years on the Trent Bridge staff until yesterday. He earned the gold award with 71 from 76 balls as Notts cruised past a modest Leicestershire total with almost 20 of their 50 overs to spare.

Welton played with style from the off, although he did receive one stroke of luck in the sixth over when James Ormond found his outside edge but Daniel Marsh could not take a difficult chance low to his left at second slip. Ormond ended an opening stand of 57 by bowling Darren Bicknell but Greg Blewett joined Welton, adding 78 in 13 overs and only 42 minutes for the second wicket, and the game was in the bag.

Welton stroked eight fours and pulled Billy Stelling's innocuous medium pace for a six in his 76-ball innings until Devon Malcolm had him caught at mid-off with the first ball of his second spell.

Blewett, who seems to have settled in quickly at Nottingham following his miserable time with Yorkshire two years ago, followed his championship century against Durham last week with a rapid unbeaten 59 which included a straight six off his compatriot Marsh, while Malcolm beat off stiff competition to be the most expensive Leicestershire bowler.

The visitors had not batted well either, despite establishing the reasonable platform of 117 for three thanks to a typically efficient 51 from Ben Smith. They collapsed after Smith was called for a quick single by Darren Maddy only to be run out by the bowler Richard Logan's direct underarm hit.

Two balls later Logan, a winter signing from Northamptonshire who ended with two for 19 from his 10 overs, nipped a ball through Aftab Habib's defence and in the next over Neil Burns wandered down the pitch to the South African off-spinner Kevin Pietersen to hand Chris Read a straightforward stumping. Greg Smith then mopped up the tail for figures of four for 34.

webTitle: Cricket: Lehmann thrills without the frills

fields.headline: Lehmann thrills without the frills
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 200-8
Yorkshire 203-5
Yorkshire won by five wickets
fields.trailText: Beneath the concrete shadow of the unfinished Western terrace stood a figure just as imposing. Darren Lehmann possesses a walloping solidity that Yorkshire have come to depend upon, a batsman with no frills, forearms like steel girders and a foreman's determination to get the job done.
fields.body:
Beneath the concrete shadow of the unfinished Western terrace stood a figure just as imposing. Darren Lehmann possesses a walloping solidity that Yorkshire have come to depend upon, a batsman with no frills, forearms like steel girders and a foreman's determination to get the job done.

To beat Yorkshire, dismiss Lehmann cheaply. Otherwise, do not even contemplate success. His threat, especially in one-day cricket, is vast; his strokes burst with a hard-hatted belligerence. A target of 201 was far from straightforward, especially with three Yorkshire wickets falling for 36, and with Dominic Cork, approaching his familiar verve after recovering from back trouble, imagining that his star had not dimmed from the moment that his fourth ball disturbed Michael Vaughan's stumps.

Lehmann's response was 103 in 114 balls. He reshaped the match with a stand of 118 in 25 overs with Gary Fellows, took 13 off one over from Richard Illingworth to announce the charge had begun and dashed to his hundred at the death with three boundaries in a row off Paul Aldred, among them a punishing square-leg six that gave an unofficial hammer test to the echoing stand . He was out next ball, caught at midwicket as he tried to slog the winning hit.

If Lehmann's offence at his omission from Australia's one-day side fires him to sharper selectivity of stroke, this crude concrete bowl might yet sound to celebration of a Yorkshire Lord's final. It is rising much in fading Yorkshire stereotype - forbidding, entirely lacking in innovation and immensely communal. Lehmann is bound to make it smile.

There was a wildness about Yorkshire's pace attack that, against a better side than Derbyshire, might have put them out of the match. Chris Silverwood and Gavin Hamilton were off beam and, without a serendipitous debut from Tom Baker, a strapping 19-year-old seamer from Spen Victoria, and a composed spell of off-spin from Vaughan, the match could have run out of reach.

Baker's debut was launched with a wide and a mental note to pull himself together but his first legitimate Yorkshire delivery, a swinging full toss, trapped Steve Stubbings leg- before. He briefly reappeared later to remove Karl Krikken at backward point.

There could even be other benefits. Given Yorkshire's perpetual urge to travel back to a more glorious era, a chap called Tom Baker might at least be able to get hold of a second-hand time machine.

The catch that accounted for Krikken, by Anthony McGrath, was one of three deft Yorkshire efforts to keep the Derbyshire innings in check, with David Byas clinging to Cork's stinging offering and Vaughan equally adept as Luke Sutton thrashed to backward point. It left the door ajar for Lehmann and he marched through it.

webTitle: Cricket: Bichel shows three strings to his bow

fields.headline: Bichel shows three strings to his bow
fields.standfirst:
Worcestershire 227
Northamptonshire 131
Worcestershire won by 96 runs
fields.trailText: Northamptonshire's batsmen came and went quicker than the suburban trains that rattled past on their way to Stourbridge Junction. It was all over, with nearly 13 overs to spare, as Worcestershire won by 96 runs.
fields.body:
Northamptonshire's batsmen came and went quicker than the suburban trains that rattled past on their way to Stourbridge Junction. It was all over, with nearly 13 overs to spare, as Worcestershire won by 96 runs.

Kidderminster has often been a good friend to Worcestershire and in mid-summer the track is traditionally full of runs. Here the old established Birmingham League club had rallied, with a minimum of notice though spontaneous enthusiasm, to come to the county's aid when New Road, always battered more than most grounds by storms and floods, was declared unplayable.

Not that stroke-making here was particularly easy. Worcestershire won the toss and chose to bat. It may have appeared a questionable decision as Anurag Singh went without offering a shot and Graeme Hick soon followed, leg-before as the ball stayed low. Both batsmen went to Darren Cousins, broad-shoul dered and uncomplicated. His first eight overs cost a cheese-paring 10 runs; he came back to take two more wickets.

But Paul Pollard and David Leatherdale gave Worcestershire some substance. The left-handed Pollard was fourth out, especially well caught in the covers by Russell Warren after an innings of 69 that brought him his first one-day match award. Leatherdale was brisker with his half-century, piercing the off-side when the line strayed. In between, the Queenslander Andrew Bichel was in an attractive hurry, out to long-on as he searched for his third boundary in a row off John Blain, who was making his delayed - and expensive - return after a back operation and two years' absence.

Northants never really suggested a realistic response. Jeff Cook stayed for a time until he spooned to mid-on, caught in two minds. Graeme Swann briefly threatened before he snatched at a short-pitched ball and hooked to the boundary fielder. He had hit two sixes in an over from Leatherdale with an abandon that would have pleased the smiter Arthur Wellard, once Kidderminster's pro after leaving Somerset.

But there were too many submissive shots, like that of Kevin Innes to Bichel, who was kept occupied in the field and no doubt surprised by the willingness of some county players to sacrifice their wickets. The newcomer took three, to complement his fielding practice.

Alamgir Sheriyar had not been expected to stay with Worcestershire this season. But he has a much more controlled delivery now and this could be a productive summer for the pacy left-arm seamer.

fields.headline: Did Things Get Better?
fields.trailText: David Walker analyses Labour's contradictions of the past four years and concludes that it is indifference which has won the day.
fields.body:
A Guardian/ICM poll taken in February 2001 showed that Labour in power had one remarkable achievement under its belt. It had educated the public to think it was as fiscally continent as the Tories. In February 1997 49% of those polled believed that once Labour came to power it would spend more than the Tories. Four years later that figure was 24%. Indeed, more people believed the Tories would spend more if they achieved office.

This turnaround stemmed from Labour's key promise in the run-up to the 1997 election: to stick to Tory spending plans for the first two years. Perhaps it was "existentially" necessary to sunder Labour from its past. But from it grew an enervating sense of disappointment in Labour ranks and among the public at large. Where, people asked, were the better schools and surgeries they thought Labour would build - though Labour's formal promises in 1997 promised nothing of the kind.

Besides, only a third of the public actually cast their ballots for Tony Blair in 1997, which might imply that most people had willed either the status quo or minimal change. None the less the buzz had been that Labour would be better for public services and, though that has eventually been proved to be true, the differences after four years are not as dramatic as expected. They couldn't be when, in aggregate, the UK state as a proportion of GDP declined. In John Major's last year the ratio of government spending to GDP was 41.2. It will still be less than that (40.6%) when Gordon Brown's extensive spending plans are realised by March 2004. The economy, of course, is growing so the physical resources available for public services will expand. Still, Labour's Third Way has not been a bonanza for public services. Blairism offered no fundamental recalibration of the importance of government in our society or economy.

The first Blair government has been busy. Its large majority tramped through the lobbies passing a raft of laws. A book could be written enumerating the policy initiatives and plans, made and accomplished. (We wrote it)

An audit of the Blair term might note, first, that there are no signs of improvement on what Labour ministers themselves identified as the battleground of modern governance: productivity. On it depends the capacity of the economy to break through the limits that have kept annual growth below 3%. Labour no longer believes the state should own significant economic assets nor plan in any traditional sense. Its main job is making markets more competitive, pulling down barriers to trade and improving the quality of the factors of production.

But government can aid science and research, in so doing improving capital, and above all it can educate and train. Labour would say that it has. The Blair cabinet can notch up improved educational attainments in the primary sector and continuing improvements at exams for 16- and 18-year-olds. The expansion of higher education has continued, unimpeded by Labour's introduction of university tuition charges and the abolition of student maintenance grants. A start has been made on reshaping vocational education. But British productivity rates remain below those in both the United States and the allegedly bloated welfare states of France and Germany.

Fearful of saying anything remotely critical about business or the British system of free enterprise, Labour ministers were never heard to speculate about one possible reason - deformations in the business culture and corporate sector. Instead the chancellor, Gordon Brown, led a chorus extolling enterprise, blaming culture for being insufficiently attuned to economic opportunity, but never addressing the structure of economic power as a possible cause of under-achievement.

But if Labour did not affect such fundamentals as productivity, it did manage to accomplish some traditional goals of socialism, including making Britain a fairer place. Changes were small in scale but noteworthy. The combined impact of Labour's changes in tax and social security increased the income of the bottom 10th of households by some 8%, over £8 a week, and it cut the income of the richest 10th by 0.5%, or £4.74 a week. Economic growth (2.6% on average since 1997) may have pulled the income distribution at large into an even more unequal shape. Labour's measures hindered rather than helped that outcome.

A ledger of achievements is hard to compile because Labour policies often contradicted each other. For example, in fulfilment of a 1997 manifesto promise, Gordon Brown cut VAT on domestic fuel to 5%: in other words, he encouraged the consumption of fossil fuels. His levy on climate change, due to be introduced in April 2001, is meant to do the opposite. It was bitterly resisted by industrialists, though it will be critical in cutting emissions of greenhouse gases in line with promises made at the Kyoto summit. Devolution of power to the new parliament in Edinburgh and, to a lesser extent, the Cardiff assembly was not accompanied by reform at Westminster. The creation of a London mayor and assembly was not matched by a coherent reappraisal of Whitehall's relationship with elective local government in England. A "liberal" approach to matters of sexual orientation led Labour to equalise the age of consent and seek the abolition of Section 28 (accomplished by the Scottish parliament but not at Westminster, after the conservative majority in the House of Lords mobilised).

A "progressive" approach to justice for young people was accompanied by a punitive policy for adult offenders leading to a 6,000-person increase in the prison population from 1997 onwards, even though no greater number of criminals was being caught. A muscular determination to uphold human rights in the Balkans did not prevent Labour pursuing commercial opportunities in China, despite the regime's record. The reconfiguration of the UK's defence after a widely praised review still left room for procurement decisions that had more to do with trade and constituency interest than military posture.

The social account is especially full, in principle as much as in practice. The various New Deals promised that nobody was going to be left out of the labour market. The Sure Start programme was introduced for poor young children; the incomes of poor families with children were greatly augmented; and money was found for pensioners, not across the board but concentrated on the poorest.

Schools, especially primaries, have been given new focus and teachers are returning to the public's esteem. After April 2001, teachers' salaries will reflect that rising esteem.

At work Labour established the minimum wage and for the first time gave workers a formal right to belong to a trade union.

Of course all judgements must be interim. The great spending increase announced in July 2000 only comes on stream in April 2001. Tony Blair liked to point out how little Margaret Thatcher accomplished in her first term - she had barely thought of privatisation. But if Thatcherism was invented on the run, Labour has shown a dismaying unwillingness to rethink the dogmas it acquired in opposition: what else explains Gordon Brown's insistence on privatisation schemes for air traffic control and the London Underground?

The watchword of a second Labour terms seems to be "delivery". But Blairite ministers did not show much interest in the nuts and bolts of public administration, especially the role of elected local authorities in providing "national" services. Expectations have been built up, despite the comparatively modest increment in public spending to meet them.

This raises a wider question about government. The Blair government did little or nothing to counter the trend towards a lack of confidence in public officials. Early scandals increased the public's cynicism. The shady dealings of Ecclestone, Robinson, Mandelson et al, soured the atmosphere further. It quickly felt like business as usual. Indifference and suspicion spread through bus queues, wine bars and pubs and were picked up with growing alarm by Labour in its own focus groups.

John Dunn, the Cambridge political theorist, speculated that Western politics in this post-socialist, post cold war age was going to be "irritable, reactive and myopic: endlessly saturated with ressentiment." Is there a better way of describing public feeling during the September 2000 fuel protests? The proportion of people expressing attachment to a political party continued to fall. Voters may feel that representative institutions themselves are weakening and little that the Blair government has done, devolution included, seems likely to arrest the trend.

Perhaps the government's economic success is a contributory factor. We are losing confidence in political leaders because we no longer think we need them, in the economic realm above all. The view may rest on a mistaken short term idea that macro economic problems have been "solved". Formerly the left wanted the state to intervene and steer the economic ship. The right resented government, but neither side denied its capacity or importance. Now in the age of the Third Way, that has been replaced by indifference.

 David Walker is editor of the Guardian's analysis page and joint author of Did Things Get Better? - An Audit of Labour's Successes and Failures (Penguin £6.99).

fields.headline: Jackson sets out Channel 4 spending plans
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: The channel is to invest more than £200m in digital and online services, reports Jason Deans.
27.04.2001: Elstein lambasts Channel 4
Useful link: www.channel4.com
fields.body:
Michael Jackson, the Channel 4 chief executive, has defended the broadcaster's plan to invest more than £200m in digital TV and online services.

Mr Jackson said the amount invested in the new services - as a proportion of total Channel 4 expenditure - was 4% last year and would rise to 10% in 2001.

However, the investment would not go above 10% of total spending on an annual basis.

"I think 10% is a pretty sensible and scalable amount of money," he said today as he unveiled Channel 4's annual report and accounts for 2000.

"If we weren't investing this money in new services, I think people would be asking questions."

The £200m-plus investment will go on projects such as the pay-TV entertainment service, E4, which launched in January.

A sum of £80m has been set aside to help E4 break even. Of that, £40m is expected to be invested in the service this year, with another £20m to be spent in 2002. The remainder will be spread over subsequent years.

E4 is expected to break even in 2005.

Another £60m has been set aside to enable Film Four to break even.

The film channel, which launched in late 1998 and now has around 450,000 paying customers, is "about half way" to the 800,000 subscribers it needs to go into operating profit, according to the Channel 4 managing director, David Scott.

Channel 4 will spend £23m on its internet ventures this year.

Another £23m investment is planned over the next 10 years as part of the channel's involvement in the horseracing media rights joint venture, Go Racing.

Mr Jackson said the amount invested in the new services - as a proportion of total Channel 4 expenditure - was 4% last year and would rise to 10% in 2001. "I think 10% is a pretty sensible and scalable amount of money," he said today as he unveiled Channel 4's annual report and accounts for 2000. "If we weren't investing this money in new services, I think people would be asking questions." webTitle: 2020 vision: London braced for pro-capitalism demonstrations

fields.headline: 2020 vision: London braced for pro-capitalism demonstrations
fields.standfirst:
May 1, 2020
20 years after Britain's creaking capitalist system was replaced by eco-communitarianism during the 2001 May Day revolution, pro-monetarist dissidents are taking to the streets to protest against green transport and ethical world trade. Derek Brown reports

Historic link: Special report: Mayday 2001
fields.trailText: In the highly unlikely event that today's May Day protests are successful in bringing down UK capitalism, Derek Brown imagines what an eco-communitarian Britain of the future might look like.
fields.body:
Thousands of community police thronged the centre of London as pro-free market protesters converged on the capital today.

There were no reports of arrests or violence as the first wave of demonstrators slowly drove their cars along the city's cycle ways.

Metropolitan community police commissioner Errol Winston dismissed rumours that his mostly female force would use the controversial virtual rubber bullet system if the demonstration grew violent.

There have also been reports, dismissed by the authorities, that the police may use high-volume broadcasts of songs by Dame Kylie Minogue to break up the rallies - a tactic which experts warn could cause lasting brain damage.

"We have no need of these draconian methods," said an MPC spokesperson. "We hope that the demonstration will be peaceful, but if it isn't, we will be relying on proven community police techniques, like issuing quite stern warnings."

As the demonstrators gathered in grounds of the People's Rest Home at the western end of the Mall, the mood was determined.

One pro-capitalism protester, dressed provocatively in a three-piece suit with a collar and tie, told Guardian Unlimited that politicians and police had exaggerated the risk of confrontation.

"We haven't come here looking for trouble," he said. "Of course you will always get a lunatic fringe element, like the people who want to bring back the Conservative party, but they are a tiny minority."

As he spoke, there was a ragged cheer from the crowd and a chant of "What do we want? Individual savings accounts! When do we want 'em? Now!"

The prime minister, Leo Blair, repeated his appeal for calm and restraint on all sides, while offering total support to the police.

Echoing his famous father's rallying cry, he added: "You know, we really have to be sensible about this. I mean, if we were not, it wouldn't be, you know, sensible."

The demonstrations have attracted widespread interest abroad. In Brussels, United States of Europe officials are assessing the damage that the protests might do to Britain's prospects of finally joining the euro zone.

One source said the disruption to the largely rural British economy could knock the value of the pound, now standing at an all-time low of £56,250 to the euro.

In Washington, President George Bush III has reiterated his offer to buy Britain, and turn it into what he calls a "thematically themed theme park".

webTitle: Charity Commission seeks new PR chief

fields.headline: Charity Commission seeks new PR chief
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: The Charity Commission is on the hunt for a new head of communications as Paul Fredericks moves to a new post, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Charity Commission is on the hunt for a new head of communications as Paul Fredericks moves to a new post within the organisation.

Mr Fredericks has held the post of head of communications at the government department that supports and monitors charities for the past five years.

He is taking up a newly created job to develop the commission's investigative function that investigates complaints about charities.

The new head of communications will be responsible for increasing awareness of the commission, liaising with the media, Parliament, the public and charities and delivering its regulatory messages.

The position reports to the director of operations and alongside the press office team.

fields.headline: Grossman serves up new shows at Taste
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Former BBC TV chef Loyd Grossman has found a new home at Taste, Carlton's joint venture TV channel with Sainsbury's. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The former BBC TV chef, Loyd Grossman, has found a new home at Taste, Carlton's new joint venture TV channel with Sainsbury's.

The vowel-challenged, posh American has joined Taste, the channel formerly known as Carlton Food Network, to launch a nationwide search for a new TV chef superstar.

Aspiring TV chefs are being asked to register, either throught Taste.co.uk or at Sainsbury's stores, and answer three food-related questions.

Wanabees also have to tell Taste in 50 words why they want the job.

The next stage is a Masterchef-style regional "cook-off" competition. Winners will then go on to compete in the televised Taste Cook of the Year finals.

"We're looking for a mastery of the basics, an in-depth knowledge of the kitchen and food, and most importantly, bags of creativity while having the ability to be graceful under pressure," said Grossman.

"The winner is also going to need enough star quality and charisma to be the host of a television show."

Grossman, who left the BBC in a huff at the end of last year, will be a prominent feature at Taste.

He will also host a show called Loyd on Location, in which he travels the globe and samples local specialities, as well as a weekly show profiling London's up-and-coming culinary talent called New Chefs on the Block.

After 10 years with Masterchef, Grossman quit when it was announced the show was to move from BBC1 to BBC2.

He described the decision to move the show as "totally moronic".

Grossman was signed up by the NHS to improve hospital food, but his two-year deal with the esoteric Taste should mean his irrepressible pontificators reach an even smaller audience than on BBC2.

Taste CFN refused to reveal financial terms of the contract.

fields.headline: Adverts bank on real people for success
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera have been beaten to the top of the advert charts by ordinary bank staff.
fields.body:
Pop divas Britney Spears and Christina Aguilera have been beaten to the top of the advert charts - by ordinary people working in a bank, a survey revealed today.

Halifax's real people TV campaign, which featured members of staff singing the company's message to pop songs, created more interest than any celebrity could muster, the findings claimed.

The bank generated more press coverage by using three of its workers than model Sophie Dahl's controversial naked billboard and magazine campaign for Opium perfume, it was discovered.

And it even managed to score points against former football star and Match of the Day presenter Gary Lineker's latest campaign for Walkers crisps.

Halifax said it was "delighted" with the findings from the latest Ads That Make News Survey covering the first quarter of this year.

Its set of three commercials have made household faces, if not names, of all its "stars". Birmingham customer services adviser Howard Brown hit the right note by advertising the bank's current account to a version of Tom Jones's Sex Bomb.

Yvonne McBride, an adviser in Belfast, was then on song to push the company's credit card to Ricky Martin's Living La Vida Loca with Halifax-based IT expert Matt Thornfield completing the trio of advertisements to the tune of The Baha Men's number one smash Who Let the Dogs Out.

Halifax spokeswoman Alison Kellington said the singing workers were picked from 700 members of staff who auditioned for the adverts last year before jetting off to exotic locations to film the 30-second commercials.

"All the tunes were catchy and I think people have found it fascinating to see normal people doing a job which is usually done by a famous actor or model," she said.

Nick Fitzherbert, director of Propeller Marketing Communications which carried out the survey, said Halifax's campaign generated 17 stories in the national press, more than any of its rivals.

"While two pop queens going head to head to advertise the world's biggest brands of soft drinks is guaranteed to create headlines, real people in the media are now capturing the public's imagination in the same way that we have seen on TV with the success of Big Brother and the various docu-soap programmes," he said.

However, he warned that interest-generating campaigns are not always a recipe for success. "Barclays featured strongly in previous surveys, but mainly because of the negative news coverage resulting from its big bank for a big world campaign which coincided with a closure programme for rural branches."

The top eight Ads That Make News for the three months to March were as follows (figures in brackets indicate how many stories each one generated):

1 Halifax (17)
2 Pepsi featuring Britney Spears (15)
3 Coke featuring Christina Aguilera (15)
4 Opium featuring Sophie Dahl (12)
5 Queercompany Thank God for women posters (8)
6 Martin Amis's Autobiography (7)
7 Walkers Crisps latest Gary Lineker treatment (6)

fields.headline: Waitrose unveils £2.5m advertising
fields.standfirst: See the ads (Real movie)
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Waitrose will this week launch its first-ever TV advertising, two months after postponing the campaign due to foot and mouth. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Waitrose will this week launch its first-ever TV advertising, nearly two months after it postponed the campaign due to the outbreak of foot and mouth.

The supermarket giant had been due to launch the advertising in March. But it decided to delay the multimillion pound campaign because one of the three adverts focused on a herd of cows that produce milk for Waitrose - a subject deemed too sensitive at the time.

Waitrose has won many plaudits for its print advertising, created by its agency, Banks Hoggins O'Shea/FCB, but has never advertised on TV before.

The £2.5m campaign will be in the same vein as the press adverts, which emphasise the quality of Waitrose products with the slogan, "Waitrose - quality food, honestly priced".

The advert for Waitrose milk shows a tanker travelling through green countryside and boasts how "only one supermarket knows every farm and farmer that supplies every pint of its fresh milk".

The Waitrose managing director, David Felwick, said the campaign came as the chain, which employs 27,000 workers and has 136 stores nationwide, announced a first quarter rise of 14% on £2bn-a-year sales in the three months to the end of April.

"We decided to break with tradition because we now feel it is a wider audience which should hear our message," he said.

"Our TV campaign helps to explain the Waitrose difference. The Food Standards Agency has shown that three-quarters of consumers are concerned about food safety and we are showing how we are first for freshness, attention to detail, quality and value."

fields.headline: May Day could cost millions
fields.standfirst: Special report: May Day
fields.trailText: The cost of the May Day protests could run to several million pounds - even if it remains peaceful, it emerged today.
fields.body:
The cost of the May Day protests could run to several million pounds - even if it remains peaceful, it emerged today.

The total bill will include lost business for stores that stayed closed, pay for thousands of extra police officers and money spent on cleaners brought in to deal with the expected mess.

A fifth of all stores on Oxford Street were boarded up as shopkeepers feared an outbreak of anti-capitalist violence. Nike Town was shut after police warned the sportswear firm that its main London store risked an "invasion" attempt by protesters. Other shops on the street were expected to close early because of fears of violence later in the day.

Many workers at City firms were also advised not to come in to work unless absolutely necessary.

The biggest expenditure was expected to be for the 6,000 police officers drafted in to deal with the protests. Last year providing extra officers was reported to have cost the Met £3m. Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens said the cost could be less this year because it is not a public holiday.

Westminster council has spent £50,000 on extra cleaning operations, with staff and equipment drafted in to move rubbish accumulated during the day, including material which could be used as weapons by violent protesters.

Extra resources were also put on standby for the expected clear-up after the demonstration.

webTitle: Bush prepares world for missile defence

fields.headline: Bush prepares world for missile defence
fields.standfirst:
After wrecking Kyoto and outraging the whole world, the US president is trying a (slightly) more careful approach over his pet son on star wars project, explains Mark Tran

George Bush's America
fields.trailText: After wrecking Kyoto and outraging the whole world, the US president is trying a (slightly) more careful approach over his pet son on star wars project, explains Mark Tran.
fields.body:
President George Bush will today set the US on a radically new course in nuclear strategy when he announces plans for a national missile defence (NMD) system.

Mindful of how he rubbed his European allies up the wrong way by dumping the Kyoto climate change accord without any warning, Mr Bush has been more careful this time.

Phone calls have been placed to key allies, including Britain and France, and senior officials will fan out over Europe to make the case for a missile shield.

But these consultations are mostly theatre. The US is determined to press ahead with its grandiose scheme, whatever the rest of the world says. It is of a piece of the administration's high-handedness as Mr Bush deploys his wrecking crew on international accords.

Kyoto has already gone by the wayside, now it will be the turn of the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, which bans national missile defences and has served as one of the crucial underpinnings of arms control.

Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, was breezily dismissive of the ABM accord, saying: "It doesn't describe the current world and will get in the way of our pursuing promises avenues before us."

For the US, the main threat is no longer a nuclear attack from Russia, but missiles from "rogue" states such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq, or accidental missile launches.

These assumptions are ridiculous. Rogue states are more likely to resort to middlemen who will plant bombs in the New York subway or at the World Trade Centre than to face a massive retaliatory attack.

The idea of an accidental launch seems even more fanciful. Mr Bush envisages a much more ambitious system than the limited defence system that was begun under Bill Clinton.

This will be a "multilayered shield, using sea and space-based radars, lasers and interceptors that harks back to the "star wars" system that Ronald Reagan wanted.

To sweeten the pill for opponents of NMD, the US has said it will make deep cuts in its current nuclear arsenal of 7,500 warheads by up to two-thirds. Russia currently has 5,000 warheads, while China has 100.

President Vladimir Putin of Russia has since toned down Moscow's objections to NMD, but is holding out for more concessions for scrapping the ABM treaty. China is likely to be more obdurate and may react by simply speeding up its fledgling ballistic missile force.

Europe is divided. France vehemently opposes NMD, but Britain has agreed to play its role as part of the early advanced warning system with the US facility at Fylingdales in north Yorkshire.

Apart from political opposition, scepticism abounds as to whether it will work. Last year, 50 Nobel laureates sent a letter to Mr Bush warning against missile defence deployment, calling it "premature, wasteful and dangerous".

They argued that the chances of destroying a missile protected by decoys and other countermeasures would face enormous challenges. Tests carried out so far bear out their reservations; out of 17 tests, only three have been successful.

The administration has no time for such doubting Thomases. Filled with ardent proponents of NMD, it will be all boosters on go. Mindful of how he rubbed his European allies up the wrong way by dumping the Kyoto climate change accord without any warning, Mr Bush has been more careful this time. It is of a piece of the administration's high-handedness as Mr Bush deploys his wrecking crew on international accords. webTitle: Asian youths arrested over attack on war vet

fields.headline: Asian youths arrested over attack on war vet
fields.standfirst:
Police investigating an alleged racist attack on a 76-year-old war veteran in Oldham have arrested four Asian schoolboys

Special report: Race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Police investigating an alleged racist attack on a 76-year-old war veteran in Oldham have arrested four Asian schoolboys.
fields.body:
Police investigating an alleged racist attack on a 76-year-old war veteran in Oldham have arrested four Asian schoolboys.

The youths, two aged 14 and two aged 15, have been arrested in the Westwood area of Oldham. They are being held at Chadderton police station and will be interviewed by officers later today, police said.

Walter Chamberlain was beaten by a gang of Asian youths as he walked to his home in Oldham, Greater Manchester, on Saturday, April 21. His attackers dragged him to the ground, kicked him in the face and battered him with a coffee flask he had been carrying, breaking his cheekbones. They told him to "get out of our area". The attack left him requiring surgery to his face.

Police are treating the attack on Mr Chamberlain, who served on minesweepers during his time in the royal navy and took part in the D-Day landings, as racist.

fields.headline: Oil giants take over exchange
fields.standfirst: International petroleum market to switch to electronic trading after Shell and BP seize control
fields.trailText: Shell and BP have seized effective control of the International Petroleum Exchange, where much of the world's crude oil is traded, via an estimated $130m (£90m) takeover through the InterContinental Exchange (Ice).
fields.body:
Shell and BP have seized effective control of the International Petroleum Exchange, where much of the world's crude oil is traded, via an estimated $130m (£90m) takeover through the InterContinental Exchange (Ice).

The two companies - the second and third largest oil majors globally - are shareholders in Ice alongside TotalFinaElf and four investment banks, including Deutsche and Goldman Sachs.

The deal - agreed between boards - means closure of the IPE's traditional trading pit with its floor dealers in brightly coloured jackets in favour of Ice's 24-hour electronic transactions using the internet.

IPE chairman Sir Bob Reid, who will join the Ice board along with his chief executive Richard Ward, said the Ice proposal offered substantial gains for shareholders.

But added: "The primary advantage arises from the creation of a global network, which brings strength and opportunity. To be absent from such a development would mean failing to secure the exchange's long-term future."

The exchange denied ownership by a company dominated by major oil companies would compromise the independence and integrity of the marketplace.

An IPE spokesman said: "I am not aware of any significant concerns in this area."

Ice was established last year and has already caused unease among small players because it is not seen as independent. Neither BP, Shell nor Ice were willing to give details of the ownership structure.

A BP spokeswoman said: "We have not made this (our shareholding) public", while Shell suggested inquiries be addressed to Ice. A spokeswoman for that organisation added: "Ice is a private company and this (its shareholding) is not public information."

The takeover brings together the IPE's futures contracts, including its benchmark Brent crude, with Atlanta-based Ice's over-the-counter energy derivative products.

Jeffrey Sprecher, chief executive of Ice, said: "The combination of Ice's state-of-the-art technology platform, growing volumes and committed shareholder base with the IPE's established liquidity and brand name makes this an extremely attractive transaction."

The offer requires 50% approval from IPE shareholders, who number 100, mainly with small stakes of 1.19%. Mr Reid said he foresaw no trouble with regulators.

The deal is a mix of cash and shares with a basic $67.5m plus shares in Ice equity, which is valued by accountant KPMG at around a similar amount. Ice will pay shareholders "B" class shares worth $5.895 - redeemable one year after IPE contracts trade exclusively electronically for 10 days.

IPE shareholders, which include BP (1.19%) and Shell (1.19%), will also receive an equal number of "A" class shares in Ice, putting the value of the one-year-old internet venture at a notional $1.35bn.

webTitle: Hugo Young on the euro referendum

fields.headline: After the election it's full steam ahead for the euro
fields.standfirst:
A referendum is no longer in doubt; the question now is how soon it will be

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: A referendum is no longer in doubt; the question now is how soon it will be.
fields.body:
The impression that there will not be a referendum on Britain's entry into the euro for the next five years reaches wide and high. One permanent secretary, a strong Europhile, told me not long ago that there wasn't a chance of the pound being abolished for the next decade. Top people at the Bank of England say the same. When EU reform proposals emerge, such as yesterday's from Gerhard Schröder's SPD, caricatured with the unfailing factual deficiency of the British media as building-blocks for a superstate, these mordant witnesses are confirmed in their belief that Tony Blair will duck the euro-crunch for the indefinite future.

This belief rests on a mass of historic evidence about politicians. Political leaders seldom take life-threatening gambles that are not forced upon them. In this case, though, the hoary seers are out of touch. They underestimate the prime minister's commitment. They also, probably, misread a shift in Gordon Brown's position. It remains to be seen how much Europe gets into the election campaign. Maybe rather little. But what happens after that will be seismic. It grows out of an analysis that's far deeper than Mr Blair, trapped in domestic crisis-management for the last nine months, has yet chosen to explain.

He sees the Europe question with ever greater clarity, and will make it his prime preoccupation, alongside public service reform, immediately the next term begins. June 8 is ground zero for Britain-in-Europe. Entry into the euro has become in Blair's mind a destiny question, for Britain and himself. Even the size of the majority is insignificant beside it. Those who say a three-figure majority must surely be a precondition for the gamble are rebutted with the assertion that a single-figure lead would be enough. But that's an academic point. The majority will not be single figures. Anticipating a much larger one, Blair is beginning to assemble a critical mass of momentum for the policy which, in 1997, he declared against: a purposeful campaign for swift entry into the single currency.

The economics, for a start, are converging. With an interest rate gap of barely 1%, euro-land looks more congenial. The economic bedrock has always been vital, not just a verbal sideshow. Sceptics will find some reason to challenge the economics for the next several decades, but for anyone else the time is getting as ripe as it will ever be. The notion, incidentally, that the economic assessment will be made exclusively by the Treasury is self-serving poppycock. The prime minister will be closely engaged.

The politics also are ripening. Urgency begins to press. The debate about the future of Europe, to which the German SPD paper is an early contribution, reaches climax in 2004. The next EU presidency, held by Belgium, will coincide with the likely launch of Britain's euro debate, and is a matter of some alarm to the Brits. They see the Belgians accelerating the 2004 process along integrationist lines. When Blair met the Belgian prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, last week it was in the hope of deflecting the kind of centralising and harmonising proposals canvassed also by the Germans.

However divided the EU may be about that trend, it's certain to keep on intruding into the 2004 debate. This poses problems for a British leader who has a different vision, yet knows that his chances of winning allies for it will be much diminished by the UK's absence from Europe's central project. My impression is that he has a chance to finesse his way around that. But it's the last one. The Euro-centralisers, all of whom want Britain in the euro, may be prepared to delay and soften their ambitions, but only on one condition: that Blair gets off the fence and commits to a critical path towards a referendum, probably next year.

This plays into another crucial circumstance, which again compels the British leader towards an early decision. The euro and its political structures are not static. The evolution of the EU, with enlargement coming, will continue. It will be, in some measure, integrationist, though the methodology is debated. It will make the EU progressively more objectionable to the same nationalist forces that dominate the British press now. The longer that hiatus lasts, with Britain clinging to the margin and still postponing the decisive referendum, the harder it will be to win any contest - after five more years of baleful propaganda that deepens British anti-Europeanism and exposes Blair to ridicule for another term of feeble indecision.

So tactical preparations are being made. People in Downing Street and the Cabinet Office are sketching the path, phase by phase, to a referendum, drafting words that might be said on June 8, at the Labour party conference, on a series of other landmark dates in the next nine months. More important is a looming shift in the psychodrama: a strategic undertaking to frontally address the intimidatory power of the Murdoch, Rothermere and Black press, and sweep it aside. That doesn't mean the papers can be ignored. Their arguments have to be taken seriously and countered. But the fact of deciding to hold the referendum will remove one of the most potent elements in this enduring political stand-off: the belief that, because the sceptic grip on the press is so tight, and the polling evidence so unfavourable, Blair wouldn't have the nerve to presume he might overturn both factors.

How he may go about this I'll discuss on Thursday. Before he gets there, he has colleagues to consider. Most of the cabinet will be less sanguine than he is, though none is a Eurosceptic. He evidently doesn't expect to have any difficulty in bringing them in behind him, especially if he does get the large majority. There's only one colleague who matters. But he does matter a great deal.

Gordon Brown's role in the saga has been enigmatic. To an extent, it still is. He's as jealous of his economic power as he is of his political ambition. A successful referendum would curb the former, a failed one might destroy the latter. Because, above all other things, Gordon wants to be prime minister, perhaps he can't face that risk. There are those who believe that if Brown doesn't stop Blair taking the plunge, he will find a score of furtive ways to limit the damage to himself in case it ends in a fatal drowning. A sulking Brown, skulking on the sides of the campaign, is summoned up.

This now looks unlikely. Close observers find the chancellor getting his pro-euro arguments into place. A month ago, abandoning his notorious veto on discussion, he told Michael Portillo, in a carefully framed Commons reply, that he was "happy for the general election campaign ... to be fought with a considerable amount of debate on the issue of the euro." He may not like it. He's still a highly calculating custodian of his personal interest. But such a man understands why timing is everything, and how a referendum that has to be held must also, at all costs, be won.

Thursday: how they plan to win it

webTitle: FBI defector acted as stripper's guardian angel

fields.headline: FBI defector acted as stripper's guardian angel
fields.standfirst: It has been revealed that Robert Hanssen, the FBI traitor who had been selling secrets to the KGB, used his payment to court a Washington lap dancer. Julian Borger reports on the increasingly bizarre tale of the spy and the stripper
fields.trailText: It has been revealed that Robert Hanssen, the FBI defector who had been selling secrets to the KGB, used his payment to court a Washington lap dancer. Julian Borger reports on the increasingly bizarre tale of the spy and the stripper.
fields.body:
He was an FBI agent, who had been betraying his country for over four years. She was a stripper in a Washington nightclub. One day in 1990, he sent a note backstage complimenting her on her "grace". He enclosed a $10 note. The relationship that ensued is still puzzling US counter-intelligence experts, and is likely to remain one of the stranger footnotes in the history of espionage.

Robert Hanssen showered money and gifts on Priscilla Galey with the aim, he told her, of freeing her from the life of an "exotic dancer". According to an interview with Galey in the Washington Post, which first unearthed the story, no sex was involved.

Hanssen, a devout Catholic then aged 45, wanted to save Galey's soul, at the same time as he was lying to his family and friends, and endangering the lives of his colleagues by selling secrets to the KGB.

Moscow is believed to have paid him a total of $600,000 in cash and diamonds, and a further $800,000 into a bank account in his name. Some of this went to pay for a Mercedes Benz for Galey, a trip to Hong Kong, jewelry and her own American Express card to pay for "emergencies".

The overlapping cross currents of faith and betrayal are worthy of a Graham Greene novel. And, as Greene would have had it, they led to nowhere but failure and unhappiness for all concerned. Hanssen was arrested in February this year while leaving documents for his Russian handlers in a North Virginian park.

By then, he had already severed links with Galey. She had been using a credit card funded by Hanssen for such frivolities as buying Easter frocks for her nieces. In 1992, he drove all the way from Washington to Columbus, Ohio, to take the card away from her. He let her know she had let him down.

"The next time we saw him," Galey's mother, Linda Harris, told USA Today, "he was on the news being arrested. Me and Priscilla about fell off our chairs." She added: "The man with an air about him. He acted like he was too good for people like us."

Both Harris and her daughter believe that Hanssen was grooming the stripper for some kind of undercover spy mission. This seems implausible, given that the FBI counter-surveillance operative already had access to a wide range of classified material which he seems to have had been able to remove with ease. He was an exceptionally cautious spy, who did not even reveal his identity to his handlers. Why would he blow his cover by telling a woman he hardly knew his deepest secrets?

Yet he took a risk on Galey nevertheless. If his FBI bosses had known about the Mercedes and the trip to Hong Kong that he had paid for, they would have been suspicious as to the source of Hanssen's finances. The spy seems to have gambled everything on a fantasy about "saving" a pretty woman. Some form of penitence perhaps?

Galey, meanwhile, has not been saved. She is a 43-year-old destitute crack addict, who feels let down by the man she had once thought of as her "guardian angel". He had urged her to go to church and insisted he wanted her to find her faith. That is precisely what she says she has now lost.

fields.headline: Thus turns the corner
fields.trailText: 2pm: Telecoms group Thus has predicted it will move into profit by the end of the year, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telecoms group Thus appears to have turned the corner after predicting a move into profit by the end of the year.

The Scottish-based company has suffered from heavy losses due to expansion of its UK network, but Thus today said it was ready to reap the rewards from its expenditure.

William Allen, the chief executive of Thus, said underlying profits would turn positive before the end of the financial year, as the company unveiled a full-year pre-tax loss of £63m, up from £66.9m last year.

A competitive telecoms market has forced the company to gamble its future on becoming a business-focused operator in a bid to separate itself from smaller rivals.

"Our improving performance demonstrates a successful strategy to move our company from a regional to a national, business focused, service provider," said Mr Allen.

fields.headline: Jeanette Winterson
fields.standfirst: The real reason why army women want bigger breasts
fields.trailText: Why are women so obsessed with their breasts? Female soldiers are so worried about what stuffs their full metal jackets that they will go through medical and psychiatric panels to qualify for the operation that makes them "a happier soldier".
fields.body:
Why are women so obsessed with their breasts? It's a problem, and it's a big one - 36C at least. Women want larger breasts and they will pay to get them. The weekend's news was dominated by MoD disclosures that female soldiers are so worried about what stuffs their full metal jackets that they will go through medical and psychiatric panels to qualify for the operation that makes them "a happier soldier". Second in line are policewomen.

I blame guns and truncheons. If your phallic symbol fires 40 rounds unaided, or hangs a foot long by your thigh, you won't be worrying about the size of your dick. It's obvious that women in active service should have weapons that mimic and magnify what they hide under their uniform. We need: a) more hand grenades - what could be a better copy of what we keep in our knickers? b) A new, round, scary girl-toy, a cross between a ball and chain and a cartoon bomb, that will whack a thug senseless when it's not clipped around your waist in stainless steel provocation.

Go girl! This is the real message. Before you think I'm getting too San Francisco, let me ask you how many women look for well-hung in the same way that men stare obsessively below the neck? I'm all for a Wonderbra - wouldn't hand-wash anything else - but why can't men enjoy the game instead of fixing on your boobs like a terrier at a pair of molehills?

Behind all this up-front anxiety is the age-old problem: women want to look the way men think they should look. And in the armed forces, if you're not a Playboy pin-up, you must be a lesbian. You think I'm kidding? Here's a confession not quite out of Nude Readers' Wives.

My trainer at the gym is ex-army. Her experience over nine years, rising through the ranks, is that women who want to squaddie are so suspect as "real women" that they have to come the Marilyn Monroe just to get even. It doesn't help that forces units are fed on pornography. My trainer tells me fellow soldiers kept torn-out porn pics in their pockets. Her personal appearance was continually under fire. Plenty of women she knew were receiving treatment of various kinds.

If women in the forces are on medication, in therapy and wanting operations, is it their problem or the price they are made to pay?

So I'm over 40, wear a Wonderbra and go to the gym three times a week. Isn't that as appearance-conscious as wanting implants?

Well, no. I do it because I want to be the best I can be with my limited resources. I enjoy feeling healthy and strong. It would be great to look like Julia Roberts but it's not going to happen. Why worry about it, and why worry some boob-brained man won't find me pneumatic enough?

OK, OK. One of the reasons I go out with girls is that men are such a pain in the - well, you choose where. I like men but I find heterosexual culture oppressive. If only women would stop trying to please men, for no better reason than that they are men, we might all be happy with the body we inherit and learn to put our energies into the life we make.

The saddest thing about this latest bout of boob-mania is the fact that women's bodies are still seen as deficient, in need of correction. Over and over, the medics consulted argued that if women didn't like their bodies, it was appropriate for science to amend them. This is woman as incomplete, unfinished goods. The real reasons for women's dissatisfaction with themselves are ignored. It seems it is better to risk the rise in cancers and brain tumours linked with breast surgery, reported last week, than to change the dismal truth that men control women's images of themselves.

I'm not interested in censorship, women-only communities or the dowdier by-products of feminism, but I believe a woman's body should be a pleasure, not a penalty. We don't need men to tell us how we should look and then offer to fix it for us on the operating table - all to make us feel better, of course.

The one good thing to come of National Boob Week is the news that M&S is introducing electronic bra sensors to ensure a perfect fit, whatever your shape. Burn that tired pink Playtex. Buy yourself a Julia Roberts and celebrate the woman you are.

 This column appears fortnightly.

Jeanette Winterson

fields.headline: Media go looking for trouble
fields.trailText:
11.15am: A BBC news chief has denied journalists have been ordered to focus on any May Day violence, reports Jessica Hodgson
. 01.05.2001: Keeping a level head
fields.body:
Insiders at the BBC have today claimed that focusing on violence at protests was "normal practice".

But the BBC's head of newsgathering, Adrian Van Klaveren, denied BBC journalists had been ordered to make violence the top story.

"The protesters are raising real issues, which we are reflecting in our reports," he said.

"If all we report is violence, it plays into the hands of those who argue peaceful protest cannot achieve anything," he added.

Mr Van Klaveren's claims follow reports this morning of a leaked BBC memo claiming BBC news was to deploy a helicopter and teams of journalists on the ground to spot outbreaks of violence.

"If it all goes off in the middle of central London, all the pictures of peaceful demonstrators will go out the window," said a BBC producer.

Meanwhile, an ITN journalist said staff were braced for violence and were being dispatched around London in three-person teams.

"We've been told our safety must come first," he said.

ITN and the BBC have secured roof-top positions along Oxford Street and other routes where violence is expected.

One ITN journalist said: "It's a huge deployment by us, the BBC and Sky.

"Our experience of last year's demonstrations has taught us it could kick off. We need to take it a bit more seriously."

The claims will confirm the fears of the peaceful protesters, who believe the mainstream media have been briefed to make violence the top story, sidelining coverage of the issues the protesters want to highlight.

webTitle: Second Commonwealth win for Peter Carey

fields.headline: Second Commonwealth win for Peter Carey
fields.trailText: Peter Carey has won the Commonwealth Writers Prize for the second time for his novel True History of the Kelly Gang.
fields.body:
Peter Carey has won the Commonwealth Writers Prize for the second time for his novel True History of the Kelly Gang.

Australian-born Carey, who last won the prize three years ago for Jack Maggs, collected the £10,000 award at a gala dinner in Accra Ghana.

Described by the judges as a "masterful book" which "bursts with creative energy", True History of the Kelly Gang marks a return to the theme of the harsh, brutal world of Australian history previously evoked in his Booker-winning novel Oscar and Lucinda. Told in journal form, True History of the Kelly Gang follows the fortunes of the notorious outlaw, Ned Kelly, as he writes to a daughter he will never see.

Zadie Smith added yet another award to her collection by picking up the £3,000 prize for Best First Book for her debut novel White Teeth. The judges described her tale of three generations of immigrant families living in Britain as "an astonishingly attractive debut novel" which "is a wonderfully expansive, inventive, exuberant, comic celebration of multicultural life".

The awards were thrown into controversy last month when the Indian writer Amitav Ghosh withdrew his book, The Glass Palace, from the shortlist, objecting to his work being classified as 'Commonwealth literature' when the prize was only open to books written in English. In a letter to the Times of India, he argued that the name "Commonwealth" for a literary or cultural grouping could "only be a misnomer" so long as it excluded the many languages that sustained the cultural lives of those countries.

Eight prizes of £1,000 each were also awarded to the best books and best first books in four regions of the Commonwealth. The regional winners were:

Best Book

Africa
The Heart of Redness by Zakes Mda (Oxford University Press, South Africa)

Caribbean and Canada
The HeroÍs Walk by Anita Rau Badami (Knopf, Canada)

Eurasia
Super-Cannes by J G Ballard (Harper Collins, United Kingdom)

South East Asia and South Pacific
True History of the Kelly Gang by Peter Carey (University of Queensland Press, Australia)

Best First Book

Africa
Thirteen Cents by K Sello Duiker (David Phillip Publishers, South Africa)

Caribbean and Canada
Burning Ground by Pearl Luke (Flamingo, Canada)

Eurasia
White Teeth by Zadie Smith (Hamish Hamilton, United Kingdom)

South East Asia and South Pacific
The Company by Arabella Edge (Picador Australia)

fields.headline: South-east councils urge spending rethink
fields.trailText: Ministers are facing a cross-party backlash over government spending levels in the south east as county councils serve notice that they will no longer tolerate a diversion of Whitehall funds to England's depressed northern regions. With Tony Blair sensitive to Conservative charges that New Labour is abandoning middle England in favour of the party's heartlands, south east council leaders accused the prime minister of presiding over a "dramatic shift" in funding from rural and south east counties towards urban areas and northern cities.
fields.body:
Ministers are facing a cross-party backlash over government spending levels in the south east as county councils serve notice that they will no longer tolerate a diversion of Whitehall funds to England's depressed northern regions. With Tony Blair sensitive to Conservative charges that New Labour is abandoning middle England in favour of the party's heartlands, south east council leaders accused the prime minister of presiding over a "dramatic shift" in funding from rural and south east counties towards urban areas and northern cities.

Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, leader of Kent council, warned that the government's commitment to elected regional assemblies in the north would lead to unwanted inter-regional competition, expose government favouritism and "diminish one nation Britain." Growing tensions emerged at a summit of eight county council leaders at Leeds castle in Kent.

Chris Williams, chief officer of Buckinghamshire council, said Tory, Lib Dem and Labour councillors agreed a problem was looming in the south east with authorities unable to meet government standards in education and social services because of underfunding.

Mr Bruce-Lockhart said it was intolerable that the south east, with over three times the population of the north east, received less in allocation of some government funds.

fields.headline: Cash boost for market towns
fields.trailText: More than 40 market towns in England - including 30 in counties badly hit by foot and mouth - are each to receive up to £1m in government aid, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced today.
fields.body:
More than 40 market towns in England - including 30 in counties badly hit by foot and mouth - are each to receive up to £1m in government aid, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced today.

The cash, part of the government's already-announced £100m aid package for market towns, will be used to boost rural communities and villages. Mr Prescott disclosed the 43 towns to benefit in the latest wave of funding on a visit to Market Drayton, Shropshire.

He said: "From Whitehall to the village hall, I am confident this £43m will make a real difference and provide an important boost to people in these towns and surrounding villages.

"We are determined to help them find long-term solutions to the serious challenges they face, by transforming market towns into vibrant hubs of local communities."

The towns have been selected by regional development agencies, in partnership with local councils and the countryside agency.

The money will go to support a wide range of regeneration projects, including a programme of waterway improvement in Market Drayton itself, designed to attract visitors and increase the character and charm of the town. Tory environment spokesman Damian Green said: "Labour's pledges on market towns are worthless.

"John Prescott's anti-car crusade - in the form of his plans for new congestion taxes, new parking taxes and higher parking charges - will stop shoppers coming into town and rip the heart out of the local economy.

"This re-announcement of money today in no way compensates for Labour's stealth taxes like higher fuel tax, soaring council tax and the extra regulations Labour have piled on market traders."

Mr Green said the Tories would cut business rates for small firms, cut fuel tax and help councils promote tourism.

The 43 towns in today's announcement join 49 others already receiving aid. Another 30 are expected to be announced shortly, including some in Cumbria where foot and mouth has delayed decision making.

The towns that will benefit from today's announcement:

South-west

Devon - Okehampton, Hatherleigh, South Molton, Crediton, Gt Torrington

Cornwall - Launceston

Will also be extended to small communities on Dartmoor, Exmoor and in Forest of Dean

North-east

Cleveland - Guisborough

Northumberland - Alnwick, Haltwhistle, Seahouses and Wooler

Durham - Barnard Castle, Middleton-in-Teesdale, Crook, Stanhope

West Midlands

Shropshire - Craven Arms, Oswestry, Wem, Bridgnorth, Highley, Alveley, Market Drayton

Herefordshire - Kington, Ledbury, Bromyard

Worcs - Bewdley, Evesham

Staffs - Leek, Uttoxeter

Warwickshire - Alcester, Atherstone, Polesworth

Yorkshire and Humberside

North Yorkshire - Thirsk, Whitby, Pateley Bridge

West Yorkshire - Otley

South Yorkshire - Penistone

East Yorkshire - Market Weighton

South-east

Kent - Hythe, Cranbrook and Minster (Thanet)

East Sussex - Battle and Heathfield

North-west

The selection process for towns in the north-west has been delayed by the foot and mouth outbreak. However, it is now underway and further announcements will be made shortly.

fields.headline: EMI calls off £10bn BMG merger
fields.trailText:
1pm: UK record group EMI has been forced to abandon its merger with Bertelsmann's BMG label following opposition from EU regulators. By Dan Milmo.

01.05.2001: EMI merger with BMG stumbles
fields.body:
The UK record group, EMI, has been forced to abandon its £10bn merger with Bertelsmann's BMG label following opposition from EU regulators.

It is the second major letdown for EMI in a year, after watchdogs scrapped its proposed £12bn tie-up with Warner Music.

"After exhaustive analysis and discussion, we have been unable to find a deal with Bertelsmann which works both for shareholders and for the regulators," said Eric Nicoli, the chairman of EMI.

EU competition watchdogs had reservations about the world's five major record companies being reduced to four in number, and shareholders at both companies were known to be against selling off assets in order to appease the watchdogs.

EMI is now a prime target for predators, despite today's claims that it would continue as a standalone company.

"We are, nevertheless, excited about EMI's future. We are the world's third largest record company and the largest music publisher and we will continue to take bold steps to build our business," Mr Nicoli added.

A successful deal would have brought together the Spice Girls, Robbie Williams and Whitney Houston under the same label, and would have given EMI a much-needed boost in the US market.

EMI must now attempt to forge its own way in a stagnating market that has seen six successive years of falling record sales and only offers modest margin and revenue growth.

However, EMI offset the merger news with a preview of its full-year results, which are due on May 22.

Revenues rose 12% to £2.7bn and adjusted pre-tax profits rose by 6% to £260m, which boosted the group's shares by over 2%.

fields.headline: Top radio award for Wogan
fields.trailText: Terry Wogan was last night named radio broadcaster of the year at the Sony Radio Academy awards, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Terry Wogan was last night named radio broadcaster of the year at the Sony Radio Academy awards, gaining some consolation for losing his BBC television contract.

After collecting the 2000 award at a ceremony in London, the veteran broadcaster took a swipe at the man being talked about as BBC1's new Wogan, Johnnie Vaughan, whom he likened to a modern day Des O'Connor. O'Connor presented Wogan with his first radio award in 1972.

The Sony award came on the day the BBC announced it would not be renewing Wogan's TV contract.

It is developing a new late night BBC 1 chat show to be hosted by Vaughan. Wogan will still present his Radio 2 breakfast show.

The Sony judges said Wogan was being honoured: "As the man who last year added half a million new listeners to BBC Radio 2 and for taking radio into a new dimension through his mastery of web broadcasting."

Radio 2 won five awards including best national station of the year, while Radio 4 picked up six Sonys. Chris Tarrant, the Capital Radio breakfast show presenter, received a lifetime achievement award.

Other winners included Radio 1's Mark Radcliffe and Marc Riley, who picked up the music programme award for a daily show for the third year running.
