fields.headline: A credit to the nation?
fields.standfirst: The new tax breaks introduced by Labour have helped over one million low-income families in Britain. Judy Hirst asks whether the government is taking far too much credit for alleviating poverty
fields.trailText: The new tax breaks introduced by Labour have helped over one million low-income families in Britain. Judy Hirst asks whether the government is taking far too much credit for alleviating poverty
fields.body:
Children's tax credits. Working families tax credits. Credits for babies, disabled people and low-income workers without kids. Voters could be forgiven for thinking that the tax system - traditionally a means of taking money from us - has been converted into a bottomless source of free hand-outs. But that would be to confuse substance with style.

Since 1997, chancellor Gordon Brown, has embraced US-style tax breaks with enthusiasm. Instead of receiving a giro to be cashed at the post office, claimants are increasingly topping up their incomes by paying less tax. The working families tax credit, for example, allows around 1m low-paid families £20 a week off their tax bills. The children's tax credit is equivalent to a 2.5% basic rate tax cut for the average family.

Administered by the Inland Revenue instead of the social security system, and delivered through employee pay-rolls, targeted tax credits are central to the government's strategy of helping the jobless out of the poverty trap by "making work pay". The political attractions of merging the tax and benefit systems are self-evident. Tax cuts play a lot better with the electorate than benefit rises, and psychologically they chime well with the New Deal work ethic. But do tax credits really help the poor?

For low-income families with children, there have been gains, says Tom Clark, research economist at the Institute for Fiscal Studies. These include real increases in the proportion of earnings "disregarded" for tax purposes, he says. "In general though, most of the changes are just presentational. The working families tax credit is much the same as the old family credit. It's just paid a different way. And tax discounts are not much use unless you're in work and paying tax."

A recent survey by the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux has also highlighted that many families may lose out on benefits, such as free school meals, or help with rent and council tax, when they claim the working families credit.

There are gender issues too. The children's tax credit is paid to the family's highest rate taxpayer, generally the father. This "purse to wallet" transfer has proved embarrassing for the government, and has led to a big shortfall in eligible families applying for the credit. The problem will be partially resolved by a new "integrated" children's credit, payable directly to a child's main carer, which is being introduced in 2003. However, according to shadow social security secretary David Willetts, this just shows that the government does not believe its own rhetoric.

"Gordon Brown claims that paying these tax credits through the payroll system acts as an incentive to get people into work. In fact there is no empirical evidence for this, and now - with the new integrated children's credit - the system is being scrapped anyway." What's left of the working families tax credit after 2003 - a new employment tax credit for the childless - will continue to be administered through payrolls. But opposition parties claim the system is at best a bureaucratic mess, which is costing businesses over £100m a year to handle, and at worst a burden rather than a boon for people on low-incomes.

Labour's tax credits are really just "benefits dressed up as tax cuts", says Willetts. Unlike in the US, where earned income tax credits are simply paid by cheque at the end of the tax year, the British variety is clumsy to administer - and has hugely extended the number of people being means-tested. If elected, the Conservatives would turn the working families tax credit back into a benefit, to be paid directly to the main carer.

The Liberal Democrats would do much the same. "The government's so-called tax credits are in fact nothing of the sort," says social security spokesman Steve Webb. "They're not even based on individual tax assessments, but on your household income, like a benefit. They're just called a tax credit as a political ploy." What really needs addressing, he says, is the big clawback of low incomes through housing costs, and measures to relieve poverty rather than "obsessively" drive people into work.

"There are substantial numbers like many lone parents and disabled people - for whom paid employment is not the right answer. Yet through the New Deal and tax credits, they are being pushed in this direction, and stigmatised if they do not want to work. Nor are real jobs being created for the long-term unemployed."

However, with unemployment officially under 1m, the Liberal Democrat alternatives - higher benefits, better and more flexible employment opportunities - are unlikely to get much of a hearing. It may take six years and a lot of circular reasoning to come up with a vaguely workable tax credit system, but so long as the government can claim that its incentives are working and over a million families are (however marginally) better off, the critics will be sidelined - and Labour will take the credit.

webTitle: EMI's £10bn merger with BMG stumbles at regulatory hurdle

fields.headline: EMI's £10bn merger with BMG stumbles at regulatory hurdle
fields.trailText: EMI's planned £10bn merger with BMG is near to collapse, sources close to the deal said last night. By David Teather.
fields.body:
EMI's planned £10bn merger with BMG, its music industry rival, is near to collapse, sources close to the deal said last night.

A final decision on the fate of the merger has not been taken but regulatory concerns are understood to have dampened enthusiasm for the deal. "The fat lady isn't quite singing yet but she's getting ready," said one source. "A final decision has not yet been taken but the broad picture has been pretty clear since last week."

If the deal is aborted it will be the second time in little more than a year that EMI has entered and abandoned merger talks. An agreement with Time Warner's music division collapsed last year after running into regulatory obstacles.

A European commission source said the deal with BMG, which is owned by German media group Bertelsmann, would be likely to face many of the same problems as its predecessor. EMI and BMG have so far sought only informal advice from the commission.

"In recording and music publishing, there are the same sort of concerns that we had in the Warner-EMI deal," the source said. "Of course, there have been concerns but that should not come as a surprise. The fact is there are only five big players who control the music sector so this was always going to pose problems as well.

"It doesn't make any difference that these are two European companies."

Both EMI and BMG are understood to be reluctant to sell off important assets to get the deal past regulators. The two sides have placed a self-imposed deadline of May 22, the day of EMI's full-year results, to decide whether they should press ahead.

Executives from the companies are said to have spent the weekend attempting to hammer out a deal which would meet with the approval of regulators on both sides of the Atlantic. They are unwilling to place the agreement fully before the commission unless they are confident it will be allowed.

EMI, led by Eric Nicoli, spent £43m in advisory fees on the failed merger with Warner Music and is said to be the more pessimistic about the latest negotiations, announced five months ago, succeeding.

EMI and Warner faced the additional complication of Time Warner's merger with internet business AOL which raised fears that the combined group would give it a dominant position in the growing market for online distribution of music.

Music groups are keen for further consolidation as a means of cutting costs in the face of a market which last year shrank for the first time.

BMG and EMI had hoped to save £200m a year from a merger. A deal would have brought together artists including the Spice Girls, Janet Jackson and Mariah Carey from EMI with Whitney Houston and the back catalogue of Elvis Presley from the BMG stable.

A deal with BMG would help EMI to fulfil its ambition of bolstering its performance in the US.

 NTL, Britain's largest cable firm, said yesterday it was talks with AOL Time Warner to develop content for its broadband service in Europe.

A statement said it was in "the early stages of talks with AOL Time Warner about some potential joint activity" but stressed it was not close to announcing a deal.

The focus is understood to be on using AOL's online content across NTL's networks in Britain and mainland Europe.

The talks are not understood to involve either an injection of cash into NTL or the acquisition of an equity stake.

webTitle: Watford set to announce Vialli as manager

fields.headline: Watford set to announce Vialli as manager
fields.trailText: Watford will hold a press conference at Vicarage Road tomorrow, at which they are expected to announce Gianluca Vialli as their new manager. Vialli has been linked with the post for the past few weeks, and will replace Graham Taylor who is to retire after 29 years in management.
fields.body:
Watford will hold a press conference at Vicarage Road tomorrow, at which they are expected to announce Gianluca Vialli as their new manager. Vialli has been linked with the post for the past few weeks, and will replace Graham Taylor who is to retire after 29 years in management.

Vialli has been out of football since Chelsea sacked him in September of last year. He lost his job after only five games of the season, amid tales of unrest inside the Stamford Bridge dressing room. He was, however, Chelsea's most successful manager ever, winning the Coca-Cola Cup, Cup Winners' Cup and FA Cup in his two-and-a-half years in charge.

Vialli will have to be similarly successful if he is to follow in Taylor's footsteps. He took the Hornets from the Fourth Division to second place in the top flight in 1983, and the FA Cup final the following season.

He then took charge at Aston Villa, leading them to runners-up in the First Division, but infamy soon followed when he succeeded Bobby Robson as England manager in 1990. England were eliminated at the group stages in Euro 92 in Sweden and failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup in the United States.

His return to management with Wolves saw the First Division club miss out on promotion to the Premiership via the play-offs, but Taylor found more success with Watford and took the club to successive promotions and a return to the top flight after 11 years.

webTitle: Surgeries shut as GPs protest over workload

fields.headline: Surgeries shut as GPs protest over workload
fields.trailText: Hundreds of family doctors are today closing their surgeries or staging a "work to rule" in protest about their working conditions, despite the refusal of their trade union to back them.
fields.body:
Hundreds of family doctors are today closing their surgeries or staging a "work to rule" in protest about their working conditions, despite the refusal of their trade union to back them.

Around 100 surgeries were expected to close, while other doctors were planning to either only see patients and do no paperwork, or refuse appointments and only perform administrative tasks.

The British Medical Association (BMA), which proposes to ballot its family doctor members about resignation from the NHS, says it cannot support the action because it would harm patients and break trade union laws.

Health minister John Denham described the action as "uneccessary", although he admitted that the government's NHS reforms had put pressure on GPs and their staff.

He said: "There is no need for action to persuade us of that. What we want to do is work with the professions to tackle these pressures and we are doing that in a number of ways."

Mr Denham also attacked the BMA over its decision to ballot members over what it sees as the slow progress the government has made over the introduction of a new GP contract.

In a letter to BMA GPs' committee chairman Dr John Chisholm, Mr Denham said: "I cannot accept that the progress of contract negotiations provides any rational for balloting your members."

He added: "It is hard to avoid the conclusion that the GPC (general practitioners' committee) is set on a particular course of action irrespective of anything we might do."

The minister listed a series of initiatives which he said he would improve the lives of all staff working in primary care, inlcuding a planned expansion of the GP workforce, and a reduction in GPs' paperwork.

The GPs' day of action has been organised by Doctor magazine after a survey showed that eight out of 10 family doctors would quit the NHS if they could.

Doctors have complained that government initiatives and targets are leaving them overstretched, with increased bureaucracy and less time to see patients.

The average GP now has just eight minutes to see each patient and doctors claim they cannot deliver the necessary standards of care.

Phil Johnson, editor of Doctor, said: "We estimate that about 100 practices across the country will close, and many are shutting down for the whole day.

"Something like 1,000 others will be showing active support in other ways, but it could be much more than that. We don't know what the full scale of support is going to be."

Mr Johnson said that in Weston-super-Mare, Somerset, all 40 GPs in about a dozen surgeries were planning to walk out.

In Marlow, Buckinghamshire, the town's only practice covering 20,000 patients was also closing for the day.

Dr Chisholm said: "I understand and share the concerns of general practitioners. Many of them are at breaking point because of their intolerable workload.

"It is important that the government listens to their concerns and takes urgent action to give patients the high quality service they deserve and which doctors want to provide - a service that protects patient health and safety, and the health of family doctors too.

"For that very reason, doctors will not wish to take any action that damages the care their patients receive."

fields.headline: Keeping a level head
fields.standfirst:
As London wonders what will happen during today's demonstrations, John Vidal (right) explains how the Guardian will be approaching the day's events

John Vidal outside McDonald's in King's Cross, London (1min 45)

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: As London wonders what will happen during today's demonstrations, John Vidal explains how the Guardian will be approaching the day's events.
fields.body:
How do you journalistically cover a day of widespread demonstrations and actions against a myriad of institutions, businesses and global bodies?

According to a leaked document sent to the Guardian, the BBC will taking to the air with a helicopter, will have hundreds of people on the ground and will be specifically looking out for violence, disorder and confrontations. They have taken over offices in Oxford Street and the City, and their correspondents have all been trained to handle riot situations.

Here at the Guardian - which, incidentally, has been warned that it can expect a demonstration too - the intention is rather different and we are a bit cooler and less over-hyped about it all.

May Day is a traditional workers' day, and there will be trade union marches and plenty of peaceful demonstations and celebrations that need to be covered as well. Rather than looking only for people who intend to be violent, we will be talking to people about why they are there.

We want to reflect the fact that May Day is also an international workers' day with hundreds of thousands of people across the world legitimately joining marches, protests and rallies.

We will not be many on the streets. Perhaps four or five. But we will also be monitoring the independent media, a growing player in demonstrations. It is run by activists, it's raw and it cannot always be relied upon, but it is an important new resource which should not be dismissed.

It's always hard to predict how many-stranded demonstrations of this sort will unfold. Having breathed deeply the teargas at Seattle and Prague, my own suspicion is that much of it will be good humoured, but it will be on nothing like on the same scale either in numbers or in police over-reaction.

But with a massive police presence - some observers are saying that this will be the biggest peacetime show of police force in the capital ever - it's not hard for agitators in the crowds to turn a gathering into a mass revolt, and equally, the police can initiate trouble by over reaction.

Yes, there will be will be a ritualistic confrontation at some point and it is tempting to say that a few people on both sides will be spoiling for a set-to by the end of the evening.

Getting to the truth of what happens is one of the hardest jobs in journalism. Everyone who goes has a different point of view. My own intention is to roam freely, observe hard and follow the day honestly.

fields.bodyText: How do you journalistically cover a day of widespread demonstrations and actions against a myriad of institutions, businesses and global bodies? According to a leaked document sent to the Guardian, the BBC will taking to the air with a helicopter, will have hundreds of people on the ground and will be specifically looking out for violence, disorder and confrontations. They have taken over offices in Oxford Street and the City, and their correspondents have all been trained to handle riot situations. Here at the Guardian - which, incidentally, has been warned that it can expect a demonstration too - the intention is rather different and we are a bit cooler and less over-hyped about it all. May Day is a traditional workers' day, and there will be trade union marches and plenty of peaceful demonstations and celebrations that need to be covered as well. Rather than looking only for people who intend to be violent, we will be talking to people about why they are there. We want to reflect the fact that May Day is also an international workers' day with hundreds of thousands of people across the world legitimately joining marches, protests and rallies. We will not be many on the streets. Perhaps four or five. But we will also be monitoring the independent media, a growing player in demonstrations. It is run by activists, it's raw and it cannot always be relied upon, but it is an important new resource which should not be dismissed. It's always hard to predict how many-stranded demonstrations of this sort will unfold. Having breathed deeply the teargas at Seattle and Prague, my own suspicion is that much of it will be good humoured, but it will be on nothing like on the same scale either in numbers or in police over-reaction. But with a massive police presence - some observers are saying that this will be the biggest peacetime show of police force in the capital ever - it's not hard for agitators in the crowds to turn a gathering into a mass revolt, and equally, the police can initiate trouble by over reaction. Yes, there will be will be a ritualistic confrontation at some point and it is tempting to say that a few people on both sides will be spoiling for a set-to by the end of the evening. Getting to the truth of what happens is one of the hardest jobs in journalism. Everyone who goes has a different point of view. My own intention is to roam freely, observe hard and follow the day honestly. fields.headline: Advertising row splits tobacco talks
fields.trailText:
11am: A huge row over tobacco advertising has divided delegates at the anti-tobacco treaty talks in Geneva, reports Julia Day.

30.04.2001: Anti-tobacco treaty rejects advertising ban

30.04.2001: Ad-free dream fades

Tobacco advertising and promotion
fields.body:
A huge row over tobacco advertising has divided delegates at the anti-tobacco treaty talks in Geneva.

Advertising has become the flashpoint of talks among the world's nations to stem the spread of tobacco-related death and disease.

The treaty, sponsored by the World Health Organisation, aims to achieve worldwide agreement on issues such as tobacco smuggling and packaging.

The African nations have united in advocating a total ban in the face of the draft treaty, which has set out a milder alternative - a ban on advertising targeting under-18s.

But the US, the EU, Japan and other countries are happy to endorse the under-18s ban, which leaves tobacco companies some room for manoeuvre.

Clive Bates, the director of anti-smoking pressure group Action on Smoking and Health, is in Geneva this week to lobby for a tougher treaty.

Mr Bates believes that if the treaty's position on tobacco advertising is not strengthened it could damage other anti-tobacco advertising legislation.

"If this draft is agreed it is worse than useless and will create a really bad precedent," he said.

"It sends a signal to developing countries that tobacco advertising is a kids' issue, that restrictions should be concentrated on young people with a laissez-faire attitude on everyone else."

fields.headline: Macca: United are predictable
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman may be earning his living in Spain nowadays, but there's no doubting his Scouse credentials. The former Liverpool player, speaking ahead of this evening's Champions League semi-final against Bayern Munich, has offered his opinion on Manchester United's European campaign and, unsurprisingly, it's not very effusive.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman may be earning his living in Spain nowadays, but there's no doubting his Scouse credentials. The former Liverpool player, speaking ahead of this evening's Champions League semi-final against Bayern Munich, has offered his opinion on Manchester United's European campaign and, unsurprisingly, it's not very effusive.

"I know most of the lads at Madrid wanted United in the semi because they felt it would be the easier tie," he told the Mirror. "When you look at their results in Europe all season, then you could say as soon as they came up against a decent side they would struggle."

McManaman, a fixture in the Real Madrid first team, believes defeat by the Spaniards last season has left United in limbo this year. "United have suffered this season because they haven't really sorted out a proper game-plan in Europe," the England man said. "They seem to have been shaken by their defeat by us in the quarter-finals last year and I think they were almost taking stock this season, wondering which direction to go."

Without the slightest trace of schadenfreude, Macca went on to show his solidarity with United captain Roy Keane, who has been outspoken in his assessment of his team's failings. "It was good to hear Roy Keane saying that United have to try and copy Real Madrid because we are the team others have to try and match", he said.

"I think what he is saying is that in Europe we have been capable of doing something different, finding a bit of extra spark when it is needed - and United have to follow that. We've the likes of Figo and Raul, who are excellent at that, whereas United maybe became a little too predictable this season and that's where they were found out.

"I think the signing of [Ruud] van Nistelrooy shows that they know they have to do something a bit different."

webTitle: FA fail to find funding for New Wembley

fields.headline: FA fail to find funding for New Wembley
fields.trailText: The FA have admitted that the Wembley Stadium project is doomed to failure unless the government bails it out.
fields.body:
The FA have admitted that the Wembley Stadium project is doomed to failure unless the government bails it out.

"We cannot act as the sole sponsor of the scheme," said the FA tonight. "Neither sports governing bodies, nor banks will take the risks associated with such a project."

The £475m stadium was initially supposed to be completed in time for the 2003 FA Cup final. But the scheme has been beset by problems over the past two years, and demolition work has still not been started.

Tonight, culture secretary Chris Smith said: "The government regrets the FA's decision to withdraw its support for the current plans for the redevelopment of Wembley Stadium."

"It is clear that escalating costs - which have risen from £334m to £660m - have played a key role. Given it is clear that the FA cannot complete its project, the government has decided to examine all the options that are available.

"A recent study into the issues surrounding the Commonwealth Games in Manchester has demonstrated the importance of cross government working and the same committee has therefore been asked to examine the national football stadium."

Today's news is hardly surprising given the problems that have been associated with the project.

Initially, it was intended to be a stadium which would incorporate both athletics and football, although the former element was eventually scrapped by Smith.

Another major money-spinner, the 2006 World Cup, was lost when Fifa awarded the tournament to Germany and it quickly became clear that the money generated would not cover the costs of building the ground.

Critics have also pointed to the Millennium Stadium and its relatively small costs, as proof that the new stadium was over priced and suggested that it should be built from scratch outside London.

webTitle: Tom Hanks to turn film into Broadway musical

fields.headline: Tom Hanks to turn film into Broadway musical
fields.standfirst: Plus: Rappers Dr Dre and Snoop Dogg to appear in The Wash; Star Wars documentary posted on internet
fields.trailText: Plus: Rappers Dr Dre and Snoop Dogg to appear in The Wash; Star Wars documentary posted on internet
fields.body:
Tom Hanks is intending to turn his 1996 film, That Thing You Do, into a Broadway musical. Variety reports that Hanks' own production company, Playtone, is currently developing the package. That Thing You Do was based on the rise and fall of the Wonders, a fictional rock band. According to Variety's Michael Fleming, the idea of turning the film into a musical arose because schools have bombarded the production company with requests to use the title song - which won an Oscar nomination - as the basis for local productions.

Rappers Dr Dre and Snoop Dogg are to appear in The Wash, for director D J Pooh. According to the Hollywood Reporter the two rappers will also be executive producers on the project and contribute to the soundtrack.

A behind-the-scenes documentary about the making of Star Wars Episode 2 has been posted on the film's official site. The clip, entitled Wedgie 'Em Out, shows the first new spaceship of Episode 2 - the Jedi starfighter.

fields.headline: Burley signs five-year Ipswich deal
fields.trailText: Ipswich manager George Burley has signed a new five-year contract with the Suffolk club.
fields.body:
Ipswich manager George Burley has signed a new five-year contract with the Suffolk club.

Burley's reward for qualifying for European competition is reported to be a deal which brings his annual salary to around the £500,000 mark.

The Scot, who joined from Colchester in December 1994 when Ipswich were bottom of the Premiership and took them back up again last season after a series of play-off near-misses, declared: "I couldn't be any happier. Ipswich has always been a special club for me.

"I've had a long relationship as player and manager, stretching back over more than 20 years. When I came back here as manager six years ago, I said it was a dream come true.

"It has certainly proved to be. The support of the club and the fans since then has been absolutely fantastic.

"Last year, in taking the club back to the Premiership, was the most special moment of my career as a player or manager.

"This year, it has just got better and better for everyone concerned. There is lots still to be done but I am so proud of the way we have performed at the highest level."

Ipswich chairman David Sheepshanks revealed that the new contract placed Burley "among the top echelons of football managers in England" and was a "measure of our belief in his talents".

He added: "I doubt that the club can call any more important press conference than announcing a new contract for their manager.

"George has done tremendously well over the past six years and this is due reward and recognition for that.

"We are fourth in the Premiership, still challenging for a Champions League place and in the Uefa Cup for sure so there is a tremendous amount to celebrate.

"So much of that is down to George."

fields.headline: Press freedom in Fiji
fields.standfirst:
Fiji's free press came through the test of last year's coup but there are broader cultural pressures on journalistic objectivity
Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Fiji's free press came through the test of last year's coup but there are broader cultural pressures on journalistic objectivity, says Reggie Dutt of the Fiji Sun.
fields.body:
Press freedom takes a whole new meaning when it comes to Fiji.

First of all, newspapers and journalists in Fiji are not subject to any specific laws that could bar press freedom.

And we don't expect that to change any time soon, well, unless a draconian government comes to power.

We have our self-regulations, usually unwritten, but inbred in most local journalists.

The press, and the media at large, has to be culturally sensitive, the need arising from traditional ties to and respect for traditional Fijian institutions like the Great Council of Chiefs and also high chiefs.

The coup last May was one of the most trying times for local journalists, especially, the indigenous; but everyone came out of that experience wiser.

There were times during the coup when the terrorists attacked and threatened the media: on May 28th the Fiji Television station in Suva was trashed by armed terrorists, forcing the station off air for two days and there were numerous threats to local newspapers for stories not suiting the terrorists' tastes throughout the crisis.

Near parliament in Suva, where the terrorists had taken the government hostage, Fiji Sun cameraman, Sitiveni Moce was assaulted by armed gunmen and ended up hospitalised.

The sensitivities so prevalent in the Fijian society were tested and many indigenous journalists had to live with the reprimand of their kinsmen for trying to maintain objectivity during the whole crisis.

Indo-fijian journalists like myself, were encouraged not to go near parliament by most media organisations out of fear they might be attacked the nationalist gunmen. As one of the few Indo-fijian faces around parliament on Friday 19th last May, I felt anything but secure.

One of the classic cases of a journalist being shunned by his own people for not respecting his chief is Jo Nata, sadly a coup accomplice last May and in custody right now. Nata did investigative reports on business dealings of his chief and former president Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara and was rebuked by his people.

That aside, there is a local media code ethics but the onus is on the individual journalist to adhere to it.

We count ourselves lucky coming out of the political crisis last year without having any restrictions imposed and I guess we should be when we look at the plight of our counterparts overseas who have not been as lucky.

Reggie Dutt is a journalist with the Fiji Sun, and currently completing his studies in journalism.

fields.headline: Promoting freedom in Burma
fields.standfirst:
Only the generals have the freedom of the press in Burma - but the internet is providing one channel for real information
Press Freedom campaign
fields.trailText: Only the generals have the freedom of the press in Burma - but the internet is providing one channel for real information, says Aung Zaw of Irrawaddy magazine.
fields.body:
As an exiled journalist who is detested by the Burmese military government, my life is full of challenges.

Yet I have also had some fascinating and unexpected experiences since I began my career as journalist in 1993, when I set up an independent media group to publish a political magazine reflecting the Burmese situation.

This magazine provides an alternative to those who are fed up with both the regime-controlled papers and bulletins put out by members of the opposition in exile.

Promoting freedom of the press among Burmese people both in and out of Burma is a tough job, but after suffering years of oppression, there are many Burmese who appreciate the nobility and importance of this freedom. These days, healthy debate and professional, constructive reporting are in constant demand from Burmese living both in and out of their homeland.

The internet is a miraculous tool for disseminating news and information. Nevertheless, many tend to abuse it rather than using it in constructive ways to help mankind. The benefits of using the internet for Burmese in exile are tremendous: better communication and better information. However, the generals in Rangoon see use of the internet as a threat to their authority.

Recently, the military intelligence chief in my country said that press freedom in Burma is permitted to an appropriate degree. This claim is total nonsense, as, in fact, press freedom in Burma is completely non-existent. At this moment, about twenty professional journalists are languishing in Burma's gulag.

Nevertheless, in a sense he is right, as the generals themselves enjoy absolute press freedom. They can attack democratic principles, insult the whole population and publish whatever they like in the government-controlled papers, radio and TV.

Aung Zaw is the editor of Irrawaddy magazine, established by Burmese citizens in exile to promote press freedom and access to unbiased information and which also covers other areas of Southeast Asia.

fields.headline: Historic canal reopens to visitors
fields.trailText: The newly restored route is expected to create 400 jobs and generate investment along the canal corridor.   One trip between Marsden and Diggle costs £35 per boat and will take more than three hours.
fields.body:
At the heart of the Huddersfield narrow canal, which reopened yesterday after lying derelict for almost 60 years, is the Standedge tunnel, described as the longest, highest and deepest in Britain.

"It is also the darkest, dirtiest and wettest," said Fred Carter, the British Waterways pilot who from today will guide visitors on trips through one of the seven wonders of the canal age.

"If anyone is claustrophobic, please let me know now," he added, as a unique electric tug began silently to push a narrow boat into the tunnel entrance on the Yorkshire side.

The Standedge tunnel is three and a quarter miles long and 645ft above sea level. It is 638ft below where sheep graze on one of the wildest parts of the Pennines and took 16 years to complete. Construction gangs were 16ft out when they met in the dark, which explains why the tunnel has a bend in the middle.

Fifty navvies, earning about 5p an hour, had died in rock falls and explosions by the time the tunnel opened in 1811.

"You cannot come here without being impressed by what you see and those men went through. Think of those guys working away in here by candlelight," Mr Carter said.

The tunnel closed to traffic in 1944 and most of the 20-mile canal, which links Huddersfield with Ashton-under-Lyne, died with it. But in 1974 the Huddersfield Canal Society was formed to restore it, although cynics promptly predicted that restoration would never happen.

Asked yesterday whether he was pleased to have been able to prove them wrong, David Sumner, the society's chairman, said: "Not half."

"Seventy-four locks had been destroyed, 17 bridges lowered, five pipe lines laid at water level, and 2,200 metres of the line had been filled in," he said at the opening ceremony.

"It's a great testament to the faith of everyone who has supported us. It's the end of a hard slog."

The society brought together three local councils and British Waterways for a £30m restoration programme supported by a £14.85m grant from the millennium commission and £12m from English Partnerships.

The newly restored route is expected to create 400 jobs and generate investment along the canal corridor.

In the canal's commercial heyday, leggers used their feet to propel boats through the Standedge tunnel in about four hours. But in 1914, David Whitehead, a stocky man with, according to a contemporary photograph, a perilously an gled flat cap, walked a boat through in 85 minutes.

Today's boats will be pulled through by the electronic tug. One trip between Marsden and Diggle costs £35 per boat and will take more than three hours.

"Seventy-four locks had been destroyed, 17 bridges lowered, five pipe lines laid at water level, and 2,200 metres of the line had been filled in," he said at the opening ceremony. "It's a great testament to the faith of everyone who has supported us. It's the end of a hard slog." The society brought together three local councils and British Waterways for a £30m restoration programme supported by a £14.85m grant from the millennium commission and £12m from English Partnerships. The newly restored route is expected to create 400 jobs and generate investment along the canal corridor. In the canal's commercial heyday, leggers used their feet to propel boats through the Standedge tunnel in about four hours. But in 1914, David Whitehead, a stocky man with, according to a contemporary photograph, a perilously an gled flat cap, walked a boat through in 85 minutes. Today's boats will be pulled through by the electronic tug. One trip between Marsden and Diggle costs £35 per boat and will take more than three hours.

fields.headline: Week 35: the expert's view
fields.standfirst: The Camel tells you how to bet and, more importantly, how not to bet
fields.trailText: The Camel tells you how to bet and, more importantly, how not to bet.
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):

Scott Murray = £143.04

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes) = £45.00

The Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective = £23.46

Sean Ingle = £13.32

Scott Murray: Bradford to win at Everton £5 @ 7/2

Bet lost - Bradford missed two penalties and lost 2-1

Bradford are appalling, Everton are merely moderate. Did this look a promising medium for a value wager for last weekend's football programme? According to the intrepid Mr. Murray it certainly did, and if it weren't for the inept penalty taking of the Italian prima donna Carbone, he would have been at the payout window as usual.

Everton's injury crisis is well documented, although rumours Walter Smith was seen in the Blue and White bar prior to the game asking if Everton fanatics Traci and Leigh had bought their boots to the game can be discounted. They certainly have been in shocking form recently, and this camel has profited greatly from their ineptitude in recent weeks by opposing them regularly.

Whether Bradford were a suitable medium for the value scout at 7/2 is debatable. Since their relegation has become a formality, their form has undoubtedly improved, playing without pressure often does this to condemned teams. But, with Everton still needing a win to avoid joining them in Nationwide, the stakes in this clash were infinitely higher than for the Bantams, and while Scott's bet wasn't entirely without merit, I decided to keep my money in my pocket on this occasion. If they had been 9/2 I might have been tempted to indulge. But, they weren't and I wasn't.

The Prince of Punts (aka Paul MacInnes): Leicester to beat Newcastle 10/3 @ £5

Bet lost - a last-minute Carl Cort goal gave Newcastle a 1-0 victory

Oppose weak favourites by all means. That is one well-trodden route to long term punting success. But - and it's a big but - whether you should oppose a weak favourite with a team who has been beaten in its last eight (count them) outings is another matter altogether.

In my experience, matches between two teams with absolutely nothing to play for are best swerved for punting purposes. The games are too random to predict with any certainty and I doubt if even the shrewdest investor can claim with honesty that a value wager exists more than very infrequently.

Certainly in this case I don't think Leicester were a good bet. Teams with a passionate home following such as Newcastle can often be expected to perform better than may be expected at this stage as they don't want to disappoint their supporters.

I certainly couldn't advocate backing Newcastle at odds-on, so no bet would have been my advice here.

Sarah Burdett of the Guardian Unlimited Punters Collective: Manchester City v West Ham United, draw £5 @ 12/5

Bet lost - despite incessant Hammers pressure, City held on for a 1-0 win

I'm afraid to say this selection had all the hallmarks of a guess. This match looked like a punting minefield to me. The enigmatic Hammers against the mediocre City. Could anyone honestly feel confident enough of the outcome to place a bet on it?

West Ham proved in their FA Cup run with wins at Manchester United and Sunderland that they are more than capable of winning at the most inhospitable venues. But whether they could be expected to repeat this here was obviously doubtful, as their moderate recent league form has proved. City's cause has looked hopeless for a long time now, although their last two outings proved the spirit was willing even if the talent wasn't.

To my eyes, this game revolved around which version of West Ham turned up. They are so inconsistent, I think betting in their matches is impossible. If the sublime team turned up, they were more than capable of walloping City, but if the "couldn't care less" team turned up, City might be able to eke out a result. As with most matches involving very inconsistent teams, I believe this match was a definite no bet.

Sean Ingle: Las Palmas v Real Sociedad: Real Sociedad to win £7 @ 9/4

Bet lost - Las Palmas won 2-1

Is this a new Mr Ingle making his selections for the weekend's football? Gone are the bizarre mix of first goalscorer, scorecast and bad-value trebles. Instead we are confronted with a well researched, deeply thought out single selection, which was almost certainly represented value.

I would say the only reason Las Parmas were the bookie's favourites was home advantage. But I have found that in relegation dogfights home advantage is spurious. The team most likely to win is either the hungrier or the more talented outfit. From their recent form I would agree that Sociedad were the more likely winner here. Even though the bet lost, I would say it was a good bet, and it would win more than the 31% represented by the odds available.

If Mr Ingle continues making selections like this he will ultimately be a winning punter.

webTitle: May Day mood begins to darken

fields.headline: May Day mood begins to darken
fields.standfirst: Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText: At 7.30am the 150 or so cyclists were heavily outnumbered by police, and almost by the media - at least six film crews and countless photographers and reporters were outside Liverpool St station.
fields.body:
At 7.30am the 150 or so cyclists were heavily outnumbered by police, and almost by the media - at least six film crews and countless photographers and reporters were outside Liverpool St station.

For 30 minutes numbers grew, as cyclists became less self-conscious, and more confident.

Bemused commuters pushed past lined up bicycles as flyers urging the boycott of Barcardi, the participation in Critical Mass bike rides, and the end of world capitalism were handed out.

Tubers and whistles signalled the start of the ride, and at 7.55am a collection of bicycles, tandems and skateboards set off at a crawls pace through the City.

The convoy - now around 500 strong and about 30% female - included a man dressed as Sherlock Holmes, two Batmen and a women in Taffeta.

As office workers peered through their windows, the convoy stopped to good-naturedly jeer a McDonald's.

For an hour, the ride continued in this good-humoured manner but at 8.55am the ride ground to a halt and confusion reigned at Monument in the City.

A man was forcibly pulled from the crowd by six police officers and then shielded by a line of 30 policemen in riot gear.

Immediately bicycles were laid on the ground and chants of "Shame on you" were hurled at the police.

Another man was pulled from the crowd and was bundled behind police lines, as the mood among cyclists quickly turned fearful and angry.

An impasse, with lines of running police suddenly emerged, but after 10 minutes, and with the first snatched protester released back into the crowd, the mass ride headed onwards, past a second heavily defended McDonald's.

All the time, commuters and office workers paused to cheer or heckle the demonstrators.

They were Spanish and German speakers among the riders but only three or four protesters fitted the stereotype of an anarchist - dressed in balaclava's and sunglasses.

At 9.30am a police helicopter appeared in the sky monitoring the convoy's progression to King's Cross station.

At the rail station a huge barrage of placards and drummers awaited the 500 cyclists - but not the breakfast which had been promised on a number of the anarchist websites.

A different convoy - of 16 police vans - was also waiting to greet the riders.

How will the Guardian be covering May Day?

fields.headline: Attic Futura's future hangs in the balance
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The future of Attic Futura is in doubt after a merger between parent PMP and another Australian publisher was called off. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The future of Attic Futura, the UK arm of Australian publisher PMP, has been called into question after the planned merger between PMP and another Australian publisher, Independent Print Media Group, was called off.

A statement from PMP said the merger had been halted because concessions required by the Australian anti-monopolies watchdog would have undermined the value of the merger.

"While a merger in its original form would have enhanced shareholder returns, PMP has concluded that the concessions likely to be required to address the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission concerns would substantially reduce the value of the merger to shareholders," the statement said.

Under the existing merger plan, IPMG would have taken a 40% stake in PMP.

A spokesman for Attic Futura said it was too early to comment on how the development would affect the company.

After the merger plans were announced in March, Attic Futura, which publishes teen titles Sugar, Shine and the new CD:UK magazine, took back control of its UK titles from joint ownership with its German parent company, North South.

Several UK publishers were named as potential buyers of Attic Futura after PMP said it planned to divest itself of the company.

The National Magazine Company, IPC and Emap were thought to be the frontrunners in the race to buy the company.

PMP was believed to be seeking an asking price of around £60m.

fields.headline: Ken Hughes
fields.standfirst: Director who yearned for serious films but won fame with Chitty Chitty Bang Bang
fields.trailText: Director who yearned for serious films but won fame with Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.
fields.body:
Film-going children around the world have cause to be grateful to director Ken Hughes, who has died aged 79, for providing them with Chitty Chitty Bang Bang (1968), a perennial favourite. However, Hughes himself was rather dismissive about this musical fantasy.

"I didn't enjoy making Chitty Chitty Bang Bang," he once remarked. "The film made a lot of money, but that doesn't really make me feel any better about it. On the other hand, I've made pictures that got awards at Berlin and places, and didn't make any money, and that doesn't make me feel any better either." Hughes was most proud of The Trials Of Oscar Wilde (1960), undoubtedly his best film, and his first with a decent budget.

It took the Liverpool-born Hughes 22 years in the film industry to make it into the big time. He worked as a projectionist before joining the BBC at 16, gradually working his way up to sound engineer. During the second world war, he learned his craft on training films, and afterwards started on documentaries and shorts, including the Scotland Yard series, writing the scripts of many of them.

It was a logical step from the latter for Hughes to start directing quota quickies - cheap programme-fillers featuring fading American stars. Among them was Little Red Monkey (1955), an espionage thriller starring Richard Conte; Timeslip (1955), with former dancer Gene Nelson as a nuclear scientist projected into the near future by a radiation overdose; Wicked As They Come (1956), featuring Arlene Dahl, and The Long Haul (1957), with Victor Mature as a truck driver.

The most interesting of these British B-films was Joe Macbeth (1955), set in the New York gangster world of the 1930s, but atmospherically shot at Shepperton. This updating of the Shakespeare play had Paul Douglas in the title role, Ruth Roman as the wife who urges him to murder his way to the top, and an American-accented Sid James as Banky.

Hughes then had a chance to show what he could do with a lavish budget, Technicolor and CinemaScope - the resulting The Trials Of Oscar Wilde was made with taste and sensitivity, allowing Peter Finch to give an Oscar-winning performance.

After that it was back to splendid monochrome with The Small World Of Sammy Lee (1963), adapted from Hughes's own teleplay, in which Anthony Newley, as a strip-club compere, spends a frantic night trying to raise cash to pay off a gambling debt. Using a lively jazz score - he was a self-styled jazz freak - Hughes captured the underbelly of Soho in real locations. But from then on, he abandoned realism.

Of Human Bondage (1964), an artificial third version of the Somerset Maugham novel, co-starred an inadequate Kim Novak, as the sluttish Cockney waitress, and an unspeakable Laurence Harvey, as the medical student obsessed by her. Hughes also was one of five directors on the elephantine James Bond spoof Casino Royale (1967), based on Ian Fleming's first Bond novel.

Fleming was also the source of Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, whose producer (Albert Broccoli), designer (Ken Adam), co-screenwriter (Richard Maibaum) and heavy (Gert Frobe, ex-Goldfinger), were all connected with Bond movies, which also relied heavily on gadgetry and special effects.

At this point, however, 007 and the flying, amphibious car of the title part company as the auto's inventor, Caractacus Potts (played by Dick Van Dyke), flies off with his fiancée Truly Scrumptious (Sally Ann Howes) and two children to the land of Vulgaria to rescue Grandpa Potts from the clutches of Baron and Baroness Bombast. Hughes handled the overlong sugar-coated story, punctuated by dreadful songs and shoddy special effects, with a certain aplomb, and the film earned back far more than the $10m it cost.

Unfortunately, the intelligent epic Cromwell (1970) failed to gain enough box-office receipts to cover its enormous budget. As sympathetic to puritanism as The Trials Of Oscar Wilde was to hedonism, it had sterling performances from Richard Harris, in the title role, and Alec Guinness as King Charles I.

In the end, after quite an entertaining thriller, The Internecine Project (1974), starring James Coburn, Hughes himself descended into the land of Vulgaria. There was Alfie Darling (1975), an unnecessary sequel with Alan Price replacing Michael Caine as the inveterate skirt-chaser, and Sextette (1978), a horrendously camp freak show featuring the 86-year-old Mae West. This was Hughes's penultimate movie, and his first made in Hollywood, where he settled with his wife and daughter, who survive him. His final film was Night School (1981), a slasher pic in which Rachel Ward made her debut.

 Ken Hughes, screenwriter and film director, born 1922; died April 28 2001

webTitle: Wheels: The Toyota Yaris T Sport

fields.headline: Spatial effects
fields.standfirst: It may be astonishingly dinky but the new T Sport Yaris can still seat four people comfortably - and not just tantric yoga experts
fields.trailText: It may be astonishingly dinky but the new T Sport Yaris can still seat four people comfortably - and not just tantric yoga experts.
fields.body:
The tiny Toyota Yaris was European Car of the Year in 2000 and would even now be hard to shove aside in another category - the Dinkiest Among Dinkies. Back in an all-new sporty format, the Yaris cheerfully embraces many of the design aspects of the toy delivery van - particularly in its snubbed front end and its Tonka-style bumpers. Once you get over the way that its name sounds unpromisingly like Cockney slang for the backside ("I gave it a good kick up the Yaris"), this car is as cute as a fluffy pencil case.

Cute and small. It makes a basic hatchback look almost wantonly space-consuming and vulgar. In Paris, where parking is done with a professional elan that British urban parkers can only be in awe of, the Yaris is the sort of car you might see wedged backwards into a gap, its bumper parallel with the kerb.

Still, these days, a car that craves a reputation for city-friendly titchiness has really got to work for it. Both the jocularly tiny Smart and the Mercedes A class have opened up the market for all-weather golf carts and if your prime requirement from a car is the ability to be able to park it in a pothole, the Smart in particular (roughly half the price and almost half the size) would serve you more fulsomely than the Yaris.

The difference is that the Yaris - for all its dinkydom and its readiness to continue down the kind of narrow urban roads where even cyclists might think about dismounting - is properly a four-seater car, and not just a four-seater in a merely cosmetic or wishful sense. Most of us will, at some time or other, have been obliged to force ourselves into the back of an alleged four-seater in which the rear cabin is actually little more than an upholstered parcel-shelf, on which there is only room to sit comfortably if you happen to be a nodding dog or an expert in tantric yoga.

From the outside, the Yaris seems set to offer passengers this kind of experience in spades. You know, from the width of the doors, that the driver and his cohort are going to be OK. But what about the people in the back, behind those tiny porthole windows? Aren't they going to be needing oxygen, or even a saline solution, by the time they've finished in there? And how are they going to get into the car in the first place? From the pavement, you may fancy your best chance is by going in head-first via the boot, punching out the seat-backs and clambering through the gap.

But no. Thanks to a spatial illusion unrivalled since the Tardis, the front seats of the Yaris tip enough to allow fairly dignified passage to the back, where one can sit upright and uncrushed in a cabin that is startlingly roomy and, thanks to the sunroof, perfectly airy. One can even avail oneself of the facilities: a moulded drinks holder and an overhead light. That doesn't sound like a lot, but bear in mind that in many rival city cars you wouldn't be looking for somewhere to rest your grande latte; you'd be sitting with cramp in your neck and your knees in your ears.

As a result, the new Yaris can be made to whip around the place and achieve speed as and when needed. That said, you will have to put up with the noise of the engine, which may not be one of the most refined sounds in modern motoring. Other connoisseurs may differ, but I was getting washing machine, with some persistent top notes of lawnmower.

In which case, what you need isn't a tiny car but a tank. Needless to say, hitting a speed bump in the Yaris felt like being tossed into an empty skip.

Other reservations: the dashboard is a grim tundra of slick plastic; the dials are in the middle of the dash, located in their own elliptical bay and angled exclusively towards the driver - depriving passengers of the fun of complaining about how fast you are going. And turning to look over my shoulder during conventional reversing manoeuvres, I kept squishing my nose on the headrest. But at least the people in the back were comfy.

Toyota Yaris T Sport

Price: £11,995

Top speed: 118 mph

Acceleration: 0-62 in 9 seconds

Consumption: 40.9 mpg (combined)

At the wheel: Kylie Minogue

On the stereo: Little Feat

En route for: Littlehampton

webTitle: Crunch time in Hollywood words war

fields.headline: Crunch time in Hollywood words war
fields.trailText: Hollywood is working on a cliffhanger which will reach its climax tonight in one of five ways, which include its film and television actors being left speechless
fields.body:
Hollywood is working on a cliffhanger which will reach its climax tonight in one of five ways, which include its film and television actors being left speechless.

The 11,500 members of the Writers' Guild of America may strike now, defer action until the summer, win or lose the battle, or arrive at a compromise with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers.

A strike would test the Cheers writer and producer Rob Long's assertion in Conversations With My Agent, his insider's account of screen industry bedlam, that "the main reason television sitcoms are so bad is that too many educated people are involved in creating them".

On the big screen an eventual return to work might resemble the world of F Scott Fitzgerald's Pat Hobby Stories, the sour 1930s satires about a washed-up hack writer trying, none too hard and none too successfully, to get back into the business.

"It could be a disaster all round if a strike should hold," said Paul Schulman, president of Schulman/Adanswers, a New York media-buying company. "Some people will desert permanently, finding other things to do with their time: on the internet or with programming, other than network programming."

Neither side was speaking to the press yesterday but the feeling was that neither wanted to risk a strike when the economy is slowing down, or to repeat the 1988 stoppage which is estimated to have cost the industry $500m (£347m).

On that occasion the writers made their point by picketing studios with wordless banners.

Richard Riordan, the mayor of Los Angeles, has produced a study which estimates that a strike would cost the city $6.9bn (£4.8bn) in business and 130,000 jobs, raising the unemployment rate from 4.8% to 6.9%.

Negotiations between the parties broke down in March and resumed at the weekend.

The main issue for film writers is respect for their craft: they want to curb directors who like to put their names after the phrase "A film by", even though they may not have written any of it.

The television writers are more concerned about money: they want a bigger share of the residuals, the payments received when shows are sold abroad or on tape or DVD, or are rerun on television.

If there is a strike, cinema-goers and television viewers will not notice much of a difference at first.

The studios have accelerated production and have 76 more films on general release than at this time last year.

Television shows such as Sex in the City would not be affected because the summer schedules are completed. In time, however, the small screen might have to run more script-free "reality" shows such as Survivor, and firm producers might turn to old unproduced scripts or foreign films.

"Imagine if the networks' Monday line-up was essentially Survivor, Millionaire and Weakest Link, and then on Tuesday Survivor, Millionaire, and Weakest Link," said Doug Lieblein, a writer-producer of the CBS comedy Yes, Dear.

"The networks may pretend that won't kill them, but it will."

There was little television production planned until the summer, he said.

fields.headline: Stop dithering, BT told
fields.standfirst: Legal & General seeks 'fixed way forward' before supporting £5bn rights issue
fields.trailText: A leading shareholder in BT yesterday publicly expressed increasing frustration with the troubled company for its failure to decide on a strategy for recovery. By David Teather.
fields.body:
A leading shareholder in BT yesterday publicly expressed increasing frustration with the troubled company for its failure to decide on a strategy for recovery.

Legal & General, which holds around 3% of the share capital in BT, also warned that it would want a fixed way forward in place before supporting a rights issue to reduce the company's £30bn debt.

"We will be having a full and frank discussion with them when they come to us but this is not just about people in charge; it's about belief in the strategy," said L&G investment director, David Rough. "We don't want the strategy revisited again in six months time."

L&G favours BT splitting itself into parts with much of the debt shouldered by the "quasi-utility" network business. But the company should not, Mr Rough said, consider selling assets at distressed prices.

"We would rather see a rights issue than the sale of parts of the business at ridiculous prices. A deep discounted rights issue, around half the current share price, would be the norm," he said.

"It can't be right to give away existing assets to try and reduce debts. There has been significant turmoil over the number of strategies that BT has been running at one time.

"It would be nice to have the board and management all on one side. It would be nice to know they have a single strategy in place that they believe they could proceed on."

The comments will not go unnoticed by Sir Christopher Bland, the BBC chairman who takes up the same post at BT today. Sir Christopher said last week he hoped to accelerate the programme of debt reduction at BT.

A BT spokesman said his first few days would be spent getting to know the executive board and understanding the logistics of the company.

Mr Rough refused to be drawn on L&G's view of whether BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield should keep his job after the resignation of chairman Sir Iain Vallance last week. But he said: "There's a real dichotomy at BT. The management of 12 months ago when there was a different strategy may not be the one needed for the next couple of years."

BT is expected to approach investors with plans for a rights issue to raise north of £5bn. The new share issue is expected to be discounted to make sure it raises the required amount of cash. Underwriting fees would also be far lower with a discounted issue because of the lower risk associated.

BT could currently issue only 5% of its share capital without going to an extraordinary general meeting for approval.

Shares in BT yesterday rallied slightly after falling last week on the assumption that Sir Iain's departure was the quid pro quo for a rights issue. They closed 8p higher at 557p.

L&G also warned BT could still lose its "A" status credit rating, even if it sticks to its pledge of reducing debt by £10bn this year.

David North, associate director of bonds at L&G, said: "Even if they succeed in reducing debt by £10bn this year, without knowing anything further of their plans, that would be a 'BBB' rating."

Falling below BBB would be "fatal" for BT, taking it into junk bond territory.

BT is not alone in being weighed down by debt, largely built up from the acquisition of licences for next generation mobile phones. France Télécom, Deutsche Telekom and KPN of the Netherlands all face similar issues.

fields.headline: Tuesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours are preparing to destroy the capitalist system, comrade
fields.trailText: Newcastle are likely complete the £4m signing of Vitesse Arnhem striker Victor Sikora at the end of the season. According to Teamtalk, Bobby Robson has been in lengthy talks with the Dutch club and negotiations are said to be "at an advanced stage". "I don't want to talk about targets and alert other clubs," said an unusually coy Robson, "but I can't disguise where I've been. I was on club business and all I will say is that we know what we want and we have to decide whether we can get it."
fields.body:
Newcastle are likely complete the £4m signing of Vitesse Arnhem striker Victor Sikora at the end of the season. According to Teamtalk, Bobby Robson has been in lengthy talks with the Dutch club and negotiations are said to be "at an advanced stage". "I don't want to talk about targets and alert other clubs," said an unusually coy Robson, "but I can't disguise where I've been. I was on club business and all I will say is that we know what we want and we have to decide whether we can get it."

Now that David Platt has accepted a two-year contract extension at Nottingham Forest, the Mirror predicts that Trevor Francis will take over at Southampton.

Arsene Wenger will stick with his ageing back four for one more year after deciding not to splash out on a big-name defender, claims the Mirror. The paper reckons that Wenger will ask his defence for "one last hurrah before sending them into retirement next summer". However, the Mirror does hedge its bets, claiming that Wenger might move for Lyon's Brazilian centre-half Edmilson or Barcelona's Michael Reiziger.

Ipswich are preparing "a south coast raid" for Hassan Kachloul in preparation for their "assault on Europe", reports the gung-ho sounding Mirror. And Kachloul himself sounds keen, admitting: "You can't argue with Ipswich's success this season. I think they're great."

"Balti-eating Baggy" Lee Hughes is becoming increasingly impatient at not being offered a new contract at West Brom, reports zoofootball. "I have one year left on my contract and I haven't been offered a new one," he told the website, before hinting that if the Baggies don't get promoted he could be off. "I'm about the right age now to play in the Premiership and any opportunity I get would be very hard to turn down," he said. Zoofootball reckons the bidding for Hughes will start at £5m - and that there will be lots of takers.

Blackburn striker Nathan Blake is "desperate" to join his hometown club Cardiff, according to the Star.

West Ham have denied they will sell Paolo Di Canio should they receive a bid of £5m. Harry Redknapp told Teamtalk: "He is our vice-captain and we are certainly not looking to sell him."

Feyenoord are close to completing a £1m deal for Chelsea keeper Ed de Goey, reports the Star.

fields.headline: BT to sell Japanese stake
fields.trailText:
10.30am: The future of BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield looks uncertain after the group revealed plans to sell its Japanese assets. By Dan Milmo.

01.05.2001: Stop dithering, BT told
fields.body:
The future of the BT chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, was looking even more uncertain this morning after the telecoms group revealed plans to sell its Japanese assets.

BT confirmed it is negotiating the sale of its highly prized 20% stakes in Japan Telecom and J-Phone to its arch-rival, Vodafone.

"BT today confirms that it is currently in discussions with Vodafone regarding the possible acquisition by Vodafone of BT's interests in Japan Telecom and the J-Phone Group," BT said in a statement.

Although a successful deal would shave £3bn off BT's £30bn debt burden, it would also signal the abandonment of one of Sir Peter's core strategies.

He has made no secret of his ambition to conquer the Japanese telecoms market, but his attempt to muscle in on the far east has left BT with expensive and ineffective minority stakes.

Shareholders have openly questioned the value of the stakes, when BT had no hope of converting them into a majority, despite repeated claims that its Japanese holdings were key investments.

The debt-reduction package, and Sir Peter's fate, will be sealed by a £5bn rights issue.

The sale of new shares will anger shareholders who have already had their fingers burnt by a volatile telecoms sector, but they will accept the move as long as it results in a P45 landing on Sir Peter's desk before the end of the month.

Today's announceent, which also revealed the possible sale of BT's Airtel asset in Spain, comes as the BBC boss, Sir Christopher Bland, arrives at BT headquarters for his first day as chairman of the group.

He will lead a board meeting to discuss other debt-slashing options, which will include the trade sale of its Yell directories business.

BT shares rose nearly 5% to 585p in early trading, while Vodafone fell 1% to 210p.

Vodafone will be very close to majority control of Japanese mobile phone company J-Phone if the deal goes through, giving it a prime position in the world's most mature mobile phone market.

Telecoms operators see Japan as the perfect testing ground for 3G mobile phone services, which promise high-speed internet access, data, video and CD-quality music services.

Related story

fields.headline: Farewell my concubine
fields.standfirst: The government may link financial corruption with sexual misdemeanours, says John Gittings, but it doesn't tackle the real problems
fields.trailText: The government may link financial corruption with sexual misdemeanours, says John Gittings, but it doesn't tackle the real problems.
fields.body:
After months of heated debate, China's parliament has finally amended the national marriage law to deal with men who "keep a second woman."

An amendment to the 20-year-old marriage law, approved by the standing committee of the national people's congress, states that "cohabitation (by a married person) with another person is prohibited."

The change will not, by itself, bring about a sharp reduction in the second households kept by many officials and businessmen - usually in discreet suburbs outside the city limits. The legislators have drawn a distinction between bigamy, which is already punished under the criminal code, and cohabitation, which carries no such sanction.

Aggrieved spouses seeking to divorce a cohabiting husband may now seek financial compensation in the civil courts - something that was not available before - but the legislators have resisted demands for cohabitation to be turned into an actual crime.

"We certainly cannot deal with all behaviour which undermines marriage by legal measures," says marriage law professor Wu Changzhen, who helped draft the amendment.

Yet the concept of a morality that is in need of defence by society and the state still plays a much greater part in China than in the west. Ms Wu goes on to say that the measures that should be adopted include "public opinion, moral censure and the restraint of communist party discipline."

The problem of "keeping a second woman" is closely associated, and for good reasons, with the growth of corruption over the past two decades and the decline of what many still loosely refer to as "socialist" morality.

Statistics abound to prove the point: in 95% of corruption cases in Guangdong province over recent years, it is explained, the guilty official or businessman was running a second household.

The "other woman" factor has sometimes been exploited crudely by the official press to explain away the worst cases of massive corruption running into billions of Chinese yuan.

It is also easier to focus upon an aspect of changing male sexual behaviour that is still relatively uncommon because of the financial outlay needed. Far more men regularly visit prostitutes without incurring the same censure.

Yet running a second household also has a particular resonance for a society in which the memory of concubinage is still recent - and a popular theme for film and drama.

It implies too that the "feudal" attitudes, thought to have been eradicated by the revolution, are still widespread.

The first marriage law, drafted soon after the 1949 communist victory, sought with some success to establish new standards for equality between the sexes and shared responsibility for child-rearing.

Yet over the Maoist decades, this emphasis upon normal family life too often became a repressive instrument, forcing unhappy couples to stay together and severely punishing sexual misbehaviour.

The post-Mao reforms since 1978 have been followed, though at first more slowly, by a loosening of these political-cum-social restraints. In recent years, the pace of change has increased to a point which scandalises the old party faithful.

Sexual experimentation before marriage is widely accepted and some young Chinese even opt to remain unmarried - unthinkable in the past, where staying single was regarded as deviant behaviour.

Many women taking part in the debate over revisions to the law acknowledge the need to recognise that China is a more diverse society, but fear that it is also becoming more exploitative again.

There were hopes that the amendments would impose tougher measures against domestic violence, which is said by the Chinese women's federation to occur in three out of 10 families and to be a factor in three-fifths of divorce cases.

Yet the law still only deals with the problem in general terms. A new provision of protecting the rights of children born outside marriage is more specific, providing for financial support by the father and stipulating equal rights with those born in wedlock.

Away from the Chinese cities, the effect of the new amendments will still depend upon popular acceptance - far from assured in many rural areas, where Chinese feminists complain that male attitudes are reverting to feudalism.

Some would argue that the largest category of exploited women today are not wives - whether first or second - in relatively well off urban households. They are the hundreds of thousands of rural women - including thousands of under age girls - who are forced into prostitution or sexual slavery.

fields.bodyText: After months of heated debate, China's parliament has finally amended the national marriage law to deal with men who "keep a second woman." An amendment to the 20-year-old marriage law, approved by the standing committee of the national people's congress, states that "cohabitation (by a married person) with another person is prohibited." The change will not, by itself, bring about a sharp reduction in the second households kept by many officials and businessmen - usually in discreet suburbs outside the city limits. The legislators have drawn a distinction between bigamy, which is already punished under the criminal code, and cohabitation, which carries no such sanction. Aggrieved spouses seeking to divorce a cohabiting husband may now seek financial compensation in the civil courts - something that was not available before - but the legislators have resisted demands for cohabitation to be turned into an actual crime. "We certainly cannot deal with all behaviour which undermines marriage by legal measures," says marriage law professor Wu Changzhen, who helped draft the amendment. Yet the concept of a morality that is in need of defence by society and the state still plays a much greater part in China than in the west. Ms Wu goes on to say that the measures that should be adopted include "public opinion, moral censure and the restraint of communist party discipline." The problem of "keeping a second woman" is closely associated, and for good reasons, with the growth of corruption over the past two decades and the decline of what many still loosely refer to as "socialist" morality. Statistics abound to prove the point: in 95% of corruption cases in Guangdong province over recent years, it is explained, the guilty official or businessman was running a second household. The "other woman" factor has sometimes been exploited crudely by the official press to explain away the worst cases of massive corruption running into billions of Chinese yuan. It is also easier to focus upon an aspect of changing male sexual behaviour that is still relatively uncommon because of the financial outlay needed. Far more men regularly visit prostitutes without incurring the same censure. Yet running a second household also has a particular resonance for a society in which the memory of concubinage is still recent - and a popular theme for film and drama. It implies too that the "feudal" attitudes, thought to have been eradicated by the revolution, are still widespread. The first marriage law, drafted soon after the 1949 communist victory, sought with some success to establish new standards for equality between the sexes and shared responsibility for child-rearing.
