webTitle: How psychodynamic counselling can help staff cope with disruptive children

fields.headline: Trouble in mind
fields.standfirst: With more disruptive children in the classrooms than ever before,  Reva Klein  looks at how a new training course in psychodynamic counselling can give staff the skills to cope while  Marina Cantacuzino sees how such children affect a day in the life of a normal class
fields.trailText: With more disruptive children in the classrooms than ever before, Reva Klein looks at how a new training course in psychodynamic counselling can give staff the skills to cope while Marina Cantacuzino sees how such children affect a day in the life of a normal class.
fields.body:
Imagine for a moment that you're William, a year 10 pupil who's feeling strange. Your parents have recently divorced, your mum is depressed and withdrawn and you haven't seen your dad for weeks. You feel abandoned by both of them and are desperate for attention. You've always been good at making people laugh and find yourself little by little slipping into a new persona as disruptive, underachieving clown. Other kids love it. Your teachers don't and show it by shouting, criticising and assuming the worst of you before you've even opened your mouth.

Now imagine that you're William's maths or English teacher. Something's wrong with this boy, but you don't know what and don't have the time, energy or inclination to find out. From being occasionally silly he's become a full-blown troublemaker whose attention-seeking is a constant irritant and whose underachievement is a real worry.

In a class of 28, William has become a thorn in your side. You've tried cajolery, threats and visits to the deputy head, but nothing seems to bother him. He's got a learning mentor who's suggested that he see the school counsellor, but the waiting list is six weeks because she only comes in twice a week. And, frankly, for one 20-minute session a week, who knows if it's going to be any use? All you know is that you can't wait to see the back of him at the end of the year.

William's got problems and he's not the only one. There are more troubled children in mainstream schools than ever before. One in five children and adolescents experiences a mental health problem serious enough to warrant professional help, but only 10% to 20% get it. And it's not that the rest don't want help, it's just that, despite the government's drive for early intervention, it doesn't exist in their area. With the rise in the number of children displaying emotional and behavioural difficulties at school, including the worrying escalation in conduct disorder, classroom teachers have very little in their professional armoury to equip them to deal with it.

Initial teacher training pays scant attention to child psychology and the vast majority of inset courses focus on curricular subject areas. But without the understanding, expertise or time to deal with these children, teachers can feel overwhelmed, at a loss and defeated by their demands, particularly when set against the diverse needs of the others in the classroom.

In this new era of inclusive schools, no one can say how many children have transient or more serious mental health problems that are ignored and who instead get shouted at, sent to the head or are temporarily excluded, again and again until, finally, they never come back.

School counselling services are very variable, says Dinah Morley, deputy director of Young Minds, the child's mental health charity. "Some are linked up with the health authority's child and adolescent mental health services, but many are hit-and-miss with people who may be qualified counsellors, but have no training in working with children. And then there are many school nurses who take on a counselling role without any training, carrying tremendous case loads of children with mental health problems of real concern."

The plethora of short, general counselling courses on the market and the absence of quality control has led, says Dorothy Eddi Piper of the Trust for the Study of Adolescence, "to some extraordinarily badly qualified counsellors working in schools. On one course I know of, people get called counsellors after just 15 hours of training." In response to the increasing demands on schools, and the absence of appropriate training, Sue Kegerreis, a child and adolescent psychotherapist and school counsellor, has developed what's believed to be the first such course of its kind: an MSc in psychodynamic counselling with children and adolescents, at Birkbeck College, University of London.

Designed for professionals working with young people - including teachers, school counsellors, social workers and youth workers - it's an intensive course that provides the insights and strategies they need to work with troubled young people within the formal structures of school.

In contrast to the short courses for professionals working with children, the Birkbeck course, which starts in the autumn, is a demanding commitment for employers as much as for participants. It runs one day a week over a period of two years for a diploma, or three years for an MSc, with the final year on placement. In addition, students are required to go through psychotherapy themselves once a week.

Schools and LEAs strapped for cash and staff are unlikely to be clamouring for places on such long-term and expensive training courses for counsellors, teachers and related staff. Since the introduction of local management of schools, education authorities no longer employ a pool of specialist counsellors. Instead, schools must buy in themselves, having to choose from the burgeoning market in counselling services run by voluntary and other agencies.

Kegerreis aims to sharpen up practice by offering a course focused on how the young person interacts with the school setting as well as with their home and social environment.

"As well as looking at how the conscious and unconscious mind works, psychodynamic counselling is about looking at the relationships around the child and at the impact of the child on people around them," she says. "It's concerned with the child in context, with what's going on around them and with finding a shared understanding with them about why they're feeling and behaving the way they are, rather than just giving them solutions."

In a case like William's, for instance, psychodynamic counselling would involve the trained adult working with him to see that his disruptive, clownish behaviour was his way of communicating despair and lack of control over his life because of his parents' divorce and their withdrawal from him.

"If the professional just reacts to the child's aggression, it becomes part of the problem," says Kegerreis.

"If a child seems wild or out of control, you can get into a situation where you're just condemning the behaviour and can so easily miss out on the underlying problems."

An important part of the Birkbeck course is the way students are put in a position of understanding what it means to be a pupil, looking at their own relationship to authority and at their own experience as learners. It's something that the increasingly pres surised "them and us" culture in schools, which separates professionals from pupils, doesn't allow reflection for.

"It gives students on the course a way of understanding more fully the kinds of things kids are experiencing with teachers, other figures of authority and their peers. It reminds them of how difficult it is to learn."

Morley believes that there is, finally, "an awakening to the realisation that children's mental health matters," with the growth of child and adolescent mental health services and their attempts to link up with the education sector.

Enabling teachers and school counsellors to understand the mental health problems being played out before their eyes day in, day out, also gives them an opportunity to reclaim their professionalism.

"The space to think is at a terrible premium in schools," says Kegerreis, "and it can be soul-destroying for teachers. If anything contributes to burn-out, it's that."

fields.headline: Four dead in Philippines protests
fields.trailText: The government today declared a "state of rebellion" in the Philippines and ordered the arrest of key opposition figures after clashes between police and backers of ousted president Joseph Estrada killed at least four people.
fields.body:
The government today declared a "state of rebellion" in the Philippines and ordered the arrest of key opposition figures after clashes between police and backers of ousted president Joseph Estrada killed at least four people.

"This is not just a demonstration. This is a rebellion," government spokesman Rigoberto Tiglao said. "I would like to assure the public that the armed forces and the national police are prepared to quell this rebellion."

He said that the declaration by president Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, restricted to Manila, gives her greater power to halt insurgence, but he did not say what those powers are.

Justice secretary Hernando Perez also ordered the arrest of at least 11 key opposition figures today, including senators Gringo Honasan and Juan Ponce Enrile, Estrada's former spokesman Ernesto Maceda and former Philippine national police chief Panfilo Lacson.

Colonel Reynaldo Berroya, police intelligence chief, said that the arrests were ordered in connection with the protests, but did not outline the accusations.

At least four people were reported dead as thousands of supporters of the jailed former president skirmished with police around the presidential palace. According to police, at least 12 policemen, a newspaper photographer and 25 civilians were injured and 30 protesters were arrested.

It was the second time in as many nights that Ms Arroyo survived an attempt to force her from office and reinstall Estrada. She claimed that he and his allies incensed supporters in an effort to seize power for their own benefit.

Ms Arroyo earlier accused key opposition figures, without naming them, of plotting to overthrow her and establish a junta. "The vandalism, robbery and injury and deaths are the work of these politicians," she said in a brief, nationally televised statement.

"They should be blamed. It is clear that their theme is to bring down the legitimate government so ... they would establish their own junta."

Earlier, there were pre-dawn clashes on a 10-mile march to the presidential palace from a shrine to the 1986 revolt that toppled late dictator Ferdinand Marcos.

At least two policemen were killed and scores injured as the crowd, which had been rallying for Estrada's release from custody on corruption charges, forced its way through police lines.

Some officials played down the significance of the clashes. "As far as we are concerned, this is not a large-scale rebellion or insurrection, just a rampage of mindless people who have absolutely no love for the country," said Renato Corona, Ms Arroyo's chief of staff.

House of representatives speaker Feliciano Belmonte added: "We will not become like Indonesia, where upheavals are non-stop. This is just one incident, an outpouring of emotion."

A statement by the US embassy backed Ms Arroyo and called on protesters to "respect the rule of law and let the judicial process take its course."

"Violence has no place in a democracy," read the statement. "The legitimacy of the Arroyo government has been reaffirmed by the country's democratic institutions and we recognise this legitimacy."

Estrada was arrested last Wednesday on the capital offence of plunder for allegedly pocketing millions of dollars in bribes and kickbacks in 31 months in office. After spending time in prison, he has been undergoing medical tests at a hospital.

He was airlifted out this morning, with local TV reporting that he was transferred to a special detention centre at Santa Rosa, 40 miles south of Manila.

Estrada's lawyers have sought house arrest or bail, neither of which is usually granted for plunder.

Ms Arroyo has vowed to permit peaceful protest and crack down hard on efforts to destabilise her government.

"Last night, there was going to be a power grab, but it fizzled out," Ms Arroyo said Monday. "I was hoping they would act so I could crush them."

Ms Arroyo was sworn in January 20 as Estrada was packing to leave the presidential palace in the face of growing protests over the corruption allegations. He denies any wrongdoing.

fields.headline: Nursery stakes
fields.standfirst: The government has made great strides in increasing childcare places - but strangely this good news has gone largely unnoticed by parents
fields.trailText: The government has made great strides in increasing childcare places - but strangely this good news has gone largely unnoticed by parents.
fields.body:
For a government supposedly wedded to spin, Labour makes a pig's ear of selling genuinely good news. Childcare offers some. Look at the chart. Childminders are in decline (though 25% of children in paid care still go to them) but nurseries are booming, thanks to Labour. More places are in the pipeline. Enough is going on for the Daycare Trust to be thinking, not implausibly, of a childcare place for every working parent who wants one within a decade*.

But its survey finds barely 25% of parents even know the government has a "national childcare strategy". One reason for childcare's low salience is fragmentation. This year the Department for Education and Employment is spending £202m on childcare but in 12 separate packages, £3m for toy libraries, £41m to help recruit childminders and so on. A full accounting of the public money available would also include bits of the separate £290m for providing nursery places for three- and four-year-olds in schools and the £450m children's fund giving grants to councils in poor areas.

One reason so few parents have been shouting praise from the rooftops is administrative. In the past a major new service would have been announced with a big bang, like Lloyd George on pensions or Attlee and the health service. Labour will not do that partly because it is sensitive over accusations of centralisation, partly because it has not so far wanted to commit the huge sums necessary to create a new national service, at least not up front. An alternative might have been to force employers to do their bit. After all, productivity and profit depend on parents. Yet only 4% of them get any financial help with childcare from their firms and only 5% of companies provide a workplace nursery.

Childcare falls between stools because the thrust of policy, so far, is redistributive - it has been about assisting lower income parents first. The "national" strategy is in fact sectional, with overlapping ambitions both for poorer people and the areas in which they live. The official target is a childcare place in the most disadvantaged areas for every lone parent entering employment by 2004. But the political cost of such a focus is the programme's invisibility and the non-participation of the middle classes. To realise the Daycare Trust's ambition of a "universal coherent system based on a children's centre in every neighbourhood" - with funding to match - is going to take middle-class involvement. More affluent parents are going to be needed both as activists and as voters to approve the large increases in public spending that would be necessary.

We are some way off. The 725,000 places available last year serviced some 5m children under eight. The appetite for help with care is huge - children between eight and 11 could benefit mightily from an expansion of after-school-hours supervised activities. Some 58% of mothers with a child aged under five are at work and four out of 10 women of working age have dependent children. Health minister Yvette Cooper was extolling the government's maternity arrangements on these pages yesterday. But as more women return to work after maternity leave, shortfalls in childcare places become more apparent.

Still, the number of economically active women whose youngest child is aged less than four rose from 48% to 58% over the decade to last year. Childcare places did expand under the Tories. But in many families it is granny and neighbours who paper over the cracks. Some 70% of work ing women with dependent children make "informal arrangements" for all or part of their childcare. Childcare outside the home is used by 13% of parents all the time and by a further 8% in combination with friends and family.

Labour has wanted to expand employment as its principal anti-poverty measure. The working families' tax credit (WFTC) is part of the armoury and is meant to contribute to the cost of childcare. WFTC childcare averages £33.48 a week, a long way short of the England average of £88.87 for childminding, let alone the £110.49 for a nursery place.

Meanwhile, in another neck of the woods, women ministers, notably Margaret Hodge and Tessa Jowell, with effective lobbying from former social security secretary Harriet Harman, have tried to expand the local supply of places. A total of 1.6m is promised by 2004 - meaning at the very least that the next three years are going to see terrific expansion of employment in this area. That must mean more training and better payment.

It is at this point that the lack of "strategy" shows. Is state-supported childcare a welfare state graft, a new arm on an old body? Open acknowledgment that this is the expansion of collective provision would raise the political stakes but might improve chances of the money being found. Childcare helps families and probably children, too - getting children out of their homes is a key aim for the parallel Sure Start programme for the disadvantaged.

There is only one subsidised childcare place for every 14 children under three who are living in poverty. But, paradoxically, the best way to provide for them might be to create children's centres in every neighbourhood. Childcare would get its missing political charge if state- sponsored nurseries catered for middle-class women who might be able to afford to pay but find the difficulties of combining parenthood and employment just as acute as poorer women.

A full accounting of the public money available would also include bits of the separate £290m for providing nursery places for three- and four-year-olds in schools and the £450m children's fund giving grants to councils in poor areas. One reason so few parents have been shouting praise from the rooftops is administrative. In the past a major new service would have been announced with a big bang, like Lloyd George on pensions or Attlee and the health service. Labour will not do that partly because it is sensitive over accusations of centralisation, partly because it has not so far wanted to commit the huge sums necessary to create a new national service, at least not up front. An alternative might have been to force employers to do their bit. After all, productivity and profit depend on parents. Yet only 4% of them get any financial help with childcare from their firms and only 5% of companies provide a workplace nursery. Childcare falls between stools because the thrust of policy, so far, is redistributive - it has been about assisting lower income parents first. The "national" strategy is in fact sectional, with overlapping ambitions both for poorer people and the areas in which they live. The official target is a childcare place in the most disadvantaged areas for every lone parent entering employment by 2004. But the political cost of such a focus is the programme's invisibility and the non-participation of the middle classes. To realise the Daycare Trust's ambition of a "universal coherent system based on a children's centre in every neighbourhood" - with funding to match - is going to take middle-class involvement. More affluent parents are going to be needed both as activists and as voters to approve the large increases in public spending that would be necessary. We are some way off. The 725,000 places available last year serviced some 5m children under eight. The appetite for help with care is huge - children between eight and 11 could benefit mightily from an expansion of after-school-hours supervised activities. Some 58% of mothers with a child aged under five are at work and four out of 10 women of working age have dependent children. Health minister Yvette Cooper was extolling the government's maternity arrangements on these pages yesterday. But as more women return to work after maternity leave, shortfalls in childcare places become more apparent. Still, the number of economically active women whose youngest child is aged less than four rose from 48% to 58% over the decade to last year. Childcare places did expand under the Tories. But in many families it is granny and neighbours who paper over the cracks. Some 70% of work ing women with dependent children make "informal arrangements" for all or part of their childcare. Childcare outside the home is used by 13% of parents all the time and by a further 8% in combination with friends and family. Labour has wanted to expand employment as its principal anti-poverty measure. The working families' tax credit (WFTC) is part of the armoury and is meant to contribute to the cost of childcare. WFTC childcare averages £33.48 a week, a long way short of the England average of £88.87 for childminding, let alone the £110.49 for a nursery place. Meanwhile, in another neck of the woods, women ministers, notably Margaret Hodge and Tessa Jowell, with effective lobbying from former social security secretary Harriet Harman, have tried to expand the local supply of places. A total of 1.6m is promised by 2004 - meaning at the very least that the next three years are going to see terrific expansion of employment in this area. That must mean more training and better payment. It is at this point that the lack of "strategy" shows. Is state-supported childcare a welfare state graft, a new arm on an old body? Open acknowledgment that this is the expansion of collective provision would raise the political stakes but might improve chances of the money being found. Childcare helps families and probably children, too - getting children out of their homes is a key aim for the parallel Sure Start programme for the disadvantaged. There is only one subsidised childcare place for every 14 children under three who are living in poverty. But, paradoxically, the best way to provide for them might be to create children's centres in every neighbourhood. Childcare would get its missing political charge if state- sponsored nurseries catered for middle-class women who might be able to afford to pay but find the difficulties of combining parenthood and employment just as acute as poorer women.  Thinking Big: Childcare for All from Daycare Trust 020 7840 3350

fields.headline: Down's screening for all mothers-to-be
fields.standfirst: More health checks for pregnant women and babies
fields.trailText: All pregnant women will be offered tests for Down's syndrome and every newborn baby will be screened for cystic fibrosis, under plans announced by the government yesterday at the start of a drive to promote policies on maternity in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
All pregnant women will be offered tests for Down's syndrome and every newborn baby will be screened for cystic fibrosis, under plans announced by the government yesterday at the start of a drive to promote policies on maternity in the run-up to the general election.

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, said she was setting up a network of counsellors to provide support and information to help expectant parents make informed choices about ante-natal screening, including tests for HIV, hepatitis, rubella and syphilis.

All pregnant women in England would be offered non-invasive tests for Down's syndrome, reducing unnecessary amniocentesis tests.

At present 80% of women are offered a test, but there are wide variations in the standard of testing and counselling.

Tests for cystic fibrosis, the most common genetic disease in children, will be available for all new babies. Ministers have accepted the results of research in Wisconsin in the US showing that early screening improved diagnosis and treatment for babies born with the disease, which clogs the lungs and other organs with mucus.

The Cystic Fibrosis Trust had complained of a postcode lottery in screening. It was available for about 20% of newborns, but the absence of a universal service led to children being misdiagnosed and subjected to inappropriate surgery.

Ms Cooper said the government was also moving towards universal screening of the hearing of newborn babies, starting with trials in 20 pilot areas. Quick identification of impairments could alert parents to call on support services.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will tomorrow announce a 10 year programme to upgrade maternity services, with better facilities and more choice for women about their preferred type of delivery. In an address to the Royal College of Midwives, he will promise to invest tens of millions of pounds more on equipment and staffing.

Ms Cooper said: "It is important that every child gets the best start in life and every parent gets proper information about what health checks are available for newborns and in pregnancy. Evidence shows that screening newborn babies for hearing problems and cystic fibrosis can make a big difference to treatment and support and can significantly improve their health and development."

Rosie Barnes, chairwoman of the Cystic Fibrosis Trust, said there were 7,500 sufferers of the genetic disease in Britain and their average life expectancy was 31.

"In 80% of the country where the test has not been offered, babies are suffering all sorts of health miseries. Often they are not diagnosed for months or years."

webTitle: Russell Crowe and Julia Roberts tipped for biopic

fields.headline: Russell Crowe and Julia Roberts tipped for biopic
fields.trailText: Russell Crowe and Julia Roberts are being tipped to play Hollywood lovers Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn in a new biopic
fields.body:
Russell Crowe and Julia Roberts are being tipped to play Hollywood lovers Spencer Tracy and Katherine Hepburn in a new biopic. Peoplenews reports that Crowe andRoberts, who both won Oscars this year, are the "hot favourites" for the roles. "Like Hepburn and Tracy, both of them have a slightly old-Hollywood, mythic air about them," a source is quoted as saying.

A biopic about Tracy and Hepburn, who appeared together in ten films, including Woman of the Year and Guess Who's Coming to Dinner, has long been suggested. However, Hepburn herself has always refused to co-operate, fearing that any film would portray Tracy, who certainly liked his drink, as a violent drunkard. However, the actress is now frail and ill, and, it is suggested that Hollywood studios are gearing up to begin production after her death.

Despite Tracy being married to actress Louise Treadwell, he and Hepburn had a 25-year love affair, which lasted until Tracy's death in 1968. Both were Oscar winners, with Hepburn garnering four awards, and Tracy winning back to back in 1937/8.

fields.headline: Removing prison toddlers 'breaches rights'
fields.trailText: A policy of removing toddlers from their mothers in prison once they reach the age of 18 months is "a clear breach of the right to respect for family life" and should be declared unlawful, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A policy of removing toddlers from their mothers in prison once they reach the age of 18 months is "a clear breach of the right to respect for family life" and should be declared unlawful, the high court was told yesterday.

Richard Gordon QC, representing two mothers convicted of drug offences, told the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, and Mr Justice Lightman that the policy failed to take account of the children's individual needs.

Lord Woolf said at the start of the two day hearing that the cases raised "very moving problems". The two mothers were granted anonymity and were named only as Q and P.

P, a 32-year-old Jamaican serving an eight-year sentence in Styal prison, Cheshire, launched the challenge after being told last January that her daughter, born in July 1999, must go into foster care.

She was arrested in March 1999, when five months' pregnant, and charged with smuggling cocaine. P, who has three children in Jamaica, will be eligible for parole in March 2003.

Q, from Brixton, south London, is serving a five year sentence at Askham Grange prison, York, for conspiracy to supply cannabis. Her daughter was born last July and will be three by the time her mother is eligible for parole in July 2002.

Two other Styal prisoners, J and K, have cases pending.

Mr Gordon said fundamental rights were at stake. The rigid "arbitrary, irrational and discriminatory" policy of removing babies at 18 months prevented the assessment of cases on their individual merits.

The across the board policy was contrary to the European convention on human rights because it interfered with a prisoner's right to family life.

"The importance of the mother-child attachment is self-evident and should be preserved if at all possible," Mr Gordon said. "There is clear parliamentary intent that children in need shall receive a full assessment of their need."

Lawyers for the Home Office are expected to argue that the home secretary, Jack Straw, has developed a policy which allows mothers to look after young children, while protecting older children from the damaging experience of prison.

fields.headline: Foot and mouth costs charity £11m
fields.trailText: Preservation charity the National Trust expects to lose £11m over the next financial year as a direct result of business lost through the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
Preservation charity the National Trust expects to lose £11m over the next financial year as a direct result of business lost through the foot and mouth crisis.

About £8m will be lost due to the enforced closure of shops, tearooms and holiday cottages on their estates, which brought in £11.7m in 1999-00. Income from admission charges, membership and farm rents are also expected to drop sharply.

A spokeswoman for the charity said they expected fewer visitors and new members because of the ongoing restrictions on movement in the countryside, and would be deferring rents for farm tenants in affected areas.

Although 402 of the trusts 600 properties have now reopened to the public about 50% of those in the countryside remain closed, she added.

"Working holidays on farmlands have also been hit hard with 90% cancelled in April and May," she said.

The trust is one of the Britain's richest charities with an annual income of £200m and claims there will be no job losses because of foot and mouth.

However, as exclusively revealed by SocietyGuardian.co.uk, up to 70 staff are set to lose their jobs this year as a result of the biggest restructuring programme in the charitys 106-year history.

Many others are expected to resign as another 250 staff have been told to relocate to new offices in the south-west if they want to keep their jobs.

The trust is not the only charity to have suffered financially because of foot and mouth. The British Trust for Conservation Volunteers, which organises conservation work by volunteers, has directly lost £300,000 in the financial year ending April 2001 because of the outbreak. Its conservation holidays have been hit particularly hard, with 60% of programmes cancelled.

A spokeswoman said: "We have temporarily closed an office in Cumbria because of the crisis and 10 of 20 staff have been made redundant. Several others have been laid off for the time being."

She said further redundancies were possible across the organisation. "We have been able to relocate conservation groups and new deal environmental task force volunteers in urban areas. But if we turn away people for several months we dont know whether theyll be there in the autumn to deal with the backlog of work."

A spokesman for the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds said only 36 of its 161 reserves had now reopened. "Visitors do generate a substantial amount of income but we have not laid any staff off," he said.

webTitle: Craig Brown's tale of two Barrys

fields.headline: Craig Brown's tale of two Barrys
fields.trailText: Craig Brown was the subject of his own phone prank, it has been revealed, when he accidentally called the wrong player into his squad for last week's friendly match with Poland.
fields.body:
Craig Brown was the subject of his own phone prank, it has been revealed, when he accidentally called the wrong player into his squad for last week's friendly match with Poland.

While Brown thought he was calling Dunfermline midfielder Barry Nicholson to give him a shot at the big time, he actually got through to Barry Wilson, striker for First Division champions Livingston.

Brown had been given the wrong number via Dunfermline striker Stevie Crawford, himself a hasty replacement, but it wasn't until Brown started talking about the Pars that Wilson knew it wasn't to be his day.

"I knew Stevie had got a last-minute call-up as Craig was struggling for players," he told the Scottish Sun, "but I said to myself 'surely he's not struggling that badly?' I was disappointed when Craig told me it was Nicholson he was after - but I was realistic about the whole thing.

"Craig was brilliant. We had a laugh about it, although I think he was embarrassed."

Nicholson went on to make an impressive debut in the 1-1 draw in Bydgoszcz, playing the whole 90 minutes, while Crawford came on at half-time and set up Scott Booth for the equaliser.

Wilson should get his chance to impress Brown for real next season: Livingston have now clinched promotion to the Scottish Premier League, with the 29-year-old's 16 goals a big factor.

webTitle: Prison campaigners issue challenge to candidates

fields.headline: Prison campaigners issue challenge to candidates
fields.trailText: Prison reformers are calling on general election candidates to sign a declaration backing a cut in the jail population rather than play the "prison card" during the campaign.
fields.body:
Prison reformers are calling on general election candidates to sign a declaration backing a cut in the jail population rather than play the "prison card" during the campaign.

The Howard League for Penal Reform yesterday urged candidates to back its manifesto, which also calls for more community sentences and imprisonment only as a last resort. The league said it would be open about those who refuse to offer support, though it said it would be "naming and praising" rather than "naming and shaming".

The new challenge to candidates comes after an anti-racism pledge drawn up by the commission for racial equality ignited the current race row within the Conservative party.

The Howard League manifesto also comes after William Hague clashed with Lord Woolf, the Lord Chief Justice, who last year urged politicians to steer clear of playing the "prison card" as he warned of growing prison overcrowding.

The Conservative leader then argued it might be necessary to increase the country's prison population - already the second highest in Western Europe - in order to tackle crime.

The league is also unhappy with government prison policy. Its president, creator of Rumpole of the Bailey, Sir John Mortimer QC, yesterday made clear his personal view that Labour had "failed totally". He said: "The business of leaders is to reawaken thinking about the efficacy of prisons. Politicians should lead public opinion rather than slavishly following it."

The league's manifesto sets out five principles, including basing the penal system on "effective community penalties" and concentrating public resources on preventing crime.

Prisons should "provide a positive experience and a realistic chance of rehabilitation", and the criminal justice process should be based on the principle of repairing the damage done by crime, the statement adds.

Publishing statistics showing that the use of imprisonment in Britain is second only to Portugal among western European states, the league sets out five priorities for action, including reducing the prison population to the European average.

Campaigners also want children taken out of prisons, "proper status" for the rights and needs of victims of crime and promotion of safer communities through social and economic policies.

A spokesman yesterday acknowledged that the league did not anticipate party leaders signing the declaration. However, supporters of penal reform will be encouraged to approach local parliamentary candidates and urge them to sign. The league's policy chairman, Professor David Wilson said:"We were concerned that politicians would play the prison card and we saw an early sign of that when Mr Blair went to Pentonville recently and announced 2,500 more prison places."

The home secretary, Jack Straw, was "trying to do good by stealth" but could not deal with the issue that prison did not work because it would lose votes, he claimed.

webTitle: Change of focus for new look PM

fields.headline: Change of focus for new look PM
fields.standfirst:
A new vision for Britain, says Blair, as his metal-rimmed reading glasses bought three years ago are seen in public for the first time

Guardian Unlimited Politics
Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: The focus groups must have given the all clear: Tony Blair has emerged in reading glasses for the first time in public.
fields.body:
The focus groups must have given the all clear: Tony Blair has emerged in reading glasses for the first time in public.

In a development which seemed to have had no connection with the prime minister's fear of missing the small print in controversial EU documents, Mr Blair brought an understated pair of metal-rimmed spectacles into the public eye when he made a speech to the London Press Club yesterday.

His decision to "come out" as a glasses wearer - often a tricky decision for the notoriously vain political class - followed an embarrassing slip-up at a teaching union conference over Easter, he confessed.

The PM corrected himself quickly when he misread his speech to the Association of Teachers and Lecturers and referred to the "chronically poor aspirations and educational attainments of so many teachers" rather than teenagers, but from then on the writing was on the wall - even if Mr Blair could no longer see it.

"Some things in life you have to accept - it gives a whole new meaning to the phrase a vision for Britain," he said yesterday, as he self-consciously reached into his breast pocket for his specs.

"I see journalists in an entirely different light as well," he told the gathering of editors, columnists and reporters.

The admission represents the final stage of a drawn out journey for Mr Blair's glasses, which were first used only for poring over late night red boxes of government papers.

The prime minister was persuaded to get his eyes tested by his wife, Cherie, who noticed he was squinting oddly at a book while reading in bed. A trip in 1998 to the opticians Whitby and Co in Fleet Street, central London, confirmed that Mr Blair, 48 next month, was suffering from the long sight that frequently accompanies middle age.

He used his neat £200 Calvin Klein spectacles in private for close paperwork and reading when his eyes were tired, occasionally being spotted working in them during the daytime. Now, after acknowledging that he can barely read the briefing papers in the folder he uses during weekly prime minister's questions in the Commons, he has subjected his specs to the full glare of the media spotlight.

In wearing glasses Mr Blair follows most previous occupants of 10 Downing Street.

John Major was never without his unapologetically untrendy pair, but Margaret Thatcher - far more conscious of her image - rarely wore her reading glasses in public and relied on large print notes during question time. Sir Edward Heath and Harold Wilson were both occasional wearers, and Sir Alec Douglas-Home famously wore half-moon glasses.

Sir Anthony Eden, Sir Winston Churchill, Clement Attlee and Neville Chamberlain all had glasses, while William Gladstone used a monocle and pince nez. Conservative leader Benjamin Disraeli was the last prime minister to manage without glasses, although he did use a monocle.

John Major was never without his unapologetically untrendy pair, but Margaret Thatcher - far more conscious of her image - rarely wore her reading glasses in public and relied on large print notes during question time. Sir Edward Heath and Harold Wilson were both occasional wearers, and Sir Alec Douglas-Home famously wore half-moon glasses. Sir Anthony Eden, Sir Winston Churchill, Clement Attlee and Neville Chamberlain all had glasses, while William Gladstone used a monocle and pince nez. Conservative leader Benjamin Disraeli was the last prime minister to manage without glasses, although he did use a monocle.

fields.headline: Fantasy football website closes
fields.trailText:
10.15am: An online fantasy football game that launched last summer in a blaze of publicity has collapsed with debts of £3m, reports Jason Deans.
Premierwin.com
fields.body:
A fantasy football website that launched last summer in a blaze of publicity has gone into voluntary liquidation with debts of £3m.

Premierwin.com, which offered a £1m first prize and £100,000 to the runner-up, said it hoped to be able to pay out to the winners at the end of the season.

A spokesman for the liquidator ,Parker Wood, said the £1.1m main prize money had been placed in an escrow protecting the prize money.

"It is hoped the site will continue to run for team changes to enable participants to continue to play," a statement posted on the premierwin.com website said.

Premierwin.com will not be able to pay the outstanding £1,000 weekly and £5,000 monthly prizes it promised, according to the website statement.

The statistics on the site, which are supplied by Opta, have not been updated since the end of March.

The last entry in the premierwin.com monthly winner's gallery is from January.

The Parker Wood spokesman said a number of factors had contributed to premierwin.com's failure.

"They weren't able to generate enough sponsorship money and they didn't attract enough players - in part due to early administrative difficulties," he added.

"The company also had very high running costs and a huge advertising spend."

Premierwin.com signed a deal with national commercial radio station TalkSport to promote the website.

The agreement involved a weekly announcement of premierwin.com winners on Alan Brazil's TalkSport breakfast show.

But the Parker Wood spokesman said this arrangement had already come to an end, adding that TalkSport had been "pre-paid" as part of the agreement.

He said the current intention was for a premierwin.com winner to be announced through TalkSport within 90 days of the end of the football season.

It was also hoped the publicity generated by the announcement of the two winners can be used to create interest in the sale of premierwin.com's assets.

These include the domain name, data-base - which is estimated to include the 17-18,000 competitors who signed up for premierwin.com - and the game format.

The Parker Wood spokesman said a number of interested parties had been in contact with the liquidator about buying premierwin.com's assets.

"The company has gone but we think it's a good concept and believe people will want to learn from this and create a successful operation, " he added.

He said a shareholder owning 52% of the company behind premierwin.com, Football Manager Limited, had invested £2.38m in the internet venture, including the £1.1m for the two main prizes.

This backer did not want their identity revealed, he added.

The other major creditors include software company Systems for Windows, which inputted all the football results data, and marketing outfit Advanced Response Marketing Direct, the spokesman said.

Opta, which supplied the results data, is also owed a smaller amount of money, he added.

The spokesman said because premierwin.com had outsourced its operations, there would be relatively few job losses.

fields.headline: BBC revels in Sony awards triumph
fields.trailText:
10am: The BBC enjoyed a stunning night of success at the 2001 Sony Radio Academy Awards last night, writes Jason Deans.
Useful link: Sony Awards website
fields.body:
The BBC enjoyed a stunning night of success at the 2001 Sony Radio Academy Awards last night, with its stations, programmes and presenters picking up 23 of the 30 main prizes.

Even by the corporation's own standards - the BBC usually does better than its commercial rivals at TV and radio awards ceremonies despite not necessarily being more popular ratings-wise - it was a good night.

Last night's BBC awards haul was six above last year's total of 17.

The commercial radio sector mustered only seven Sonys last night.

BBC Radio 4 led the way for the corporation with six awards, including a special Sony award for the Food Programme creator and presenter, Derek Cooper, who was honoured "for his pioneering work as one of the first journalists to take the subject of food seriously".

Radio 2 bagged five Sonys, including the prestigious national station of the year award, which last year went to Classic FM.

"Over the last 12 months Radio 2's development has continued apace," the Sony judges said, "and its online presence in particular, has come to play a significant part alongside the station's audio appeal."

Other Radio 2 winners included A Beginner's Guide to Reggae, presented by Mark Lamarr, for best specialist music show; and Stuart Maconie, who beat off competition from Henry Kelly and the Dreem Teem to be voted best music broadcaster by the Sony judges.

BBC regional and local stations came away with seven Sonys, including three for The Jon Gaunt Breakfast Show, from BBC Three Counties Radio.

The show was honoured for breaking the news of the closure of the Vauxhall car plant in Luton and staying with the story for the following 24 hours.

The Jon Gaunt Breakfast Show came away with the Sony news coverage award and the breakfast award for a news and talk show.

Mr Gaunt also beat off competition from BBC Radio 4's Eddie Mair and Radio 5 Live's Peter Allen and Victoria Derbyshire to be named radio news broadcaster of the year.

On a night of slim pickings for the commercial sector, Heart 100.7 FM's Daryl Denham snuck past Kiss 100's Bam Bam and Radio 2's Terry Wogan to secure the breakfast music show award.

And Murf Media, a Sheffield-based independent radio producer, saw off Radio 2's Jonathan Ross Show and Radio 1's Mark Radcliffe Show to take the entertainment award for its Bitz and Pieces CD show for selected Emap and local stations.

Useful link
Sony Awards website

fields.headline: Keep radio spontaneous, says Tarrant
fields.trailText:
Chris Tarrant has called on radio execs not to squeeze the 'spontaneity' out of the medium by replacing personalities such as Kenny Everett with rigid playlists and station formats. By Jason Deans.

01.05.2001: Top radio award for Wogan
fields.body:
Chris Tarrant has called on radio executives not to squeeze the "spontaneity" out of the medium by replacing personalities such as Kenny Everett with rigid playlists and station formats.

The TV and radio star, after collecting his Sony Radio Academy gold award for lifetime career achievement last night, said the UK radio industry was now at a "crossroads".

"When the next Kenny Everett walks into a radio station, for God's sake do not ask him to pre-record all his links for the next fortnight and put them into a computer," he added.

"The test of great radio is sitting in your car and remembering something that Kenny Everett - or Terry Wogan, or I hope in years to come maybe myself - said, 15 years ago."

Tarrant was honoured for his 14-year stint as presenter of the Capital breakfast show, which has 2m listeners.

"Do not take that spontaneity away, do not lose it in playlists or formats," Mr Tarrant told the Grosvenor House audience last night in London.

"It's about choice, the amazing range of personalities here tonight. The music is part of it, but it's not all of it."

webTitle: Leader: Halt the tube plans now

fields.headline: Halt the Tube plans now
fields.standfirst:
Or else we will pay for them over 30 years

Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The government's decision to push ahead with the part-privatisation of London Underground has all the signs of a disaster in the making.
fields.body:
The government's decision to push ahead with the part-privatisation of London Underground has all the signs of a disaster in the making. Most business people and academics are against it and so are the overwhelming mass of the voters of London for whom a safe and reliable transport system is the number one priority. If the government persists with its public private partnership (PPP) - a dogmatic policy being pursued with a relentlessness worthy of Mrs Thatcher - then we could end up with the worst of all worlds: an expensive, unsafe and inefficient underground system for which no one will take responsibility for failure. The numerous sub-contracting companies will blame each other or Transport for London (TfL) for interfering in a re-run of what has been happening with Railtrack. TfL will blame either the government for forcing it to oversee a system it never had any faith in or the contractors (for exploiting the small print for compensation claims in a way that TfL predicts they will). And the government - if not this one then the one after or the one after that - will blame TfL for not carrying out the brief given to it.

This has long ceased to be a metropolitan problem. It is about how we are being governed and whether there is any role at all for a "public sector" driven solution to anything. The government devolved power to London, but did not devolve the thing that matters most to Londoners - the refurbishment of its transport system. We still do not know whether this is because of a paranoid dislike of Ken Livingstone or because they really believe in the PPP approach, which hardly anyone else does, except the contractors standing to benefit from it. Ministers have resolutely refused to defend in public the details of the deal they are about to sign, which awards contracts for a period of 30 years. For once, the right man to do the job - rather than someone plucked from the ranks of the great and the good - is available: Robert Kiley, the highly respected businessman who has transformed the New York and Boston subways. At one stage it looked as though a compromise with the government was about to be signed, only to be scuppered when the infrastructure companies refused to agree.

Bob Kiley's eleventh-hour letter to London Transport makes extremely sobering reading. He claims not only that the PPP proposals are "unworkable and dangerous", but that putting the plans through London Underground's own model shows that the PPP is likely to produce no improvements over the 30 years of the contract (in terms of passenger kilometres) compared with continuing the present set-up. Using train kilometres as a criterion instead, at best the service will match, not exceed continued operations under existing conditions.

There are lots of other criticisms and, of course, Mr Kiley is talking his book. But it is a book he knows very well and much better than the politicians making the decision. If they do not believe him, they should come out and say why. The boneheaded approach adopted so far shows New Labour at its most arrogant and uncompromising. Even at this late stage - with a preferred bidder due to be unveiled this week - the government should reflect on the awesome consequences of being wrong. Sadly, it is possible to sketch the scenario five years on when the national audit office concludes that the project was flawed from the start. Maybe the NAO, which has, unusually, commented unfavourably on some of the principles involved, should be called in for a serious study before the project gets locked in stone for 30 years.

fields.headline: May Day
fields.standfirst: Like the last two years, protests are planned in central London on May 1. Why on May Day? Simon Jeffrey explains
fields.trailText: Like the last two years, protests are planned in central London on May 1. Why on May Day? Simon Jeffrey explains
fields.body:
What is Mayday Monopoly?
A day of protest and demonstration planned for central London on May 1. The Mayday Monopoly website says that it will be a "celebration of diversity, vitality, creativity and the imagination" to oppose the "monopoly that capitalism has over our lives." But the Metropolitan Police and London mayor believe this is a front for attacks on financial institutions, large chain stores and the police officers themselves.

Who is taking part?
Various groups are linked to the day including Reclaim the Streets, Critical Mass and No Sweat. They have their own interests but are broadly anti-capitalist. One, the Wombles, models itself on Ya Basta!, a highly disciplined non-violent direct action Italian support group for the Zapatista rebels in Mexico. However, as with any similar event, many people may attend who are not affiliated to any group but generally sympathetic to their causes.

Why anti-capitalism?
Mayday Monopoly says capitalism is the "logic of an economy that produces war, famine, ecological destruction, fear and instability in its search to accumulate profit." Not everyone agrees with this, especially since war has existed since pre-capitalist times, but there is a growing awareness of the specific nature of the global economic system. The power of the multinational companies to alter the societies where they do business and exploit cheap labour in developing countries is one example. Protests against world trade in Seattle, Quebec and Prague, and books such as Naomi Klein's No Logo, have brought these issues to a wider audience.

What will the protestors be doing?
This is the contentious part. Nothing is scheduled for Mayday save a mass cycle between London railway stations to disrupt motorists in the morning and a mass convergence of protestors at Oxford Circus in the afternoon. Police are concerned what will happen in the intervening hours: they say an encouragement to take "autonomous" DIY action against symbols of capitalism in Mayday Monopoly's publicity material is little more than a call to arms. Senior officers estimate that a core of 1,000 demonstrators from all over the country are intending to cause trouble, and that their strategy will involve injuring police officers and damaging up to 200 businesses and banks, with a focus on Oxford Street. Scotland Yard has promised a "zero tolerance, in your face approach."

Will there be violence?
If history is any guide, then yes. The J18 "Carnival against capitalism" in June 1999 ended with a riot, as did the 2000 Mayday protest. Then a McDonald's restaurant was attacked and the Cenotaph was daubed with graffiti. But there were other events, such as the planting of cannabis in Parliament Square, and a large-scale peaceful protest that involved the vast majority of people.

Violence came to characterise the Seattle protest and, to a lesser extent, Quebec protests. There are three further factors that suggest London may see something similar. Firstly, this Mayday is not a bank holiday and the less committed anti-capitalists may be deterred from attending because of work pressures. Secondly, sources inside the main groups suggest that pro-violence "spikies" have eclipsed their pacifist "fluffy" rivals and, finally, the police will be preparing for a riot, which may go some way to encouraging one.

Is that just police propaganda?
Some stories do appear a little incredulous, such as a suspicion that rioters armed with samurai swords will attempt to infiltrate the protests. Scotland Yard has also said that protestors have been training at US camps linked to the Body Shop and plan to occupy a London landmark for weeks after the event. Members of the anti-capitalist groups have accused the police of using propaganda against them and cite similar stories last year that suggested "guerilla garderners" were a front for activists who would battle the police with spades and pitchforks. Nothing of the sort happened, but we will not know who is telling the truth until the day is over.

Why Mayday?
May Day has been an international workers day since the late 19th century, when, in 1886, six people were executed after a May 1 general strike in Chicago ended in rioting. The day was adopted by the International Labour Congress in 1889. However, the traditional left has distanced itself from the actions of the anti-capitalists while agreeing with its critique.

fields.headline: Win double Sports.com buys Megastar
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Lord Hollick's United Business Media will today take another step away from consumer focused internet activities by selling its popular Megastar.co.uk website to Sports.com. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick's United Business Media will today take another step away from consumer focused internet activities by selling its popular Megastar.co.uk website to Sports.com.

United began its retreat from consumer publishing by selling its Express Newspaper group to Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell in November last year. Megastar, pictured right, was the website for the Daily Star, one of a portfolio of papers bought by Mr Desmond, although the site's ownership remained with United.

Sports.com is thought to be paying less than £100,000 for a site that attracts 15m page views a month, and has 500,000 unique users - showing the decline in the value of consumer orientated websites.

The new buyer hopes to attract the site's customers - mainly young men in search of photos of glamorous women - to sports and betting too.

"The demographics of 18- to 45-year-old UK males is ideal for us and very attractive to advertisers," said Sports.com finance director Gavin Chit. Showbiz and entertainment news will be sourced from the Press Association, while photos will be bought from a celebrity news agency.

Sports.com claims to be Europe's biggest sports news and data site. It is backed by $62.5m(£43.6m) in venture funds from investors including CBS's Sportsline, Mark McCormack's IMG, Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan.

International golfing supremo Tiger Woods and US basketball star Michael Jordan are also shareholders. The venture plans to move into profit by the end of the second quarter next year.

United Business Media is also looking for buyers of its dotmusic.com site. Ministry of Sound and Emap are rumoured to have expressed an interest.

Sports.com is thought to be paying less than £100,000 for a site that attracts 15m page views a month, and has 500,000 unique users - showing the decline in the value of consumer orientated websites. The new buyer hopes to attract the site's customers - mainly young men in search of photos of glamorous women - to sports and betting too. "The demographics of 18- to 45-year-old UK males is ideal for us and very attractive to advertisers," said Sports.com finance director Gavin Chit. Showbiz and entertainment news will be sourced from the Press Association, while photos will be bought from a celebrity news agency. Sports.com claims to be Europe's biggest sports news and data site. It is backed by $62.5m(£43.6m) in venture funds from investors including CBS's Sportsline, Mark McCormack's IMG, Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan. International golfing supremo Tiger Woods and US basketball star Michael Jordan are also shareholders. The venture plans to move into profit by the end of the second quarter next year. United Business Media is also looking for buyers of its dotmusic.com site. Ministry of Sound and Emap are rumoured to have expressed an interest. Sports.com Megastar.co.uk

fields.headline: Gameplay detects glimmer of hope
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Online retailer Gameplay yesterday offered investors a glimmer of hope by announcing that it had received offers for all or part of the group. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
Online retailer Gameplay yesterday offered investors a glimmer of hope by announcing that it had received offers for all or part of the group. Shares in the loss-making firm jumped 2.25p to 16.75p, but remain 98% below last year's high of £11.

There is no certainty that the conditional offers made by the unnamed third parties will be satisfactory, however. Interim results, which were to be announced yesterday and would have revealed the amount of cash Gameplay has in the bank, have been delayed until after the outcome of the offer talks.

Earlier this month Commerzbank Securities was appointed to carry out a strategic review of the group's activities. Gameplay is split into two divisions: one focuses on its technology, which enables consumers to play the games and buy them over the internet; and the other handles its mail order boxed games interests.

Management teams from some of the boxed game division businesses are said to have made buy-out offers.

Shares in Gameplay soared last year as investors eagerly backed its plan to build a pan-European business selling games over the internet to PC, digital television and mobile phone users.

However, the shake-out in the valuation of dot.com companies and the slower than expected roll-out of the faster internet connections, needed to play games on the web, have hit the company's share price hard.

In February the company cut 275 jobs and closed its high street stores, in response to pressure from investors who wanted to see a reduction of losses. It failed to stop the decline in the company's share price, and when partnership talks with US networking firm Cisco were abandoned after details were leaked to the press, Gameplay had little option but to put itself up for sale.

Analysts say it is unclear who would be interested in buying the business at a time when e-commerce is firmly out of favour.

webTitle: A new start for one youngster homeless for nine years

fields.headline: A new start for one youngster homeless for nine years
fields.standfirst: Since he was 16 Keith has been homeless. He is now 25. Last October the Depaul Trust helped Keith turn his life around. This is his story
fields.trailText: Since he was 16 Keith has been homeless. He is now 25. Last October the Depaul Trust helped Keith turn his life around. This is his story.
fields.body:
"I come from Greenwich in south east London. When I left school at 16 I got on a youth training scheme course training to do painting and decorating."

Everything went wrong when I got caught thieving. I was charged by the police. The next day I found myself in Feltham, the detention centre. I spent a week in there.

It was horrible. I would not go there again! There were fights, drugs, all kinds of stuff going on. People would fight over anything. I kept myself to myself. I kept my head down. Luckily I was only there for a week.

When I left I had no one to go to. I was no longer on speaking terms with my family, because of the thieving. I was given a place in a bail hostel in Catford. It was good. There were only seven other people there.

I could only stay there for three months, but there were workers around to help you out. They found me a place in a 28-day hostel in Sydenham. That was all right. It was a mixed hostel. I made friends and began looking for work. But I had to move on.

I was given a place in a shared house in Clapham. Life was improving. I was working my way up, trying to forget about the past. I was exploring different courses and looking for work at the job centre.

I got a lot of help from the support staff. I felt I was getting myself together, but there was trouble in the hostel. I don't take drugs and I only drink socially. But there were a lot of drugs flying around. Other residents started to kick the doors open. So I packed my bags and left.

I ended up on the street sleeping rough. It was so boring. Nothing to do. Just walking around all day trying to find somewhere to put my head down.

I got a bed in an emergency hostel. It was OK, but I could only stay there for 28 days. They found me a place at Spur House, another hostel which was in Lewisham. It was great. At first I even had my own room. The staff were friendly. There was no trouble there.

I was then moved on to another shared house in Greenwich. There were no staff. People could do what they liked. Drugs were everywhere. It was a nightmare. I just walked out of the door and left.

I went back to the street. I spent the next seven years just going round the system. I can't even remember how many hostels I've stayed at. I would move from one to the other then back on the streets for a bit.

Last autumn I had just had enough. I was tired of this life. I wanted to be settled. I wanted to get my own flat and get a job.

I'd been to the Depaul Trust's Lord Clyde hostel a few times. The staff knew me. The resettlement worker Sally found me a flat in Brixton. It's great there. There are six others but I have my own kitchen and bathroom. I've been there seven months. It's the longest time I've ever been in one place.

I went on the trust's six week Step Ahead course. It helped me focus on my future and improved my employment skills. I learned how to use computers and how to write a CV.

Sally from the trust still visits me. I'm now waiting for a permanent flat. I'm getting on better with my family again. I want to move back to the Greenwich area to be closer to them. I hope to get a job soon.

The Depaul Trust fixed me up with some voluntary work doing painting and decorating with Moves, which is a self-help group for homeless people. I like painting and I've done it before. I've got the experience and I want to work.

Life is now so much better. The Depaul Trust has really helped me to get back on my feet. I'm much happier now. I can look forward to the future. I can do something with my life. I'm never going back to the streets."

 Interview by Adam Woolf

webTitle: A wealth of projects empower the disadvantaged young

fields.headline: A wealth of projects empower the disadvantaged young
fields.trailText: The Depaul Trust works with young homeless people, young offenders, people leaving care and other disadvantaged youngsters across England. It offers them hope and gives them the practical support they need to overcome their problems and move towards an independent and positive future.
fields.body:
The Depaul Trust works with young homeless people, young offenders, people leaving care and other disadvantaged youngsters across England. It offers them hope and gives them the practical support they need to overcome their problems and move towards an independent and positive future.

The charity is named after Vincent de Paul, a French priest who, 400 years ago, worked with beggars and the under privileged in Paris. After his death he was canonised.

Today the trust sees itself as working in the same tradition as Saint Vincent de Paul. Although it has strong links with the Catholic faith, it is committed to working in a practical and non-judgmental way with young people on the margins of society.

Perhaps the highest profile project run by the Depaul Trust is the Lord Clyde emergency hostel for young street homeless people in central London. With 26 beds this night shelter offers immediate hope and support to young people whose only alternative is sleeping rough on the streets of London.

The trust has also recently opened a similar hostel in Didsbury, south Manchester. While there are other hostels in Manchester for young people to turn to, this high support project is designed to help those 16 to 21-year-olds most at risk from life on the streets.

But the trust's work does not stop with emergency night shelters. It runs a range of short and medium term accommodation schemes that help young people gain the skills and confidence to live independently. Emphasis is placed on learning key life skills such as budgeting and cooking and living as part of a community.

The charity then seeks to resettle them into their own accommodation. Support and practical help is offered. It is then gradually withdrawn as the ability to cope on their own grows.

Young homeless people are not the only group who need help and support. At present more than 70% of young people released from young offender institutions will re-offend. The Depaul Trust is working with this group to help them break out of the cycle of crime and despair.

The Outside Link project is based in Feltham, Middlesex. It targets young offenders who have little or no support "on the outside". The project's specialist advice worker then helps them to forge links with support networks in the community and helps them overcome immediate problems with accommodation.

Through its one to one project, the trust recruits volunteer mentors from the local community to befriend young offenders before they are released. With the help of a caring adult mentor young offenders can gain a new confidence in their futures.

Employment issues are a key concern for the Depaul Trust. The Next Step project is a good example of its work. Established last January, it aims to provide jobs for young people who have been socially excluded by long-term employment.

The project has set up a furniture store. This involves finding old furniture, storing it, and transporting it to the charity's furniture restoration project - Step Ahead II - based in the Wirral. Training is given in furniture restoration and the young people can take an HGV driving course. Both can lead to full-time employment.

The Community Development project has recently been established in east Newcastle. It works with 16 to 25-year-olds who have few other opportunities. One way this scheme aims to help is by establishing a credit union to help young people learn to budget and save money. It is also planning to run a training scheme in sports coaching.

The Depaul Trust is a diverse organisation. Then again, the problems and issues faced by disadvantaged young people across the country are also diverse. In this sense the trust is responsive. It reacts to poverty, deprivation and despair faced by young people by offering opportunities and hope.

It offers them hope and gives them the practical support they need to overcome their problems and move towards an independent and positive future. The charity is named after Vincent de Paul, a French priest who, 400 years ago, worked with beggars and the under privileged in Paris. After his death he was canonised. Today the trust sees itself as working in the same tradition as Saint Vincent de Paul. Although it has strong links with the Catholic faith, it is committed to working in a practical and non-judgmental way with young people on the margins of society. Perhaps the highest profile project run by the Depaul Trust is the Lord Clyde emergency hostel for young street homeless people in central London. With 26 beds this night shelter offers immediate hope and support to young people whose only alternative is sleeping rough on the streets of London. The trust has also recently opened a similar hostel in Didsbury, south Manchester. While there are other hostels in Manchester for young people to turn to, this high support project is designed to help those 16 to 21-year-olds most at risk from life on the streets. But the trust's work does not stop with emergency night shelters. It runs a range of short and medium term accommodation schemes that help young people gain the skills and confidence to live independently. Emphasis is placed on learning key life skills such as budgeting and cooking and living as part of a community. The charity then seeks to resettle them into their own accommodation. Support and practical help is offered. It is then gradually withdrawn as the ability to cope on their own grows. Young homeless people are not the only group who need help and support. At present more than 70% of young people released from young offender institutions will re-offend. The Depaul Trust is working with this group to help them break out of the cycle of crime and despair. The Outside Link project is based in Feltham, Middlesex. It targets young offenders who have little or no support "on the outside". The project's specialist advice worker then helps them to forge links with support networks in the community and helps them overcome immediate problems with accommodation. Through its one to one project, the trust recruits volunteer mentors from the local community to befriend young offenders before they are released. With the help of a caring adult mentor young offenders can gain a new confidence in their futures. Employment issues are a key concern for the Depaul Trust. The Next Step project is a good example of its work. Established last January, it aims to provide jobs for young people who have been socially excluded by long-term employment. The project has set up a furniture store. This involves finding old furniture, storing it, and transporting it to the charity's furniture restoration project - Step Ahead II - based in the Wirral. Training is given in furniture restoration and the young people can take an HGV driving course. Both can lead to full-time employment. The Community Development project has recently been established in east Newcastle. It works with 16 to 25-year-olds who have few other opportunities. One way this scheme aims to help is by establishing a credit union to help young people learn to budget and save money. It is also planning to run a training scheme in sports coaching. The Depaul Trust is a diverse organisation. Then again, the problems and issues faced by disadvantaged young people across the country are also diverse. In this sense the trust is responsive. It reacts to poverty, deprivation and despair faced by young people by offering opportunities and hope.

webTitle: Sketch: Make speech, show off glasses, cheesy grin

fields.headline: Make speech, show off glasses, cheesy grin
fields.trailText: I went to see the Radio 4 show Dead Ringers recorded last week and caught Jon Culshaw's brilliant impression of Tony Blair.
fields.body:
I went to see the Radio 4 show Dead Ringers recorded last week and caught Jon Culshaw's brilliant impression of Tony Blair. This is the one where he does a running commentary on what he's saying. For instance: "Foot and mouth, terrible tragedy for farmers, sincere smile, crinkly eyes, we can defeat it and we will defeat it, firmly stick out jaw..."

The trouble with caricature is that it can supplant reality. So when I watched the prime minister speak at the London press club awards lunch yesterday I kept listening to an imaginary soundtrack provided by Mr Culshaw. "Ladies and gentlemen," he said, "it gives me great pleasure, button coat nervously, adjust tie, to be here at the London press club, slightly goofy grin, turn head round so that audience can all see magnificent set of teeth..."

"Today I have an important announcement to make, diffident smile, cupped hand lands on lectern in style of parachuting crab..."

We had probably noticed, he said, genial self-deprecating smile, that he didn't refer to notes at prime minister's question time any more. "People thought I knew the figures so well I didn't need notes, rest body on right leg."

In fact, he said, it was due to his eyesight. In Devon he had made a speech about the way drugs and crime affected, well, he was supposed to say "teenagers", but in fact he read "teachers".

"So," he said, "it's time to come out! Scrabble round in inside pocket, pull out pair of wire-rimmed glasses, put them on to loud applause from newspaper executives, editors, hacks and similar riff-raff.

"Sometimes in life you've got to accept it! It gives a whole new meaning to the phrase 'vision for Britain'. Turn round, let everyone admire new glasses, and reflect that frankly it doesn't make any difference to his face at all."

I must say that as an "out" glasses-wearer for decades I was faintly offended by the notion that the possession of spectacles sets you apart from the rest of humanity. I felt rather like Quentin Crisp must have done when all those chat show hosts came out as gays.

Nor are people curious about how your glasses relate to the details of your private life. "Do you take them off, I mean, when you, you know what I mean, er, when...?" they don't say.

It isn't a big deal. We glasses wearers don't have special clubs where we can relax among our own kind. We don't go on marches de manding equal rights. We don't skulk into opticians and try pairs on when nobody is looking, then mumblingly ask if they have anything stronger.

"It seems very strange to do this," he said as he popped them on.

No it isn't. It's no more strange than going to the toilet or scratching your backside. It's not half as strange as putting in false teeth or screwing on a wooden leg would be.

"Now I see journalists in a whole new light. What a very good looking lot you are, cheesy grin, shake shoulders very slightly..."

It is a measure of how well Mr Blair understands the British press that he devoted such a large chunk of his speech - before getting onto foot and mouth and today's promised riots - to the matter of the glasses. He knows that we are obsessed by celebrity, and the tiniest details connected with celebrities. And he knows that we have acres of newsprint to fill with nothing. As I have just done.

To me the most interesting part of the speech came at the end, when he asked us, in the interests of democracy, "to treat the Conservatives seriously" in the election.

Prime minister begs press to give opposition a fair crack of the whip!

"They're not completely barking. Believe me! Sombre expression, stare at floor a few feet in front of your face, purse lips..."
