fields.headline: Violence is our enemy
fields.standfirst:
Today's May Day protesters must take on the bullies who privately horrify them

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: Today's May Day protesters must take on the bullies who privately horrify them.
fields.body:
In today's game of May Day Monopoly, most of the press appear to have decided, the boot will land on all the squares. Armed with samurai swords and machetes, supported by the Real IRA, bolstered by hordes of asylum seekers, the protesters gathering in some of London's most famous streets threaten to bring life as we know it to an end. The police have been releasing pictures of the terrifying looking people whom, they say, have been waiting to pounce upon innocent Londoners since the chaotic protests on May Day last year.

All this, of course, is about as likely as a Tory victory in June. The police are seeking to persuade us that unless they receive extra resources we'll all be murdered in our beds, while some newspapers appear to be using the threat of minor mayhem as a means of delegitimising all protest, violent or otherwise. But while most of the past week's reports are absurd, there's little doubt that some parts of the protest movement have changed.

Four or five years ago, video newsreels such as Undercurrents and Conscious Cinema broadcast heroic images of peaceful campaigners being dragged away and beaten up by police. Today the means of instruction have changed. Crowd Bites Wolf, a commemoration of last September's protests in Prague, produced by a collective called Guerillavision, celebrates anarchist attacks on police lines, including a firebombing in which a policeman - who had not been issued with fireproof clothing - was severely burned. Another sequence frames a police helmet as if it were a target in a video game, before the helmet is struck by a rock and its occupant collapses.

This is a fetishisation of violence, a sadistic pornography of pain. A few years ago it would have been furiously dismissed. Today I am sure that the great majority of activists are privately horrified by these images. But they appear to have lost the will to speak out.

It's not hard to see why. While funny, inclusive, colourful events, organised by women as well as men, still take place all over the country, some of the key planning meetings for the big demonstrations have become dominated by a handful of aggressive and overbearing men. People questioning their plans are dismissed as "reformists" or "middle-class wankers". Inverted snobbery (articulated in some cases by men whose estuary accents come and go as the occasion demands) has become a powerful weapon against competing ideologies.

A few months ago, one of Reclaim the Streets' most prominent activists arrived at a meeting to discover that he had been branded a heretic. A list of his sins (such as speaking to the media) was read out, then he was excommunicated. When conflicting voices have been driven away and the remaining participants cowed, the organisers claim that they have achieved a consensus built on "direct democracy".

The result is that non-violent direct action has gradually been displaced by anything-goes direct action. Though the physically and psychologically powerful people who hector the doubters at some of the meetings impose their will on everyone else, they argue that it is undemocratic to decide how the group as a whole should behave. If some people want to be violent, that's up to them. While nearly all the protesters opposing globalisation, corporations and environmental destruction are peaceful, they - or perhaps I should say we - have become reluctant to demand that our movement abides by the principles of non-violence. We call upon the world to exercise collective responsibility for the state of the planet. Yet we seem unprepared to exercise collective responsibility for the state of our own movement.

The advocates of violence insist that their aggression is insignificant by comparison to the violence of global capitalism. This is true, but it's hard to see how it could be construed as a justification. I have heard activists condemn the continued bombing of Iraq on the grounds that violence of this kind will only hurt the people it is supposed to protect, then go on to advocate attacking the police as a means of saving the world. If, as they argue, advanced capitalism is the most violent of all political systems, then violent conflict with that system is surely doomed to fail.

They, who also maintain that activists shouldn't talk to the press, now seek to justify violence by insisting that it is the only form of protest the media will report. There is some truth in this, but part of the reason why peaceful protest is seldom covered is that the media now expect to see bloodshed, and judges the newsworthiness of the event accordingly. The cycle blockades, the peaceful actions outside corporate headquarters, the cardboard city being built by homelessness activists on Park Lane, the demos taking place in Swansea, Bristol, Brighton, Birmingham, Dudley, Manchester, Sheffield, Newcastle and Glasgow today, will all be blotted out of the public consciousness by images of violence.

Even if one were to accept the legitimacy of violence in principle, it must also be clear that it's seldom the perpetrators of global injustice who get hurt. The only victims of rock throwing and petrol bombing are the police, passers-by and other protesters (after four cans of Special Brew no one seems able to tell the difference). By masking up and refusing to be held accountable for their actions, violent protesters provide cover for any skinhead or agent provocateur who wants either to discredit the movement or use someone else's demo as an excuse for a ruck.

Violent activists are stealing the political space which peaceful protesters have worked so hard to secure. They are squandering the goodwill we have accumulated, the burgeoning public demand for radical change which will disappear or find another outlet if we cannot mobilise it within the next couple of years. Like the police, they compress our protests both physically and politically, lumping us together with them in the public mind, ensuring that our peaceful actions are broken up with baton charges. Violence is our enemy, yet we refuse to treat it as such.

Confronting violent protest requires far more physical and moral courage than throwing rocks at the police. It means standing up to the bullies who seek to corral and dominate some of our meetings. It means seeking, as some brave souls have done during international protests, both to remove the sticks and stones from the hands of masked-up class warriors and to stand between them and the police. We're likely to be harangued and vilified, perhaps even beaten up by both sides. But if we think we're big enough to stand up to globalisation, we're surely big enough to stand up to a handful of its opponents.

If violence holds sway, it will deliver the movement into the hands of its enemies. Many protesters have argued that seeking to tackle it would be divisive. But if we can't divide ourselves from violence, then violence will divide us from society.

fields.headline: Telling the truth
fields.standfirst:
McGuinness is right to talk straight

Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: It has been one of the more peculiar conventions of Northern Irish politics. Almost as a matter of politeness, one is meant to discuss Sinn Fein and the Irish Republican Army as if they were two separate entities.
fields.body:
It has been one of the more peculiar conventions of Northern Irish politics. Almost as a matter of politeness, one is meant to discuss Sinn Fein and the Irish Republican Army as if they were two separate entities. Ask Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein's president, why the IRA have done this or failed to do that and he will tell you to put that question to the IRA or insist he does not speak for them but for the wider and vaguer "republican movement". He will never, despite countless attempts to trap him, speak of the IRA and Sinn Fein as if they were synonymous. Unionists may refer to Sinn Fein/IRA but republicans themselves never confuse the two.

Now Mr Adams' partner in the republican leadership has broken that convention. Martin McGuinness has ended decades of denial and hedging to admit what close observers said they always knew: that he was a senior figure in the IRA, serving as the organisation's number two in Derry at the time of the Bloody Sunday massacre in 1972. The admission came in a written submission to the Saville inquiry into British paratroopers' killing of 13 people during a civil rights march. His testimony is that the IRA decided not to get involved that day, hoping the march would be peaceful - and that he definitely did not fire the first shot, as an earlier witness had alleged.

Was he right to do it? There's certainly a risk. Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party instantly asked what other decisions Mr McGuinness might have taken in his role as the IRA's second-in-command in Derry: they would like to use the admission as grounds for eventual prosecution on terrorism charges.

Still, this was a risk worth taking. For the pretence of complete separation of Sinn Fein and IRA was another example of the abnormality of Northern Irish politics. The secretary of state, John Reid, says this burst of honesty signals a new openness. We hope that it signals not only that - but a new maturity, too.

webTitle: Leader: Halt the tube plans now

fields.headline: Halt the Tube plans now
fields.standfirst:
Or else we will pay for them over 30 years

Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The government's decision to push ahead with the part-privatisation of London Underground has all the signs of a disaster in the making.
fields.body:
The government's decision to push ahead with the part-privatisation of London Underground has all the signs of a disaster in the making. Most business people and academics are against it and so are the overwhelming mass of the voters of London for whom a safe and reliable transport system is the number one priority. If the government persists with its public private partnership (PPP) - a dogmatic policy being pursued with a relentlessness worthy of Mrs Thatcher - then we could end up with the worst of all worlds: an expensive, unsafe and inefficient underground system for which no one will take responsibility for failure. The numerous sub-contracting companies will blame each other or Transport for London (TfL) for interfering in a re-run of what has been happening with Railtrack. TfL will blame either the government for forcing it to oversee a system it never had any faith in or the contractors (for exploiting the small print for compensation claims in a way that TfL predicts they will). And the government - if not this one then the one after or the one after that - will blame TfL for not carrying out the brief given to it.

This has long ceased to be a metropolitan problem. It is about how we are being governed and whether there is any role at all for a "public sector" driven solution to anything. The government devolved power to London, but did not devolve the thing that matters most to Londoners - the refurbishment of its transport system. We still do not know whether this is because of a paranoid dislike of Ken Livingstone or because they really believe in the PPP approach, which hardly anyone else does, except the contractors standing to benefit from it. Ministers have resolutely refused to defend in public the details of the deal they are about to sign, which awards contracts for a period of 30 years. For once, the right man to do the job - rather than someone plucked from the ranks of the great and the good - is available: Robert Kiley, the highly respected businessman who has transformed the New York and Boston subways. At one stage it looked as though a compromise with the government was about to be signed, only to be scuppered when the infrastructure companies refused to agree.

Bob Kiley's eleventh-hour letter to London Transport makes extremely sobering reading. He claims not only that the PPP proposals are "unworkable and dangerous", but that putting the plans through London Underground's own model shows that the PPP is likely to produce no improvements over the 30 years of the contract (in terms of passenger kilometres) compared with continuing the present set-up. Using train kilometres as a criterion instead, at best the service will match, not exceed continued operations under existing conditions.

There are lots of other criticisms and, of course, Mr Kiley is talking his book. But it is a book he knows very well and much better than the politicians making the decision. If they do not believe him, they should come out and say why. The boneheaded approach adopted so far shows New Labour at its most arrogant and uncompromising. Even at this late stage - with a preferred bidder due to be unveiled this week - the government should reflect on the awesome consequences of being wrong. Sadly, it is possible to sketch the scenario five years on when the national audit office concludes that the project was flawed from the start. Maybe the NAO, which has, unusually, commented unfavourably on some of the principles involved, should be called in for a serious study before the project gets locked in stone for 30 years.

He claims not only that the PPP proposals are "unworkable and dangerous", but that putting the plans through London Underground's own model shows that the PPP is likely to produce no improvements over the 30 years of the contract (in terms of passenger kilometres) compared with continuing the present set-up. Using train kilometres as a criterion instead, at best the service will match, not exceed continued operations under existing conditions. There are lots of other criticisms and, of course, Mr Kiley is talking his book. But it is a book he knows very well and much better than the politicians making the decision. If they do not believe him, they should come out and say why. The boneheaded approach adopted so far shows New Labour at its most arrogant and uncompromising. Even at this late stage - with a preferred bidder due to be unveiled this week - the government should reflect on the awesome consequences of being wrong. Sadly, it is possible to sketch the scenario five years on when the national audit office concludes that the project was flawed from the start. Maybe the NAO, which has, unusually, commented unfavourably on some of the principles involved, should be called in for a serious study before the project gets locked in stone for 30 years.

fields.headline: Ebookers thrives against the odds
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Ebookers.com, the online travel agency, yesterday showed evidence of surviving the dot.com meltdown as it announced first quarter sales up 35%. by Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Ebookers.com, the online travel agency, yesterday showed evidence of surviving the dot.com meltdown as it announced first quarter sales up 35% on the previous quarter - and double those of a year ago.

Shares in the company, which recently listed on the London stock exchange at 99.5p, rose up 23.5p to 150p.

Dinesh Dhamija, the chief executive,said: "Our main priority is going to be cost control. We are going to focus on profitability. Growth comes second."

Ebookers would have positive cash flow in the fourth quarter of this year or by early 2002, and profitability would follow shortly after. The com pany, which raised $45m (£31m) from European institutional investors last July, has $43.8m cash in the bank.

The firm reported a pretax loss of $11.9m for the period, compared to a $10m loss last year, and sales of $48.7m. Site traffic also rose, to 10.1m this quarter from 7.6m in the fourth quarter of last year.

"We will continue to remain highly focused on reducing expenditure while maintaining cost-effective growth, with cash burn falling to under $1.5m per month in the second half," Mr Dhamija said.

The company is looking to move its administrative base to India to reduce costs, though without job losses, and plans to extend its services to business travellers.

fields.headline: Scargill still yearns for 1970s rerun
fields.trailText: Arthur Scargill, miners' leader and election challenger to former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson in Hartlepool, yesterday launched the manifesto of his Socialist Labour Party with a call for a return to the 1970s - "the quicker the better".
fields.body:
Arthur Scargill, miners' leader and election challenger to former Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson in Hartlepool, yesterday launched the manifesto of his Socialist Labour Party with a call for a return to the 1970s - "the quicker the better".

The National Union of Mineworkers leader said his party would be putting up candidates in 116 constituencies in England, Scotland and Wales, and stressed on the eve of today's May Day protests that he firmly backed "direct action" against capitalism.

At a sparsely attended press conference, Mr Scargill unveiled plans for a 10-year, £100bn programme to restore railways, buses and airlines to public ownership and slash defence expenditure by two thirds.

Boasting that the SLP will qualify for party election broadcasts in England, Scotland and Wales, Mr Scargill proclaimed: "When someone says we never want to go back to the 1970s, we say: we do, the quicker the better!"

fields.headline: Reuters bolsters US appeal
fields.trailText: Reuters is beefing up its business in the US after agreeing a £188m deal to acquire assets from bankrupt rival Bridge Information Systems. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Reuters, the financial news and information group, is beefing up its business in the US after agreeing a $275m (£188m) deal to acquire a number of assets from bankrupt rival Bridge Information Systems.

Reuters won the assets in an auction organised after Bridge applied for Chapter 11 protection from creditors last month. It saw off a rival bid for some assets from SunGuard of the US. Investors were encouraged by the deal and shares in Reuters climbed 24p to £10.24.

The bid focused chiefly on Bridge's content and trading applications for US institutional investors, an area where Reuters is perceived to be relatively weak. It included Bridge Information Systems, EJV Bond Data, Bridge Trading Technologies, eBridge and CRB Index which measures commodity prices.

The gains allow Reuters to build market share as it faces a potential slowdown in business from investment bank clients.

webTitle: Police failing to stop crooks being jurors

fields.headline: Police failing to stop crooks being jurors
fields.standfirst: Watchdog says errors will make court vetting system unworkable
fields.trailText: Watchdog says errors will make court vetting system unworkable.
fields.body:
People with serious criminal records could serve on juries because a new computer system to vet prospective jurors automatically will rely on data from the notoriously inaccurate police national computer.

The information commission - an official watchdog - told the Guardian that the system, due to be launched next month by the Lord Chancellor's Department, could become unworkable because of the error-riddled police information that might allow previous offenders to slip the net.

The department is planning a direct link between its juror computer system and the PNC to disqualify automatically from juries those with previous convictions.

But a senior official at the information commission warned that the system may breach data protection laws because the PNC information may be unfit for the purpose of accurately vetting jurors.

Jonathan Bamford, assistant information commissioner, said: "If the Lord Chancellor's Department is going to be accessing raw PNC data, which may be inadequate for its purpose, that would breach the Data Protection Act."

His intervention also raises doubts about the ability of the current, manual vetting system to weed out offenders. The Lord Chancellor's Department carries out manual checks of randomly selected potential jurors against police records.

Mr Bamford said: "The PNC data is only part of the police data handling; they have other information. But when other people have access to the PNC who are not used to the inadequacies of the data, then you are running the real risk that people's lives are going to be adversely affected."

Amid growing concern about the use of PNC data across the criminal justice system, the National Association of Probation Officers called on the government to postpone the launch of the juror system after it unearthed a catalogue of deficiencies in police data.

In one case last year, a man appeared at Highbury Corner magistrates' court, in north London, charged with the theft of £2,700. Because of PNC data, the court was told that the defendant had no previous convictions so he was freed on police bail. It subsequently emerged that he was a convicted murderer, released from prison on life licence.

In another case uncovered by Napo, a defendant on a common assault charge last year was given a place in a bail hostel in south London on the strength of PNC information stating that he had only two previous convictions, both for minor offences. In fact, he had 32 previous convictions for a string of serious offences, including arson, rape and indecent assault on children.

Harry Fletcher, Napo's assistant general secretary, said: "I am amazed that department after department is going to be relying on the PNC because of what we know. They have to put this new scheme on hold or they are going to end up with people on juries who have all sorts of convictions."

The scale of the PNC's shortcomings is overwhelming.

Every two years, the Metropolitan police conducts an unannounced audit of the PNC information. The last audit, between January and April 1999, found "wholly unacceptable" levels of inaccuracy. The overall error rate was 86%, an increase of 34% on the previous audit in 1997. According to the Met report, 85% of those errors were, being "those that could lead to serious consequences with the possibility of financial compensation to those affected".

In a nationwide study of PNC data last year, the chief inspector of constabulary found an error rate of between 15% and 65%, with substantial delays in updating records. The report concluded: "Overall, the level and nature of errors, omissions and discrepancies found were unacceptable."

Police forces have complained that they do not have the resources to keep the PNC data up to date, or to train officers on data input.

Deficiencies in PNC data are already the source of serious concern about the new criminal records bureau, which will use the information to allow employers to vet applicants wanting to work with children. The bureau should start work in July, but earlier this month the Commons home affairs committee urged the government to postpone the launch amid doubts about the quality of PNC data.

A spokeswoman for the department admitted the police data was not ideal but said the new system would mean vetting that was more thorough than random manual checks.

webTitle: Germany wants EC to be a government

fields.headline: Germany wants EC to be a government
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor declares there is no alternative to integration

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: German leaders of both left and right made it clear yesterday that they were backing an all-out push for the political integration of Europe by the end of the decade.
fields.byline: John Hooper and Kate Connolly in Berlin
fields.body:
German leaders of both left and right made it clear yesterday that they were backing an all-out push for the political integration of Europe by the end of the decade.

The text of a document drawn up under the guidance of the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, showed that he was aiming for the key decisions on the continent's future to be taken within the next 10 years.

It also showed that Mr Schröder and his fellow Social Democrats see it as essential to harmonise taxes in the European Union: a policy which is anathema to both the main parties in Britain and to governments in some other EU states.

The document, which was leaked at the weekend, was unveiled at a press conference in Berlin by the general secretary of Mr Schröder's Social Democratic party, Franz Münterfering. "The debate must begin urgently, even if everyone does not agree on everything," he said.

He and other senior Social Democrats will get their first opportunity to lobby for their ideas at a meeting of the pan-European Party of European Socialists in Berlin on Monday.

Mr Münterfering presented the scheme as an attempt to democratise the workings of the EU, and the German opposition seized on this aspect to welcome it.

"We have a democratic deficit in the EU and that must change," the leader of the Christian Democrat Union (CDU), Angela Merkel, said .

Mr Schröder expressed delight at the reaction of the opposition conservatives, describing it as "great".

At the heart of his plan is a transformation of the European commission, the union's unelected executive.

"We want the EU commission from now [on] to be strengthened to become a government - a real European government beside the national governments," the SPD's chief spokesman, Michael Donnermeyer, said.

Many of the details of the plan, which is to be put before the SPD's conference in November, have yet to be defined.

In essence, senior SPD sources said yesterday, the chancellor would like a set-up similar to that in Germany with the considerable powers of the states serving as a model for the future powers of nation states.

But it remains unclear, for example, how the proposed European government would be chosen, and whether its leader would be elected by one or both of the chambers in a new, two-tier legislature.

While the document contains several nods in the direction of preserving national identities, it is emphatic that the SPD wants a pan-continental structure to emerge from talks on the future of Europe due to begin in 2004. "There is no alternative to further integration and Europeanisation", the paper declares.

Its key passage is set out in the language of cast-iron inevitability: "In 10 years we shall live in a Europe with a constitution. In 10 years, we shall live in a Europe with a [single] currency".

The document argues that "an internal market and a common currency demand more energetic harmonisation of fiscal policy, especially with regard to taxes on business, the taxation of capital gains, the taxation of investment in energy and the organisation of value added and corporation tax".

If that is enough to provoke apoplexy among some British MPs, then there are plenty of other passages able to incite an angry reaction elsewhere in the community. A proposal that EU spending be controlled by parliament will be seen in France as a bid to slash spending under the Common Agricultural Policy. Likewise, the document proposes devolving structural funding to national governments - a move that would land Spain, Portugal and Greece with the bill for modernising their economies.

The chancellor's blueprint represents the latest, and by far the most decisive, attempt by Germany to set a new European agenda. Mr Schröder, his aides and ministers are convinced that an enlarged European Union will prove unmanageable unless it is rapidly integrated politically as well as economically.

fields.headline: Rights 'conflict with MI5 secrecy'
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: Freedom of expression is a "pre-eminent right" which conflicted head-on with the state's attempts to impose a blanket ban on disclosures by former MI5 members, the defence in the David Shayler case told the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
Freedom of expression is a "pre-eminent right" which conflicted head-on with the state's attempts to impose a blanket ban on disclosures by former MI5 members, the defence in the David Shayler case told the high court yesterday.

Edward Fitzgerald QC described the absolute ban on communications between former MI5 officers and journalists demanded by the prosecution as "uniquely draconian".

Mr Shayler's lawyers argued in pre-trial hearings that the Official Secrets Act - which imposes an absolute, lifelong duty of confidentiality on members of the security and intelligence agencies - was incompatible with the Human Rights Act.

The defence also insisted it was for the jury, not the judge, to determine whether criminal sanctions imposed by the secrets act were a "proportionate" response to allegations of wrongdoing by the security and intelligence agencies.

It argued that it should be up to the jury to decide whether Mr Shayler's allegations damaged national security. He must also be allowed to argue that he disclosed allegations of wrongdoing and incompetence in MI5 in the public interest.

Judge Alan Moses indicated his belief that there could be circumstances when exceptions to the blanket ban should be allowed. He understood the defence argument that it was easy for the state to "fly the flag of national security".

He told Mr Fitzgerald: "You have won that battle. I am not going to throw my hands up and say 'national security' and that's the end of the matter."

Mr Fitzgerald said Mr Shayler should be allowed to tell the jury that he disclosed information about the activities of MI5 for the "greater good".

The judge questioned, however, whether Mr Shayler had no alternative avenue through which to air his complaints. What if his allegations turned out to be a "complete load of rubbish"?

Mr Shayler is charged with disclosing information and MI5 documents to the Mail on Sunday in 1997.

webTitle: Lenny Henry has the last laugh at Montreux

fields.headline: Lenny Henry has the last laugh at Montreux
fields.standfirst:
Comic's one-off for the BBC scoops golden rose as British shows triumph, with silver awards for Weakest Link, Popstars and Coupling

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Lenny Henry, whose comedy career has been on the wane, has scooped the Golden Rose of Montreux, Europe's most prestigious television award, reports Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Lenny Henry, whose comedy career has been on the wane, scooped the Golden Rose of Montreux, Europe's most prestigious television award, yesterday.

British shows almost swept the board in the competition - rivalled only by the US Emmys for international prestige - taking three of the five silver roses. ITV's Popstars, made by LWT, took silver in the variety category, while the BBC's Weakest Link and Coupling took silvers in the game show and comedy sections respectively.

But Henry's one-off BBC show, Lenny Henry in Pieces, beat off hundreds of other programmes from around the world to take the overall award at the ceremony in Montreux, Switzerland. The award delighted Henry and BBC executives.

Winning a Golden Rose can be a huge boost for performers. The pilot episode of Granada's Cold Feet won in 1997, and a full series might never have been made without the award. It went on to be a groundbreaking programme, with the fourth series now in production. The last BBC golden rose was in 1999, won by the surreal sketch show The League of Gentlemen.

In recent years Henry's career has been overshadowed by that of his wife, Dawn French, star of the hit comedy series the Vicar of Dibley.

He has been moving away from straightforward comedy into more serious roles, playing a headteacher in the drama series Hope and Glory, which received mixed reviews.

His winning sketch show marked a return to his traditional strength. Lenny Henry in Pieces, broadcast last December, is understood to be the precursor of a series to be made by the independent production company Tiger Aspect.

Henry's win was a surprise: it had been assumed that the Weakest Link and Popstars, both successful around the world, were the British frontrunners. European shows often take the best prize at the Montreux festival. Last year's winner was The Mole, a Belgian game show format that was taken up in Britain by Channel 5.

The other British wins this year were Channel 4's Black Books, starring the Irish comedian Dylan Moran, which took a bronze rose in the sitcom category, and the channel's Ali G, the spoof character created by Sacha Baron Cohen, which won a comedy bronze.

Another British series, The Truth About Vince, made by Carlton, got a special prize for the programme that displayed the strongest "human values".

webTitle: Berlusconi said to have lied in tax-fraud case

fields.headline: Berlusconi said to have lied in tax-fraud case
fields.trailText: Silvio Berlusconi misled a Spanish court investigating £4m tax fraud allegations at a TV station he partly owned, a Madrid newspaper has claimed. By Giles Tremlett and Rory Carroll.
fields.byline: Giles Tremlett in Madrid and Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.body:
The Italian opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi misled the Spanish court investigating £4m tax fraud allegations at a television station he partly owned, the Madrid newspaper El Mundo claimed yesterday.

It said it had proof that Mr Berlusconi, who expected to be returned to power in the Italian general election on May 13, misled the national court in Madrid when he said his Fininvest empire did not control front companies which received £70mfrom the Spanish channel Tele 5.

It alleged that the companies in the Netherlands and Hungary were used to bleed Tele 5 of money by setting contract prices above the market rate.

Tele 5 and Fininvest have denied the allegations and Mr Berlusconi has denied any personal responsibility for fraud at Tele 5.

"All the accountancy, tax and administrative aspects of Tele 5 were handled by my Spanish partners," he said.

Court documents obtained by El Mundo described the front companies as part of "an international financial network, fiscally opaque, based in several countries considered tax havens".

The paper printed copies of contracts sent by the companies which, although allegedly coming from Hungary or the Netherlands, apparently came from a fax machine at Fininvest offices in Switzerland.

As a result of the £70m sent to these companies in the early 1990s, El Mundo alleged, Tele 5 was thrown into financial crisis and forced to sack staff to balance the books.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday inquiry: MI5 on the spot

fields.headline: Move to testify puts MI5 on the spot
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: The decision by Martin McGuinness to testify to the Bloody Sunday inquiry will increase pressure on MI5 to explain claims made by one of its informants, codenamed Infliction.
fields.body:
The decision by Martin McGuinness to testify to the Bloody Sunday inquiry will increase pressure on MI5 to explain claims made by one of its informants, codenamed Infliction.

The tribunal last year was given a heavily censored account of a debriefing of the informant in 1984, 12 years after Bloody Sunday.

A part of the MI5 document selectively released to the inquiry says: "One thing that bothers McGuinness about the Bloody Sunday thing was that he fired the first shot, and no one knows this. This seems to be on McGuinness's conscience. He has spoken to 'Infliction' about it several times."

The rest of the document is covered by a public interest immunity certificate signed by Jack Straw, the home secretary. A tape of Infliction's debriefing has not been disclosed.

Lord Saville, the inquiry chairman, still has to decide whether to accept the gagging orders demanded by Mr Straw. His officials have interviewed David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, who claims that the informant called Infliction was known in the agency as a "bullshitter".

Mr Shayler wrote in the Observer this year that he came across Infliction when he was attached to MI5's counter-IRA section, T8 branch.

He said Infliction was terminated as an MI5 agent when he made the agency look stupid. MI5 labelled the intelligence he had provided as coming from a "source whose reliability is being reassessed".

Lord Saville is understood to have questioned MI5 about Mr Shayler's comments. This is one reason why the inquiry chairman has delayed a decision on the deletions demanded by Mr Straw.

webTitle: McGuinness vows to clear IRA of role in Derry killings

fields.headline: McGuinness vows to clear IRA of role in Derry killings
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Northern Ireland
Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness yesterday vowed to do verbal battle with the British establishment to stop it "getting away with murder," when he admits to the Bloody Sunday tribunal that he was a leading member of the Provisional IRA.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness yesterday vowed to do verbal battle with the British establishment to stop it "getting away with murder," when he admits to the Bloody Sunday tribunal that he was a leading member of the Provisional IRA.

The Northern Ireland education minister has sent a draft statement to Lord Saville's inquiry into the deaths of 14 unarmed civilians shot by paratroopers on January 30, 1972, in which he acknowledges he was the Provisional IRA's second in command in the city at the time.

But Mr McGuinness insists the organisation ordered its members not to open fire on soldiers in an attempt to keep the demonstration peaceful. And he categorically denies intelligence claims that he precipitated the violence by firing the first shot.

"As far as I am concerned the British army got away with murder on Bloody Sunday and they are presently trying to get away with murder at the tribunal," he said yesterday.

"The people of Derry are involved in a battle here with the British establishment, the British Ministry of Defence. The relatives are in the front line of that battle. The people who were injured are in the front line of that battle and I intend to stand with the people of Derry."

He would not discuss details of his statement, on which he will be cross-examined when he finally enters the witness box at the inquiry in Derry's Guildhall. But he will refuse to name any other IRA member and will be questioned only about Bloody Sunday.

He will say there were eight armed IRA men on standby in the Creggan and Brandywell areas - well away from the Bogside protest - and that all other IRA weapons were secure in a secret hide, while he was on the march, unarmed, from start to finish.

Relatives of Bloody Sunday victims welcomed news of Mr McGuinness's evidence, which they hope will absolve the citizens of Derry of any blame. "Soldiers have said there was an IRA gun battle but we know that's not true. Martin McGuinness saying this publicly will help lay this myth to rest," said Micky McKinney, whose brother, Willie, was shot dead.

But many think his statement will raise more questions than answers, such as his involvement in terrorism since. Security sources believe he is still a member of the IRA's seven-strong ruling army council.

The attorney general has granted all those giving truthful evidence to the Saville inquiry immunity from prosecution but the Democratic Unionist party is calling for Mr McGuinness to be arrested.

The DUP security spokesman, Gregory Campbell, said: "Two RUC men were murdered one mile from the events of Bloody Sunday three days before the march. If the IRA were acting under his instructions on Sunday, were they acting under his instructions on Thursday?"

Others have again floated the idea of some sort of truth and reconciliation commission as a way of healing a still deeply divided society.

The Progressive Unionist David Ervine, a former member of the loyalist Ulster Volunteer Force who served an 11-year jail sentence for possession of explosives in 1974, said:"I'm pleased Martin McGuinness is going to come out of the shadows, albeit just a little bit, but I think republicans ... are still trying to justify their war."

webTitle: Confusion reigns as police brace for mayhem

fields.headline: Confusion reigns as police brace for mayhem
fields.standfirst:
May Day Scale of protest remains unknown quantity, while polls show public shares activists' disquiet over might of global capitalism

Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: The largest force of police ever assembled in London will today confront 10,000 people. Or perhaps 2,000. There may be 1,000 people intent on damaging property, or there may be 500. Or 200. Or 5,000.
fields.body:
The largest force of police ever assembled in London will today confront 10,000 people. Or perhaps 2,000. There may be 1,000 people intent on damaging property, or there may be 500. Or 200. Or 5,000.

The police intelligence is at a loss to predict clearly what will happen, just as the protesters themselves do not have a big picture. Modern protest is no longer about people making great speeches and leading orderly marches behind banners; increasingly it is a form of free expression, with disinformation rife by both "sides".

With more than 30 separate protests across London against everything from capitalism to the banning of pigeon feeding in Trafalgar Square, the police have a near-impossible task. They must justify why they will be adopting draconian no-tolerance policies, while at the same time they must not be accused of curtailing civil liberties. The line is fine, but to cross it with images of over the top policing would be disastrous for New Labour.

The protesters were worried their message of solidarity with others around the world, anger at world debt, or disappointment with global governance might not get through either. No matter that 9,000 people are peaceful, if 1,000 run riot in Oxford Street or in the City the media will focus on the violence. Any appeal the majority would make to the public about the justness of their cause would be lost.

Last night there were conflicting messages coming from both sides, with some protesters sensing more people would turn out on the principle that no one should be deterred by a massive police presence, and the police and Ken Livingstone, mayor of London, suggesting the authorities had succeeded in keeping many people away.

An opinion poll yesterday indicated people agreed strongly with one of the protesters' main complaints - that corporations influence life more than government does. An NOP poll for C4's Powerhouse programme had 76% agreeing "big international companies usually care only about profits, and not the interests of the people in the countries where they operate". Only 19% disagreed.

Of 1,000 people asked whether they agreed or disagreed that "big international companies have more influence on daily life in Britain than our own government", 67% agreed while 25% disagreed.

On the other hand, only 25% disagreed with the suggestion that international companies had helped to increase prosperity in Britain by building factories and creating jobs.

The protests in London are expected to be mirrored across the world, with many countries preparing for the traditional workers' day with massive street demonstrations against globalisation, unemployment and corruption.

In Berlin the government has banned anarchist and other marches in an attempt to prevent violent clashes. But a court decision allowing a march by the neo-nazi National Democratic party threatens to heighten tension.

In France, where global free trade is widely blamed for cultural and economic problems, thousands of people are expected to demonstrate against recent job losses at international firms, including Marks & Spencer.

In Australia a predicted 10,000 activists will blockade stock exchanges and other financial institutions in the big cities.

Spanish trade unions have organised 61 demonstrations to denounce precarious working conditions and labour market reforms by the conservative government, which they say favour companies which want to make redundancies cheaper.

Protests over unemployment, discrimination and poverty are also expected in Greece, Poland, Guatemala and Taiwan, where some 20,000 people are expected to take to the streets.

The Japanese, for whom May 1 is a normal working day, brought forward their protest to last weekend when 450,000 people turned out to demand wage rises.

Peter Mandelson, MP for Hartlepool, and Arthur Scargill, the National Union of Mineworkers leader who is challenging him in the next election, clashed yesterday over the protests . Mr Scargill backed the anti-capitalists but Mr Mandelson responded that he was an "an extremist prepared to give more support to a bunch of violent anarchists than a democratically elected Labour government".

webTitle: Kirch raises stake in formula one TV

fields.headline: Kirch raises stake in formula one TV
fields.trailText: German media group Kirch is poised to consolidate its hold on television broadcasts of formula one motor racing. By Mark Milner.
fields.body:
German media group Kirch is poised to consolidate its hold on television broadcasts of formula one motor racing.

It is set to take a controlling stake in SLEC, a holding company, which in turn controls the commercial and broadcast rights to formula one.

Kirch and fellow German media group EM.TV currently own 75% of SLEC through a separate holding company on a near 50:50 basis. But yesterday it emerged that, under a convertible bond issue used to finance the purchase of 25% of SLEC earlier this year, Kirch has the right to become the dominant partner, taking its stake in SLEC from 37.5% to 57.5%. EM.TV's stake would fall to 17.5%.

EM.TV said that both sides wanted to see the Kirch stake increased though Kirch itself was more cautious, saying that no decision had been taken.

The news comes shortly after a row over TV coverage of the sport which Kirch has sought to diffuse with assurances that formula one would remain available on terrestrial television. The formula one teams had previously threatened to set up their own cham pionship if coverage was moved from terrestrial television, where it attracts huge audiences and advertising, to pay-TV.

Yesterday EM.TV, where Kirch in turn has a 16.74% stake, said that it was taking a DM1.3bn (£412m) write-down against the original SLEC stake and a further DM684m write-down against its purchase of Muppets maker, the Jim Henson Company.

The write-downs pushed the Munich based group DM2.8bn into the red in 2000 - more than double its total turnover for the year.

Chief executive Thomas Haffa said the results marked the end of the company's difficulties. "We've cleaned up our numbers without mercy. This is very painful but with this we are creating a basis for the future of EM.TV," he said.

The company is still considering what to do with the Jim Henson Company. "It may be a complete sale or it may be a strategic partner," a spokeswoman said yesterday.

However, EM.TV is believed to prefer a strategic partner as that would allow it to keep distribution rights.

EM.TV shares rose more than 8% to €5.68 (£3.52).

fields.headline: Blair attacks 'spurious' May Day protests
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mayday
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday promised "absolute and total backing" for the police during today's anti-capitalist May Day celebrations and demonstrations in London, and dismissed the protests as a "spurious cause".
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday promised "absolute and total backing" for the police during today's anti-capitalist May Day celebrations and demonstrations in London, and dismissed the protests as a "spurious cause".

The prime minister said that protesters passed the limits of tolerance when they sought "to inflict fear, terror, violence and criminal damage" on people and property.

"I believe people in Britain are tolerant, outward-looking, inclusive," he said. I believe, too, that there are indeed limits to that tolerance.

"The limits are past when protesters, in the name of some spurious cause, seek to inflict fear, terror, violence and criminal damage on our people and property.

Last year's May Day protests were wrong. There is a right way to protest in a democracy and there is a wrong way. Britain and its people are not just tolerant of peaceful protest but see it, rightly, as a vital part of our democratic process."

Some protesters immediately responded that many thousands of people wanted to demonstrate against the effects of the monetary system and free trade, but were being discouraged by the fear of thousands of riot police in central London with orders to not tolerate any disturbances.

"The point about a democracy is to allow freedom of expression," said Joyce, a spokeswoman for a genetics protest group.

"It is no way to run a democracy with rubber bullets. It would seem we are living in Northern Ireland in the 1970s. He never asked us whether he should bomb Iraq."

A spokesman for a socialist youth group, Revolution, said: "What about the violence that kills 19,000 people a day because of international debt?"

Ken Livingstone, London's mayor, is to have special branch bodyguards throughout the day after he was criticised for advocating a "no-tolerance" policing policy and telling the protesters to stay away.

Many shops and businesses in central London have hired extra security guards, or said that they will not be opening today.

The police said yesterday that they had no intention of using rubber bullets, although Lord Harris, chairman of the Metropolitan police authority, had said on Sunday that rubber bullets could be used in "very extreme circumstances".

The force's commissioner, Sir John Stevens, said: "The authorisation to use baton rounds would be my personal responsibility and mine alone.

"Such ammunition has never been deployed on mainland Britain and I have no intention to do so."

Last night there were very few people in the convergence centre in South London, where protesters had been meeting to exchange advice and plans.

With the police filming everyone going in and out, mainstream press reporters were refused entry. Internet chatlines suggested that some protesters would be out during the night disabling CCTV cameras with spray paint.

The latest police estimates suggest that there could be 1,000 people intent on causing mischief, and between 6,000 and 10,000 people demonstrating peacefully. It roughly matches the 5,000 police who will be on duty, with 4,000 being held in reserve.

fields.headline: 'Agony aunt' Tara unveils website
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The original It Girl, Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, has launched her own website, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Move over Lady Victoria, Tara P-T is back in town. The original It Girl, Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, has launched her own website at www.TaraPT.com.

Images of a scantily-clad Ms Palmer-Tomkinson decorate the site, which has her trying out the rather unlikely occupation of agony aunt.

"I've had my share of troubles," she admits, listing cocaine addiction and compulsive shopping among them, before going on to offer her services as a "social agony aunt".

The site also provides everything you ever wanted to know about Ms Palmer-Tomkinson, from an exhaustive description of her childhood to lists of her favourite things. It even allows users to text message her.

Tara's Tantalising Titbits is a section devoted to her party-hopping, and visitors can also delve into Ms Palmer-Tomkinson's secret world where she admits to shopping at Top Shop.

The personality-driven site is a far cry from Ready2, the fashion business created by It girls and Telegraph writers Susannah Constantine and Trinny Woodall. The site went into "hibernation" last year.

Tara's rather kitsch site has already pulled in sponsorship from Carphone Warhouse and BA.

She said she decided to set up the website after being inundated with requests for advice on what to wear and where to go.

"I have been amazed by the number of people who have urged me to set up the website. Lots of people, especially girls want to know where I shop for my clothes and where I go in the evenings."

Useful link

TaraPT.com
fields.bodyText: Move over Lady Victoria, Tara P-T is back in town. The original It Girl, Tara Palmer-Tomkinson, has launched her own website at www.TaraPT.com. Images of a scantily-clad Ms Palmer-Tomkinson decorate the site, which has her trying out the rather unlikely occupation of agony aunt. "I've had my share of troubles," she admits, listing cocaine addiction and compulsive shopping among them, before going on to offer her services as a "social agony aunt". The site also provides everything you ever wanted to know about Ms Palmer-Tomkinson, from an exhaustive description of her childhood to lists of her favourite things. It even allows users to text message her. Tara's Tantalising Titbits is a section devoted to her party-hopping, and visitors can also delve into Ms Palmer-Tomkinson's secret world where she admits to shopping at Top Shop. The personality-driven site is a far cry from Ready2, the fashion business created by It girls and Telegraph writers Susannah Constantine and Trinny Woodall. The site went into "hibernation" last year. Tara's rather kitsch site has already pulled in sponsorship from Carphone Warhouse and BA. She said she decided to set up the website after being inundated with requests for advice on what to wear and where to go. "I have been amazed by the number of people who have urged me to set up the website. Lots of people, especially girls want to know where I shop for my clothes and where I go in the evenings." fields.headline: US star chairs C5's election
fields.standfirst:
Election 2001
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Jerry Springer is hardly Jeremy Paxman, but Channel 5 is not exactly known for its high brow approach to current affairs.
fields.body:
Jerry Springer is hardly Jeremy Paxman, but Channel 5 is not exactly known for its high brow approach to current affairs.

The broadcaster is lining up the US talk show presenter to front its election coverage.

Channel 5 is even considering whether to approach the main party leaders with a request for a series of one to one interviews with Springer.

It is the channel's first election, and it is developing a number of "alternative" ways of covering the event. During the campaign its 30-minute 6pm news programme will be extended to an hour, brought forward to 5.30pm and retitled Five News and Talk.

The extra half hour will be taken up with more discussion, chaired by James O'Brien, one of the ebullient presenters of Channel 5's daily talk show, The Wright Stuff, which is fronted by the former Mirror showbiz editor, Matthew Wright.

Springer is also to get a new series of his late night talk show - which follows a more conventional format than his wild US discussion programmes - and is presenting the new £1m game show Greed.

Springer is being developed as a regular face on Channel 5. A spokeswoman said: "It's common sense: he wants to do as much as he can in Britain, and we'd be mad not to use him."

webTitle: More sex, please - we're French Big Brother

fields.headline: More sex, please - we're French Big Brother
fields.standfirst: More sex, please - we're French
fields.trailText: French television viewers are up in arms - not because broadcasting standards have sunk too far, but because they have not sunk far enough. By Jon Henley.
fields.body:
Days after the long-awaited Gallic version of Big Brother went on air, French television viewers are up in arms - not because broadcasting standards have sunk too far, but because they have not sunk far enough.

"They censor it as soon as things get steamy," Laurent Lemercier, a 24-year-old stu dent, complained. "I was on the website at midnight on Saturday and I saw Loana take her top off in the pool with Jean-Edouard, but they didn't show any of that on the telly the next day."

The show, Loft Story, has had record audiences since its much-hyped launch last week. An average 4m French people watched the first three episodes of the 10-week marathon, which will follow 11 young men and women locked into a loft-style flat in the Paris suburbs.

But for anything more than an anodyne half-hour daily summary of events on TV, viewers must subscribe to a cable network running a 24-hour-a-day live feed. And even on the show's website, the cameras recording the contestants' more intimate moments are pay-per-view.

"It's all just a huge rip-off," Jean-Louis Malnoy, an angry telecoms consultant, told Le Parisien newspaper, which devoted a two-page spread to the great no-sex scandal yesterday beneath the banner headline: "What you saw on the telly - and the rest."

"It's like watching the longest X-rated film in the world," Mr Malnoy complained, "except the scenes in between are interminable, and there's never any sex."

The show's producers, the French commercial channel M6 and the Dutch company Endemol, which devised Big Brother and has helped to develop its 27 international variants, described it in the pre-launch publicity as "reality television with a French touch".

To the waiting nation, that meant only one thing. Hopes for televisual titillation shot higher when the contestants, all attractive and uninhibited twentysomethings, were introduced. The five women, one an ex-stripper, were in miniskirts and plunging necklines; the six men sported cool shades and fabulous abs.

Equally enticingly, their early confessions to camera featured few reflections on the psychological challenge ahead, but plenty on the physical attributes of their new flatmates.

The French press instantly condemned what one editorialist called "an exercise in vulgarity unique in French television - an operation whose objective is plainly sex and which, by the promise of lots of it, transforms the television viewer into a voyeur".

Two government ministers have registered official disapproval of the programme, and the CSA, the French equivalent of the broadcasting standards authority, warned it would be watching to see if it exceeded the bounds of Gallic decency. Judging by viewers' reactions so far, it need not bother.

webTitle: FT.com chief to head industry body

fields.headline: FT.com chief to head industry body
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Periodical Publishers Association has made Michael Murphy the chairman of its interactive division, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Periodical Publishers Association has strengthened its interactive division by appointing FT.com's Michael Murphy as chairman.

Mr Murphy takes over from Julian Treasure, who has served as PPAi chairman for the last two years and who will remain on the PPAi council.

The appointment of Mr Murphy, chief operating officer of FT.com, comes at a time of expansion for the interactive division.

It wants to set more targeted goals for interactive publishing, improve its website and expand into new areas, such as research and training.

Mr Murphy will work with other magazine publishing chiefs, such as Helen Alexander of the Economist Group, Julian Turner of beeb ventures and Roger Green of Emap.

His priorities as PPAi chairman will be to push for an industry-wide standard for site metrics and auditing standards, as well as developing ways of making content pay online - something also top of his own list at FT.com.

"PPAi has an important role to play in the internet publishing industry," said Mr Murphy.

"These are exciting times for the sector and I am delighted to be playing a key role in driving the industry forward."

The PPAi was set up as an offshoot of the PPA two years ago in order to educate and bring publishers online.

It meets four times a year and will meet later this month to discuss e-commerce practices, web traffic measurement and auditing.

fields.headline: Freeserve lures Hawkins from AOL
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Freeserve has poached AOL's Keith Hawkins to be its first managing director of marketing, reports Amy Vickers.
23.04.2001: Freeserve set to take on Europe
fields.body:
Freeserve has poached the AOL marketing chief, Keith Hawkins, to be its first managing director of marketing.

Mr Hawkins, who left AOL in January following a reshuffle, takes the reins at Freeserve immediately.

He replaces the chief marketing officer, Neil Sansom, who left at the end of last year for the oil company, Shell.

"Keith's appointment to the senior Freeserve team demonstrates the seriousness with which we are approaching the task of communicating to consumers the strength of our access and portal propositions," said John Pluthero, the chief executive officer of Freeserve.

Freeserve had originally said it would promote its head of advertising and PR, Khim McCall, to the top marketing role.

But the company now claims Ms McCall was only acting as group head of marketing while it sought a director level marketeer.

Ms McCall will now report directly into Mr Hawkins, who will lead a 15-strong team.

At AOL, Mr Hawkins was responsible for the three UK brands, AOL, Netscape and CompuServe, and led AOL UK's consumer marketing for the launch of flat rate access.

A Freeserve marketing campaign is said to be in the pipeline.

Related story

fields.headline: Destiny's child
fields.standfirst: Tina Weaver takes the helm at the Sunday Mirror at a time when her horoscope is on a lucky Jupiter high. Nothing could indicate more strikingly that she just happened to be in the right place at the right time
fields.trailText: May 1: Tina Weaver takes the helm at the Sunday Mirror at a time when her horoscope is on a lucky Jupiter high, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
The debacle of the Leeds United trial and the resignation of the Sunday Mirror editor, Colin Myler, brought a remarkable twist of fate for Tina Weaver.

The way something begins often reveals the seeds of its future, so will her editorship of the Sunday Mirror be subject to the same lawless upsets?

The good news is Ms Weaver takes over at a time when her horoscope (June 17 1965) is on a lucky Jupiter high and nothing could indicate more strikingly that she just happened to be in the right place at the right time.

Ms Weaver is a streetwise, networking Gemini, a sign perfectly at home in the fast, shifting world of the press and ideal for a media queen with a tabloid background.

She has all the smartness of the Gemini twins, coupled with the toughness of aggressive Mars square to her Sun in the hard-working sign of Virgo.

This can make her highly strung and prone to sudden, ratty arguments when she is stressed out.

Astrologer Isabelle Pagan says of this Gemini quality: "There is always a strong desire to be 'in the running' and in the very centre of things; and if these people find themselves in any way inferior to those around them - and are consequently compelled to take a back seat - they feel very sore and ill-used - and show it." (From Pioneer to Poet).

Her big rival on the Sundays is Rebekah Wade at News of the World and, as the only women editors left in the nationals, comparisons are inevitable.

Since Ms Wade is another magpie Gemini (May 27 1968), we can expect fun and "coincidences" as these two second-guess each other's headline-grabbing moves.

There is, however, a huge difference between them.

Ms Weaver's horoscope is not fully typical of Gemini because it contains gallons of emotional water, giving her a strongly humane touch and making her super-sensitive to other people's needs.

This high level of compassion for the suffering of others is not common in horoscopes connected to the tabloids - Ms Wade has no water at all - but it seems to motivate Ms Weaver more than outsiders might imagine.

Her watery Venus in Cancer gives her a populist, caring instinct and tunes her in to the human interest side of any story, with such scoops as the Blairs' baby and Michael Jackson's marriage.

This fits well with the Sunday Mirror - the paper is a watery Pisces with origins in the Sunday Pictorial (March 14 1915) - but it does mean Ms Weaver can go soft at the wrong moment.

As she goes with the flow it will be difficult for her to forge the distinct identity the paper now needs.

She has no planets in fire so, although she can pull off Gemini tricks, taking risks and playing a dangerous game does not suit her and Ms Wade beats her hands down in the dare-devil department.

Enter Piers Morgan. Although he has a watery Pisces moon, he is a fiery, courageous Aries with a pioneering spirit that makes up for Ms Weaver's missing fire.

The astrology suggests she will need support from his nerves of steel, especially when she hits her first Saturn crisis this August and when self-doubt and panic over the ABC figures affect her adversely and test her authority in August 2002.

When the going gets tough, Geminis get going, usually as far away as possible from the trouble.

This is the Peter Pan sign that wants to stay forever young and forever foolish and, often, just at the point of achieving what they want, their innate duality makes the Twins question whether they do want it after all.

For Ms Weaver, the either/or, hot/cold Gemini games are over; the main astrological connection between her and the Sunday Mirror puts weighty, heavy-duty Saturn onto her Sun.

It's the call of destiny and the test is whether she has the gravitas to carry it off.

fields.headline: Coke unveils 'Popstars' campaign
fields.trailText:
4.45pm: Coca-Cola is to launch a Popstars-style search for the stars of its new national advertising campaign, reports Claire Cozens.

Fantamates website
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is to launch a Popstars-style search for the stars of its new national advertising campaign.

The company's Fanta Best Mates Challenge will give talented teenagers across the country the change to appear in a series of commercials as part of a marketing blitz.

Its search launches today with a series of TV commercials kicking off in tonight's episode of the Channel 4 chat show, the Priory.

The advertising features real-life teenage best friends telling funny stories about what they have got up to together.

They will direct viewers to a website that gives details of the "Fanta cam", the talent scouts that will be visiting shopping malls around the country to spot teenagers to appear in the next campaign.

The campaign will run for six weeks before being replaced by a new set of adverts featuring the teenage stars.

"Programmes like Popstars have shown that fame is a great motivator for young people," said a Coca-Cola spokeswoman.

"The campaign is a sort of virtual circle with the TV adverts driving entries to the auditions."

The advertising is part of a major marketing blitz from Coca-Cola that began last week with the launch of a campaign for the main Coca-Cola brand.

Two more campaigns will launch on Friday, one for Dr Pepper and for Coca-Cola's new still fruit drink Alive.

All four campaigns have been specially made for the UK market, a change of tack for Coca-Cola, which has traditionally tended to focus on global advertising campaigns.

Useful link

Fantamates website

fields.headline: Violence erupts in central London
fields.standfirst:
 Rioters smash banks and shops
 Central London paralysed

Do you agree with the demonstrations?

Special report: May Day 2001
fields.trailText:
 Rioters smash banks and shops
 Central London still paralysed
fields.byline: Sarah Left, Simon Jeffery, Jane Perrone and agencies
fields.body:
Rioters went on the rampage tonight as London's May Day protest finally escalated into violence.

As darkness fell, a group of hard core demonstrators turned their attention to the busy and unguarded Tottenham Court Road area.

Militant anarchists intent on violence broke away from peaceful demonstrators and left a trail of destruction.

More than 20 shopfront windows on the road were smashed with rocks and other missiles, including those of Bank of Scotland, Abbey National, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays Bank, Coffee Republic and Habitat.

The rioters also attempted to set fire to a Tesco store on nearby Goodge Street.

Staff were in the store at the time. One said: "I was working downstairs when the manager told us to stay down because the shop was being attacked.

"We stayed down for about 20 minutes and then they said we should all go because we were being evacuated." Scotland Yard said about 50 to 60 of the protesters contained in the Oxford Circus area had broken away into Oxford Street at about 8.30pm.

"They regrouped very quickly and overturned a car. They tried to set fire to Tesco's in Goodge Street," a spokesman said. "Some of those were arrested. Tension in the area remains high."

Nearby Goodge Street tube station was closed by British Transport Police after the attack and Tottenham Court Road tube was also reported to be shut.

Police in riot gear this afternoon penned several thousand anti-capitalism protesters into Oxford Circus in central London as several further groups of May Day protesters attempted to break through police lines in the area.

The capital's May Day protests became tense as police formed human barricades to prevent groups of demonstrators from converging on Oxford Street. Surrounding side streets were cordoned off.

Although the protest has been largely peaceful, there have been some skirmishes, with bottles and cans thrown at police. Riot police have surged forward on several occasions, batting protesters with shields and batons. Shops closed their doors and boarded up windows. Several demonstrators have emerged from scuffles covered with blood.

Some 50 demonstrators have been arrested in today's protests across the capital, seven of them "foreign nationals", police said. Fifteen people have been injured in the skirmishes, 10 of whom were taken to hospital, according to the London ambulance service.

Riot police are not allowing anyone into or out of the intersection of Oxford Street and Regent Street. A repeated police announcement to protesters said: "You are being detained here to prevent a breach of the peace and criminal damage to property. You will be released in due course."

Two protesters who climbed on to a balcony of the John Lewis building in Holles Street ripped two CCTV cameras from their mounts and passed them down into the crowd. They also stripped metal segments from the balcony and passed them down into the crowd where people appeared to be trying to smash John Lewis windows.

Meanwhile police mounted a series of charges on Oxford Street as they came under a hail of bottles from protesters attempting to join other campaigners in Oxford Circus.

One demonstrator managed to kick in the windows of the disused C&A building after climbing the balcony running around the building.

Police charged again as protective chipboard hoardings were ripped off the front of a Wallis shop.

Members of the public who were not involved in the demonstrations were told by police to leave the Oxford Street area and the Tube station was closed at police request.

Wombles lead protests

Meanwile, a group of 600 to 1,000 people has slipped around the police lines to the north side of Oxford Circus. The group was led by around 40 "Wombles", protesters dressed in white overalls and padding.

In Holles Street, beside the John Lewis department store, protesters broke through police lines several times to join up with another group of demonstrators.

Demonstrators have complained that there is no water and no toilets inside the cordon, with some protesters pointing to police and saying, "They're the urinals."

Earlier in the afternoon, before the atmosphere became aggressive, the May Day demonstrators in Oxford Circus chanted and sang in front of front of shops such as Niketown that were closed and protected by wooden hoardings. The protestors threw Monopoly money into the air.

Nike store targeted

Police later faced a hail of bricks from close range and pushed protesters back into Oxford Circus. Demonstrators also attempted to break the windows of the Niketown store by hurling bricks but the windows held. A protester on stilts approached a police cameraman perched on a lamppost outside Niketown and began filming him amid cheers from the crowd.

The demonstrators have accused the police of fuelling tension by surrounding groups of anti-capitalism protesters at various locations in central London.

Protests around capital

While the main body of the protest converged on Oxford Circus, at the Elephant and Castle roundabout in south-east London, two groups of demonstrators - one cyclists and the other an environmental group with a pedal-powered sound system - met. The atmosphere was carnival-like and there were many different groups.

Sebastian Martineau, a member of the Dangerous Anarchist League, who was wearing a green uniform complete with padded armour, elongated ears and two small horns on his forehead said: "We are just protesting. It is important that people come along."

Nick Wrack said: "The day is a good carnival atmosphere, people came to demonstrate against global capitalism and the destruction of the environment - and it is their right to do so." He added that the police presence was completely unnecessary.

The police ringed the traffic island as the demonstration was about to move on, and it turned into a rally as a spokesman told the protesters that it was their right to demonstrate in central London, but they should be aware of provoking any violence.

The police then moved the demonstrators off the traffic island and through back streets to the north bank of the Thames.

Activists have staged demonstrations at a variety of places in the capital today, including Trafalgar Square and Euston.

Cyclists start day of action

Today's demonstrations in the capital began early today with a mass cycle ride through the City to King's Cross station.

Following the two Critical Mass bike rides, hundreds of protesters gathered in Euston station plaza were corralled by police and searched before they were allowed to leave.

One of the marchers, Mick Gordon, from Cambridge, said he believed the police actions had led to an escalating feeling of tension among the crowd.

"I'm appalled by the police's behaviour in this situation. They seem to be turning this peaceful process into a potentially dangerous situation by penning people in."

By lunchtime the independent website IndyMedia reported that police had surrounded Trafalgar Square, blocking in protesters who had been feeding the pigeons, which is now banned.

The demonstration has so far been peaceful, with Sir David Howard, the Lord Mayor of London, reporting a "carnival atmosphere" as the first cyclists set off from Liverpool Street station at 8am.

Professor Kayoss, of the Save The World Club, who was attending the demonstration, said that he hoped the day would pass without violent clashes.

"Thousands of people want to just protest without violence and show some kind of statement about what they feel is happening to the planet," he said.

Police prepare for May Day

The Metropolitan police chief, Sir John Stevens, today ruled out the use of plastic bullets, despite police intelligence estimates that around 1,000 activists were intent on causing trouble.

He also denied suggestions that police would be armed with CS gas but said it would be "much more likely" that officers would have their own individual sprays.

fields.bodyText: Rioters went on the rampage tonight as London's May Day protest finally escalated into violence. As darkness fell, a group of hard core demonstrators turned their attention to the busy and unguarded Tottenham Court Road area. Militant anarchists intent on violence broke away from peaceful demonstrators and left a trail of destruction. More than 20 shopfront windows on the road were smashed with rocks and other missiles, including those of Bank of Scotland, Abbey National, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays Bank, Coffee Republic and Habitat. The rioters also attempted to set fire to a Tesco store on nearby Goodge Street. Staff were in the store at the time. One said: "I was working downstairs when the manager told us to stay down because the shop was being attacked. "We stayed down for about 20 minutes and then they said we should all go because we were being evacuated." Scotland Yard said about 50 to 60 of the protesters contained in the Oxford Circus area had broken away into Oxford Street at about 8.30pm. "They regrouped very quickly and overturned a car. They tried to set fire to Tesco's in Goodge Street," a spokesman said. "Some of those were arrested. Tension in the area remains high." Nearby Goodge Street tube station was closed by British Transport Police after the attack and Tottenham Court Road tube was also reported to be shut. Police in riot gear this afternoon penned several thousand anti-capitalism protesters into Oxford Circus in central London as several further groups of May Day protesters attempted to break through police lines in the area. The capital's May Day protests became tense as police formed human barricades to prevent groups of demonstrators from converging on Oxford Street. Surrounding side streets were cordoned off. Although the protest has been largely peaceful, there have been some skirmishes, with bottles and cans thrown at police. Riot police have surged forward on several occasions, batting protesters with shields and batons. Shops closed their doors and boarded up windows. Fifteen people have been injured in the skirmishes, 10 of whom were taken to hospital, according to the London ambulance service. A repeated police announcement to protesters said: "You are being detained here to prevent a breach of the peace and criminal damage to property. You will be released in due course." One demonstrator managed to kick in the windows of the disused C&A building after climbing the balcony running around the building. Police charged again as protective chipboard hoardings were ripped off the front of a Wallis shop. The group was led by around 40 "Wombles", protesters dressed in white overalls and padding. In Holles Street, beside the John Lewis department store, protesters broke through police lines several times to join up with another group of demonstrators. Demonstrators also attempted to break the windows of the Niketown store by hurling bricks but the windows held. A protester on stilts approached a police cameraman perched on a lamppost outside Niketown and began filming him amid cheers from the crowd. The demonstrators have accused the police of fuelling tension by surrounding groups of anti-capitalism protesters at various locations in central London. The atmosphere was carnival-like and there were many different groups. Sebastian Martineau, a member of the Dangerous Anarchist League, who was wearing a green uniform complete with padded armour, elongated ears and two small horns on his forehead said: "We are just protesting.
