fields.headline: Politics not parliament
fields.trailText: To the thousands of activists championing the issues governments have neglected, parliament has been peripheral to the life of the nation for years, writes George Monbiot.
fields.body:
When Tony Benn announced his intention to retire as an MP he said he was "leaving parliament to go into politics". He didn't need to explain what he meant. To the thousands of activists championing the issues governments have neglected, parliament has been peripheral to the life of the nation for years.

It's not hard to see why. The first and most obvious reason is that MPs are no longer permitted to represent their constituents. The lavish use of the parliamentary whip, the increased efficiency of the party machines, the fudged reform of the House of Lords, the marginalisation of even the cabinet as the government is run by unelected advisers, have all helped to sever the links between the people and their representatives.

As the government is gradually removed from effective, democratic supervision, unprecedented opportunities emerge for undemocratic lobbying. While petitions signed by one million electors are binned, Rupert Murdoch is admitted to Downing Street every time he knocks. All governments, aware that the best way to acquire power is to appease those who possess it, are enlisted by the powerful to marginalise dissent. But this government has been so comprehensively captured by its lobbyists that it has marginalised itself.

There is, both Tony Blair and Gordon Brown have assured us, "no alternative" to neoliberal globalisation. This leads to, although they would never express it this way, the gradual privatisation of everything, brokered by means of the Private Finance Initiative and the forthcoming General Agreement on Trade in Services. It means the deregulation of business activities, resulting in even lower environmental, workplace and consumer standards. It means fiscal policies whose purpose is to provide "a more competitive environment" for business, which translates as a longterm shift from corporate to personal taxation.

None of these issues are subject to debate, as all three major parties are courting the same corporate constituency. National sovereignty, for example, is an issue only when the European Union suggests raising the standards to which business must conform. Its deregulatory measures, by contrast, are never construed as a danger to democracy. The gravest of all recent challenges to sovereignty was the Multilateral Agreement on Investment. Had this global measure been approved, it would have permitted corporations to sue governments for the removal of any laws restricting their ability to make money. But when it was debated in parliament, the Conservative benches were empty. When, on the day of its negotiation, the home secretary, Jack Straw, was asked about the agreement, he admitted that he had never heard of it.

So the electorate is left to wonder why, in a state that has never been richer, public services are falling apart, the state pension is dwindling and schools are being privatised. Why, though no one wants them, we are being forced to accept genetically modified crops. Why the government that promised traffic reduction, rail renationalisation and integrated transport has instead relaunched the road building programme. Why Tony Blair refuses to rule out British participation in the deadly and farcical Nuclear Missile Defence programme.

While the government insists that there is no alternative, those seeking to promote one are treated as dangerous outcasts. Non-violent campaigners have been reclassified as terrorists by the new terrorism act, while the investigatory powers act and the new criminal justice act allow the security services to intercept emails and raid computers without a warrant. Yet, in the absence of an independent, investigative press, peaceful protest is now among the few means of raising the issues that will determine the future course of most people's lives. We are, as a result, entering a new age of activism.

Until recently, protest in Britain has been fragmentary and confused. But suddenly the dissenters appear to be coalescing, and a coherent, radical opposition movement is beginning to emerge. Socialists, anarchists and greens seem to be laying aside their differences in order to campaign against global neoliberalism. Even the farmers who joined the fuel protests are beginning to talk to environmentalists, as both sides come to see that corporate power threatens small businesses and the ecosystem in equal measure. While the turnout for the general election promises to be one of the lowest on record, the protests scheduled for the G8 summit in Genoa in July are likely to number among the biggest held.

These are, as a result, exciting times. While extra-parliamentary activism will make little difference to the outcome of this election, the concerns it expresses will become harder to ignore. With or without the help of a marginalised parliament, Britain's politics at future elections will bear little resemblance to those of 2001.

 George Monbiot is a Guardian columnist

webTitle: Prison campaigners issue challenge to candidates

fields.headline: Prison campaigners issue challenge to candidates
fields.trailText: Prison reformers are calling on general election candidates to sign a declaration backing a cut in the jail population rather than play the "prison card" during the campaign.
fields.body:
Prison reformers are calling on general election candidates to sign a declaration backing a cut in the jail population rather than play the "prison card" during the campaign.

The Howard League for Penal Reform yesterday urged candidates to back its manifesto, which also calls for more community sentences and imprisonment only as a last resort. The league said it would be open about those who refuse to offer support, though it said it would be "naming and praising" rather than "naming and shaming".

The new challenge to candidates comes after an anti-racism pledge drawn up by the commission for racial equality ignited the current race row within the Conservative party.

The Howard League manifesto also comes after William Hague clashed with Lord Woolf, the Lord Chief Justice, who last year urged politicians to steer clear of playing the "prison card" as he warned of growing prison overcrowding.

The Conservative leader then argued it might be necessary to increase the country's prison population - already the second highest in Western Europe - in order to tackle crime.

The league is also unhappy with government prison policy. Its president, creator of Rumpole of the Bailey, Sir John Mortimer QC, yesterday made clear his personal view that Labour had "failed totally". He said: "The business of leaders is to reawaken thinking about the efficacy of prisons. Politicians should lead public opinion rather than slavishly following it."

The league's manifesto sets out five principles, including basing the penal system on "effective community penalties" and concentrating public resources on preventing crime.

Prisons should "provide a positive experience and a realistic chance of rehabilitation", and the criminal justice process should be based on the principle of repairing the damage done by crime, the statement adds.

Publishing statistics showing that the use of imprisonment in Britain is second only to Portugal among western European states, the league sets out five priorities for action, including reducing the prison population to the European average.

Campaigners also want children taken out of prisons, "proper status" for the rights and needs of victims of crime and promotion of safer communities through social and economic policies.

A spokesman yesterday acknowledged that the league did not anticipate party leaders signing the declaration. However, supporters of penal reform will be encouraged to approach local parliamentary candidates and urge them to sign. The league's policy chairman, Professor David Wilson said:"We were concerned that politicians would play the prison card and we saw an early sign of that when Mr Blair went to Pentonville recently and announced 2,500 more prison places."

The home secretary, Jack Straw, was "trying to do good by stealth" but could not deal with the issue that prison did not work because it would lose votes, he claimed.

fields.headline: Removing prison toddlers 'breaches rights'
fields.standfirst: Special report: prisons
fields.trailText: A policy of removing toddlers from their mothers in prison once they reach the age of 18 months is "a clear breach of the right to respect for family life" and should be declared unlawful, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A policy of removing toddlers from their mothers in prison once they reach the age of 18 months is "a clear breach of the right to respect for family life" and should be declared unlawful, the high court was told yesterday.

Richard Gordon QC, representing two mothers convicted of drug offences, told the lord chief justice, Lord Woolf, and Mr Justice Lightman that the policy failed to take account of the children's individual needs.

Lord Woolf said at the start of the two day hearing that the cases raised "very moving problems". The two mothers were granted anonymity and were named only as Q and P.

P, a 32-year-old Jamaican serving an eight-year sentence in Styal prison, Cheshire, launched the challenge after being told last January that her daughter, born in July 1999, must go into foster care.

She was arrested in March 1999, when five months' pregnant, and charged with smuggling cocaine. P, who has three children in Jamaica, will be eligible for parole in March 2003.

Q, from Brixton, south London, is serving a five year sentence at Askham Grange prison, York, for conspiracy to supply cannabis. Her daughter was born last July and will be three by the time her mother is eligible for parole in July 2002.

Two other Styal prisoners, J and K, have cases pending.

Mr Gordon said fundamental rights were at stake. The rigid "arbitrary, irrational and discriminatory" policy of removing babies at 18 months prevented the assessment of cases on their individual merits.

The across the board policy was contrary to the European convention on human rights because it interfered with a prisoner's right to family life.

"The importance of the mother-child attachment is self-evident and should be preserved if at all possible," Mr Gordon said. "There is clear parliamentary intent that children in need shall receive a full assessment of their need."

Lawyers for the Home Office are expected to argue that the home secretary, Jack Straw, has developed a policy which allows mothers to look after young children, while protecting older children from the damaging experience of prison.

webTitle: Whites a minority in big US cities

fields.headline: Whites a minority in big US cities
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Non-Hispanic whites became a minority in the 100 largest US cities during the 1990s, outstripped by a booming population of Latinos and other minorities, researchers studying the 2000 census figures said yesterday.
fields.body:
Non-Hispanic whites became a minority in the 100 largest US cities during the 1990s, outstripped by a booming population of Latinos and other minorities, researchers studying the 2000 census figures said yesterday.

The findings, prepared by the Brookings Institution centre on urban and metropolitan policy, have political and fiscal implications for cities and follow decades of white flight from urban America.

"The other side of the story, which is probably more critical, is that the loss of white population was more than offset by gains in minority populations, particularly Hispanics," said Bruce Katz, director of the Brookings center.

The Brookings study found that between 1990 and 2000, the non-Latino white share of population in the top 100 cities fell to 44% from 52%.

The five largest US cities alone - New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston and Philadelphia - together lost 1m white residents, while the number of cities with a majority white population slid to 52 from 70 a decade ago.

Meanwhile, the top 100 cities gained 3.8m Latino residents between 1990 and 2000, an increase of 43%.

Doug Peterson, senior policy analyst for the National League of Cities, an advocacy group, said the census indicated lower household incomes for Latinos than whites, suggesting a fiscal balancing act between growing overall populations and lower average household incomes.
Reuters

fields.headline: Bitter pills for the people
fields.standfirst: Special report: globalisation
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was on the plinth at Trafalgar Square on Sunday to endorse Nelson Mandela's celebration of independent, apartheid-free South Africa.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was on the plinth at Trafalgar Square on Sunday to endorse Nelson Mandela's celebration of independent, apartheid-free South Africa. Looking at the pictures of the celebration, I wondered whether the two men had time to discuss the threat to democracy in both their countries from large multinational corporations.

Nelson Mandela must have been rejoicing over the recent victory in his country over the big drug companies. The companies had sued the elected government to preserve their right to sell patented drugs at their own high prices, rather than the lower generic prices threatened by the government. Here was a straight issue between the "right" of a democratic government to charge generic (reasonable) prices for medicines to safeguard the health of their people; and the "right" of the drug companies to charge their much higher patented prices. A prolonged international campaign, imaginatively conducted on the internet, and backed by the dreadful statistics for Aids in South Africa, forced the companies to back down. Amid glorious scenes of popular rejoicing, the companies withdrew their action, rightly described in the Guardian as "one of the great corporate PR disasters of all time".

It was impossible not to join in the enthusiasm of the poor and sick Davids in South Africa as the corporate Goliaths slunk away from the courtroom. But were Tony Blair and his health ministers cheering too? Apparently not. Only three weeks before the drug companies' humiliation in South Africa, in a report jointly written by drugs company executives and two of the prize duds in the new Labour government, science minister David Sainsbury and health minister Philip Hunt, the government took up their stance firmly on the side of the rich drug companies and against the poor and sick.

Patents and the right to charge at patented prices, they declared, "are the lifeblood of the innovative pharmaceutical industry". Tony Blair added a personal rider. "I am committed," he started in a surprise phrase (not many of us realised he was committed to anything in particular), " ...to ensuring that the UK retains the features that have made it an attractive location for investment". This commitment was enthusiastically endorsed by the representatives of the big drug companies. They must have congratulated themselves on their corporate PR triumph with British health ministers so soon before one of the greatest corporate PR disasters of all time.

The shameful, obsequious report was the work of yet another of the quangos whose influence Labour once promised to curb. A drugs industry and government "task force" snapped to panic-stricken attention when leading drugs companies threatened to take their business elsewhere if the government dared to clamp down on the high drugs prices paid by the NHS. The very suggestion that companies like GlaxoSmithKline might scale down their operations in Britain was enough to persuade Blair, Hunt, Sainsbury and co to proclaim the case for the expensive medicines (and some of the most grotesque profits) in the corporate world.

It is this determination to make policy by CVQ (corporations via quangos) which distinguishes this government from past Labour administrations. It is symbolised by the so-called "reforms" to the greatest quango of all, the House of Lords. The plain fact is that after all the grand talk about a democratic second chamber, there is still not a single elected member of that body, nor even the prospect of one. The truth is that the prime minister and his close colleagues do not want an extension of democracy at Westminster. They are happy with a chamber that allows Sainsbury and Hunt to capitulate to the drugs companies.

The whole glorious farce reached its climax last week when Dennis Stevenson picked his people's peers from people who, he insisted, must be "comfortable" in the House of Lords. Stevenson is the quango king. Ever since, at the age of 26, he was picked out by the Tory millionaire Peter Walker as just the man to chair a new town development corporation in the north-east, he has stormed to the top of unelected powerhouses in every corner of British business. No wonder he is a friend of Peter Mandelson and a Blair favourite. No wonder he himself is a lord. No wonder he has picked as people's peers a clutch of cronies most of whom I thought must have been peers already. With GlaxoSmithKline supreme, and people's peers like Stevenson, Hunt and Sainsbury in high places, the most appropriate constitutional solution now seems obvious. Do away with the Commons altogether and construct an entire government out of those who do not have to bother with the rather vulgar business of voting but who do know how to make money for big corporations by fleecing the poor and the sick.

webTitle: Bush speech to bury arms pact

fields.headline: Bush speech to bury arms pact
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush will launch the biggest weapons policy gamble of his presidency today when he announces that Washington is willing to spend whatever it takes to build its controversial missile defence shield.
fields.body:
George Bush will launch the biggest weapons policy gamble of his presidency today when he announces that Washington is willing to spend whatever it takes to build its controversial missile defence shield.

The announcement, which involves crucial decisions for America's allies including Britain, will put relations between the US, EU and Russia to their most critical test since Ronald Reagan's 1980s cruise missile deployments.

On the day which the former Soviet Union always chose to parade its military might, Mr Bush will tell a May Day military audience that the US is preparing to scrap the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty which both Russia and China claim is the cornerstone of arms control agreements.

The scrapping of the treaty paves the way for a vastly more ambitious missile defence programme than anything the Pentagon has yet contemplated.

Instead of the relatively limited but still controversial national missile defence system developed under Bill Clinton, Mr Bush intends to build a "multi-layered" shield for the US and its allies, using sea- and space-based radars, lasers and interceptors, in a project reminiscent of the Reagan-era "Star Wars" system.

The Clinton administration's plans were confined to 100 land-based interceptors in Alaska that were intended to provide a shield for the US.

The 1972 treaty explicitly bans the US and Russia from developing national missile interceptor systems for defence, and is regarded by most countries as the foundation of three decades of negotiations to prevent arms proliferation. Military chiefs and Republican politicians in the US have long disliked the treaty, however, and have won the argument in the new administration.

"We will deploy defences as soon as possible. Therefore we believe that the ABM treaty will have to be replaced, eliminated or changed in a fundamental way," a Bush administration official, Lucas Fischer, said in Denmark last week.

"Mr Bush appears to be on the threshold of unleashing nuclear anarchy," Dan Plesch of the British American Security Information Council in Washington, said.

In an attempt to cushion the inevitable blow which the decision will deliver to the existing structure of international arms control, Mr Bush is expected to signal US willingness to make deep new cuts in its nuclear arsenal, reducing the current 7,500 warheads by up to two-thirds.

The US is already committed to cutting its strategic nuclear warheads to 3,500 under the 1993 Start-2 strategic arms limitation treaty with Russia, but Mr Bush is expected to go further. Administration hawks believe such decisions should be made unilaterally, befitting the US's post-cold war status as the sole global superpower.

Mr Bush will also announce that the US is launching an intensive diplomatic offensive with Nato and Russia to win international acceptance for the missile shield plan. Britain will be a particularly important part of that persuasion effort because the US shield involves the upgrading of the Fylingdales radar station in north Yorkshire.

Yesterday he telephoned Tony Blair and Jacques Chirac, the French president, to discuss today's announcement.

Teams of senior US officials are expected in European capitals within days in an exercise which governments on both sides of the Atlantic hope will give a face-saving cover of consultation to what most independent observers now see as a fait accompli .

President Bush is due to come to Europe next month for the first time to meet Nato chiefs in Brussels and to attend a US-EU summit in Gothenberg.

Britain and other US allies have pressed Washington to consult widely and in detail about its plans before announcing its conclusions, but there has never been any question of the administration's commitment to a policy which was at the heart of Mr Bush's election platform. "We want this to be a consultative process," the US secretary of state, Colin Powell, told a congressional committee last week. "But we're going forward with a missile defence."

Mr Bush is not expected to go into detail about his plans in today's speech to the National Defence University in Washington, but the announcement will make little attempt to hide the fact that his administration has already decided to commit billions of extra dollars over the coming decades to missile defences.

The plans were "a hairbrained scheme to defend the US against non-existent threats," Stephen Young of the Union of Concerned Scientists, said.

fields.headline: It's revolutionary, but Britons will rush to build their air-raid shelters
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Gerhard Schröder's proposals for European Union reform created less outrage among his fellow leaders yesterday than among British Eurosceptics. But they are still unlikely to find many buyers elsewhere in the club.
fields.body:
Gerhard Schröder's proposals for European Union reform created less outrage among his fellow leaders yesterday than among British Eurosceptics. But they are still unlikely to find many buyers elsewhere in the club.

Romano Prodi, president of the European commission, welcomed the German chancellor's ideas as a "contribution" to the debate about the EU's future, though he gave no hint of his own thoughts, due to be published shortly.

Tony Blair has good reason to be irritated by Mr Schröder's views - not so much because he disagrees with most of them, but because they are grist to the mill of a Tory party desperate to make Europe an election issue.

But the French president, Jacques Chirac, and the Spanish prime minister, Jose-Maria Aznar, a fierce defender of his national interests, will be no less annoyed at this revival of divisive debate so soon after last December's Nice summit.

Wolfgang Schüssel, the Austrian chancellor, who often speaks for smaller countries, warned against a "European superstate".

The federally minded Belgium, which is taking over the EU's rotating presidency in July, was predictably delighted.

But under EU rules the kind of changes under discussion in Berlin could only take place if all 15 member states agreed: that is simply unimaginable.

Viewed from Brussels, Mr Schröder's ideas are a mixed bag: his call for transforming the European commission into a "real executive" sounds radical if unclear, but will please integrationists.

"Some of the things we do clearly do involve governing," said one bemused commission official, "though calling us a government is obviously a red rag in the UK." Others suggested that the ideas were half-baked, and were not the chancellor's own. But Mr Schröder's suggestion of making the council of ministers into a second chamber of the European parliament is revolutionary. It is likely to be brusquely rejected in most national capitals.

French officials insisted that they would not accept such a dilution of sovereignty. Paris feels Mr Schröder is making a renewed bid for a leadership role for Germany. "He's constructed himself a nice platform," said one veteran EU-watcher.

But however much they disagree, EU leaders do not publicly rubbish each others ideas. Mr Schröder's are part of a series of attempts to put national stamps on a debate that will be raging in 2004, when a conference on changing the European treaty is to be held.

It was at Nice that leaders agreed, largely under German pressure, on a fresh round of reform negotiations to clarify the crucial division of labour between EU institutions, national governments and regional authorities.

Germany's Green foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, set the ball rolling before that, followed by Mr Chirac, who effectively called for a "two-speed" Europe in which like-minded states would forge ahead, leaving the laggards behind.

Tony Blair, whose main worry is the euro, followed suit in October -declaring that he wanted a Europe that was a "superpower, but not a superstate".

But the prime minister's most significant point then was the idea that the 626-member European parliament should have a second chamber to redress the democratic deficit and increase links with voters at home.

Here he has something important in common with Mr Schröder - a desire to bring Europe closer to its citizens.

British reactions to the German proposals were greeted with familiar dismay in Brussels. "It is a massive problem for Britain," sighed a commission insider, "because as soon as anyone says anything about Europe people rush out to dig air-raidshelters in their back gardens. It means we just can't have a serious discussion."

fields.headline: Wagner quits Bright Station board
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Dan Wagner, the outspoken chief executive of Bright Station, yesterday confirmed that he plans to quit the board after seven tempestuous years.
fields.body:
Dan Wagner, the outspoken chief executive of Bright Station, yesterday confirmed that he plans to quit the board after seven tempestuous years.

The decision is likely to lead to the break-up of a technology company that has never quite persuaded the City of its merits.

Details of the plan, disclosed last week by the Guardian, were accompanied by figures showing that Bright Station has just £7.4m left in the bank and needs to raise further funds.

Shares in Bright Station, which have fallen by 95% over the past year, slipped a further 5.5p to 15.25p, valuing the firm at £26.4m. The fall places in danger a plan for Credit Suisse First Boston to issue a convertible bond to fund the group. The investment bank says it will provide the money only if Bright Station's market capitalisation is £30m or more.

Mr Wagner, 36, has quit the board after failing to persuade the City to share his bullish evaluation of the group he floated on the stock market and amid unease within the firm that the baggage his reputation brings with him is holding back business.

The fast-talking former salesman has not been afraid to go against the grain. Last year he snapped up 44 software programmers from Boo.com at a time when the collapsed e-tailer was a dirty word in the technology world.

But his belligerence won him many critics in the City. When Bright Station was still called Dialog, its faltering finances won it the nickname "dial-a-dog".

His image has not recovered from the ill-fated £260m acquisition of the debt-laden Knight Ridder information business which he was forced to sell on for a £90m loss. Name changes from Maid to Dialog to Bright Station have failed to erase damage.

In an illustration of his continued faith in Bright Station's non-core assets of Sparza and Office Shopper, however, Mr Wagner is in talks about making an offer to take them private.

If successful, it would leave Smartlogik, a knowledge management software product and the core of the group, as a "pure play" listed technology company.

Last year Steve Hill, the highly rated founder of US software group Inktomi, was recruited to run Smartlogik in preparation for a stock market listing of its own. But market conditions turned against a spin-off, leaving Mr Wagner with little choice but to restructure the group in a way that makes Mr Hill's team its focus.

Smartlogik insiders believe it has the potential to become as big as Autonomy, the market-leading intelligent software firm, but funding restrictions are said to have held it back. Bright Station will be renamed Smartlogik if the talks with Mr Wagner are concluded.

He will only offer a minimal sum for the businesses because the likely alternative is to close them and that would incur added costs.

Efforts have already been made to reduce costs by laying off about a quarter of the staff.

Analysts say that the performance of Bright Station's share price over the next few weeks will play a crucial part in enabling the group to secure new funds and warn that if the market capitalisation remains below £30m Mr Wagner could be forced to renegotiate less favourable terms with CSFB or another backer.

webTitle: Red Herring sounds out the market

fields.headline: Red Herring sounds out the market
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: Red Herring Communications, publisher of Red Herring magazine, one of the first newsletters of the dot.com community, could be looking for a buyer.
fields.body:
Red Herring Communications, publisher of Red Herring magazine, one of the first newsletters of the dot.com community, could be looking for a buyer.

The San Francisco-based owner of the magazine, a website, a conference business and a research unit, according to the Wall Street Journal, recently approached AOL Time Warner's magazine division and Ziff Davis Media, a US-based internet magazine publisher, about selling part or all of the company.

Ross Settles, senior vice-president for marketing, refused to be more specific but said the firm recently secured funding and did not need to sell. It is thought AOL Time Warner and Ziff Davis Media may not be interested in completing a deal with Red Herring.

A company spokeswoman said: "We do not need to sell the business, we just finished a strategic round of financing to grow the business and we are looking to expand internationally."

The reports come weeks after the demise of the European arm of internet business magazine Industry Standard. Red Herring, which was at the centre of the dot.com boom, is the latest in a series of internet publications to suffer as the demand for technology and new economy magazines has waned.

Magazine publisher Future Network announced last week the closure of all the European editions of its new economy title, Business 2.0. There has been speculation over the possible sale of the US edition during the past couple of months, with some estimating it to be valued at $50m (£35m).

Red Herring is one of the more established internet magazines - it was founded in 1993 - and describes itself on its website as providing "timely market information, strategic insight and access to growing entrepreneurial communities".

The company expanded last year and doubled the magazine's publishing frequency at the height of the technology sector boom. Red Herring has, however, seen advertising revenues fall and has had two rounds of staff cuts. In December the companycut 32 workers - 9% of its employees - two months after announcing the loss of 22 jobs.

The Wall Street Journal report said the number of pages of advertising in Red Herring fell 28% in the first quarter of 2001 as dot.com firms ran out of cash. It is thought to be more financially secure than some of its competitors because it has a relatively large circulation - 325,000, according to the company.

Red Herring's chairman, Tony Perkins, last month was said to have considered selling the company to help fund a campaign to run for governor of California.

Ziff Davis Media yesterday refused to comment and AOL Time Warner and Red Herring were unavailable.

Red Herring has, however, seen advertising revenues fall and has had two rounds of staff cuts. In December the companycut 32 workers - 9% of its employees - two months after announcing the loss of 22 jobs. The Wall Street Journal report said the number of pages of advertising in Red Herring fell 28% in the first quarter of 2001 as dot.com firms ran out of cash. It is thought to be more financially secure than some of its competitors because it has a relatively large circulation - 325,000, according to the company. Red Herring's chairman, Tony Perkins, last month was said to have considered selling the company to help fund a campaign to run for governor of California. Ziff Davis Media yesterday refused to comment and AOL Time Warner and Red Herring were unavailable. Red Herring magazine

 Lets save it After almost going spectacularly bust last year, the e-tailer Letsbuyit said yesterday it had found investors prepared to provide €25m (£15.6m) in new funds. Shares in the London-based firm jumped by more than a third after it said it had enough cash to see it through to the end of next year, when it is forecast to turn a profit for the first time.

New York venture capital firm GEM was identified as the provider of the new money. Another €30m fi nancing deal is being renegotiated. Founder John Palmer has returned to take over the day-to-day running of the firm and is adamant that the trimmed down operation has a bright future in Europe.

 Royal return Saudi Arabia's Prince Alwaleed bin Talal might invest in technology stocks to take advantage of low share prices. "I might find it now a golden opportunity to buy [technology] stocks because they are very cheap," he told a news conference. The 44-year-old prince said last year that he invested $2bn (£1.3bn) in US companies, half of it in technology stocks. He told the news conference that his investment in America Online was still profitable, unlike other tech holdings.

 Top shop Online auctioneer eBay has scored a victory over Amazon.com in the battle for e-commerce supremacy, overtaking the internet bookseller to become the world's most-visited retailing website, according to a Nielsen/Net Ratings report.

 Portal exit High-speed internet service provider Excite@Home will cut 13% of its staff - 380 workers - a spokeswoman said. The layoffs come as the company struggles to cut costs and offset the drain created by its Excite portal and other media assets.

Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: Franny Traynor is 66. He has smoked since he was 10 - and has had nine heart attacks. He is one of 20 people suing the tobacco industry in the Scottish courts, but it is feared he might not live to see his trial. So this week he will give evidence - and be cross-examined - in advance. Kirsty Scott and Clare Dyer report.
fields.body:
A grey cloud hangs almost permanently above Franny Traynor's head. A thick fug of smoke curls from the cigarettes he nurses in thin, nervous hands. "Look at me," he says. "I'm still smoking. I have had nine heart attacks, I have had open-heart surgery and I'm still smoking. All I hear from the doctors is stop the smoking but I am addicted. I will be smoking until I die."

That day may well come sooner rather than later; or so, at least, contends Imperial Tobacco. This week, at the tobacco giant's request, Traynor faces a grilling by its lawyers at the court of session in Edinburgh. The 66-year-old from Milngavie near Glasgow is one of 20 people suing the tobacco industry in the Scottish courts, and the company has asked for him to give his evidence "on commission" in case he dies before his legal action comes to court.

Over three days from tomorrow, despite his frailty, Traynor will be questioned by a QC for Imperial. He has been refused legal aid, so he will have no lawyer of his own to lead him gently through his evidence-in-chief as a build-up to a tough cross-examination by the company's QC. His solicitor, Cameron Fyfe, who is running the cases on a no-win, no-fee basis, has prepared an affidavit for him to hand in, but otherwise he will be on his own.

The tobacco industry has been forced to pay out millions of dollars in the US, but in Britain it has managed to see off all attempts so far to bring it before the courts. Litigation on behalf of more than 50 lung cancer victims in England collapsed in 1999, losing the lawyers who backed it on a no-win, no-fee basis £2m in fees. But north of the border, the industry is still in the line of fire. The first test case, pursued by Margaret McTear from Ayrshire, whose husband, Alfred, died of lung cancer in 1993, goes to court in September. The evidence Alfred McTear gave on commission before his death will form part of her case.

The tactic of taking evidence on commission has been condemned by anti-smoking campaigners, who say it can be used as a means of intimidating victims, scaring them away from pursuing a case. (Imperial insists it is "a straightforward and normal procedure to preserve evidence", approved by the court; and points out that McTear's solicitors had suggested it in his case.) Does the prospect frighten Traynor? "I'm not worrying about it," he says, lighting and lifting another cigarette with the practised ease of the lifelong smoker. "There's no point any more in worrying. Although, if I'm honest, I'm nervous about a couple of QCs trying to talk smart to me.

"The thing I object to, that unsettles me, is that they have gone through my whole life: all my files, every record from the day I was born to the present day, my health, my work, my DHSS, my criminal cases have been pulled. I'm no angel, I've been in court maybe half a dozen times, and they will be pulling all of this out of the hat. But it has nothing to do with cigarettes; 90% of my life has nothing to do with cigarettes."

Fyfe, a Glasgow solicitor who is acting for Traynor and the others who have lodged cases against the tobacco trade, says the commission hearing will be gruelling. "It will be an ordeal for him and I applaud his courage in proceeding with this. It is bad enough for a healthy man with experience of court matters to go through what he will go through, but for someone with no experience and in poor health it will be even more of an ordeal. But I know he is a very brave and determined man and he will fight his corner in that commission."

Like so many, Traynor started smoking at school. "I was the same as any other boy. I started smoking at 10 or 11 in the toilets. You will hear the same from any boy. Most of them stuck with it, like me. I've been a regular 20-a-day man. I wouldn't say I was a heavy smoker but I have been smoking all my life."

He has always smoked Embassy and he can still recite the gifts he collected from the old Embassy coupons; an electric cordless screwdriver, a jigsaw. After spells in the army and navy he set himself up in the furniture removal trade, operating in and around Milngavie, where he was born. It was a thriving business that he had to give up after his heart packed in. He had his first heart attack when he was 53. "The pain is that bloody severe that you lie about the floor like an idiot writhing. That's the terrible thing about heart attacks. It's like someone switched you into a socket. The pain is tremendous; people were all around me trying to hold me down."

The attack almost killed him and doctors told him to stop smoking and drinking. He managed to give up the drink, but not the cigarettes. "I tried to come off but I found it terrible because I have been smoking all my life. I told the doctors I couldn't do it. I was ready to thump somebody." In the past 14 years he has had eight more heart attacks. He says he could die at any time. "It might even be next week."

His wife, Mary, herself a lifelong smoker, has been listening to him talk. A quiet, questioning woman, she wonders why America seems so far ahead in the tobacco litigation battle and why her husband must face a gruelling court ordeal to try to convince the authorities that he is addicted.

"When I think back to when he tried to give up, he was just so depressed. It got to the stage where he would just sit and stare and say nothing. He just couldn't do it. I have tried to stop so many times but I can't, even although they have made my husband so ill."

The English cases, run by two leading law firms, Leigh Day & Co and Irwin Mitchell, involved exhaustive research and cost Leigh Day £750,000 in out-of-pocket expenses, according to senior partner Martyn Day. They collapsed when the judge, Mr Justice Wright, ruled that most of the claims had been launched too long after the original diagnosis of lung cancer. He refused to exercise his discretion to allow them to go ahead anyway, describing them as "speculative".

Cameron Fyfe explains: "The problem in England was that they were required to take the cases on as a group action, whereas in Scotland we could just go ahead with one case, that being McTear. So it's much more manageable. We're trying as well as we can to do it very simplistically, just putting forward very basic arguments without getting tied up in millions of documents, which is what the tobacco companies try to do. Our basic argument is that prior to 1971, when the warnings came on cigarette packets, the tobacco companies knew or ought to have known that cigarettes were injurious to health, but they failed to warn the consumers. When the warnings came on in 1971, our clients, in particular Mr McTear, tried to stop smoking but couldn't, because by that time they were addicted."

If Mrs McTear loses, all the other cases, including Franny Traynor's, will be dismissed. "If she wins, I would hope Imperial Tobacco might then settle some or most of them," says Fyfe. "If they do, fine. If they don't, I'm almost certain we will get legal aid for the ones that are in dispute. Sometimes I think, if you'll excuse the pun, that there's a smokescreen around the tobacco cases. If it were anything else - if Coca-Cola was producing products that kill people and didn't warn anybody about it - there would be a national outcry."

In the Traynors' home in Milngavie, seven of the nine children smoke and the conversation is interrupted by one son who comes in to beg a cigarette off Mary. Traynor says he is not going to court for their sake, or anyone else's for that matter. "I'm not bothered about anyone else. I'm not out crusading for other people. I'm just doing this because I'm angry. I'm doing it because I'm angry with them. It is the chief interest for me getting them to say that it is bloody addictive and getting that put on the packet with all their other fancy warnings. I'm addicted and if any judge asks me to prove that I'll just ask him to give me an ashtray."

webTitle: Shipman asked about deaths in West Yorkshire

fields.headline: Shipman asked about deaths in West Yorkshire
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: The serial killer Harold Shipman was being interviewed yesterday over nine suspicious deaths while he was working as a GP in West Yorkshire at the beginning of his medical career.
fields.body:
The serial killer Harold Shipman was being interviewed yesterday over nine suspicious deaths while he was working as a GP in West Yorkshire at the beginning of his medical career.

The inquiry reinforces the fears of the relatives of some of his victims that the former family doctor could have been systematically murdering patients for more than a quarter of a century.

Detectives from West Yorkshire police travelled to Frankland prison in Durham, where the bearded and bespectacled killer is serving 15 life sentences, to talk to him about the deaths in the Todmorden area in the 1970s.

Shipman worked at the Abraham Ormerod medical centre between 1974 and 1976. Colleagues remembered his dedication, hard work and energy, but he also had an unusually high death rate. Police were investigating all 22 death certificates signed by Shipman.

It is the first time Shipman has spoken to detectives since the run-up to his court case last year, when he was convicted of killing 15 women patients from Hyde, Greater Manchester. He has always refused to cooperate with Greater Manchester police, who have been investigating the deaths of hundreds of other patients.

Shipman has also turned down requests from the South Manchester coroner, John Pollard, who has held 24 inquests into deaths of former patients. In all but two cases the coroner recorded verdicts of unlawful killing.

Three patients from the Todmorden practice died on the same day - January 21 1975. Relatives of Lily Crossley, Robert Lingard and Elizabeth Pearce insist that they died suddenly after bedside visits from Shipman.

His modus operandi in all his known murders was to inject his patients with a lethal dose of diamorphine. Most of his victims were elderly women - although some were middle aged and a handful were men.

Shipman worked in Todmorden, a former mill town, until forced to leave when he was convicted of illegally possessing the prescription drug pethidine - an analgesic and anaesthetic often used to relieve the pain of childbirth. He was fined by Halifax magistrates and escaped a General Medical Council disciplinary hearing after he was treated for drug addiction.

A former GP, now retired, who worked with Shipman in Todmorden described him as a breath of fresh air to the Todmorden practice. Michael Grieve, now 72, said he was very keen and a good technician. "If any extra work came up, you didn't have to ask for a volunteer because Fred - as he was known to colleagues and patients alike - was there two paces ahead of you," he said.

Other former colleagues spoke of a sense of disbelief about the alleged murders. Another said: "He didn't bump off everybody he treated, so presumably he did some of them some good."

Jane Ashton-Hibbert, who runs a support group for the families, said she would be very surprised if Shipman answered the detectives' questions. Her grandmother, Hilda Hibbert, was unlawfully killed by Shipman in 1996.

"I have seen the pain these families have gone through and the hurt because he has not admitted what he has done. It must be particularly bad for people in Todmorden because it happened such a long time ago.

"I would love to be wrong, but I would doubt he will ever admit his guilt. He has got all the power, so why would he help any of us?"

A public inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the activities of Shipman will begin in Manchester in June, chaired by Dame Janet Smith, a high court judge.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Last week's announcement of David Lock's Stupidest MP 2001 candidacy (for threatening a local free sheet, you will recall, over the same remarks he ignored in Private Eye) brings forth a torrent of information.
fields.body:
 Last week's announcement of David Lock's Stupidest MP 2001 candidacy (for threatening a local free sheet, you will recall, over the same remarks he ignored in Private Eye) brings forth a torrent of information.

We will come to it all in time, but let it suffice for now that before he joined the lord chancellor's office as official carrier of Derry Irvine's ermine train on state occasions, David was quite the lefty. Before the last election, indeed, he was strongly rebuked by David Blunkett after telling the pupils and headmistress of a fee-paying Kidderminster girls school that "private schools are a cancer in society". His views on New Labour's early performance were no less trenchant, and when asked what he made of Tony Blair's first year in power by a Rotary club in his Wyre Forest constituency, he said: "We had 18 years of Tory misrule, now you can say we've had 19 years of Tory misrule."

What a firebrand the then practising barrister was - and how sad that his then obscurity cost him a Turncoat place.

 Speaking of which, the weekend brought such a deluge of Turncoat votes (including two for dear old Reg Race) that if we only had a postbag, it would bulge today. Robin Cook, Bomber Short and Paul Boateng have now broken away from the field, but one-time second favourite Peter Hain, who was coming under pressure on the rails, is fighting back and may yet make the shake-up. Keep at it, Hainy!

 Surveillance: Boris the Jackal Johnson, in the crowd at Sunday's Trafalgar Square concert, leading the booing when Mr Tony had the audacity to appear on the platform beside Nelson Mandela.

 Meanwhile, a challenger to David Lock for Stupidest MP 2001 steps forward. It is Nigel Evans, Tory MP for Ribble Valley, who answers a movie questionnaire in the Clitheroe Advertiser. "Tom Cruise," he replies when asked after his favourite actor, "he reminds me of me."

My colleague Marina Hyde asks Nigel if there is a point at which stupidity and unfunny faux vanity merge in an indistinct blur of imbecility? "I'm sorry?" says Nigel. Marina explains slowly. "Aha! Yes. Ha ha. Well, it was the continuation of a joke I made before about being amazed people couldn't see my likeness with Tom Cruise." The exact same joke, then? "Yes." How maddening they didn't make that clear and you simply look like a puffed-up halfwit. "Ha ha. They didn't make it clear, yes, I see. I see." Do you ? "No. Well, goodbye then." Bye.

 More on David tomorrow when we examine the transcript of the threatening call he made to For You, the above mentioned free sheet. This chap could turn into quite a character.

 In the Sun, political editor Aussie Trevor Kavanagh considers how Mr Tony will reshuffle his cabinet of all the talents after the election. It's all fairly predictable stuff, to be honest, until the very last paragraph. "Chief whip Ann Taylor is tipped for the chop," writes the ocker, "with former health secretary Frank Dobson... in the running to replace her." Sorry, Trev, once more with that."... with former health secretary Frank Dobson in the running to replace her." But, er... yes, a little time, please, to let the notion sink in.

 William Hague's henchman Seb Coe grows ever more masterful. Having bodily cast aside three student protesters who sported Hague masks in Leeds last week, Seb wheeled round, in the manner of the hero in a bad martial arts movie, to find himself confronted by a fourth assailant. Instead of whirling sticks menacingly, this one asked what job he'd be doing after the election. "At least some of us have got a job," sneered Seb, a fighter's exhaustion giving way to pure instinct. "Are you studying hairdressing or media studies or something?" Politics, as it happened, but a triumph for our noble sensi all the same.

Robin Cook, Bomber Short and Paul Boateng have now broken away from the field, but one-time second favourite Peter Hain, who was coming under pressure on the rails, is fighting back and may yet make the shake-up. Keep at it, Hainy!  Surveillance: Boris the Jackal Johnson, in the crowd at Sunday's Trafalgar Square concert, leading the booing when Mr Tony had the audacity to appear on the platform beside Nelson Mandela.  Meanwhile, a challenger to David Lock for Stupidest MP 2001 steps forward. It is Nigel Evans, Tory MP for Ribble Valley, who answers a movie questionnaire in the Clitheroe Advertiser. "Tom Cruise," he replies when asked after his favourite actor, "he reminds me of me." My colleague Marina Hyde asks Nigel if there is a point at which stupidity and unfunny faux vanity merge in an indistinct blur of imbecility? "I'm sorry?" says Nigel. Marina explains slowly. "Aha! Yes. Ha ha. Well, it was the continuation of a joke I made before about being amazed people couldn't see my likeness with Tom Cruise." The exact same joke, then? "Yes." How maddening they didn't make that clear and you simply look like a puffed-up halfwit. "Ha ha. They didn't make it clear, yes, I see. I see." Do you ? "No. Well, goodbye then." Bye.  More on David tomorrow when we examine the transcript of the threatening call he made to For You, the above mentioned free sheet. This chap could turn into quite a character.  In the Sun, political editor Aussie Trevor Kavanagh considers how Mr Tony will reshuffle his cabinet of all the talents after the election. It's all fairly predictable stuff, to be honest, until the very last paragraph. "Chief whip Ann Taylor is tipped for the chop," writes the ocker, "with former health secretary Frank Dobson... in the running to replace her." Sorry, Trev, once more with that."... with former health secretary Frank Dobson in the running to replace her." But, er... yes, a little time, please, to let the notion sink in.  William Hague's henchman Seb Coe grows ever more masterful. Having bodily cast aside three student protesters who sported Hague masks in Leeds last week, Seb wheeled round, in the manner of the hero in a bad martial arts movie, to find himself confronted by a fourth assailant. Instead of whirling sticks menacingly, this one asked what job he'd be doing after the election. "At least some of us have got a job," sneered Seb, a fighter's exhaustion giving way to pure instinct. "Are you studying hairdressing or media studies or something?" Politics, as it happened, but a triumph for our noble sensi all the same. diary@theguardian.com

webTitle: 40 tonnes of unfit meat seized in warehouse raid

fields.headline: 40 tonnes of unfit meat seized in warehouse raid
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: Forty tonnes of chicken, beef and lamb unfit for human consumption have been seized from a warehouse in Liverpool.
fields.body:
Forty tonnes of chicken, beef and lamb unfit for human consumption have been seized from a warehouse in Liverpool.

Environmental health officers from Liverpool city council raided the warehouse and found the meat in a walk-in freezer. It is feared that the meat - later certified by magistrates as unfit for human consumption - could have been repackaged and sold to unsuspecting supermarkets and restaurants.

The meat had no documentation, but is thought to have originated from a pet food factory in Derbyshire, which is at the centre of a police investigation into the sale of unfit meat. Last month, the food standards agency seized another 40 tonnes of unfit meat from Denby Poultry Products, near Ripley in Derbyshire. Nineteen people from across the country were arrested as part of the inquiry.

The FSA - set up last year in the wake of the BSE crisis - is considering proposals to stain meat unfit for human consumption.The illegal trade in poultry deemed unfit is said to be increasing due to the increased demand for chicken, following health scares including BSE and foot and mouth.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: We described Hosni Mubarak as the foreign minister of Egypt in a report headed Doubts over trial ceasefire, page 3, yesterday. He is, of course, the president.
fields.body:
We described Hosni Mubarak as the foreign minister of Egypt in a report headed Doubts over trial ceasefire, page 3, yesterday. He is, of course, the president.

Our statement that P&O Princess's Golden Princess would be the largest cruise ship ever to dock in Britain, page 27, Finance, April 27, was wrong. Royal Caribbean International's Explorer of the Seas, which visited Southampton in October last year, is bigger - the largest ship of its kind in the world.

In our obituary of Michael Northen, the lighting designer, page 22, April 28, we said he worked on John Gielgud's production of King Lear at Stratford-upon-Avon in 1952. The Gielgud production in 1952 was, in fact, Macbeth, not King Lear. Gielgud directed Lear there in 1950, but the designer on that occasion was Leslie Hurry.

More than a few readers noticed that the shipwrecked people on The Raft of the Medusa. the painting by Géricault, page 9, Saturday Review, April 28, were sailing in the wrong direction. The picture, the original of which is in the Louvre, was accidentally reversed.

Contrary to what we said in our G2 front (On a wing and a prayer, April 26) the Amundsen-Scott polar research station is no longer operated by the US Navy but by the US National Science Foundation, and at 2,800m its altitude is almost one-third the height of Mt Everest, not two-thirds.

In our report about the Monet painting of haystacks, "Last rays of the sun", to be auctioned at Sotheby's later this year, page 1 and page 9, April 27, we neglected to say where it could be seen. It is on view at Sotheby's in London from June 21 to June 26. Before that it can be seen at Sotheby's, New York, May 9 to May 15, and in Paris May 21 and 22.

A correction to a correction, page 21, April 28: the film When the Sky Falls is about the journalist Veronica Guerin, not Victoria Guerin.

webTitle: A beautiful game, but not in Bootle

fields.headline: A beautiful game, but not in Bootle
fields.standfirst: Billionaires now govern football's fortunes, at least in most places
fields.trailText: Billionaires now govern football's fortunes, at least in most places.
fields.body:
I think the favourite of all the books on my shelves (yeah, I've got Ulysses and War and Peace and all that stuff too) is a Penguin Special from 1958 by one RC Churchill entitled 60 Seasons of League Football. According to the pencil-mark at the front, it cost me 10p.

This forgotten masterwork devotes a page of mostly tedious stats to every club that has ever played in the Football League. Churchill, however, was a polymath in an era when football intellectualism was far less fashionable than it is now, and he adorns each team with an apt literary quotation. And it is the clubs that were long since buried, even in 1958, that make the book so resonant.

Ashington, the Charlton boys' home town, were in Division III (North) in the 1920s ("Ye Northumbrian shades... How gladly I recall" - Akenside). So were Durham City, Nelson and Stalybridge Celtic. In Division III (South) were Merthyr Tydfil ("Afar behind a western hill" - Flecker) and Thames, based in the East End.

Long before that came Darwen, Glossop North End and - savour this - Middlesbrough Ironopolis. Bootle were voted into the Second Division in 1892 and voted out in 1893 ("Hope of a season's fame" - Newbolt). There was even a town which now has no League clubs that once had two. Naming the town (answer below) used to be a cruel press-box initiation rite for tyro sports journalists.

Nowhere is there a mention of any town as one-horse as Rushden (pop: 25,000). Yet this week, barring an improbable set of results, a football club called Rushden and Diamonds will be promoted to what some of us still call the Fourth Division of the Football League. And this is a game so metropolitan that Norwich, once England's second city, are usually referred to as "country cousins". Rushden's elevation is not just a bit of football trivia; it is a slice of geopolitical history.

Rushden, you may need to be told, is an old Northamptonshire shoe town. The only apt quote comes from HE Bates, who was born there and called it "a palpably dreadful mess ... blue slate, factory, chapel and that harsh Midland red brick which equally oppresses heart, soul, eye and senses."

Writers can only be that cruel about their home town. I worked briefly in a Rushden newspaper office and found it charmingly dull: like Aberystwyth on Valium. Mind you, I didn't last long: after being sent to interview four golden wedding couples in four days and reporting back each time that the happy pair had gone away on holiday without giving the neighbours a phone number, I thought it safest to resign before someone cottoned on.

And nothing is happening in Rushden, even now. The successful football club was formed from a merger between two old rivals, Rushden Town and Irthlingborough Diamonds, and they actually play in Irthlingborough, several miles away (pop: 6.500). This is a town with no horses at all, possibly because they were all rendered at the animal products factory that traditionally stank the place out. Locals call the town Artlenock and don't ask me why.

All it has, apart from a "remarkable" (Pevsner) church tower is a swanky new football stadium, Nene Park (Note to BBC: it's pronounced Nen not Neen). It's more like a multiplex - you get shown to your seat by "Rusherettes" and have your own popcorn holder - instead of a proper ground, with someone peeing on the back of your leg. And next week the sports pages will be full of how marvellous and "romantic" it is that next year teams from cities like Hull, Plymouth and Oxford have to find Irthlingborough on the map.

Well, up to a point. The towns in Churchill's book are there because ordinary but determined folk formed football clubs and made them successful. Rushden and Diamonds will be in there because a millionaire called Max Griggs (294th on the Sunday Times rich list) willed it. He chose to sink the money he makes from Dr Martens boots (or used to make - sales lately halved, six factories closed) into this elaborate trainset rather than a string of racehorses or saving Africa from poverty. It's a well-run trainset, which just happens to be in Irthlingborough.

That's his right, just as Mohamed Al Fayed can gain solace and glory from making Fulham a top-class club again and Jack Walker was able to purchase the Premiership title for Blackburn. Perhaps only billionaires can now compete with Manchester United, the Microsoft of football. But when you realise that the same rules work right down the ladder of "the people's game" as well, it makes it all very empty. For Irthlingborough, it's a meaningless honour. Alas, poor Bootle.

(Answer to question above: Burton upon Trent. Closing date for last week's real quiz: Thursday. Loads of entries already, hardly any of them right.)

fields.headline: UBS bails out fugitive's victims
fields.trailText: Swiss bank UBS is understood to have paid compensation to former partners of the Phillips & Drew stockbroking firm who lost some £15m at the hands of a former colleague.
fields.body:
Swiss bank UBS is understood to have paid compensation to former partners of the Phillips & Drew stockbroking firm who lost some £15m at the hands of a former colleague.

UBS, which now owns P&D, is thought have covered many of the losses, which left 23 of the City's top financiers out of pocket two years ago, and prompted a fraud squad investigation at the time. No charges have been brought.

The losses surfaced after Hugh Eaves, then 56, and a former partner of P&D, wrote to his former colleagues and told them he had lost the money and wanted to "come clean".

The episode prompted Mr Eaves to go into hiding amid descriptions of his Walter Mitty-style double life.

It caused financial difficulties for Bury football club where he had been the largest shareholder. His other hobbies included being deputy chairman of the Festiniog line, a steam-preservation railway in north Wales.

Mr Eaves had been entrusted by his 23 former colleagues to look after the millions of pounds in shares and loans they received for selling their P&D stockbroking and fund management to the then Union Bank of Switzerland in 1985. Not all the partners entrusted their wealth to Mr Eaves, who resigned from UBS in 1988.

Their former business has now been incorporated into UBS which was formed when Union Bank of Switzerland merged with Swiss Bank Corporation.

The Phillips & Drew name is only used by the fund management arm of the Swiss bank, and Mr Eaves's actions concern only the former partners.

The account he looked after is once thought to have contained some £20m. In the letter he wrote to his friend two years ago he is said to have listed all his remaining assets, which at that time included a number of homes in Hampstead, a restaurant, sports cars and his shareholding interests in Bury football club. He is also thought to have invested in derivatives instruments.

Confidential agreements are thought to have prevented the former P&D partners discussing the payments they are thought to have received from UBS.

The precise size of the payments is unclear and according to some City executives UBS decided to make the payments to put an end to the incident.

Mr Eaves could not be reached for comment last night while the solicitors representing him two years ago said they were no longer retained by him.

UBS and Phillips & Drew refused to comment. Law firm Ashurst Morris Crisp, which represented the P&D partners, was unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Help sought from drug firms
fields.body:
Help sought from drug firms

Gordon Brown is to press pharmaceuticals companies to help tackle HIV, Aids, malaria and tuberculosis by agreeing to cut prices and carry out more research on infectious diseases in poor countries.

The chancellor and Clare Short, the development minister, are to meet with multilateral organisations as well as some of the world's wealthiest charitable foundations in New York today to elicit support for the fund.

Details of the total raised, expected to be in the region of $3bn-$4bn, could be released as early as June at a special meeting on Aids hosted by the United Nations. "We call upon pharmaceutical companies to respond," said Mr Brown.

Scottish Power finds US target

Scottish Power has been holding talks in the US about a possible $3bn (£2bn) takeover of Portland Power. Discussions with Portland's parent, Enron, followed the collapse of negotiations last week to sell Portland to Sierra Pacific Resources.

The Glasgow-based utility has made no secret of its desire to expand across the Atlantic following its successful purchase of PacifiCorp and the opportunities for post-merger cost-savings.

Sources confirmed talks between Enron and Scottish Power had taken place but the British company declined to comment on what it described as "market speculation".

Bombardier in Lufthansa deal

Bombardier, owner of Shorts of Belfast, yesterday won a $340m (£237m) contract to supply 15 of its Canadair Regional Jets to Lufthansa , the German national flag carrier.

The contract for Bombardier, the world's third-largest civil aircraft maker, includes 15 firm orders for the 50-seat CRJ200 and 30 options.

Deliveries are to begin in October and continue to the spring of 2003.

The jets will be operated by Lufthansa affiliate Eurowings. Lufthansa is a 24.9% shareholder in the Dortmund-based airline.

Vodafone takes stake in Japan

AT&T, the biggest US long-distance and cable television company, said it had completed the $1.35bn (£943m) cash sale of its 10% stake in Japan Telecom to Vodafone.

Net after-tax proceeds of the sale to Vodafone, the world's biggest mobile phone company, would be about $1bn. The sale raises Vodafone's stake in Japan Telecom, Japan's third-largest carrier, to 25%, making it the company's biggest shareholder.

fields.headline: Bank's 'sell' note enrages Tesco
fields.trailText: A fierce behind the scenes row has broken out between Tesco, the nation's leading grocer, and ABN Amro over an aggressive piece of research due to be published by the Dutch-owned investment bank this morning.
fields.body:
A fierce behind the scenes row has broken out between Tesco, the nation's leading grocer, and ABN Amro over an aggressive piece of research due to be published by the Dutch-owned investment bank this morning.

Preparing a "sell" note on Tesco, ABN's highly-rated sector analyst Mark Wasilewski is understood to have made damaging allegations about the UK supermarket's depreciation policy, leading to fiery exchanges between the company and the analyst, and sparking rumours yesterday that Tesco had broken off communications with the bank.

Tesco's finance director, Andrew Higginson, last night described the rumours as "misleading and mischievous", but stated that the analyst had misunderstood certain aspects of the group's accounting.

Later Mr Wasilewski, who vehemently denied there had been a row, confirmed that he now accepted there was nothing untoward in Tesco's accounting treatment of assets such as property, land and store fixtures, but insisted he was still intending to publish a downgrade on Tesco's in vestment prospects. Both parties were insisting last night that they had overcome their differences, but the affair highlights the increasingly fraught relations between big corporates, buffeted by share price volatility, and City analysts, who declare themselves to be independent experts, untainted by pressure from the corporate finance divisions of their own banks.

ABN, for example, acts as corporate broker to Tesco's chief rival, J Sainsbury, although Mr Wasilewski has made it clear that his work on the sector has remained free of any conflict or bias.

In the research note now to be published the analyst questions acceleration in Tesco's earnings growth and also raises doubts about some of the supermarket's international operations.

Earlier, Mr Wasilewski is understood to have expressed suspicion over why a rise in Tesco's depreciation charge had failed to match a rise in other costs. The matter echoed a similar City row Tesco became embroiled in several years ago, which led to a change in accounting policy.

Yesterday, shares in Tesco closed 6p lower at 250p.

ABN, for example, acts as corporate broker to Tesco's chief rival, J Sainsbury, although Mr Wasilewski has made it clear that his work on the sector has remained free of any conflict or bias. In the research note now to be published the analyst questions acceleration in Tesco's earnings growth and also raises doubts about some of the supermarket's international operations. Earlier, Mr Wasilewski is understood to have expressed suspicion over why a rise in Tesco's depreciation charge had failed to match a rise in other costs. The matter echoed a similar City row Tesco became embroiled in several years ago, which led to a change in accounting policy. Yesterday, shares in Tesco closed 6p lower at 250p.

webTitle: Tea bid leaves the analysts guessing

fields.headline: Tea bid leaves the analysts guessing
fields.trailText: A takeover is brewing at Whittard of Chelsea, the purveyor of fine teas, which saw its shares surge 38% yesterday on news of a bid approach.
fields.body:
A takeover is brewing at Whittard of Chelsea, the purveyor of fine teas, which saw its shares surge 38% yesterday on news of a bid approach.

The news came at a tricky time for the 115-year-old company, which has dipped into the red after heavy investment in new stores and online activities.

Shares in Whittard rose 10.5p to 38p, valuing the business at £8.2m. The biggest shareholders are chairman Will Hobhouse, who has a 24% stake, and non-executive director David Glyne-Thompson, with 20%.

The identity of the bidder remained a mystery. It is understood that the management is not involved, and neither is PizzaExpress entrepreneur Luke Johnson, who recently resigned from the board.

Insiders ruled out internet incubator Antfactory, which has a 15% stake. Rival tea specialist Taylors of Harrogate is not a runner and neither is Associated British Foods, which owns Twinings Tea.

Analyst David Stoddart of Teather & Greenwood said: "Broadly speaking, it's a good business. Their problem has been that they overexpanded the UK retail side and, at the same time, they incurred launch costs on the internet."

Traditionally, Whittard's sales were split into three roughly equal portions: tea, coffee and ceramics. However, Whittard's crockery has lost ground to bigger stores such as Woolworth and Bhs.

Whittard last year bought bestofbritish.com, a luxury goods website, from Conrad Black's Hollinger Group. As part of the deal, Hollinger took an 8% stake in Whittard.

What about Neville Chamberlain on the tarmac after his trip to Munich, saying: "Peas in our time?" "That's brilliant," says Chris. You're very kind. There's no charge.

 Bad news for fans of Simon Walker, the genius behind the recent PR triumphs involving the royal family. Simon - who made his name as a TV journalist after provoking the prime minister of New Zealand to walk out of a live interview - won't be returning to his old job at BA after his secondment to the palace ends, according to BA sources. Simon and his Brunswick PR colleague Nick Clayden were brought in by Bob Ayling to run BA's PR. Now Ayling's long gone as chief executive, and Clayden has gone back to Brunswick. And Simon? Well, there's always that promising career in New Zealand television.

 Staff at the Bank of England have often marvelled at the management skills of deputy governor Mervyn King. Tact, gracious good humour and empathy are all concepts that Mervyn is familiar with - in the same way people have heard of Kyrgyzstan, even if they don't know much about it. Last week it was the turn of staff at Washington's prestigious Watergate Hotel to get the King treatment, after Mervyn couldn't get his room key to work. So impressed were staff by Mervyn's manner that they shifted him to the hotel's penthouse suite.

 Also living in the lap of luxury during a trip to Washington for the World Bank spring meeting was Sir John Vereker, permanent secretary to the Department for International Development. As befitting a senior civil servant, Sir John flew first class, and quite right too. We need him fully refreshed after the eight-hour flight to conduct negotiations on developing world debt. Let's be charitable and assume he got an upgrade from business class - otherwise his minister Clare Short would have to justify the £6,000 cost of a first class fare.

 Customers of Virgin Mobile: this is how they spend your money. A press release arrives with the usual blah. Before putting it in the round filing cabinet, the eye is caught by the £5 note stuck to it. At last the PR industry has learned to cut out the nonsense and go straight for cash bribes. The logical step is to cut out the press release and just send the money (clearly marked "bribe", to avoid them being binned).

 It's not smart or clever to snigger at foreign names, no matter how amusing they might be. Such as Turkey's largest white goods maker, Arcelik. No, it's not funny at all. Even if some 40% of Arcelik is owned by Koc Holding.

webTitle: Company man with a ruthless streak

fields.headline: Company man with a ruthless streak
fields.trailText: Phil Condit, Boeing's chief executive, has ordered a complete overhaul of strategy to stop the company being humbled by Airbus, its European rival.
fields.body:
Phil Condit, Boeing's chief executive, has ordered a complete overhaul of strategy to stop the company being humbled by Airbus, its European rival.

The company is the United States' largest exporter, with revenues of $51bn last year, but Mr Condit has recognised the weakness of keeping a tight corporate hold on worldwide operations from Seattle, and has started to set up key management posts overseas, particularly in Europe.

Mr Condit's career has spanned 35 years with the company, where he started as an aerodynamics engineer. His position seemed to be under threat three years ago when Boeing suffered reverses and job losses, but this stabilised after he removed a raft of senior managers.

Mr Condit said that one reason for leaving Seattle - which will continue to be the home of the commercial aircraft operation - was that he spent 600 hours a year in the air flying to different appointments. Instead, he will leave more decision-making to people on the spot.

One senior colleague said Mr Condit was "re-inventing Boeing, which will be a remarkable achievement if he can pull it off".

Mr Condit said: "The progress we have made in our business performance gives us great confidence in our future success."

He admitted "there remains a lot of runway for further improvement. That is why we are pressing ahead with new products and services that extend the boundaries of our businesses."

He conceded that Boeing was "in a period of immense change and a very demanding business environment" and that concentration on some core businesses had "limited the potential growth of our revenues".

webTitle: ECB dashes hope of rate cut

fields.headline: ECB dashes hope of rate cut
fields.trailText: A defiant European Central Bank yesterday ended hopes that a weekend of arm twisting by US and Japanese policymakers had softened its determination to keep interest rates on hold.
fields.body:
A defiant European Central Bank yesterday ended hopes that a weekend of arm twisting by US and Japanese policymakers had softened its determination to keep interest rates on hold.

Jean-Claude Trichet, governor of the Bank of France and a member of the ECB's governing council, insisted that the bank had to remain on guard against the dangers of inflation. "There is a slowing down of external demand triggered by the slowing down of the US economy but continued vigilance is appropriate due in particular to the evolution of wages and salaries," he said.

Inflation in the eurozone is currently running at 2.6% - well above the ECB's 2% ceiling - and the bank is worried that this will trigger high pay demands.

Its uncompromising stance was reinforced yesterday by a sharp rise in the money supply in the eurozone - data which the bank sees as a good guide to the future path of inflation.

M3, the broad measure of money supply, accelerated to 5% in March from 4.7% the previous month. Analysts blamed investors fleeing tumbling equity markets for the haven of bank accounts for the jump.

The money supply numbers had been taken into account when the ECB met last week but Bundesbank president Ernst Welteke noted: "This underlines that we in the ECB were on the right track when we decided not to reduce interest rates too early. The current eurozone inflation data and the M3 numbers confirm the ECB's 'on-hold' policy [on interest rates]."

Responding to calls from the IMF for lower euroland rates Welteke commented: "This is one voice that we hear but it is good that we are independent and we have decided on our own assessments."

In London the FTSE 100 share index was up 15.5 at 5996.9, while the Frankfurt and Paris stock markets were each up by more than 1%.
