webTitle: Notebook: FSA bemuses with indecipherable code

fields.headline: FSA bemuses with indecipherable code
fields.standfirst: Document scares only the honest
fields.trailText: It is difficult to read the financial services authority's code on market conduct, published yesterday, without immediately becoming suspicious. For a start, the preamble, which details how the City watchdog has listened to (and in part ignored) the responses to its never-ending exercises in consultation and which alone runs to 37 pages, repeatedly refers to this "final" version of the code - the quotation marks belonging to the FSA.
fields.body:
It is difficult to read the financial services authority's code on market conduct, published yesterday, without immediately becoming suspicious. For a start, the preamble, which details how the City watchdog has listened to (and in part ignored) the responses to its never-ending exercises in consultation and which alone runs to 37 pages, repeatedly refers to this "final" version of the code - the quotation marks belonging to the FSA.

So we must assume that this code, which is due to be implemented from the end of November at the latest, is not the final version at all.

Yet this terrifying document, which extends to 92 pages, is required reading for anyone whose work is even remotely in contact with the City of London. The hundreds of thousands of individual investors who deal directly in London's markets are promised a stripped-down, simplified version later this year. But everyone can get a taste of what is coming at www.fsa.gov.uk/pubs/index-chrono-2001.html

It is bemusing stuff. Take this example, casually chosen from a section chewing over use of the word "likely" in the code: "The FSA has reviewed these cases carefully and has concluded that the appropriate definition in this statutory context is as stated in the Code: namely that there must be a 'real and not fanciful likelihood'. This is more than a 'bare possibility' but less than 'more likely than not.'"

This monstrosity is with us because the current regulatory regime governing financial markets, which largely dates from 1986, has not worked. The wording of legislation has alternately proved to be too tight or too slack, with the result that only the most gormless have had their collars felt for insider dealing and precious few of these have been convicted. Meanwhile, blatant cases of market rigging and price manipulation have become a daily occurrence in London - and just about every outrageous example has remained beyond the regulators' reach.

Yet whether the latest policy statement from the FSA, carrying the sexy sub-title Feedback on CP59 and CP76, does much to level the field for the cops and robbers of finance remains as debatable as ever. The immediate response among most City practitioners yesterday was to go into spasm. They foresee wrangle after wrangle, dealing rooms carpeted with legal advisers and a whopping great thing called "cost" which, in the end, will be passed on to the end customer of the financial markets - the public.

What we can be sure of is that there is more than a bare possibility that, as soon as the FSA tries to implement any of the heavier powers soon to be at its disposal, the whole matter will end up in the courts. In fact, it is more likely than not.

Six of the best

Bank of Scotland and Halifax have not declared it publicly but in the next few days, provided executive egos can be suitably massaged, they will bill their £27bn merger as a creation of a "fifth force" on the high street.

This is precisely how BoS and Abbey National had described their potential alliance - before Lloyds TSB spoilt the party with its attack on Abbey.

Little wonder, then, that Lloyds is taking heart. A combined Halifax/Edinburgh bank would be a new powerhouse on the high street to rival the big four - Lloyds TSB, HSBC, Barclays and NatWest/Royal Bank of Scotland. The competition would come not just in the sensitive area of current accounts but also in business banking, where a separate competition investigation is under way.

If Lloyds has its way, this changing dynamic will be enough to persuade the competition commission that its £18bn bid for Abbey should be given the green light. The City has started to begin thinking this way, too, and it is not difficult to see why.

But this is just too simplistic. Two players uniting to take on the undoubted dominance of the big four does not automatically mean that the competitive mismatch in high street banking has magically disappeared.

Abbey still has a crucial role to play in competing against the big four, most importantly in the area of current accounts, which affects almost every consumer's life. One day, Abbey might even manage to break in to business banking where the big four - and BoS - have provided all the muscle. And, with a bit of luck, Abbey's chief executive Ian Harley will eventually realise the error of his decision to ditch his own talks with BoS, and find another suitable partner.

Yes, we should have a decent sixth force in banking.

Creating a fifth and then instantly tipping the cart over with a newly empowered sector leader rather misses the point.

As for Lloyds, it should get on and do what it has been threatening to do for years: expand into Europe.

webTitle: Market forces: Rethink on US lifts Regus

fields.headline: Rethink on US lifts Regus
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Market forces
fields.body:
Timing is everything in the market. Last Monday there was not a buyer in sight for Regus, the serviced office provider, as Merrill Lynch went about placing the 5% stake of two early-stage venture capital backers and investors fretted about the company's exposure to the slowing US economy. The shares eventually closed 13% lower at 272.5p.

As in politics, a week is a long time in the stockmarket and by the close of play last night the shares were standing at 292.5p, up 17p, with dealers wondering if the venture capitalists had made the right move.

After Friday's strong US GDP data, analysts believe Regus's aggressive expansion on the other side of the Atlantic - it plans to open 19,000 of its 32,000 new "workstations" in the US this year - no longer looks like a bad idea.

"Investors had questioned this expansion programme but with the US business centres moving to a profit faster than any other country [five months versus an average of nine months], this seems to be the right strategy," Deutsche Bank analyst Paul Ginocchio said.

Mr Ginocchio, who thinks the venture capitalists made a mistake selling, expects Regus to post strong first-quarter figures on May 15.

Meanwhile, it was a quiet start to the week for traders as the FTSE 100 index crept to a seven-week closing high in the wake of more encouraging economic data from the United States.

With resurgent tech and telecoms stocks leading the way on hopes that the US economy has avoided recession, the blue-chip index settled 15.5 points higher at 5,966.9.

Traders said the advance had been limited by weakness in the banking sector, where Bank of Scotland fell 19p to 803p, and Royal Bank of Scotland lost 35p to £16.19. Turnover waspoor, with about 1.6bn shares changing hands.

Elsewhere, the performances were much stronger. Without the banking sector to hold it back, the FTSE Techmark 100 index rose 78.42 points to 2,100.42. IT services group Logica spearheaded the advance, rising 89p to £10, with Sage gaining 20.5p to 295.75p, and Dimension Data moving forward 20p to 331p.

Back among the blue chips, Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, was marked 37p higher at 409.5p after Dresdner Kleinwort Wassertein advised clients to switch out of French rival Alcatel.

There was also a good showing from Cable & Wireless, which rose 15p to 513.5p on talk that the company will soon disclose plans to hand-back some of its £6bn cash pile to shareholders.

In the mid-cap world, Matalan, the out of town discount retailer, was again the worst performer as brokers advised clients to avoid the stock after the unexpected exit on Friday of chief executive Angus Monro.

Goldman Sachs said a cloud would remain over the stock until a convincing explanation for Mr Monro's departure emerged, while Deutsche Bank said that it was difficult to advise clients to invest in a company where the outgoing chief executive had been so instrumental in its growth. The shares, which fell 15% on Friday, slipped a further 50.25p to 416p.

Matalan's problems did not hold back the FTSE 250 index, which closed 67.1 points higher at 6,409.2 on solid contributions from the likes of Autonomy, 59p higher at 591p, and Pace Micro, 48.5p better at 549p.

Elsewhere, aerospace engineer Britax added 5p to 126.5p with market professionals convinced that bid talks, first announced in January, are close to a satisfactory conclusion. Apparently an offer in the region of 140p has been tabled.

Dealers were also keeping a close eye on Intec Telecom, 9p higher at 97p, as Lehman Brothers placed 3.6m shares on behalf of an institutional seller, ending an overhang that has dogged the stock in recent weeks. Traders reckon Intec could rally sharply over the next couple of sessions.

IT services group Logica spearheaded the advance, rising 89p to £10, with Sage gaining 20.5p to 295.75p, and Dimension Data moving forward 20p to 331p. Back among the blue chips, Marconi, the telecoms equipment maker, was marked 37p higher at 409.5p after Dresdner Kleinwort Wassertein advised clients to switch out of French rival Alcatel. There was also a good showing from Cable & Wireless, which rose 15p to 513.5p on talk that the company will soon disclose plans to hand-back some of its £6bn cash pile to shareholders. In the mid-cap world, Matalan, the out of town discount retailer, was again the worst performer as brokers advised clients to avoid the stock after the unexpected exit on Friday of chief executive Angus Monro. Goldman Sachs said a cloud would remain over the stock until a convincing explanation for Mr Monro's departure emerged, while Deutsche Bank said that it was difficult to advise clients to invest in a company where the outgoing chief executive had been so instrumental in its growth. The shares, which fell 15% on Friday, slipped a further 50.25p to 416p. Matalan's problems did not hold back the FTSE 250 index, which closed 67.1 points higher at 6,409.2 on solid contributions from the likes of Autonomy, 59p higher at 591p, and Pace Micro, 48.5p better at 549p. Elsewhere, aerospace engineer Britax added 5p to 126.5p with market professionals convinced that bid talks, first announced in January, are close to a satisfactory conclusion. Apparently an offer in the region of 140p has been tabled. Dealers were also keeping a close eye on Intec Telecom, 9p higher at 97p, as Lehman Brothers placed 3.6m shares on behalf of an institutional seller, ending an overhang that has dogged the stock in recent weeks. Traders reckon Intec could rally sharply over the next couple of sessions.

fields.headline: At this price?  Computerland
fields.trailText: Computerland, the network hardware supplier, has said it is unlikely to meet its profit target for the year to May 2001 because of a downturn in IT spending by firms anxious about the economy.
fields.body:
Computerland, the network hardware supplier, has said it is unlikely to meet its profit target for the year to May 2001 because of a downturn in IT spending by firms anxious about the economy.

"A lot of companies are being a little bit more cautious about their capital spending plans," said Graham Gilbert, the chairman and chief executive. As a result, the company's hardware inventory - mainly Compaq stock - has been gathering dust on the shelves, and profit forecasts have been cut from £800,000 to £300,000.

Shares in Computerland fell 12.5p to close at 57.5p on the back of the company's announcement to the stock exchange yesterday.

Against a background of shrinking demand for hardware, Computerland has been attempting to refocus its business away from product sales and into contracted services. Since floating in 1997, it has raised the proportion of non-product related revenues from 12% of turnover to 35%.

Mr Gilbert said that, prior to the downturn in IT investment, he had been hopeful that Computerland was recovering from a slowdown in sales following fears over the millennium bug. The company was also hit by difficulties integrating KDL, a support services provider it bought in 1998.

Problems have been exacerbated by the collapse of an exclusive deal with Intel over a network management product. Competition in this area was also cited as a reason for yesterday's profits warning.

Ian Mitchell, an analyst with Computerland's house broker Beeson Gregory, said the company was having some success in securing contracted service work, but turnover was still heavily reliant on hardware sales. He pointed out that the Nottingham-based company was well placed to sell additional services to businesses that bought hardware supplied by Computerland.

In the present climate of uncertainty, Computerland looks an investment for the long term only.

fields.headline: My fair ladies
fields.standfirst: The understudy made good is part of a grand tradition, says  Brian Logan. But the understudy's understudy?
fields.trailText: The understudy made good is part of a grand tradition, says Brian Logan. But the understudy's understudy?
fields.body:
As they pace the West End's backstages, London's understudies have a new-found swagger. And no wonder: sickness is spreading like gossip among the capital's stage stars (forget foot and mouth - it's doublet and hose) and their stand-ins are pouncing on the opportunity. Last week another episode was added to the soap opera that, appropriately enough, surrounds the National Theatre's My Fair Lady, when Martine McCutcheon's understudy was herself replaced by an understudy. To lose one Eliza might be considered an accident, but to lose two - well ...

It fell to Jonathan Pryce, McCutcheon's co-star, to nail the absurdity of the situation. "This will be your first Eliza," he told last Wednesday's sell-out crowd, "but it is my second of the day - and my third this week. Any member of the audience interested in playing Eliza can find applications at the door." Wednesday's lucky opportunist was 21-year-old Kerry Ellis, who had previously played Cinderella in Southend. Her predecessor, 18-year-old Alexandra Jay, recovered in time to re-inherit the role for the weekend.

Ellis, Jay and the rest (elsewhere in the capital Earl Carpenter is covering for Ian McShane in The Witches of Eastwick) have the fad for star casting to thank for their sudden fame. Telly actors lack stamina: Anna Friel has had to miss several performances of the Almeida's Lulu due to illness (she has no stand-in; the shows have been cancelled). It will be the only boon offered by that baleful phenomenon, but celebrity-driven theatre may at least haul a few deserving apprentices up the ladder. For the role of the understudy isn't a glamorous one, and those who play it night after night merit a break.

Few spare a thought for those occupying a position - one rung below spear-carrier - that seems to symbolise the flipside of showbiz success. The musical 42nd Street, and its fantasy of being plucked from behind-the-scenes boredom, seems a long way away when your onstage alter-ego is in rude health, someone's used the last teabag and the crossword clue for four across is incomprehensible.

Life is hardly sweeter for the understudies who make it to the stage. When the manager of the Theatre Royal Haymarket had to announce that a stand-in was to replace Dustin Hoffman as Shylock, 700 punters left before Hoffman's hapless shadow had so much as laced his boots. When Daniel Day Lewis withdrew from a 1989 Hamlet at the National Theatre blaming the "demons" inherent in the role, his replacement, the young Jeremy Northam, had to grapple not only with the play's challenges but with an audience prepared to give him just five minutes.

Of course, Northam went on to greater things - who can for get The Net with Sandra Bullock? - and theatre lore hums with tales of stand-ins who've come good. In Noël Coward's The Vortex, the young John Gielgud famously understudied the writer, who seldom clocked in until moments before his character's first entrance. Nightly, Gielgud would gaze into the street, greasepaint in hand, willing a puncture on the tyres of his mentor's transport. He later struggled to shed mannerisms he'd picked up from Coward. It's the understudy's occupational hazard, and chief dilemma - should they parrot the principal or come up with an interpretation of their own?

Gielgud passed on the baton, rescuing Alec Guinness from an understudy's role in a play called Queer Cargo (in which Guinness also made walk-on appearances as a Chinese coolie and a French pirate). The modern era reveals few such eminent interventions, though in 1998 the writer Sarah Kane took over the lead role of her own play Cleansed when actress Susan Sylvester was injured. This only heightened the play's threatening intimacy. A year later she was dead, and the value of that one-off stage turn retrospectively rocketed.

Less tragic, if hardly less poignant, is the story of Nancy Seabrooke, who spent 15 years waiting in the wings of the West End whodunnit The Mousetrap. Seabrooke retired, aged 79, in 1994, describing the job as if it had merely been a colourful alternative to sheltered housing. "I've got a cosy dressing room, I like to sew and I love to read Shakespeare - there hasn't been time to get bored." Let that be a warning to Jay and Ellis. It pays the bills, it brings you within an ace of stardom - but stay off the needlepoint, or understudying may engulf you for ever.

webTitle: Lyn Gardner on artist Franko B.

fields.headline: Bloody peculiar
fields.standfirst: Franko B: artist or masochist?  Lyn Gardner  investigates
fields.trailText: Franko B: artist or masochist? Lyn Gardner investigates.
fields.body:
It is a cliche to say that artists suffer for their art, but it's certainly true of Franko B. His performances are written in blood - his own. Over the past decade you could have caught him cutting his flesh, suspended from a meat hook as his blood pooled beneath him, or walking up and down a catwalk, blood dripping on the white canvas strip like some bizarre action painting. He later had a friend turn the canvas into a suit for him.

In his latest performance, Oh Lover Boy, a series of work that encompasses a book and video as well as a show, Franko B puts his body and blood on show as never before. He makes an exhibition of himself.

It begins with the audience being ushered into a room, one end of which is hidden by hospital screens. There is a slight smell of antiseptic. At a signal, the screens are removed to reveal Franko B naked on a tilted platform that is reminiscent of the mortuary slab and an artist's canvas.

His big, flabby stomach moves and the blood pours from two open veins in his arms. It runs down either side of his body, which is caked in white paint. The surprisingly thick globules look like ants scurrying down bloody highways. The blood begins to make a map of red streaks like main roads. No wonder they call transport systems arteries. At the bottom of the canvas is a gutter for the blood.

After about 10 minutes he sits up and stares at the audience. The blood begins to drip down his arms and over the rest of his body. He stands up and walks off, disappearing through a door that slams shut. All that is left behind is the image of his body and streaks of blood. It is hard not to think of the Turin shroud. "I imagine watching the crucifixion was a bit like that," comments one spectator.

Tempting though it is to look for religious iconography, Oh Lover Boy is a wholly secular experience. The entire 12 minutes is accompanied by the whirl and click of cameras. The show may create the atmosphere of a hospital morgue, but it is about life, not death. You never feel the slightest urge to call an ambulance, no matter how fast the blood flows. Unlike the chainsaw performances of certain circus groups, or the work of 1970s performance artist Chris Burden - who thought nothing ofgetting himself shot in the name of art - the piece is not about risk, or seeing how far you can go. It is precisely controlled; it is about control, in particular - Franko B's control over his own body and his right to do with it what he pleases. It recalls the blood-letting techniques of early medicine, the idea that only by a free flow of blood can there be release, some kind of catharsis.

When a teenage girl repeatedly cuts herself we think it's time to call the psychiatrists; when Franko B does it, we call it art. He turns his body and blood into a canvas and invites us to view it, not as a freak-show but as an object, a living painting, in all its vulnerable, ugly beauty.

 Oh Lover Boy will be at the Custard Factory, Gibb Street, Digbeth, Birmingham (0121-440 3838), on June 9.

webTitle: MPs give Wahid his final warning

fields.headline: MPs give Wahid his final warning
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: As expected, the Indonesian parliament voted overwhelmingly yesterday to issue a second and final censure of President Abdurrahman Wahid for his failure to solve the country's political, economic and social crises.
fields.body:
As expected, the Indonesian parliament voted overwhelmingly yesterday to issue a second and final censure of President Abdurrahman Wahid for his failure to solve the country's political, economic and social crises.

After 11 hours of open and closed-door debate MPs voted by 363 to 52 with 42 abstentions to send him a memorandum ordering him to improve his performance.

He has a month to respond. If MPs are dissatisfied with his reply they can start impeachment proceedings.

With seven of the 10 parliamentary factions, together occupying more than 80% of the seats, apparently determined to depose him, most MPs said the only uncertainty was how long it would take to organise the session of the People's Consultative Assembly to begin the impeachment proceedings. Their estimates varied from one or two months.

Expecting huge protests by fanatical Wahid loyalists, the authorities turned the parliament building into a fortress, surrounding it with barbed wire and barricades, and stationed thousands of police officers and troops throughout the capital, Jakarta.

Several thousand of Mr Wahid's supporters marched from the central square to parliament but a tropical storm and the heavy police presence dampened their enthusiasm and they dispersed without incident.

Mr Wahid's fate was effectively sealed early in the debate when the three biggest parties all declared that they would support the second censure.

The Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle, led by Vice-President Megawati Sukarnoputri, attacked Mr Wahid's mismanagement and failure to tackle the rampant corruption.

Other parties adopted a similar tone, each focusing on a different issue. The former government party Golkar concentrated on the economy and the biggest Islamic party, United Development, criticised Mr Wahid's propensity to travel abroad - he has visited more than 50 countries since taking office 18 months ago - during regional unrest at home.

The influential military and police faction abstained.

Mr Wahid spent the day listening to classical music and receiving ministerial briefings.

His spokesman said the opposition was "blaming Wahid for everything from A-Z", but had no right to, since the first censure focused on his alleged involvement in two financial scandals.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Riots continue in Algeria | Third term for Chiluba | Silver treasure found off Korea
fields.body:
Riots continue in Algeria

Rioting continued in the the north-eastern Algerian region of Kabylie yesterday as Berbers and police fought running street battles.

So far at least 40 people have died in the protests since a student was shot to death in custody last week. Some reports put the figure high as 61.The government says 32 have been killed and more than 600 riot police injured

The anger spread to the capital, Algiers, where a police cordon confined protesting students to their campus.
Reuters, Tizi Ouzou

Third term for Chiluba

The Zambian government party, the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, voted overwhelmingly yesterday to amend the constitution so that President Frederick Chiluba can stand for a third term.

Four-fifths of the 1,082 delegates at a special party conference voted in favour. Foreign donors have urged Mr Chiluba, a former union leader and lay preacher, to stand down in October.
Reuters, Kabwe

Silver treasure found off Korea

A salvage company has found a Chinese ship sunk in 1894 with 600 tons of silver, worth about £5m today, and 963 Chinese soldiers on board.

The vessel, sunk during the Sino-Japanese war, lies in the Yellow Sea off the west coast of Korea.
AP, Seoul

webTitle: Patty Hearst to be witness in terror trial

fields.headline: Patty Hearst to be witness in terror trial
fields.trailText: A middle-aged mother of three, a paragon of middle-class respectability to her friends, appeared in court yesterday accused of conspiring to kill police officers 26 years ago.
fields.body:
A middle-aged mother of three, a paragon of middle-class respectability to her friends, appeared in court yesterday accused of conspiring to kill police officers 26 years ago.

Sarah Jane Olson, who could be jailed for life, is a church-going doctor's wife who appears in amateur drama productions, is involved in community affairs, and is rated a superb cook.

But in 1975 she was an angry radical known as Kathleen Soliah, linked to the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA) revolutionaries who aimed to overthrow the state.

The group's most prominent member was the newspaper heiress Patty Hearst, originally a hostage, who changed sides after she was kidnapped in 1973.

Mrs Olson is accused of putting pipe bombs under two police cars in 1975. The bombs failed to explode and no one was hurt. Now 54, she was arrested in St Paul, Minnesota, in 1999. She denies the charge.

Ms Hearst is expected to be the star witness, and it is thought that she will testify that Mrs Olson once took part in a bank robbery in which a bystander was killed. Mrs Olson has not been charged with robbery.

"For 22 years I knew her as one of the most wonderful Minnesotans anyone could wish to know," said Andy Dawkins, a friend. "None of us had any idea she was in the SLA and we are all shocked even now. We hope she gets a fair trial."

Mrs Olson was caught on camera in 1974 at a service for six SLA members killed in a shootout with the police.

webTitle: Mutilated children of a crippled Palestine

fields.headline: Mutilated children of a crippled Palestine
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's award-winning Middle East correspondent, Suzanne Goldenberg reports on what the fragmenting bullet has done to the children of the uprising

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Guardian's award-winning Middle East correspondent, Suzanne Goldenberg reports on what the fragmenting bullet has done to the children of the uprising
fields.body:
The beds of the four teenagers take up an entire wall at Wafa hospital in Gaza. Tharif Ghora, 16, was shot in the shoulder when he peeked over a barricade at the Karni border crossing on November 19. Hussein Na'ezi, also 16 and with Tharif a regular at the confrontations with Israeli soldiers at Karni, took a bullet in the neck the day before.

Ahmed Abu Taha, a stick-thin boy with almond eyes, the baby of the ward at 14, was running from a tank in Rafah refugee camp on February 18 when a bullet penetrated his back. Mahmoud Sarhan, 16, was shot in the neck.

None of them will walk again. Hussein and Mahmoud will not even be able to lower themselves into wheelchairs because their injuries are higher up the spinal cord.

They - and 1,000 others - are the maimed of the intifada, with permanent injuries which range from a limp or the loss of an eye to paralysis and mental disability: a harvest of mutilation which far outstrips the death toll in the Palestinian uprising.

All four of the boys threw stones at Israeli soldiers and tanks - Tharif used to detour past Karni on his way home from school - and all four were unarmed.

They, like many of the other injured and dead, are the victims of what the UN security council and international and Israeli human rights groups condemn as excessive use of force by Israel against the uprising, now in its seventh month.

A great deal of the criticism has focused on Israel's use of high-velocity bullets fired from M-16 assault rifles. When these penetrate flesh they cartwheel through the body with explosive force.

None of the four boys is aware that he will spend the rest of his life as prisoner of his body. In his hospital bed, a beaming Tharif is being fattened up with shwarma, the meat sandwiches his father sells at a roadside stall in Gaza City.

There is an involuntary twitch in his swollen left foot. "You see?" says his father, Abid Ghora. "One day, God willing, he will make a full recovery. Maybe if we can send him to Germany, they can do something for him."

The number of Palestinians left with some form of permanent disability by this uprising is not entirely clear. According to the Palestinian Red Crescent Society, the injured up to two days ago numbered 13,296, 20% of the hit by bullets.

The Institute of Community and Public Health at Bir Zeit University, the premier Palestinian academic establishment, sifted through mounds of hospital records to arrive at an estimate of at least 1,000 people who will be permanently afflicted after being hit by Israeli live fire, shrapnel, or rubber-tipped steel bullets.

More than 400 of the injured have been treated for lasting disability at three rehabilitation 12centres in the West Bank and Gaza Strip - the only places of their kind for a combined population of 3m people - and at an eye hospital in occupied Arab East Jerusalem. Five hundred of the seriously injured have been treated abroad, including Tharif and Hussein, who were sent to Jordan.

In the West Bank town of Beit Jala, Elias Saba, a therapist at the Bethlehem Arab Society for Rehabilitation, is trying to coax a response from Amjed Saadi, 18.

"Marhaba," Dr Saba, says to him: hello in Arabic. Sitting in his wheelchair with his right hand clenched in a fist, Mr Saadi grunts twice in reply.

The doctor asks him to put a hand on his nose; Mr Saadi shades his eyes.

Mr Saadi was shot in the head with a high velocity bullet fired by an Israeli soldier on October 2, in the first few days of the intifada. He woke from his coma five weeks ago with permanent brain damage.His eyes are alert but spinal fluid is collecting in a bulge on the side of his head, and he will need more surgery.

Human rights groups have condemned Israel for relying heavily on live ammunition, rather than non-lethal force, and for shooting when its soldiers' lives are not in danger.

The Nobel prize-winning US group Physicians for Human Rights blames the widespread use of the M-16 automatic rifle for the high rate of crippling Palestinian injuries. The American-designed weapon is standard issue for Israeli troops.

Daniel Reisner, a colonel in the advocate general's office of the Israeli army, admits that some soldiers have broken the undisclosed rules on opening fire.

"Did all cases in which Israeli army soldiers shoot Palestinians involve live fire incidents? I don't think so," he said. "Could it be that some soldiers reacted with more fire than I would have used in hindsight? Maybe. Some of the reports seem to indicate that."

The chief of staff, General Shauf Mofaz, told comman ders last month to investigate every fatal shooting of a Palestinian by Israeli soldiers in circumstances where there was no12 previous exchange of fire. The army is making criminal investigations in six such cases.

Col Reisner argues that many of the soldiers - like a third of the 370 Palestinians killed to date - are practically children themselves. "These are kids out of high school. We train them, but we can not make them adults in a day.

"In a lot of the incidents with the Palestinians there has been talk about children doing the fighting, and that they were sending 16-year-olds to throw stones or firebombs. We were sending 18-year-olds, only ours are lawful.

"The general staff can give orders, but at the end of the day the person that has to carry out those orders is a 20-year-old kid, and that is in a good situation, with a 22-year-old commanding office, and a 25-year-old company commander."

The results - particularly when M-16s are used - are devastating. Other high-speed ammunition passes cleanly through the body, but a lightweight 5.56mm bullet from an M-16 tends to tumble and spin after it penetrates the flesh at a speed of more than 800 metres a second. Then it breaks up into tiny metal fragments.

"They move like an insect, buzzing around your body, said Dr Jumaa Saqqa, spokesman for the Shifa hospital in Gaza City, where the territory's worst injuries are treated.

"On the outside of the body you just see a small inlet - one centimetre big - but if there is no exit we find hundreds of small metallic pieces inside."

Most of the new disabled were hurt during the first three months of the uprising. Hailed as heroes in the early days, and handed cheques for up to $1,000 (£700) afterwards, they now in danger of being abandoned on the outer margins of a society on the verge of economic collapse, and itself crippled by a corrupt and undemocratic leadership.

"Most of these injured are relatively young," said Mohammed Abu Tair, an orthopaedics specialist at Mukassad hospital in Jerusalem, "the potential labour force - the power of society itself."

webTitle: Truce blocked by terms for talks

fields.headline: Truce blocked by terms for talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The prospects of an early truce evaporated yesterday as the Palestinians angrily rejected the latest Israeli overture and four more Palestinian men were killed in the West Bank and Gaza.
fields.body:
The prospects of an early truce evaporated yesterday as the Palestinians angrily rejected the latest Israeli overture and four more Palestinian men were killed in the West Bank and Gaza.

A spokesman for the Palestinian Authority, Famir Rantissi, said: "Unfortunately, the Israelis are not serious about a ceasefire."

Israel's foreign minister, Shimon Peres, who arrived in the US yesterday, is to meet President George Bush tomorrow to discuss the truce proposal, which is part of a peace plan put forward by Jordan and Egypt.

Under the plan, Israel would also lift its economic blockade of Palestinian areas. But the plan also proposes a return to negotiations based on the offers on the table at Taba in February: defined borders, Jewish settlements and the future of Jerusalem.

Israel is adamant that those terms, put forward under the former prime minister, Ehud Barak, no longer apply.

The Israeli foreign ministry said that Mr Peres expected a Palestinian response to the new proposals on his return to Israel on Thursday.

But Mr Rantissi said: "The ball is still in their court." The Palestinians accepted a ceasefire in principle, he said, but Tel Aviv was not prepared to accept the whole peace plan.

"They can't take out the bits that do not suit them," he said.

Meanwhile, a bomb exploded in a parked car owned by a Jewish settler in the Gaza Strip yesterday. The Israeli army said that a Palestinian was killed and another hurt.

Near Qalqilya, on the West Bank, a man wanted by the Israelis, was shot and killed. The Israeli army said that Adnan Odeh had tried to avoid arrest.

In Gaza City, an explosion in a building killed two Palestinians and injured five others. A neighbour said the building belonged to a Hamas activist; Israel radio said it was a bomb factory.

The former Israeli defence minister, Yitzhak Mordechai, was put on probation and given an 18-month suspended sentence yesterday after being convicted of sexually assaulting two women.

webTitle: Award for Guardian's reporter in Jerusalem

fields.headline: Award for Guardian's reporter in Jerusalem
fields.standfirst: 'Courageous and objective journalism'
fields.trailText: Suzanne Goldenberg, the Guardian's Jerusalem correspondent, was yesterday awarded the London Press Club's prestigious Edgar Wallace award for outstanding writing.
fields.body:
Suzanne Goldenberg, the Guardian's Jerusalem correspondent, was yesterday awarded the London Press Club's prestigious Edgar Wallace award for outstanding writing.

The judges commended her coverage of the Middle East, an area they said was uniquely difficult to report, as "exemplary examples of courageous and objective journalism".

Peter Preston, the former editor of the Guardian, was also commended, as was Guardian Unlimited in the new media category.

webTitle: Dingoes kill boy, 9, and maul brother on tourist isle

fields.headline: Dingoes kill boy, 9, and maul brother on tourist isle
fields.trailText: Two dingoes killed a nine-year-old boy and savaged his younger brother yesterday on a world heritage-listed island off the north-east coast of Australia. Police said the wild dogs stalked the nine-year-old and attacked him when he tripped and fell near a campsite on Fraser Island, the largest sand island in the world.
fields.body:
Two dingoes killed a nine-year-old boy and savaged his younger brother yesterday on a world heritage-listed island off the north-east coast of Australia. Police said the wild dogs stalked the nine-year-old and attacked him when he tripped and fell near a campsite on Fraser Island, the largest sand island in the world.

The younger brother was mauled when he and his father ran to the scene. The seven-year-old was airlifted to hospital, where he was treated for bites on his arms and legs.

The Queensland government ordered the destruction of the two dogs, which were later shot by police marksmen aided by aboriginal trackers. Nearly 200 of the wild dogs, believed to have been introduced into Australia by Asian fishermen thousands of years ago, roam free as a protected species on the island.

It was the first fatal dingo attack since the disappearance of nine-week-old Azaria Chamberlain at Uluru, central Australia, in 1980. The case inspired a film starring Meryl Streep as Azaria's mother, Lindy, who spent three years in prison before her claim that a dingo had snatched her baby was accepted and she was finally exonerated in 1987.

Local people and farmers on Fraser Island renewed calls for a cull of the animals yesterday. There have been more than 400 relatively minor dingo attacks recorded along the island's 76-mile-long stretch of sand. Two British tourists were bitten in 1998.

Conservationists said that many of the island's 300,000 annual visitors had fed the dingoes, emboldening the naturally timid species. "People have encouraged dingoes to the point where they have lost their fear of humans," John Sinclair, of the Fraser Island Defenders' Association, said. "Not so long ago dingoes would lurk in bushes, but now they boldly strike through the camp areas."

Felicity Wishart, co-ordinator of the Queensland Conservation Council, said that the tragedy should not trigger a cull, and holidaymakers needed to be more respectful of Australia's wildlife. "We mustn't have animals being fed, and people shouldn't be trying to take photographs with these wild animals - they need space to live free from us encroaching on them."

The island is also where a British tourist, David Eason, vanished five weeks ago, but his relatives said yesterday that they did not believe he had suffered the same fate.

His brother-in-law, Michael Eames, of Hayes, near Bromley, Kent, said: "We do not believe David was attacked by dingoes, as all the research we have done suggest dingoes will only attack young children individually, or older children in a pack.

"They will threaten adults in certain circumstances, but it is very unlikely and would have been noticed by now. There would have been some evidence of an attack."

Mr Eason, 46, disappeared on March 28, after becoming separated from a group being driven around the nature reserve in a four-wheel drive vehicle.

fields.headline: No 1,870
fields.standfirst: Customised stamps
fields.trailText: Customised stamps.
fields.body:
Stamps? Stamps? Oh, come, come, you can do better than this. Withdraw your scepticism. Stamps are a terribly interesting subject.

Go on, then. Impress me. Well, did you know that the first stamp appeared exactly 161 years ago today in England? And did you also know, perchance, that the term "philately", referring today to the act of "stamp collecting", comes from the Greek "philos" (to love) and "telein" (to tax)?

I can honestly say I did not. And did you know that the first catalogues of stamps were issued in 1861 in Paris and Strasbourg, and then in England the following year?

Uh-huh. After all, philately is a worthy pursuit. Why, one of its most noble pursuers was none other than our own King George V.

That's it. Kill me now. No, stop. Things are about to get even more interesting, I assure you.

Surely not. Yes! As of today, we lucky subjects of the Queen are no longer limited to licking the back of her head. Instead, we can (hold on to your hats) lick ourselves.

I beg your pardon! Those lovely people at Royal Mail have come up with the rather jolly wheeze of letting us personalise our stamps with photos of our own choosing. Personalised stamps are all the rage in Canada and Australia, and will be arriving in France in a few months.

What has provoked such comedic carryings on from Royal Mail? It hopes to entice us away from our email and back to the postbox - though a pack of 20 personalised first-class stamps will cost £11.95, nearly 60p a letter. Gillian Wilmot, a Royal Mail executive, says: "We need to keep [letter writing] alive or we lose an important part of social history."

I see. So it's actually a sociological issue, and not just the postal equivalent of novelty ties or comedy cufflinks? There's no pleasing some people.

Do say: " How wonderful. An 1840 Twopenny Blue!"

Don't say: "Just send me an email."

fields.headline: I am Charles, Son of the Big Boss
fields.standfirst:
The palace says it is pursuing a 'Marmite jar strategy' - modernising the monarchy so gradually that no one notices it happening. So what was different about Charles' latest tour? Not much, says Stephen Bates

Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: The palace says it is pursuing a 'Marmite jar strategy' - modernising the monarchy so gradually that no one notices it happening. So what was different about Charles' latest tour? Not much, says Stephen Bates.
fields.body:
A teenage girl, in teeth braces, grey T-shirt and denim shorts, stands among a crowd in the tiny township of Assiniboia, out on the wide prairie of Saskatchewan. As she waits for the arrival of the man who might one day be her king, she rolls her gum around her mouth. "It's kind of nice that he's coming," she says. "Really neat. But ... I don't think it will make any difference to me whether he's king or not. Some old people would be really sad but most people here just wouldn't notice."

A few minutes later, the appearance of a rather gaunt, middle-aged Englishman with a diffident wave and a double-breasted suit, tips the teenage girl into a mild screaming fit. But otherwise there is distinctly modified rapture from the local inhabitants, whose leathery faces bear witness to a hard life in the harsh climate of the central Canadian plains. It is, someone remarks, not so much empire loyalism as small town curiosity that has driven them out to gaze at Prince Charles.

This Englishman who may one day inherit the crown of Canada (not that such a thing exists) and become its head of state returns to Britain this morning after a whistlestop five-day sweep through his mother's largest dominion. He's been out there meeting the people like a particularly low-key politician. He has shaken hands with elders representing indigenous tribes, greeted farmers and flown to meet the folks in the far northern Yukon territory, where winter temperatures sink to -60C.

Each has been met, in the fleeting seconds he spends with them, with a wry grin, a muttered aside, a shy twisting of the signet ring on his left hand and sometimes a worried stroke of his forehead. He is a man conscious of the need to fly the flag, to cover the ground and to shore up the commonwealth - and, perhaps, to restore the credibility of the monarchy in a country in which, if there is no great move to get rid of it, there is little sense of real support either.

Canada remains one of half a dozen commonwealth countries to have the queen as head of state. Although there is not much sign of any move to get rid of her here, people murmur privately that the question may reopen when she dies. For the present though, the Monarchist League, with its complaints about the lack of royal portraits in public buildings, remains a small force to be reckoned with. And a rosy fairy-tale view of the monarchy seems to remain. For a Brit it is almost like stepping back a decade to before the Diana debacle and all the rest - 10 years of disaster that have reawakened and strengthened the republican debate in Britain, and even caused the monarchy to start questioning itself, seem barely to have registered here. Not even Sophiegate has caused comment in Canada: people appear not to know who Sophie is.

So once again Charles has been out there, shaking hands and meeting the people and trying on costumes, just as he always has. This is what the more managerial royal courtiers are now calling the Marmite-pot monarchy. It is corpo rate-speak culled from business practice and it is designed quietly to reposition the institution for the 21st century. As one senior palace strategist says: "The idea is like the Marmite jar: everyone thinks it's never changed its design over the decades but that's because the changes have been so subtle, no one's noticed them. The Marmite jar isn't a bit like it was - it's changed its shape and its top and its label but everyone thinks it's still the same product. That is what we're trying to do with the monarchy." But if the Marmite jar is changing it is changing very slowly indeed.

The prince's appearance before the actually rather small crowds in Canada, made up largely of the elderly and the very young, had overtones of a medieval progress, with all the laying on of hands and touching of the hems of garments. But there were strict limits to this intimacy. Journalists accompanying the trip were instructed that photographers and cameramen must not approach closer than 20ft. This left us with the curious experience of having less contact with the prince than the most casual passer-by engaged in conversation. We might as well have been watching a play, which I suppose we were.

Charles barely spoke publicly during the trip and when he did he confined himself to shoring up the fairy-tale image with references to his beloved grandmother and wry allusions to himself. The number of issues on which he is allowed to speak publicly, or have views on, is small. He tried a reference to holistic health care in a speech to the Saskatchewan parliament, which is considering medical reforms, and he met organic farmers in Assiniboia.

"It is vital to take stock of the long term consequences of industrialised farming systems ... we neglect the delicate balance of the rural community and the need for harmony with the workings of nature at our peril," he said in virtually the only comments that might be considered outspoken on the whole trip. Not surprisingly the organic farmers agreed with him, though whether his views have any wider resonance on the open prairie, where grain fields stretch to the far horizon, is questionable.

And there were also titles to add to those he has already. At the weekend, the prince who, on an earlier visit was named Son of the Big Boss by the Inuit and who has also been called Picanniny Belong Mrs Queen by the natives of Papua New Guinea, was awarded the highest honour the Cree tribe can bestow. The elders retreated into a sweat lodge - local equivalent of a sauna - overnight and the prince's new name was revealed unto elder Gordon Oakes. Charles is now officially Kisikawpisim Kanayowahpahmikoot, which apparently means The Sun Watches Over Him in a Good Way, a translation that delighted the Sun's royal correspondent.

In some ways I am still impressed with that."

At the tyre recycling plant, the prince's eyes lit up when he saw a white hard hat that was being provided for him. "At last - a hat!" he exclaimed, perching it like a small white pimple on top of his head.

But there is also a limit to these signs of down-to-earth humanity. Watching closely as the factory tour ended, one could see the prince casually remove his protective gloves and drop them negligently by his side for an aide to catch before they fell to ground.

And there are straws in the wind that the prince could not fail to have noticed. "Say Hi! to William For Me," read one placard held aloft in Ottawa. "Meet Your Future Daughter-in-law," read another. In Saskatoon, Saskatchewan's state premier Lorne Calvert effortlessly mortified his 15-year-old daughter Stephanie by telling Charles: "Come back soon, or send the kids." The prince muttered that he would do his best to package his offspring and send them over by parcel post. For it is William the crowds really wanted to see, not their ageing father.

Charles will have flown home last night with a warm glow of duty done, but while Canada is nowhere near following Australia down the path towards republicanism there is no real sense of identification with this foreign prince either.

But perhaps there is one thing way beyond its powers of control that helps the monarchy here. Senator Frank Mahovlich, a former ice hockey star turned politician, puts it most succinctly: "The monarchy is something we're an important part of. I like it for our country and I like it partly because it is something the Americans haven't got." Whereas in Australia the debate helps shape a sense of national identity, here it still, just, helps define what makes Canada distinctive - and that is not being part of the United States.

Charles on tour: the highs and the lows

He's very photogenic, Charles, on his holidays; snapped naked in a hotel window, patting his wife's derriere on a trip to New Zealand, and then, some 10 years later, in South Korea in 1992, the royal couple, looking anywhere but at each other. Then there was the trip to Oz in 1994, which saw David Kang, aged 23, firing blanks at the prince with a starting gun during a ceremony in Sydney.

There was more photo magic in South Africa, when he tackled the bongo drums. Xhosa tribal dancer, Nick Madlebe said: "The prince was a very good drummer and had a natural sense of rhythm."

Mr Madlebe was right. On a trip to Buenos Aires in 1999, we witnessed the lovely Adriana Vasile tangoing with the prince, resplendent in fishnets, red lipstick and a dress split thigh-high (Ms Vasile, you understand, not the prince).

Not that Charles is a stranger to donning a nation's traditional costume. Last year he insisted upon wearing a Rastafarian hat backwards. He has something of a soft spot for headgear: over the years he has sported eagle-feathered titfers, trilbies, woolly hats and even, in Krygyzstan, a kakelpak - whatever that may be.

And it doesn't end there, for the Prince of Wales has made continued efforts to blend with the natives, sipping jungle root brew as if it were Darjeeling, in deepest, darkest Guyana. On the last day of his 1993 Mexican tour, he even tried his hand at troughing - working a wooden-bladed plough pulled by two bullocks. After ploughing two furrows he called it a day, declaring: "I am upset that I do not have time to do some more ploughing." Aren't we all, Charles.

fields.standfirst: The census man wants to find out if you have a basement and what colour you are but, frankly, there are more interesting things we'd like to know.  Oliver Burkeman conducts his own survey    Household form
fields.trailText: The census man wants to find out if you have a basement and what colour you are but, frankly, there are more interesting things we'd like to know. Oliver Burkeman conducts his own survey.
fields.body:

Yes

0-5

Yes

No

Yes

No

Neither of the above

12 Are you a cat person or a dog person?

Cat person

Dog person

Neither of the above

The offside rule in football

"Going out for a duck" in cricket

"Shooting an albatross" in golf

Why anyone watches snooker

14 Which football team do you support?

Please write in, using combinations of letters to form words.

15 Do you own, and actually know how to use, any of the following pieces of home entertainment equipment?

Video

MP3 player

DVD

Other

Do not include chairs, lampshades, food processors or other things which are not home entertainment equipment.

16 When you press the button over and over again at pedestrian crossings, do you really think it's going to make the green man appear sooner?

Yes - it's like writing "urgent" on first-class letters makes them get there quicker

No

18 Do you sleep naked?

Yes

No

19 Why do you do that really annoying thing with your eyebrows?

fields.headline: Brandreth's babes
fields.standfirst:
Gyles Brandreth has revealed that he and his fellow Tory backbenchers used to while away boring hours in the Commons by rating the 'fanciability' of Labour women MPs. Julia Langdon isn't surprised

Special report: House of Commons
fields.trailText: Gyles Brandreth has revealed that he and his fellow Tory backbenchers used to while away boring hours in the Commons by rating the 'fanciability' of Labour women MPs. Julia Langdon isn't surprised.
fields.body:
It must have come as little surprise to any woman Labour MP to have had confirmed in print that it is not always actually what any of them says in the House of Commons that has much impact on their Conservative parliamentary colleagues. It is far simpler than that - indeed so simple that sometimes, apparently, it is not even necessary for a woman MP to go to the trouble of opening her mouth to speak, let alone preparing a few well-chosens.

Because what really matters, of course, is nothing to do with the vulgarities of politics. No, no! It's what she looks like.

It isn't her pertinence but the pert tilt to her nose that excites the interest of most red-blooded Tory MPs. It isn't her arguments but what an alluring image she presents, "tousle-haired and bleary-eyed", when a division is called at 4am during an all-night sitting of the finance bill. And whatever else any woman politician may have going for her, it certainly isn't the size - nudge, nudge - of her majority.

We have all this interesting detail on how the Conservative party whiled away the long years of government on the weary authority of a former Conservative government whip, Gyles Brandreth. This is a man now driven to turn a penny from journalism by the exigencies of unemployment quite unaccountably visited upon him by an ungrateful electorate, and perhaps we should be appreciative of that fact: his recollections, unlike some of the heavier memoirs of former ministers, at least have the merit of truth.

Apparently short of anything more perspicacious to discuss, Brandreth revealed in the pages of the Sunday Telegraph that "laddish Tory backbenchers" were accustomed to passing the boring bits of the 18 years between 1979 and 1997 - waiting for promotion or the next election, whichever was the sooner - scanning the opposition benches row by row and assessing the Labour women MPs "solely in terms of their fanciability". They even kept a book measuring the odds of the fancied fillies - with Jane Kennedy, Diane Abbott and Dawn Primarolo as favourites - although Brandreth does not share with us on what measure of performance payouts, if any, were distributed.

The reader may imagine that poor Brandreth was just being paid to be amusing and was short of material, and anyway, this was the Sunday Telegraph after all, and therefore no readers were likely to object to such nonsense - boys will be boys, even when they're grown up!

But this wasn't amusing. It was puerile. As Brandreth himself wrote, having described how he "slept with" Harriet Harman on the finance bill and how she "looked quite delicious" when aroused from sleep in the early hours of the morning (see above), "this confession is shaming". And so it was. One of the particularly shaming aspects is that we have a parliamentary system and a democracy which pretends that we extend equal treatment to both sexes and yet still expects men and women, fathers and mothers, to work all day and all night and continue to function as effective politicians and parents the next day.

As Brandreth himself goes on to observe, his comments will not startle anyone. He even wrote: "Men are only men when all's said and done." Now I quite like Brandreth, whom I know slightly, and I have admired his recent published interviews. And he is right that this antediluvian nonsense will surprise nobody. That is not an excuse. Not just women MPs of any party, but any woman who has worked for any period of time in any capacity at Westminster, knows that there are still plenty of men there who view the world much as Brandreth does. But it is they who are absurd.

When Elinor Goodman, the political editor of Channel 4 News, and I were both lobby correspondents for daily newspapers, we used to dine out on stories of the sexist nonsense we encountered. There were the two Tory MPs we heard observing: "This place gets more like the Reeperbahn every night" when they passed us standing together, waiting to talk to members, in the Ways and Means corridor. There was another member who sidled up and murmured: "Are you in the Liberal whips' office?" his eyes alight with the exciting implications of the words "liberal" and "whips".

I do not lack a sense of humour, but Brandreth did not bring a smile to my face. More to the point, on this occasion in his new journalistic career he was not filling space in some "lifestyle" column at the back of the trivia section of the newpaper. He was writing in a column normally occupied by the absent editor. I am myself, as it happens, a former political editor of that newspaper and I hope that had I still been a member of the staff last Saturday night I might have prevented such a piece of silliness from being published.

webTitle: Portrait of Russell Watson, the people's tenor

fields.headline: Salford's Pavarotti
fields.standfirst: Russell Watson used to sing Les Mis numbers in pubs and clubs. Now he performs for the Pope, works with Mel C and records movie theme songs.  Stephen Moss meets the people's tenor
fields.trailText: Russell Watson used to sing Les Mis numbers in pubs and clubs. Now he performs for the Pope, works with Mel C and records movie theme songs.  Stephen Moss meets the people's tenor.
fields.body:
Now I don't want to be cynical about Russell Watson, aka "the people's tenor" and "the new Pavarotti". He's a nice bloke, can belt out a good tune - I particularly like his rendition of Bridge Over Troubled Water - and no doubt deserves the phenomenal success he is having. I would hate to be seen as one of those snooty critics who can't bear the thought that an untrained Salford lad should come out of nowhere, get a record deal and take the world by storm. But I have to raise the small matter of Watson's age.

His publicity material and the booklet that accompanies his mega-selling album, The Voice, claim that he is 27, and a fawning profile on the South Bank Show recently said the same. But Watson, as he freely admits, is actually 34, though with his pale complexion and spiky, gelled hair he looks about 22. It is a small point, but a worrying one: what is his record company trying to tell us - or, rather, not tell us?

We meet at the BBC's Manchester offices. He is there to plug this month's BBC Music Live weekend in Leeds, but mentions en passant his Hyde Park appearance with Pavarotti in July, an engagement to sing for the Pope, the theme song he has recorded for the film of Captain Corelli's Mandolin, his imminent US tour, his new album (to be released in September), a Christmas concert in Manchester, and something or other with Spice Girl Mel C. I look impressed, if a little confused, as I try to imagine other possible links between the Pope, Pavarotti and Mel C.

Watson is also appearing on that evening's BBC news in the north-west. The presenter talks to him as if he were an old friend: his two-year march to superstardom has been minutely chronicled hereabouts. On the way to the studio, we bump into Roger Wright, the controller of Radio 3, in the lift, and he introduces himself to Watson. I reflect on this symbolic (and entirely accidental) meeting of posh and pop, and wonder if it will result in Watson and Mel C duetting together on future editions of In Tune. Possibly introduced by the Pope.

Watson prides himself on his skill as an interviewee. He has just been on a tour of Japan, where, he says, he had to do dozens of interviews with journalists who insist on their hour even if they have nothing to ask. This puts me on my mettle, and I busily ask inconsequential questions about his pre-stardom life that he must have answered a thousand times before. He looks unfazed and goes through his repertoire of funny northern accents and time-honoured working-men's-club stories.

He learned piano and guitar as a child, but says he preferred football, and his only exposure to classical music came from the records of Chopin waltzes that his parents liked to play. He became a steelworker, but at 21 entered a local talent competition, won and started singing in pubs and clubs, soon afterwards abandoning his lathe for the bright lights of Batley and Goole. High spots included appearing in Cinderella at the Bradford Alhambra and a summer season with Lily Savage in Blackpool. It all sounds grimly Les Dawson-ish, and it lasted for 10 years (or perhaps three if you trust the record company).

"There were times when I thought about chucking it in, but I kept batting away," he says. "There were clubs where the audience wasn't interested in me in any way, shape or form, and I'd be stood on stage singing my heart out thinking, 'What the bloody hell am I doing up here?' It's like anything: you have your good days and your bad days, and the good days were good and the bad days were terrible."

He sang a mixture of Neil Diamond, Elvis Presley and "West End classical" (Phantom, Les Mis), depending on the sophistication of the venue. "I learned how to assess an audience when I walked in," he says. "One of the things that makes me different is that I've gone through this club route, and I wouldn't change that for anything. It made me a different person. It taught me how to communicate with audiences and bring an audience round."

Enter fate, in the form of the club secretary of the Wigan Road Working Men's Club, who suggested Watson sing Nesty Doormat by Pavarotti. He did, won a standing ovation and realised that his future lay in operatic blockbusters rather than Neil Diamond torch songs. That club secretary ought now by rights to be head of A&R at Decca International, which has sold 800,000 copies of The Voice in the UK alone. It has been top of the classical charts since it was released last September and made substantial inroads into the pop album charts too. As Melvyn Bragg perceptively noted, Watson is "a phenomenon".

When Watson changed his repertoire, he also decided to get some vocal coaching, and is currently under the tutelage of William Hayward. "When I first went to Bill, he said that if I continued to sing the way I was - forte and full on all the time - I would burn myself out, so I had to go on to develop the lighter side of the voice and inject some light and shade into my music."

Watson didn't get his big break until 1999, when he was singing at a charity evening in Manchester. Martin Edwards, the chairman of Manchester United, was in the audience and invited him to sing Nessun Dorma at Old Trafford, which he did before the last game of the season. Watson, a lifelong Man U fan, almost certainly did not sleep the night before. "I walked on to the pitch and nobody was taking much notice," he recalls, "but when I started singing, the buzz from the crowd began to die down and I could feel people were beginning to think, 'Who is this guy?' By the end, when I hit the top note, the whole place erupted. I felt like David Beckham on the edge of the 18-yard box after curling one in to the top left-hand corner."

Watson sang at England rugby union matches, at the European Cup final in Barcelona, and before England's World Cup match with Germany at Wembley. (He was one of the few participants to escape censure for that ignominious defeat.) An enterprising producer introduced him to Decca, and there followed another of those moments that belong to Broadway fantasy rather than Salford reality.

"There were eight or nine executives from Decca," Watson recalls, "and they asked me if I'd brought a CD or video for them to hear. I said, 'No, but I have brought my voice.' I burst into O Sole Mio, holding the top note and, like the cheeky bugger I am, looking at my watch at the same time. I held it longer than I had ever held it before. Their jaws dropped gradually to the floor and that was it: I walked out of the office and within an hour there was a fax back in Manchester with an offer of a five-album deal."

Success has brought fame, fortune and a broken marriage. Watson was all over the tabloids in March when he split with his wife, Helen. It is clearly a horrible situation, and for a moment Watson's jovial persona is punctured. All that matters, he says, is the well-being of their two children.

The past year looks, to this observer at least, to have been a kind of madness. He says he hasn't changed as a person, and quotes a rehearsal in Manchester where he was tucking into a meat pie while everyone else picked at sushi. Maybe, but being separated from your daughter of five months must be desperate, and at some stage he will have to learn to say no. Even if it means disappointing Japanese journalists, record executives eager to squeeze a little more from their "27-year-old" superstar, and the Pope. At least the Pope will understand.

fields.headline: Out of the woods
fields.standfirst: Pays de Gascogne
fields.trailText: Pays de Gascogne.
fields.body:
We crossed the wide slopes near Sauternes in cold weather. It was hard to believe that little villages which looked so plain and grey could produce the ultimate in luxury sweet white wines. This April has been one of the bleakest that people here remember, and a bitter north wind was driving fine rain across the great lake at Biscarrosse when we arrived.

At the coast, Atlantic winds have, over the ages, formed the sand into mountainous dunes, and twisted pines into fantastic shapes. Inland, endless rows of tall, straight pines cover the flat landscape. An ancient law required local authorities to plant trees to stabilise the light, sandy soil. In grass clearings beside the long, straight roads, you see little settlements that are survivors of the traditional, forest life of "Les Landes": timber-framed homesteads, roof-tiles bleached yellow, with a grazing cow or two, some sheep, maybe a horse, scattered wooden barns, and outhouses full of neatly stacked logs. Besides sheep-farming, men made charcoal and worked from primitive forest cabins, tapping trees so that resin ran down over a zinc lip into earthenware pots.

We watched the lake one evening, around dusk. All of a sudden, great numbers of swallows swooped in from nowhere, almost skimming the water's surface. Then a small bow-wave came towards the jetty. A furry and whiskered creature about 18 inches long, and with a humped back, clambered up the bank. After a short walk, it swam off. We were told it was a "ragondin", and, like the swallows, a spring visitor reappearing on cue, despite the unseasonal temperature.

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

B1 Which statue was damaged 2000's May Day riots?

(a) Roland Gift

(b) Winston Churchill

(c) Lenin

(d) A lion

B2 "Mayday! Mayday!" is shouted by

(a) Injured Frenchmen

(b) Someone in distress

(c) Euphoric pagans

(d) Someone who has lost their dog

B3 The Maypole is

(a) A May Day tradition

(b) An instrument of torture

(c) A new diet plan

(d) My local pub

B4 In 1644, Philip Stubbe attacked May for

(a) Coming after April

(b) Its sexual debauchery

(c) Cash for questions

(d) Lack of nutritional value

B5 In poetry, the mayfly often symbolises

(a) The ephemerality of life

(b) Loss of innocence

(c) Prostitutes

(d) The darkness of the soul.

 Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday May 9. The winner will be notified by May 16. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at Guardian Unlimited Quiz Room.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: What Do They Know About Us? | Case Notes | A Tonic To The Nation
fields.body:
George Orwell saw it coming 50 years ago, of course. We drive into town, use a credit card, make a mobile phone call, draw money from a cash dispenser, and are uneasily conscious that someone, somewhere, has recorded every action. Paul Vickers, reasonably wondering What Do They Know About Us? (8.0pm, Radio 4), set out to follow his own data trail. Big Brother may be just a paranoid delusion, but there are still a lot of Little Brothers squirrelling away useful information about what we do with our lives.

Perhaps it's time for a calming tonic. In Case Notes (9.0pm, Radio 4) Dr Graham Easton suspects a glass of water may work at least as well as a slug of anything stronger. He has been studying the strange impact of placebos, the inert "medicines" given to selected patients in clinical drug trials. Their effects can be startling. Doctors report unexpectedly beneficial responses from people suffering anything from arthritis to cerebral palsy.

Tony Robinson looks back on the 1951 Festival of Britain in A Tonic To The Nation (9.0pm, Radio 2). As one interviewee remarks, it's impossible now to convey the unremitting drabness of those postwar years in Britain. The country was gasping for some harmless jollity and the South Bank festival at last brought colour and energy into their lives. It was symbolised for me by the suspended wand of light called the Skylon, wonderfully pointless and thoroughly cheering.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: King of Comedy | Caro Diario | The Commitments
fields.body:
Films

King Of Comedy
(Martin Scorsese, 1982)
8pm, FilmFour

Among all the weirdos Robert De Niro has created for Scorsese - Johnny Boy, Travis Bickle, Jake La Motta and all - the repellent Rupert Pupkin is the wackiest, an excruciating study of sad fantasy and sinister reality. Abetted by the equally disturbed Masha (Sandra Bernhard), the man who would be king of stand-up comedy hatches a mad plot to kidnap Johnny Carson-style showman Jerry Lewis to win TV primetime. Scorsese's black comedy is far more funny-peculiar than funny ha-ha; a sick joke.

Pushing Tin
(Mike Newell, 1999)
8pm, Sky Premier

Fasten your seat belts, you're in for a bumpy ride in this tale of duelling air traffic controllers. John Cusack's slick control room king is peeved at the arrival of Billy Bob Thornton's zen-spouting, hick, and the relationship grows even more turbulent when he seduces Thornton's wife (Angelina Jolie). meanwhile, the pair should be concentrating on guiding planes through the air-traffic jam over New York. It's an undeniably enjoyable trip, even if Newell never quite makes up his mind whether he's doing comedy or melodrama.

Halloween H20
(Steve Miner, 1998)
10pm, Sky MovieMax

Twenty years on from John Carpenter's original Halloween, Jamie Lee Curtis's Laurie, survivor of the encounter with teeny slasher Michael Myers, is now a twitchy, alcoholic single mum with a teenager (Josh Hartnett) of her own. It's only a matter of time before Myers returns to his dirty work, and Miner has fun giving us several false starts before Laurie realises he's not a figment of her imagination but a real, live, nightmare. The middle sags a little, but Curtis is very watchable as the body count rises.

Caro Diario
(Nanni Moretti, 1994)
3.55am, FilmFour

Moretti wrote the script and also stars in a three-part tale that takes an idiosyncratic tour through suburban Rome, finds no peace even on a stunningly beautiful island, and finally, jarringly, recounts his battle against cancer in a ramshackle health system. A deeply moving and disquieting diary.

The Commitments
(Alan Parker, 1991)
8pm, Sky Cinema

Worth watching for the tremendous R&B soundtrack: Mustang Sally, Mr Pitiful, In The Midnight Hour and all, worked over by the extraordinary 16-year-old singer, Andrew Strong. There's an exhilarating tale in there too, adapted from Roddy Doyle's novel: an account of young Dubliners getting a band together. Raucously funny.

Sports

Live football
7pm, ONsport1

It doesn't matter who you are or who you support, the semi-finals of the European Cup are simply not to be missed. Particularly when you've got the chance to see the continent's sexiest team (that's Real Madrid) teach those, mean, nasty, po-faced Germans of Bayern Munich - conquerers in the last round of Manchester United - a thing or two about the beautiful game. They should get some sort of victory from tonight's home leg in Spain.

fields.headline: Get your skates on
fields.trailText: Britain's Big Freeze | This Morning | Jungle Trip
fields.body:
And nobody knows (tiddley pom)

How cold my toes (tiddley pom)

How cold my toes (tiddley pom)

Are growing.

Bears aren't known for their pragmatism - some are so mad, they will hang about with Amanda Burton - so it seems unlikely that the house at Pooh Corner has double glazing. Also, given that honey pots often presented logistical problems for poor Winnie, the idea that he could actually work the timer on the central heating seems somewhat fanciful. This being the case, those toes are liable to turn black and drop to the ground like old raisins off a scone, if Britain's Big Freeze (Channel 5) is to be believed.

At school, I was warned that global warming - or more specifically, the flagrant non- recycling of aluminium cans, the wasting of science jotters and superfluous photocopying - was all set to turn Britain into Italy, complete with olive groves, sunny beaches and cerulean skies. Living in dreich West Lothian, this probably wasn't the best message to give a class of unruly 13-year-olds, especially when the rumour went round that Donna McMorran had rickets.

Thus, jotters were squandered - and often photocopied afterwards - recycling bins remained empty vessels and energy generally wasted at every opportunity, all in the uncertain hope that one day we'd all wake up bathed in Siena shades of light.

Only now, the boffins on Britain's Big Freeze are saying that Britain won't be warmed up by global warming at all but will instead turn into Siberia. Despite my school chums' best efforts, our home town could become an icy wasteland complete with marauding polar bears and carnivorous penguins. Now I come to think about it, this may not be a bad thing.

This theory would be quite distressing if it weren't for the fact that Britain's Big Freeze is probably one of the most ridiculous, melodramatic documentaries lately to grace our screens. The "if" in "if Britain's Big Freeze is to be believed" is so big, it blots out the sun. From the tone of the narrator's voice ("We will be in the grip of a big freeze!"), you'd think we were all about to be quick-frozen in our beds - just before the aliens arrive, pound the earth with asteroids and start harvesting our organs. Even though there is some science behind the "Cool Britannia" thesis, it all comes over as rather loopy. Those toes are safe. For now.

When Richard is in vintage form on This Morning (ITV), you have to grimace, particularly if you're Judy, who, just because Richard was talking about running the London marathon sighed, "He's soooo boring." And that wasn't even the highlight of the show.

That came with the pair's interview with Andrew Solomon, a man who has travelled the world investigating different cultures' dealings with depression, and written a book about his experiences. Having watched his mother die, Andrew had reason enough to suffer from depression and search out "cures", but Richard, like a kid with a scab, couldn't resist having a pick.

"You were also sexually confused", he nodded in a not-that-it-bothers-me way. "You thought you were bisexual but now you say you're gay." fields.headline: South-east councils urge spending rethink
fields.trailText: Ministers are facing a cross-party backlash over government spending levels in the south east as county councils serve notice that they will no longer tolerate a diversion of Whitehall funds to England's depressed northern regions. With Tony Blair sensitive to Conservative charges that New Labour is abandoning middle England in favour of the party's heartlands, south east council leaders accused the prime minister of presiding over a "dramatic shift" in funding from rural and south east counties towards urban areas and northern cities.
fields.body:
Ministers are facing a cross-party backlash over government spending levels in the south east as county councils serve notice that they will no longer tolerate a diversion of Whitehall funds to England's depressed northern regions. With Tony Blair sensitive to Conservative charges that New Labour is abandoning middle England in favour of the party's heartlands, south east council leaders accused the prime minister of presiding over a "dramatic shift" in funding from rural and south east counties towards urban areas and northern cities.

Sandy Bruce-Lockhart, leader of Kent council, warned that the government's commitment to elected regional assemblies in the north would lead to unwanted inter-regional competition, expose government favouritism and "diminish one nation Britain." Growing tensions emerged at a summit of eight county council leaders at Leeds castle in Kent.

Chris Williams, chief officer of Buckinghamshire council, said Tory, Lib Dem and Labour councillors agreed a problem was looming in the south east with authorities unable to meet government standards in education and social services because of underfunding.

Mr Bruce-Lockhart said it was intolerable that the south east, with over three times the population of the north east, received less in allocation of some government funds.
