webTitle: Peers launch new Chinook crash inquiry

fields.headline: Peers launch new Chinook crash inquiry
fields.trailText: The House of Lords, in an unprecedented move, yesterday voted to set up an all-party inquiry into the crash of a Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre in 1994 - the RAF's worst peacetime accident.
fields.body:
The House of Lords, in an unprecedented move, yesterday voted to set up an all-party inquiry into the crash of a Chinook helicopter on the Mull of Kintyre in 1994 - the RAF's worst peacetime accident.

The vote, which has widespread constitutional implications, follows a long campaign led by Lord Chalfont, the former Labour foreign minister, to right what many MPs of all parties, as well as peers, regard as a serious miscarriage of justice - the decision by two RAF air marshals to blame the pilots for the crash.

David Davis, Conservative chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, which last year accused the Ministry of Defence of "unwarrantable arrogance", last night described the issue as one of "law, morality and logic". Twenty-nine people, including 25 senior MI5, RUC, and army anti-terrorist officers based in Northern Ireland, died in the crash on June 2 1994. The Lords voted by 132 to 106, a majority of 26, to set up an inquiry by a special select committee, a move supported by former law lords, Lord Mayhew, the former Tory attorney general, and Lady Thatcher.

Lord Chalfont said an RAF board of inquiry had originally placed no blame on flight lieutenants Jonathan Tapper and Rick Cook but a second inquiry by two air marshals - Sir William Wratten and Sir John Day - found them guilty.

Though they were "perfectly entitled" to reach that conclusion, said Lord Chalfont, a wealth of evidence had been uncovered subsequently to suggest many doubts.

Independent reports by military aviation experts, a fatal accident inquiry in Scotland and other investigations had all concluded that there was no conclusive proof of what caused the accident, he said. RAF regulations at the time demanded no airman should be found guilty of negligence unless there was "no possible doubt whatsoever about the causes". The MoD has refused to consider reviewing the verdict, despite the emergence of evidence of serious technical malfunctions in the newly upgraded Chinook fleet. Some of the evidence, including a US accident involving a MoD Chinook , was known at the time. Some emerged later after repeated allegations by MPs that they had been misled by successive defence ministers.

Supporters of the Lords move want the special select committee to conduct a swift inquiry concentrating on evidence already available which, they say, would contradict the official verdict.

Last month the Guardian and Computer Weekly revealed that two leaked internal documents showed that the RAF was aware that technical problems experienced in the Chinooks could have endangered the safety of an aircraft.

Lord Mayhew, a former attorney general, denied that a Lords inquiry would be tantamount to the legislature interfering with judicial discretion. "This is not the judiciary we are looking at but extremely senior and experienced officers of one of the armed forces, for whom ministers answer in parliament," he said.

The defence minister, Lady Symons, said: "Nothing has been or is being hidden because there really is nothing to hide."

fields.headline: Paul Daneman
fields.standfirst: Versatile actor at home in theatre, film and television
fields.trailText: Versatile actor at home in theatre, film and television.
fields.body:
Paul Daneman, who has died aged 75, triumphantly defied the critical augury that the actor who thrives on versatility is only showing off; that he lacks depth. Daneman's technique took him from Shakespeare to musical comedy, revue, pantomime, West End drama and television. He relished the difference between stage and television acting, trying to alternate his work so that he never came to fear a return to the stage.

In 1955, he appeared in the English premiere of Samuel Beckett's Waiting For Godot. He changed roles - ending up as Vladimir - just before rehearsals began. But although he looked at home in all kinds of play, he did not reach those heights for which he had seemed destined at the Old Vic in the 1950s and 1960s, when he brought what the young Kenneth Tynan called "a touching bewilderment" to Henry VI in Douglas Seale's legendary revival of Shakespeare's trilogy (1957).

He also acted a witty and unsentimentalised Justice Shallow in Henry IV - "a forked radish of a man with a rambling tongue, a senile reiteration but a shrewd eye still to the main chance and possible court advancement," as one reviewer put it.

JW Lambert wrote: "It is not clear to me how an actor whom I recall as an extremely well set up Aufidius [in Coriolanus] has transformed himself into a twig-limbed old silly." But then Daneman was a supremely good exponent of doddering silliness - or the younger variety, such as the self-torturing, anxious lover, Faukland, in Sheridan's The Rivals, whose complicated character he refused to explore too seriously, settling instead for just the right level of what a critic called "inflated Byronism."

Or what about his suave young aristocrat in BBC-TV's Corrigan Blake (1963), the breezy sidekick to John Turner's cockney layabout? He is remembered also as Commander Ryan, in the BBC's Spytrap (1972), as the suburban patriarch opposite Wendy Craig in Not In Front of the Children (1967), and, a year later, in another television domestic comedy, Never A Cross Word, playing opposite Nyree Dawn Porter (Obituary, April 12).

These performance were a long way from the feverish vitality of the deplorable Duberdat, in the Doctor's Dilemma (Saville, 1956), or his long-nosed Richard III at Birmingham Rep in the 1950s (which he repeated at the Old Vic in 1962), or his princely Malcolm to Paul Rogers's Macbeth.

Born in London, Daneman was educated at Haberdashers' Aske' school in Borehamwood, and Sir William Borlase's school in Marlow, Buckinghamshire. He then read fine art at Reading University. From 1943-47, he served in RAF Bomber Command, where stage performances for fellow service-men whetted his appetite for the theatre. Then came Rada and a Boxing Day 1947 debut, at Bromley's New Theatre, as the front legs of a horse in Alice In Wonderland.

In the early 1960s, he was Christopher Marlowe's Dr Faustus and Richard III with the Old Vic, before joining the Nottingham Playhouse, with which he toured west Africa. He also played King Arthur, in Lerner and Loewe's Camelot, touring Australia before taking over from Laurence Harvey at Drury Lane (1965), after starring in CP Snow's The New Men, at the Strand.

It was not in Daneman's nature to stray for long from the classics, though television was, by then, a force in the land. In order to keep abreast of the theatre, he had a way of turning up in all kind of West End plays, thrillers and farces. When, in 1979, he took over from Donald Sinden in Shut Your Eyes and Think Of England, he had a heart attack while tending one of the characters in the play who was supposed to have suffered the same thing.

So he turned to writing. His television sitcom, Affairs Of The Heart (1985) starred Derek Fowlds as a man who had had a heart attack. His novel, If I Only Had Wings, was published in 1995.

Another role which the versatile Daneman assumed was Rolfe, which Alec McCowen had created, in Hadrian The Seventh (Haymarket, 1969), in which the character's dream of being the first English pope seemed, to him, to have come true. Later stage credits were Don't Start Without Me (Garrick, 1971), Macbeth (Guildford), Henry Higgins in Pygmalion (Malvern), Double Edge (Vaudeville) and Spine Chiller (Duke of York's).

Among other television credits were The Professionals (1977), Alan Bleasdale's GBH (1991), and as Douglas Hird in Thatcher: The Final Days (1991). His films included Joseph Losey's Time Without Pity (1956), Cy Endfield's Zulu (1964), and Dick Lester's How I Won The War (1967).

His 1952 marriage to Susan Courtney, with whom he adopted a daughter, ended in divorce. He is survived by his second wife, Meredith, and their two daughters.

 Paul Daneman, actor, born October 26 1925; died April 28 2001

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: As you read this, the May Day protests in London will already be under way. Whether the day ends in the violence and anarchy widely predicted remains to be seen.
fields.body:
As you read this, the May Day protests in London will already be under way. Whether the day ends in the violence and anarchy widely predicted remains to be seen. Certainly, the Met are ready for it, having already sanctioned the use of rubber bullets for the first time on the mainland. It goes without saying that the police have a right to protect themselves, and a duty to protect private citizens and property, but will upping the ante in advance really diffuse trouble? Meanwhile, their preventive arrests policy, in addition to the publication of pictures of those "expected" to cause trouble, is a massive infringement of civil liberties.

Protest is an inalienable right. It is often dismissed as a truism to say it's a cornerstone of living in a democracy, but that's because we are made lazy by our luck in this country. I personally couldn't care less about the fate of a few plate glass windows - what I do care about is the McDonald's workers inside, terrified for the sake of the very slave wages that those outside are campaigning against. And I also care because any organised violence de-legitimises the deeply felt reasons that have brought the rest of the crowd on to the streets.

"But what do they want ?" is the constant refrain. Anti-capitalists are criticised, variously, for their historical ignorance ("Marx thought of it first," tut the theory snobs), for offering an emotive critique without practical alternatives, for being anti-everything and pro, er, the right to plant cannabis in Parliament Square. (Point of information: the protesters are not anti-globalisation, only anti-the elitist effects of it. It is globalisation, particularly within the field of technology, that has afforded the movement a chance to blossom.)

Third world debt, the environment, sweatshops, the unaccountability of the IMF - yes, these are huge causes, not immediately connectable nor solvable. But there's something in the air, other than rubber bullets. There's an excitement and a willingness to engage that belies those ready taunts about voter apathy and social narcissism. This isn't about fighting for the right to be wacky - it's about a recognition that money isn't enough. Connections are being made. Serious and radical lines of thought are slowly emerging. Don't rush it. Do you have to have all the answers before you can ask the questions? Today is a day to feel joyous. If that thrill gets extinguished in a hail of bricks, then that really will be criminal.

fields.headline: Down's screening for all mothers-to-be
fields.standfirst: More health checks for pregnant women and babies
fields.trailText: All pregnant women will be offered tests for Down's syndrome and every newborn baby will be screened for cystic fibrosis, under plans announced by the government yesterday at the start of a drive to promote policies on maternity in the run-up to the general election.
fields.body:
All pregnant women will be offered tests for Down's syndrome and every newborn baby will be screened for cystic fibrosis, under plans announced by the government yesterday at the start of a drive to promote policies on maternity in the run-up to the general election.

Yvette Cooper, the public health minister, said she was setting up a network of counsellors to provide support and information to help expectant parents make informed choices about ante-natal screening, including tests for HIV, hepatitis, rubella and syphilis.

All pregnant women in England would be offered non-invasive tests for Down's syndrome, reducing unnecessary amniocentesis tests.

At present 80% of women are offered a test, but there are wide variations in the standard of testing and counselling.

Tests for cystic fibrosis, the most common genetic disease in children, will be available for all new babies. Ministers have accepted the results of research in Wisconsin in the US showing that early screening improved diagnosis and treatment for babies born with the disease, which clogs the lungs and other organs with mucus.

The Cystic Fibrosis Trust had complained of a postcode lottery in screening. It was available for about 20% of newborns, but the absence of a universal service led to children being misdiagnosed and subjected to inappropriate surgery.

Ms Cooper said the government was also moving towards universal screening of the hearing of newborn babies, starting with trials in 20 pilot areas. Quick identification of impairments could alert parents to call on support services.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, will tomorrow announce a 10 year programme to upgrade maternity services, with better facilities and more choice for women about their preferred type of delivery. In an address to the Royal College of Midwives, he will promise to invest tens of millions of pounds more on equipment and staffing.

Ms Cooper said: "It is important that every child gets the best start in life and every parent gets proper information about what health checks are available for newborns and in pregnancy. Evidence shows that screening newborn babies for hearing problems and cystic fibrosis can make a big difference to treatment and support and can significantly improve their health and development."

Rosie Barnes, chairwoman of the Cystic Fibrosis Trust, said there were 7,500 sufferers of the genetic disease in Britain and their average life expectancy was 31.

"In 80% of the country where the test has not been offered, babies are suffering all sorts of health miseries. Often they are not diagnosed for months or years."

webTitle: Union reinforces fears over safety in gas industry

fields.headline: Union reinforces fears over safety in gas industry
fields.trailText: The GMB union yesterday condemned Transco, the privatised monopoly which operates and maintains Britain's gas pipes, for "presiding over the running down of gas services" and said it had serious concerns about the safety of the network.
fields.body:
The GMB union yesterday condemned Transco, the privatised monopoly which operates and maintains Britain's gas pipes, for "presiding over the running down of gas services" and said it had serious concerns about the safety of the network.

Following an article in yesterday's Guardian, Brian Strutton, the union's national secretary for energy and utilities, said: "Our members are constantly telling us that the number of [gas] escapes is rising fast and they are genuinely concerned for their own and the public's safety."

He said the Guardian's figures on the crisis in staffing at Transco underestimated the size of the problem. "Transco needs to recruit at least 1,000 new engineers and apprentices this year before the winter to maintain safety."

These figures had been agreed with Transco's director of operations, John Hinchliffe, Mr Strutton said. A further 400 to 500 a year would be needed for the next four years.

The former head of engineering at British Gas, Andrew Duffield, also said he had several anxieties about safety.

"I am concerned that Transco does not have the experienced and qualified staff to meet its obligations. Once you've lost staff it's not something you can remedy quickly. But the restructuring of Transco is the major issue. Continual restructuring has meant a loss of continuity and things inevitably fall through the gaps and the importance of long-term planning gets forgotten," he told the Guardian.

He accused Transco of "exceedingly poor record keeping" and said it would be difficult to recover the situation. "We are talking about a potential risk to people's lives. If the gas distribution network isn't properly maintained, monitored and replaced, there is a real risk to public safety and people's lives."

According to Transco, "the gas pipeline network is safe and it is nonsense to suggest that there are lots of accidents waiting to happen". The firm repudiated allegations that it did not have enough engineers to ensure safety and said that it "continues to exceed its safety targets to attend all reports of gas emergencies within an hour".

It also denied that there had been an increase in the number of leaks left for later repair. "Nationally the number of such escapes has dropped by more than 50% in the last year. These are escapes which pose no danger," a statement said.

It did, however, admit that it was planning to recruit and train up to 1,000 people , including 150 apprentices, to meet its obligations under the European working time regulations. It also said it was in discussions with the health and safety executive about the replacement programme for metal mains and was looking with the HSE and the regulator at increasing the replacement rate.

A spokesman for the company said it had spent £60m in the past three to four years improving records, but added: "We are not complacent."

The energy minister, Peter Hain, said a forum was reviewing safety across the industry, identifying gaps and improving safety standards. "I will be looking closely at changes in Transco's structure to ensure that safety is not compromised," he said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: New driver in train crash
fields.body:
New driver in train crash

An inexperienced driver caused a two-train rush-hour collision while working a shift on his own for the first time, a safety report published yesterday revealed. The Connex South Eastern train passed a red signal at 40mph before colliding with another Connex train at Hither Green, south-east London, on March 12. One passenger suffered whiplash injuries and eight were treated for shock.

No tax on war bank accounts

Holocaust victims and their heirs will not have to pay tax on cash reclaimed from 10,800 UK bank accounts frozen since the second world war, the government announced yesterday. The accounts hold £2.8m. The names of account holders are listed on www.restoreuk.org.uk.

Cod fishing ban expires

A ban on fishing in cod breeding areas of the North sea ended at midnight last night. The 10 week ban over the spawning period was imposed by the European commission in a 40,000 square mile area to revive depleted cod stocks.

Beaver makes a comeback

The European beaver, extinct in England for almost 1,000 years, is to return to a wildlife reserve. The Kent Wildlife Trust is introducing 10 animals to an undisclosed restored wetland area in a five-year trial.

Here comes the sun

Heavy rain, low pressure and a lack of sunshine made April the coldest in over a decade. Average temperatures were 7.7C (45.9F), the worst since 1989. It was the 10th wettest April in the past 100 years with average rainfall for the month 65% above average. But Michael Dukes of the PA WeatherCentre said better weather was on the way. "There should be five to seven days of bright sunshine to come."

webTitle: Mandela triumphs in heart of Yorkshire

fields.headline: Mandela triumphs in heart of Yorkshire
fields.standfirst: South African statesman says gardens bearing his name remind him of childhood, as thousands turn out to greet him in Leeds
fields.trailText: A council's public address system yesterday took a few seconds to do what apartheid South Africa failed to manage in three decades: it silenced Nelson Mandela.
fields.body:
A council's public address system yesterday took a few seconds to do what apartheid South Africa failed to manage in three decades: it silenced Nelson Mandela.

Just as well, too, according to those nearest the huge stage in the middle of Leeds, who swore that the veteran statesman began his speech by hailing the people of Liverpool.

Not that anyone would really have minded, given the good nature spread by a man who introduced himself as "an unemployed pensioner with a criminal record". A better description was "the world's greatest living statesman", replied city council leader Brian Walker, before the dud mike silenced him too.

Things were much better, though, than in 1982, when the opening of Leeds's Mandela Gardens by Bishop Trevor Huddleston was boycotted by the council's Conservative group. Nearby Dewsbury had just recorded only 11 votes in favour of naming a street Nelson Mandela Way - a gesture people thought would make the town a laughing stock.

Opening a £12m improvement of the gardens, Mr Mandela recalled those hard times by thanking local people for every small gesture of support during his 27 years in prison. The ceremony's compere, Jon Snow, recalled some of those gestures.

"When scientists at Leeds University discovered a new fragment of matter in the late 1980s," he told a crowd of about 5,000, "they named it the Mandela Particle." Local students also got in smartly to make Mr Mandela their union's life president less than a year after his jailing in 1964.

Mr Mandela's flying visit to the north was an attempt to include grassroots activists in his British tour, after the prestige and prime ministerial trappings of Trafalgar Square.

He thanked the city for continuing help for South Africa, including a public appeal which sent 250,000 school books there this year.

Mr Mandela's motorcade was diverted at the last minute to go through the Chapeltown area, the heart of Leeds's Afro-Caribbean community, where he passed another local namesake, the Mandela Neighbourhood Centre.

He waved and beamed at 100 children from Leopold primary school, which has the highest percentage of Afro-Caribbean pupils in the country. Another Mandela grin was prompted by Leeds's attention to detail in the new garden's plaque, which gives a rare outing to the statesman's middle name, Rolihlahla.

As the microphone came back to life he told the crowd: "For me to see this garden reminds me of my childhood and the happy days associated with it. It is an exciting moment for me when I see a blade of grass or the leaf of a tree, when a bird chirps or I hear running water in a stream."

webTitle: Olympic rower 'felt stupidity and panic after gold medal was stolen'

fields.headline: Olympic rower 'felt stupidity and panic after gold medal was stolen'
fields.trailText: A taxi driver stole Olympic hero Matthew Pinsent's gold medal and left the sportsman feeling "shock, panic and stupidity", a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A taxi driver stole Olympic hero Matthew Pinsent's gold medal and left the sportsman feeling "shock, panic and stupidity", a court heard yesterday.

The star had left his rowing medal in a briefcase on the roof of his car before going for a coffee with his girlfriend at Heathrow airport last October.

Cab driver Terry Sandford parked next to Pinsent's car and took the briefcase, Edward Lewis, prosecuting, told Isleworth crown court, west London.

The alleged theft happened three days after the rower celebrated Olympic triumph with Steve Redgrave, Tim Foster and James Cracknell.

Pinsent told the court that on the day of the theft he arrived at Heathrow to meet his girlfriend who was flying back to Britain from Toronto.

He realised the briefcase was missing when he returned to his car. Asked how he felt, he said: "I suppose shock, panic and a feeling of stupidity about allowing it to be stolen."

Pinsent told two police officers who began a search. Sandford was questioned by a police officer, but did not answer her. The taxi driver denied seeing anything and drove off, the court heard.

Pinsent was advised by his agent to broadcast appeals on the radio. Sandford heard one of these and contacted Pin sent, who asked whether he had everything inside the briefcase.

The driver replied: "I've got one wallet, and I've got one medal, it's in my cab and you cannot get safer than a London black cab," the court heard.

Mr Lewis said: "Sandford said that he pulled up to some traffic lights where the driver of another car showed the bag to him and asked him to hand it into the police station. That turned out to be a lie."

The bag was then handed over at a hotel near Heathrow airport.

"At this time, Sandford was being treated as a witness and very much as a hero," Mr Lewis said. But when Sandford was being interviewed by police at a hotel near the airport that afternoon, he was spotted by the female police officer who had spoken to him that morning, and she identified him as the cabbie beside Pinsent's car.

Detective Sergeant Roderick Hall, who headed the inquiry into the theft, told the court that when questioned Sandford had dropped his claim that another driver gave him the bag. "He said it was on the roof of the car and that he did not steal it but just threw it into his car."

Sandford, 42, from Bexleyheath, south-east London, denies stealing the medal, and an alternative charge of attempted theft.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Low-flying plane 'panicked ponies to death'
fields.trailText: A horse breeder in Wales is demanding up to £12,000 compensation from the Ministry of Defence after low-flying aircraft allegedly so terrified her ponies they lost their lives.
fields.body:
A horse breeder in Wales is demanding up to £12,000 compensation from the Ministry of Defence after low-flying aircraft allegedly so terrified her ponies they lost their lives.

Kathleen Cuff found one of her ponies badly injured and the other dead the morning after a military transport plane flew over her stud farm in Cardigan, west Wales. One pony, Downland Petra, aged five, appeared to have been so frightened it had smashed through a wooden barrier and then died after impaling itself on a barbed wire fence.

The other pony, Downland Emblem, aged six, had multiple injuries including a fractured skull, and was subsequently put down by a vet. Both ponies were pregnant.

Mrs Cuff said the aircraft had been flying perilously low over her home last Thursday afternoon and she had believed it would crash. "We're used to low-flying jets but this was exceptional. It was a great big black propeller plane," said Mrs Cuff, 91. "It was so loud I came outside because I thought the chimney would fall off."

A neighbour identified the plane as an RAF Hercules.

A stud association 25 miles away from the farm was also disturbed by noise from the aircraft last week. "There was certainly low-flying aircraft," said Lyn Moran, administrator for the Lipizzaner National Stud Book Association. "Horses are animals of flight. Their instinct is to run away from danger, and something like that sweeping through the air would be dangerous to them. When they go into a blind panic horses don't know what they are doing."

Mrs Cuff, whose grandson is Andrew Davies, the show jumper, had already arranged a buyer for the mares' foals and had expected to gain £12,000 from the sales. She now intends to contact the MoD to claim back the loss. "My animals have been exported around the world from Germany, France and Sweden. I would much rather have them alive than the money."

A spokesman for the MoD said yesterday that although the ministry was aware of the allegations it had not been contacted by Mrs Cuff. "If she cares to make a formal complaint it will be fully investigated and determined on its own merits."

Mrs Moran said that low-flying aircraft affected other animals besides horses. She claimed farmers had previously claimed compensation for similar occurrences.

webTitle: Fans branded as soccer louts say match ban breaches human rights

fields.headline: Fans branded as soccer louts say match ban breaches human rights
fields.trailText: Two football fans yesterday challenged orders barring them from matches in a test case which could have implications for the powers of police and the government to tackle hooliganism in the sport.
fields.body:
Two football fans yesterday challenged orders barring them from matches in a test case which could have implications for the powers of police and the government to tackle hooliganism in the sport.

The high court case was a direct challenge to the Football (Disorder) Act 2000, allowing courts to ban suspected hooligans from matches, and could affect 560 people who were barred last year.

Derby County supporters Carl Gough, 37, and Gary Smith, 38, both from Derby, claimed orders barring them from home and international fixtures were unlawful under the Human Rights Act and incompatible with European legislation on freedom of movement. The pair were among 11 people who appeared at Derby magistrates court last October after the police applied for match banning orders under the Football (Spectators) Act 1989, which was amended by the 2000 act.

Gough and Smith were forbidden to go within a defined area around Derby home and away matches and within five miles of stadiums in London and Birmingham during matches, and were ordered to hand over their passports to the police within five days of designated international matches. They faced six months in prison if they refused to hand over their passports.

In the magistrates court, police cited previous convictions against Gough and Smith and intelligence gathered by "spotters", who alleged they had been seen with groups of troublemakers, as evidence they could cause trouble.

But in court yesterday their counsel, Rhodri Thompson, argued the standard of proof required to bar fans from matches under the legislation was inadequate. He said a ban could be imposed only if the court was satisfied there were reasonable grounds to believe it would help to prevent violence or disorder at matches. A criminal standard of proof was not required, however, and it was unclear what "reasonable grounds" should mean.

"This legislation really falls off the possible cliff of legality," Mr Thompson said. "There are no constraints on the form of evidence, and the chief constable in this case seems to think he can just go along to court with anything."

He said the bans went against the Human Rights Act because they affected a person's right to move freely between places and countries. This right to freedom of movement of goods and services and a person's right to leave a country were also enshrined in European legislation.

Gough was not allowed to go within five miles of London when there was a match yet no consideration had been given to the inconvenience this might cause him. The restrictions could also hamper the men's right to a family life if, for example, they were stopped from taking their children shopping in Derby on match days.

The case continues.

webTitle: BBC looks beyond youth to please the over-30s

fields.headline: BBC looks beyond youth to please the over-30s
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Broadcasters are rediscovering the "Viagra generation", after years of pursuing the lucrative youth audience. The BBC has admitted that it has not paid enough attention to its more mature viewers and is to produce a raft of shows - particularly on BBC2 - for this market.
fields.body:
Broadcasters are rediscovering the "Viagra generation", after years of pursuing the lucrative youth audience. The BBC has admitted that it has not paid enough attention to its more mature viewers and is to produce a raft of shows - particularly on BBC2 - for this market.

Nigel Havers, Steve Coogan and Paul Whitehouse will star in three comedy series for which divorce and desire will be the new broadcasting buzzwords.

Jane Root, controller of BBC2, said she wanted to provide more "sophisticated, intelligent, educated entertainment". She recognised that there were shows, such as the music programme Trevor Nelson's Urban Choice, that said "piss off if you're over 30".

But BBC2's "centre of gravity", she said, was around age 35. As more viewers were able to reach other BBC networks, such as the digital youth and entertainment channel BBC Choice, BBC2 could concentrate on a more discerning audience.

"There is not a u-turn but a slight shift towards an audience which has not really been concentrated upon in the past," Ms Root said at the Golden Rose television festival in Montreux.

Earlier at the festival it was revealed that the BBC had signed up the former Big Breakfast star Johnny Vaughan in a £3m deal.

It almost clinched the Channel 4 presenter Graham Norton with an offer worth £4m, the Guardian has learned.

The first of the three new comedies commissioned, Manchild, written by the teen magazine agony uncle Nick Fisher, stars Nigel Havers, Anthony Head, Ray Burdis and the former Rising Damp actor Don Warrington.

They play four middle aged men who appear to have forgotten their age. "It's Sex in the City for the Viagra generation," a BBC source said.

The show is likely to reinvent the television career of Havers, who has tended to play upper-class cads. Sophie Clarke-Jervoise, the producer, said of the characters: "They think they are the coolest guys, but in fact they make complete prats of themselves."

Steve Coogan has written a "prequel" to his acclaimed comedy Marion and Geoff, titled A Small Summer Party. The original series charted the breakdown of Marion's marriage and her relationship with Geoff. In the prequel, Geoff will be seen for the first time, played by Coogan.

There are also plans for a second series of Happiness, the dark comedy from the Fast Show's Paul Whitehouse, in which he plays a voice-over actor experiencing a mid-life crisis.

And in a nod to the theme of appealing to older viewers, the 1960s star Twiggy is to make a guest appearance in the new series of Absolutely Fabulous.

Danielle Lux, controller of entertainment commissioning, said there was room across all BBC channels for "a range of programmes as wide as the tastes of the British public, and as diverse as the ambitions of the artists we work with".

But Ms Root insisted that certain youth-oriented shows were safe on BBC2 for the foreseeable future: "The thought of the Robot Wars viewers of Britain marching on Television Centre is not appealing."

She recognised that there were shows, such as the music programme Trevor Nelson's Urban Choice, that said "piss off if you're over 30". But BBC2's "centre of gravity", she said, was around age 35. As more viewers were able to reach other BBC networks, such as the digital youth and entertainment channel BBC Choice, BBC2 could concentrate on a more discerning audience. "There is not a u-turn but a slight shift towards an audience which has not really been concentrated upon in the past," Ms Root said at the Golden Rose television festival in Montreux. Earlier at the festival it was revealed that the BBC had signed up the former Big Breakfast star Johnny Vaughan in a £3m deal. It almost clinched the Channel 4 presenter Graham Norton with an offer worth £4m, the Guardian has learned. The first of the three new comedies commissioned, Manchild, written by the teen magazine agony uncle Nick Fisher, stars Nigel Havers, Anthony Head, Ray Burdis and the former Rising Damp actor Don Warrington. They play four middle aged men who appear to have forgotten their age. "It's Sex in the City for the Viagra generation," a BBC source said. The show is likely to reinvent the television career of Havers, who has tended to play upper-class cads. Sophie Clarke-Jervoise, the producer, said of the characters: "They think they are the coolest guys, but in fact they make complete prats of themselves." Steve Coogan has written a "prequel" to his acclaimed comedy Marion and Geoff, titled A Small Summer Party. The original series charted the breakdown of Marion's marriage and her relationship with Geoff. In the prequel, Geoff will be seen for the first time, played by Coogan. There are also plans for a second series of Happiness, the dark comedy from the Fast Show's Paul Whitehouse, in which he plays a voice-over actor experiencing a mid-life crisis. And in a nod to the theme of appealing to older viewers, the 1960s star Twiggy is to make a guest appearance in the new series of Absolutely Fabulous. Danielle Lux, controller of entertainment commissioning, said there was room across all BBC channels for "a range of programmes as wide as the tastes of the British public, and as diverse as the ambitions of the artists we work with". But Ms Root insisted that certain youth-oriented shows were safe on BBC2 for the foreseeable future: "The thought of the Robot Wars viewers of Britain marching on Television Centre is not appealing."

fields.headline: The joy of specs
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Politics
Special report: Labour party
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is lucky. Wearing glasses may once have been considered old fashioned and dowdy, but these days it is chic,  writes Jess Cartner-Morley. The Hollywood actor George Clooney and the pop star sisters Nicole and Natalie Appleton of All Saints are just a few of the image-conscious celebrities who are frequently photographed wearing glasses.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is lucky. Wearing glasses may once have been considered old fashioned and dowdy, but these days it is chic, writes Jess Cartner-Morley. The Hollywood actor George Clooney and the pop star sisters Nicole and Natalie Appleton of All Saints are just a few of the image-conscious celebrities who are frequently photographed wearing glasses.

The prime minister's spectacles are similar in style to those favoured by the Appletons. Modest in size, oval and wire-rimmed, they are a classic shape that made a comeback several years ago and has been popular ever since.

Wire rims have slightly bookish connotations and are traditionally favoured by academics and by those wishing to "brain up" their image.

The shape makes Mr Blair's eyes look smaller, which could make him appear shrewish. But the gesture of putting on his glasses to read a speech has a pleasing air of elder statesman gravitas - just the thing for a second term.

Had Mr Blair wanted more unobtrusive glasses, he could have copied the England football manager Sven-Goran Eriksson and chosen to wear the clear, rimless style which is almost invisible on the face.

But being seen to wear glasses could work in Mr Blair's favour. After his four years in the public eye, they change the way he looks, forcing a possibly Blair-jaded public to recognise and register his familiar face all over again.

In this way, glasses are the perfect style move, whereas a new haircut or wardrobe might have backfired by appearing vain and "spun".

webTitle: Army at risk, says MoD leak on cuts

fields.headline: Army at risk, says MoD leak on cuts
fields.trailText: Pressure on the defence budget will have a "highly damaging impact" on the country's military capabilities and could put British soldiers at risk, army commanders warn.
fields.body:
Pressure on the defence budget will have a "highly damaging impact" on the country's military capabilities and could put British soldiers at risk, army commanders warn.

Confidential Ministry of Defence documents say the army faces the prospect of having to make cuts in planned equipment programmes of £1.2bn over the next four years, according to information leaked to the Daily Telegraph.

The cuts are said to arise from extra expenditure elsewhere, particularly money spent on the Royal Navy, with two new aircraft carriers and their planes put at £8bn.

Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, chief of the defence staff, has described the proposed carriers as essential to Britain's future defence policy.

According to the newspaper, one MoD document says: "We propose to reduce the cost of the planned equipment programme by some £1.2bn over the four year period 2001-02 to 2004-05."

The document adds: "Inevitably, the deferrals, reductions in planned numbers and in some cases cancellations needed will have a highly damaging impact on our previously planned improvements to capability."

The document is said to conclude by stating: "In some cases, where the threat from potential enemies is increasing this could result in future operations carrying a higher level of risk than current ones."

A second document is said to refer to the need to get rid of two tank battalions, a quarter of Britain's total tank force, warning that it would, however, leave the forces "structurally flawed" and the army facing "some difficulty" taking part in even "medium-scale war fighting operations".

MoD officials said they could not comment on leaked documents, but insisted that the ministry was not in the business of taking risks with British service personnel.

fields.headline: Stay away, says Ken
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police service should, where it has strong evidence about serious anarchist plans to engage in criminal activities during the May Day Monopoly demonstrations, arrest those individuals concerned (Backlash against May Day zero tolerance, April 30).
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police service should, where it has strong evidence about serious anarchist plans to engage in criminal activities during the May Day Monopoly demonstrations, arrest those individuals concerned. Ken Livingstone has asked for the law to be vigorously enforced to clearly demonstrate that the police enjoy the full support of the mayor and the Greater London assembly, and the majority of peaceful and law-abiding Londoners.

Many Londoners share political views on many of the key issues raised by the march - ending third world debt, opposing experiments on animals for non-medical purposes and privatisation of the tube - but equally do not support an anarchist tendency whose criminal intentions are widely known and apparently accepted as legitimate by both a small number of trade unionists (Letters, April 30) and the Guardian (Backlash against May Day zero tolerance, April 30).

Last year the desecration of war monuments constituted a deliberate insult to those who had lost their lives during the second world war. It is precisely the freedoms that latter-day genuine protesters enjoy that were so stoutly defended by our war heroes in the face of the fascist threat.

The anti-apartheid movement (which on Sunday received recognition from Nelson Mandela for its contribution to freeing South Africa), groups such as Jubilee 2000 and anti-racist movements have all proven society can be changed by means other than violence.

The mayor has and will continue to support such campaigns, reflecting a range of public concerns with which he agrees. What he will not support is violent and extreme anarchists who use the cover afforded by the attendance of thousands of legitimate peaceful demonstrators who share a genuine desire for global economic change.

The failure of the May Day monopoly protest organisers to communicate and work in partnership with the police speaks volumes. These causes are not helped by portraying the mayor as responsible for whipping up media frenzy or by creating the false impression that demonstrators enjoy a democratic right to smash up London. The mayor's message is simple and straightforward: do not attend this demonstration. The Metropolitan police has huge experience of handling sensitive demonstrations; it is able, as it demonstrated last year, to isolate troublemakers from those engaged in genuine peaceful protest. We are depending on that experience to inform their professionalism today.
Lee Jasper
Mayor of London's adviser on policing

webTitle: Letter: The true costs of the Hackney case

fields.headline: The true costs of the Hackney case
fields.trailText: We deeply regret the jailing of one of our former councillors for electoral fraud in the 1998 Hackney local elections (Two councillors jailed for electoral fraud, April 21).
fields.body:
We deeply regret the jailing of one of our former councillors for electoral fraud in the 1998 Hackney local elections (Two councillors jailed for electoral fraud, April 21). We are, however, delighted that three other individuals who were charged with similar offences were found not guilty and believe that this verdict raises serious questions about the whole case.

It is important to get this trial into perspective. The fraud charges involved up to a dozen miscast votes or non-existent electors. Contrary to your report, this would not, by any stretch of the imagination, have in itself "robbed Labour of retaining control of Hackney council in 1998". This was the claim made by prosecution counsel on the first day of the trial, and was certainly not substantiated during the trial. However, it has been widely repeated in the media. In addition, it is factually incorrect to state that the Liberals and the Greens gained joint control of Hackney; they never had a majority to do so.

Zev Lieberman, a young, Orthodox Jew, is a close adherent to his faith. Why would a man so influenced by religion in his everyday life, and of previously good character, risk so much for so little?

While it is true that over 200 proxy votes were cast in this ward, the wider picture is that all parties urge their canvassers to gather proxy votes. Labour entered the 1998 local elections with campaign material setting a target of "one million proxy votes".

The crown has stated that prosecution costs were a minimum of £80,000. The true figure for the entire investigation, we understand, is in the region of millions of pounds of taxpayers' money. We also understand that one of the senior officers in charge of this case is himself under investigation in relation to his conduct in this case.

In his short period as a councillor, Zev worked hard to create unity between all the communities in Hackney, which are so bitterly divided elsewhere. His conviction raises more questions than it answers. We are calling for a fundamental review of the currently crude proxy vote procedures, to ensure new safeguards for both electors and candidates.
Cllr Mark Williams
Lib Dem group leader,
London Borough of Hackney

fields.headline: Lords are yesterday's men
fields.trailText: I agree that titles are an irritant (Off with their silly titles, April 27). I find it depressing when people like Paul McCartney accept knighthoods.
fields.body:
I agree that titles are an irritant (Off with their silly titles, April 27). I find it depressing when people like Paul McCartney accept knighthoods. I've seen him addressed as Sir Paul to his face on television (and Cliff Richard as Sir Cliff) and I feel embarrassed on behalf of both the interviewer and the lord or knight or whatever he has become. The Beatles were part of my youth and Sir Paul McCartney is no longer the same person as Paul McCartney of Lennon and McCartney, the Beatles - it is as if I've been robbed of something.

The delight with which Michael Caine received his title was ghastly to behold. I loathe the word "Sir", except as used by a child to their teacher. Whenever someone accepts a knighthood they are reinforcing the pyramid of privilege that sits above us.
Michael Farley
Yelverton, Devon

 Why stop at titles? The whole honours system rewards supposedly eminent persons with what are now completely remote, pretentious and defunct titles. As far as I am aware, knights, with their shining armour, and cavalries, disappeared with the Middles Ages, and the British empire (OBEs, CBEs etc) is no longer in existence. As for dames, they sound more like the names of pantomime characters than real-life people. What really is absurd is the establishment's myopic yearning for these ridiculous titles and the politician's readiness, whether Labour or Tory, to exploit their power of patronage. All this in a new century. So can't the Guardian really show its republican credentials by dropping all titles from all its pages henceforth?
Jonathan McInerny
London

 David Leigh was both relevant and amusing, but to say that the Wessexes were named after a place that doesn't exist is historically misleading. Alfred the Great (871-899) was the King of Wessex who in 878 set out from his residence in Athelney to win his great victory over the Danes at Ethandun.

The fact that Alfred was the only king able to read until Henry I (1100-35), over 200 years later, shows that today's learned scribes should study Anglo-Saxon history, and maybe learn a few facts, such as Wessex did and does exist - the water from our taps from Dorset westward is Wessex water.
DM Stephens
Dulverton, Somerset

 Roy Hattersley is right (Hairdressers of the world unite, April 30). Dennis Stevenson is an ass in the Lords. My hairdresser for the last 30 years, on the other hand, would be an asset. He's well travelled, top of his profession (ex-european freestyle haircutting champion) and is never short of a pithy opinion. He's media friendly and once made a guest appearance on Coronation Street. To cap it all he trains a junior rugby league team.

In terms of the lords as we know them, he's clearly not good news. Even worse, his accent is Wigan rather than Wokingham and he runs with a couple of evil-looking lurchers rather than the hounds. On one occasion, dining in a slightly downmarket trattoria, a death threat attached to a brick came through the window. But the Lords need have no fear. It was aimed at the chef.

Why not create a Hairdressers' List? May I nominate Roy Critchley?
Aidan Roe
Manchester

 If the government is still looking for an alternative to election as a means of finding more representative members of the second chamber, they could start from those holding the award of an MBE, who have thus shown some distinction in community service.
Alan Hart
Derby

fields.headline: Wrong diagnosis on NHS
fields.trailText: It is not only ministers who would describe Allyson Pollock's and Fiona Campbell's apocalyptic predictions of the demise of the NHS as scaremongering (Bye-Bye Bevan, April 26).
fields.body:
It is not only ministers who would describe Allyson Pollock's and Fiona Campbell's apocalyptic predictions of the demise of the NHS as scaremongering (Bye-Bye Bevan, April 26). Pollock and Campbell suggest that no one has noticed that the health and social care bill paves the way for dismantling the NHS; perhaps that's because it doesn't.

They assert that private companies will be given the power to take over GP surgeries, to provide staff and to sell healthcare to patients. This is not the case. The bill and the NHS plan extend the private finance initiative to GP premises.

The NHS has been contracting out GP services since 1948: GPs are in private businesses which, if they wish to do NHS work, do so under contract to the NHS. Presumably Pollock and Campbell would like to see this change, and it is: GPs have the option of being salaried NHS employees, and around 25% have taken this up.

Their rhetorical over-statements is are not helpful as it allow ministers to dismiss any criticism of health policy - both the incredible and the credible.
John Appleby
Director, health systems programme, King's Fund jappleby@kehf.org.uk

fields.headline: Damn lies
fields.trailText: If the census was about the accumulation of statistics the form would be composed of tick boxes (Leader, April 28).
fields.body:
If the census was about the accumulation of statistics the form would be composed of tick boxes (Leader, April 28). But it asks for specific names and addresses throughout. The only conclusion is that this is for a database for Big Brother's personal use. We are being lied to.
Jim Barty
London

 How reassuring to complete the census form. Information vital for governments to plan for the future: enough hospital beds, avoidance of waiting lists, enough teachers ... Er?
Patrick Dodd
London

fields.headline: Free speech loses again
fields.standfirst: The Times deserves wide support
fields.trailText: Dr Loutchansky was allowed to make use of our obliging libel laws. Last week he won his case against the Times, driving another nail into the cause of free speech.
fields.body:
Dr Grigori Loutchansky is - according to a congressman speaking under congressional privilege - a "purported Russian mob figure". A former CIA director, John Deutch, has said something very similar. Bob Woodward, the Washington Post journalist who helped bring down Richard Nixon, has reported other unflattering things about the Latvian-born businessman. All this information - true or not - is freely available on the internet. But it is unlikely that we in Britain will be reading much about Dr Loutchansky in the near future. Though he has been barred by successive home secretaries from entering Britain since 1994 because his presence "would not be conducive to the public good", Dr Loutchansky was allowed to make use of our obliging libel laws. Last week he won his case against the Times, driving another nail into the cause of free speech.

The Times did not attempt to justify the allegations, but attempted instead to make use of the developing defence of qualified privilege (QP). It hoped that a more enlightened culture was developing in the courts in the wake of the so-called Reynolds judgment and the advent of the Human Rights Act. Mr Justice Gray's unhesitating rejection of the QP defence in this case dashed those hopes: it will make the reporting of serious matters of public interest much harder.

The Times's coverage of Dr Loutchansky's business affairs was not flawless. Its reporter should doubtless have made more strenuous efforts to contact Dr Loutchansky and allowed him a chance to respond to the allegations being made against him. But the courts ought to be very wary of becoming fastidious arbiters of journalistic practice or (as here) the status of sources. It is more important for judges to protect free speech than to punish careless journalism.

Mr Justice Gray's judgment agonises over the "duty" of a newspaper to publish material even when - as he concedes in this case - the subject matter was clearly in the public interest. This displays an over-literal concern to reflect the 19th-century origins of the concept of QP, with its theoretically pleasing balance of duty in publishing and interest in receiving. Elegant and internally coherent though his argument is, he has delivered a judgment which will be profoundly damaging to robust and free newspaper reporting in this country. The Times has announced that it will appeal. It is right to do so and deserves wide support.

fields.headline: Marcel Berlins
fields.standfirst: Let's abolish the parliamentary right to use spoiler tactics to thwart the democratic process
fields.trailText: Let's abolish the parliamentary right to use spoiler tactics to thwart the democratic process.
fields.body:
 Two bills were killed off in the House of Commons last Friday. Both had the support of the vast majority of MPs and of the government. Yet both died because our legislative system still allows one or two MPs to use parliamentary tactics to deny the will of the overwhelming majority of the elected representatives.

One of the bills would have allowed women in the position of Diane Blood, whose son was conceived using her dead husband's sperm, to register him as the child's father on the birth certificate. Under the current law, a line is drawn through the space for the father's name. The bill was on course to become law when, very late in the debate, the Tory MP Desmond Swayne unexpectedly stood up and started speaking against it, until time ran out and no vote was able to be taken. With the imminence of the general election, its salvage is not possible.

Earlier in the day, Tory MP Christopher Chope had spoken for just under two hours putting forward amendments to the high hedges bill, which was aimed at dealing with the menace of thick fast-growing high trees such as leylandii, whose capacity to cut off light has caused countless disputes between neighbours. Chope (whose lengthy monologue on the nature and definition of a hedge is almost worth reading in full) was helped by a speech and many interventions from the serial bill-buster Eric Forth. Between them, they made sure that there would not be time to finish the debate. I do not doubt (though I do not fully understand) their, or Desmond Swayne's, concerns. But is it not time (centuries too late) to abolish this ancient right of a single malcontent to thwart democracy?

 Last week, a co-op man ager who was victimised by his company after blowing the whistle on a senior executive accused of sexual harassment was awarded £140,000 by an employment tribunal. The company was strongly criticised by the Liverpool tribunal for its intimidating tactics in trying to silence the whistleblower as well as the women who had complained. So far, so unexceptional.

But the tribunal then refused to name the offending company. The tribunal explained that if the company was named, its business might be harmed. This role of employment tribunals as the guardians of the financial interests of employers who behave badly is one I haven't come across before. Nor does it appear anywhere in the rules governing the tribunals. How considerate of the Liverpool one to be so innovative in protecting the wrongdoer from any publicity about the way it behaved.

Well, let me reveal that the company in question is United Co-op. To be fair, when outed, it said immediately that it regretted the failings criticised by the tribunal and had already taken action to reform its procedures. But I hope that protecting commercial interests doesn't become a habit in employment tribunals.

 There was another example of enterprising secrecy in the courts last week. Journalists covering an attempted murder case at Dudley magistrates' court found the courthouse doors firmly closed against them, even though remand proceedings were taking place inside against the two men charged. Was the hearing being held in secret because it had national security implications? Was it, perhaps, threats to the defendants' safety that required such action? Nope. The principle of open justice on which the English system is based was being abandoned because - it was staff training day. The journalists are quite rightly complaining to the lord chancellor and to the local MP, who just happens to be the solicitor general, Ross Cranston QC. Next week: journalists are banned from reporting trials at the Old Bailey. The carpets have to be cleaned.

 Kavanagh QC reappeared last week in a one-off and proved yet again that it is still the only television drama to get its legal bits correct. The storyline in the first of the new series was a little strained and over the top, but John Thaw was wholly convincing (actors playing lawyers rarely are) and the legal stuff, including a tempting offer for him to become a high court judge, was spot on; though Thaw - Kavanagh - was surely a little old to be described as youngish, a reason given to him for wanting him on the bench. Still, Kavanagh QC proves that it's possible to make good, watchable drama and be accurate about the professional milieu you're describing. So why can't other legal dramas do the same?

fields.headline: Wilson at work
fields.trailText: Peter Preston's memory is at fault (Comment, April 30). It was Harold Wilson, not the Conservatives, who transferred Charles Hill to the chairmanship of the BBC.
fields.body:
Peter Preston's memory is at fault (Comment, April 30). It was Harold Wilson, not the Conservatives, who transferred Charles Hill to the chairmanship of the BBC. The story goes that at a cabinet meeting Wilson sent a note to Herbert Bowden, lord president of the council; "BBC or IBA?" Bowden ticked IBA, became chairman and Charles Hill went to the BBC. It may be apocryphal, but it sounds like Wislon at work.
Paul Fox
London sirpaul.fox@virgin.net

 How ironic that, just as politicians, mainly on the right, have objected to being pressurised to sign up to statements from the CRE, along comes Paul Sykes, as a self-appointed guardian of "British democracy", with a full page ad (April 30) seeking to force them to sign up to his particular style of referendum.
John Beanse
Liberal Democrat PPC, Chingford & Woodford Green

 Was Tony Blair's appearance on stage with Nelson Mandela (Mandela magic, April 29) arranged before or after the decision to postpone the May 3 election? Can Mr Mandela be persuaded to return on June 3?
John Powell
Brill, Bucks

 A New Labour election poster around the corner proclaims "The Work Goes On". Not far removed from "Arbeit Macht Frei" really.
Bruce Nairne
Brighton

 Re Max Hess's letter (April 30): the Guardian doesn't print my fairly mild anti-Hague, anti-racist letters either. This is almost certainly not because they are closet Hague-lovers, but because my letters about complex matters are not short enough. Letters editors everywhere value (overvalue?) brevity. I feel mildly miffed, but not persecuted.
Bob Margolis
Yateley, Hants

fields.headline: Attention Houston, Tito has boarded
fields.standfirst:
Nasa keeps out of the picture as the world's first space tourist smiles for the cameras, soaking up the atmosphere 250 miles above the Earth

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Nasa keeps out of the picture as the world's first space tourist smiles for the cameras, soaking up the atmosphere 250 miles above the Earth
fields.body:
When the Russian Soyuz spacecraft docked with the International Space Station yesterday it brought with it a vital component that the costly and much-criticised project has so far failed to attract: the public imagination.

Spinning weightless through the connecting hatchway in a grey jumpsuit, grinning like a 10-year-old who had just made his first home run, Dennis Tito, space tourist, had wangled his way further and higher than a 60-year-old stockwatcher could ever have reasonably expected to go.

Nasa, which did not want him on board, ignored his arrival on its website yesterday.

World space agencies plan to spend about £65bn finishing the station, equivalent to half the money owed to the west by the most indebted developing countries, but the project has failed to stir public passions. Mr Tito paid £14m for bed and board in orbit, and suddenly the space station is news.

"Well, it was a great trip here," he said joyfully as he floated with his new astronaut and cosmonaut friends before the cameras yesterday, the vomiting of his first bout of space sickness on the way up from the Baikonur launch site seemingly forgotten.

He got a cheery "Welcome aboard!" from the current Russian commander of the space station, Yuri Usachev, and the Soyuz crew chief, Talgat Musabayev, told him that space travel had made him look 10 years younger. Their enthusiasm is understandable: Mr Tito's £14m is probably going to be paying their wages.

Mr Tito's week-long holiday will be spent with two other Americans and three Russians. He has signed a disclaimer absolving Nasa of any responsibility for his death or injury, and has promised to pay for anything he breaks.

He has also had extensive space training from the Russians and, in the 1960s, worked for Nasa as an aerospace engineer.

This does not satisfy the fears of the anxious Americans. The Unity module linking the Russian and US sectors will become a kind of Checkpoint Charlie, preventing the visitor crossing into the American sector without an escort.

It is something of a mystery how the five men and a woman are going to occupy their time, since Nasa has cleared its crews' diaries for the week while it wrestles with some recalcitrant computers.

It is not known if there is a game of Scrabble on board, but astronauts say they never tire of watching blue Earth and its veil of clouds unrolling through the window.

Mr Tito has brought some opera CDs, and plans to take lots of pictures.

"This is not a vacation, it's the fulfilment of a life's dream to fly into space," he told CNN before lift off.

"Only 400 people have flown into space, so that is for me a privilege to be able to actually observe the Earth from outer space, circle the Earth, you know, once every 90 minutes."

There is every chance of further clashes between Nasa and the Russian space agency. Nasa says Mr Tito would be a danger to himself - he is not trained in emergency drills for the US section of the station - and to others if something went wrong. They also complain that Moscow did not consult them about launching Mr Tito.

The Russians retort that they are partners in the project and they can send whom they like. They are already talking to other prospective paying guests, and they need the money. Since Nasa is still dependent on some Russian hardware, Moscow holds the whip hand.

There has been some sneering at Mr Tito from space pundits back home.

John Pike, a US space analyst, said yesterday that Mr Tito was going to "throw up for three days, spend three days looking out the window, and bore people to tears for decades to come".

Mr Tito can afford to shrug off such barbs. He is in space. Mr Pike is on Earth, and likely to remain there.

fields.headline: Halifax back in credit
fields.trailText: A late goal by Craig Middleton was enough to keep Halifax on course for League survival.
fields.body:
The chairmen of the Third Division clubs are fighting to resist the demands of the Conference, supported by the Football Association, to increase from one the number of automatic promotion places into the league from next season and on this evidence it is not hard to see why. One would back both Rushden and Yeovil to dispose of either of these basement teams.

Halifax, who started last but one, are still not absolutely safe, though an injury-time equaliser by Craig Middleton salvaged a point they just about deserved, moved them up two places and prompted a joyous pitch invasion by their fans.

Lincoln, thanks to late run of improved results, had already gained their safety and were entitled to celebrate too. Earlier this season a trust formed by supporters and funded by the Co-op acquired a majority shareholding in theclub and staying up was a question of pride and at least £600,000 in income.

The next step is to hang on to the nucleus of the team beginning to acquire some sort of shape under the experienced guidance of Alan Buckley, who took over two months ago. Ten of the squad, not to mention Buckley, are out of contract next month.

It was one of the few who is under contract, Ben Sedgemore, who opened the scoring, driving in a Tony Battersby cross after a mistake by the Halifax centre-back Clive Clarke. It was the first goal Halifax have conceded in four games. That new-found solidity has taken them off the bottom of the table but in the first half here they looked distinctly shaky at the back. With 33 full-timers on their staff they can ill afford a return to the Conference.

Without the injured top scorer Steve Kerrigan they were equally unconvincing in attack but the second half was a different story as they finally found the sense of urgency the occasion demanded.

 Bristol Rovers, in the final relegation place in the Second Division, failed to get any points in the first of three home games this week when they went down 3-0 to Port Vale. All three goals came in the last 20 minutes, two of them from Tony Naylor.

Lincoln City: Marriott; Barnett, Holmes, Dudgeon, Bimson, Peacock, Sedgemore, Finnigan, Gain, Battersby, Thorpe.

Halifax Town: Butler; P Mitchell, Clarke, G Mitchell, Jules, Middleton, Redfearn, Stoneman, Reilly, Clarke, Proctor.

Referee: G Frankland.

fields.headline: Graham pursued by Palace
fields.standfirst: Sinking south Londoners see 'strong leader' in their former coach
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace chairman is looking to appoint someone with "bollocks" from a 'shortlist' of 30 potential successors to Alan Smith, with former coach George Graham reportedly top of the list.
fields.body:
Crystal Palace, on the verge of slipping out of the top two divisions for the first time in 24 years, are hoping to tempt George Graham back to the club where he started his coaching career in the late 70s.

Palace will be relegated to the Second Division if they lose at Portsmouth tomorrow - a level from which they last rose under Terry Venables in 1977. Graham, currently in dispute with Tottenham after his sacking in March, may be tempted by the prospect of resurrecting a former club, backed by the funds of Palace's ambitious chairman Simon Jordan.

"I have heard George Graham's name being mentioned," said Jordan. "I will be drawing up a short-list of around 30 candidates but I want someone with bollocks. We need a strong leader.

"I'm a big admirer of Graeme Souness - someone who commands respect from the players. Unfortunately he's away in Blackburn and so he will not be considered."

Palace's former midfielder Alan Pardew, manager of Reading, would be a popular choice but Jordan has ruled out reappointing Steve Coppell or Dave Bassett.

Steven Gerrard, voted the PFA young player of the year on Sunday, was brought back to earth yesterday after his manager Gérard Houllier challenged him "to break with the English culture" or become a forgotten man.

The England midfielder returns to the Liverpool starting line-up for this evening's trip to Bradford after missing Saturday's 2-0 win over Coventry through suspension. Though Houllier is convinced the 20-year-old can emulate Patrick Vieira and Roy Keane, he warned Gerrard against complacency.

"He is not the type of player to rest on his laurels but he must make sure he keeps looking after himself and keeps focused on his career," Houllier said. "He can scale real heights but the main thing he has to keep doing - and I'm sorry to say this - is to break with the English culture and behave like a professional.

"He has to ban things like alcohol and all sorts of other things. If he doesn't keep improving and starts playing within himself, he could be forgotten within two years. These are the 10 best years of his life and he has to look after himself. That's why players are paid so highly. His mates will go to night-clubs but he can't go; he can go to the night-clubs at the end of his career."

Roy Keane reacted to speculation about his private life by issuing a blunt statement last night to deny reports that he had sought counselling for depression. "I am not suffering from depression or any other illness, nor am I receiving treatment at the Priory clinic, as has been alleged in certain newspapers," the Manchester United captain said in a statement.

Of his recent criticism of the team he added: "My recent comments reflected my intense disappointment - a feeling shared by my team-mates and the rest of the club - at our elimination from the Champions League. I have not wished to cause any offence to Sir Alex Ferguson, my team-mates or the supporters."

Nottingham Forest's manager David Platt has dropped out of the race to succeed Glenn Hoddle at Southampton by agreeing to a two-year extension on his contract.

Bobby Robson has taken his first steps towards signing the Dutch international striker Victor Sikora. The Newcastle manager missed his team's 1-0 win over Leicester on Saturday to watch Vitesse Arnhem's 23-year-old. "We've had talks with the club and there's another meeting to be undergone soon," Robson said.
